HEADLINE: Paul Borsky, 75; Studied Effects Of Sonic Booms

BYLINE: By SARAH JAY 

 BODY:
Paul Borsky, who studied the effects of aircraft noise on people just when the term sonic boom was entering the common vocabulary, died last Tuesday at his home in Plainview, L.I. He was 75.
The cause was cancer, his daughter Phyllis Borsky said. 
 At a time when jet planes were making the world an ever smaller and noisier place, Mr. Borsky measured the psychological consequences on communities and people.
As a result, Mr. Borsky, a professor at Columbia University's School of Public Health, was called by government agencies as an expert witness. His professional publications included a study of human reactions to sonic booms, a work on fear as a factor of community annoyance at airplane noise and reports of sleep disturbances near air traffic.
Mr. Borsky, who was born on Nov. 15, 1920, in Paterson, N.J., was valedictorian of his class at Lincoln High School in Brooklyn. He graduated from Brooklyn College in 1942 and completed his graduate courses in economics in 1946 at American University.
His interest in airplane noise began a decade later, while he was a senior study director for the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago.
To find his research subjects, Mr. Borsky sometimes looked no farther than his own children. In the early 1970's, he asked his son Arthur, then a senior at Adelphi University, to gather some college friends to be in a control group. But Arthur rode to his father's office in a car with a faulty muffler, leaving him with a short-term hearing loss that kept him from participating in the study.
Besides his son, Arthur, of Princeton, Mass., and his daughter Phyllis, of Westbury, L.I., Mr. Borsky is survived by his wife, Rosalyn; another daughter, Susan Cohen of Columbia, Md.; a sister, Ruth Gold of Mexico, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Fortune Attacks Rival Forbes And Its Editor

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
In an unusual direct attack on a competitor, Fortune charged in a cover story today that some large advertisers in Forbes magazine had been "exempt from tough editorial criticism."
The article said General Motors, Ford Motor, Rockwell International, General Electric and the insurer American International Group were among the advertisers enjoying favorable treatment. 
 Beyond challenging the integrity of Forbes, Fortune questioned whether the magazine's editor in chief, Steve Forbes, is qualified for public office. Mr. Forbes is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination and ranks second in many polls. It also questioned his motivation, with a cover headline that asked: "Does he really want to be President? Or is he just trying to sell magazines?"
Mr. Forbes promptly denounced the Fortune article as untrue.
"I am astonished that a direct competitor would stoop so low," Mr. Forbes said in a telephone interview from Anchorage, where he was campaigning yesterday. "Competitively, we've cleaned Fortune's clock for 10 years. We have consistently beaten them in editorial quality, in circulation and in advertising, and they are just sore."
Fortune said one editor at Forbes, who was not identified, had provided the names of the companies that it said received favorable treatment.
Fortune said seven current or former Forbes editors had told of how "during Steve Forbes's stewardship they have seen stories changed if the writer has turned in a negative assessment of an advertiser," adding: "In other words, the magazine's editors are turning downbeat stories into upbeat stories in order to keep advertisers happy -- even at the risk of misleading their own readers."
Fortune said the former employees of Forbes magazine who now work at Fortune did not provide information for the article.
Fortune, which is owned by Time Warner Inc., said it had drafts of two articles by Willy Stern, now a writer at Business Week, which supported its claim. Fortune also cited two stories in Forbes -- a March 1993 piece on the Georgia-Pacific Corporation and an April 1994 story on the AT&T Corporation -- in which "a negative assessment became a positive one" after the stories were sent to Mr. Forbes and his publisher. Fortune said the two men read all Forbes articles before publication.
Mr. Forbes confirmed that was so, although he noted that he was now on leave to campaign. He also acknowledged that he directly solicits advertisers "as did my father and my grandfather" when they ran the magazine.
In its article, Fortune said that it and Business Week, which is published by McGraw-Hill Inc., did not allow advertising or other noneditorial executives to review articles before publication. The Fortune article, written by Jeanie Russell Kasindorf, asserted, "Forbes is alone among major business publications in tolerating such a cozy relationship between its editorial and advertising operations."
Forbes magazine is owned by Forbes Inc.
Fortune's managing editor, John Huey, said his magazine was simply practicing good journalism in exploring the fitness of a prominent candidate for President.
"Our article is kind and gentle and nice and polite," Mr. Huey said from his home in Georgia. "We are not saying he is unelectable or unfit for public office, but we are saying here is a barrel full of stuff that in the typical political process he is going to have to deal with -- and with a press that has a lot sharper teeth than we do."
Forbes magazine publishes an annual list of what it estimates are the 400 richest Americans, a list that does not include Mr. Forbes, Fortune noted. Fortune estimated that Mr. Forbes is worth $438.9 million, and that most of his wealth was from the 35 percent stake that he inherited in Forbes Inc., and his 51 percent of Forbes voting stock.
That figure would place Mr. Forbes among the 300 richest Americans on the Forbes list.
Mr. Forbes declined to comment on his wealth or his income and said that he would not release his income tax returns even if he wins his party's nomination. He also said he found nothing objectionable in Fortune's efforts to determine his wealth.
Fortune's 12-page article also examined what it called Mr. Forbes's "aggressive tax-avoidance" strategy at a time when he is campaigning against tax breaks. Fortune said Mr. Forbes, by using a New Jersey law intended to preserve farmland, pays $2,251 in annual property taxes on land worth nearly $9 million.
"The law is intended to preserve open space," Mr. Forbes said. "I pay the taxes that are required."
The article also scrutinized the practices of a Forbes family land-sales company that Fortune charged "has left hundreds of buyers feeling ripped off."
Mr. Forbes responded that his family's real estate company engaged in ethical conduct and let buyers recoup their money for up to a year after their purchase, "no questions asked."
Fortune said that in his campaign for the Republican nomination, Mr. Forbes had benefited from "soft" and "gauzy" coverage including "a celebrity kiss from Vanity Fair; uncritical sketches in The New York Times and The Washington Post; affectionate columns on the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, whose supply-side economic fanaticism marks the true north of his ideology."
Officials of the other Republican candidates' campaigns have been complaining to the press for several days about what they felt was gentle coverage of Mr. Forbes. These officials said the press had not probed deeply into his conduct and interests.
Two prominent educators who study press ethics said yesterday that they had not seen the Fortune article but were delighted to see one major magazine investigate another.
"One of the problems with the media in this country is that they don't watch each other enough," said David M. Rubin, dean of the S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University.
Stephen D. Isaacs, who teaches journalism ethics at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, said, "It is great when one media organization takes on another because the media tends to be too much of a club."
Professor Isaacs said he regularly read Forbes closely and had "not seen any pulling of punches." He added, "But I am suspicious, as we all should be, of the press, and it is important to keep in mind that most people believe that the press takes money for articles."

HEADLINE: THE NEXT WONDER: A special report.;
Cracks Show Early in China's Big Dam Project

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: SANDOUPING, China

 BODY:
From horizon to horizon, the ancient landscape here has been sundered, scored and stripped by the big steel blades of countless front-end loaders. Dust storms rise from monster truck caravans hauling a million boulders across a riven plain to the place where the Three Gorges Dam is to emerge, eventually, to mount and tame the timeless and often devastating flood of the Yangtze River.
Mountains are disappearing and a new concrete topography is rising in their place, connected in a manmade design whose foundations are being laid across a dust bowl so broad that it seems almost planetary in scale. 
 As soon as the river's torrent is blocked and diverted by a spectacular berm of crushed rock, legions of engineers and workers are to begin installing the largest array of hydroelectric turbines and generators ever bolted to the earth.
Thus this dream of China's Soviet-trained engineering corps, this symbol of Chinese Communism's triumph -- some say arrogance -- over nature and economic backwardness, and the bane of environmentalists is relentlessly becoming a reality.
But a year after construction began on this vast project in central China, serious problems are arising that underscore the politically precarious future of the world's largest dam.
Interviews with municipal officials and engineers along the 400-mile stretch of river that will swell to inundate a treasure of Chinese relics and vistas say chronic money shortages are plaguing the resettlement of the 1.13 million people who will be displaced by the dam project. This is causing serious disaffection among a population whose economic security is crucial to the success of the effort and to the political stability of the region.
In addition, environmental engineers in Chongqing, a city of 15 million that will sit at the head of the serpentine Three Gorges Lake that is to be created by the dam, say national and local leaders have no money to treat the 265 billion gallons a year of raw sewage and industrial waste that they say will flow into the impounded waters.
These engineers, who have prepared for decades to create a reservoir deep enough to bring ocean traffic 1,500 miles inland to Chongqing, accuse national authorities of shortsightedness and of misleading the public about the potential threat of the untreated industrial and municipal sewage that will flow from dozens of cities and towns along the reservoir.
They say an environmental impact statement recently given to the United States Embassy in Beijing glosses over fundamental concerns about pollution. Further study is needed, they argue, including the use of models to show how the huge sewage flows will affect vital fresh water supplies and the environment, which will be critical to the survival of the tourist industry.
"I am just telling the truth," said Guo Chengmo, a senior engineer and technical adviser in Chongqing's Environmental Bureau. "There are a lot of problems that have to be solved, and I don't think the leaders are thinking that far ahead. This is my personal opinion."
 
The Marvel
Feat of Engineering And Political Clout
The Three Gorges project managers acknowledge that there are no immediate solutions to a host of problems, most dealing with money, environmental threats and the impact of huge volumes of sediment that could settle in the upper lake and choke Chongqing's aspirations to become a major port upstream from Shanghai.
But they are unwavering in their commitment to the project, which they say will protect millions of Chinese from disastrous floods, boost China's electrical output by 10 percent with "clean" hydropower (as opposed to coal) and further open markets in China's interior, where nearly 400 million people live in the Yangtze watershed.
"As water resources engineers, we are proud to be involved in this project," said Yang Guowei, a leading scientist at the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission, the state organization of 7,000 professionals who have planned and designed every aspect of the Three Gorges Dam.
Mr. Yang exudes the confidence of a Communist Party stalwart who not only believes in his ability to complete his mission, but also understands that Prime Minister Li Peng has muscled the Three Gorges project through the party leadership to make it China's highest-priority construction project. The project has a work force of 40,000 and an estimated cost of anywhere between $17.3 billion (the official figure) and $30 billion.
If completed, the dam will be an engineering marvel, conveying ocean-going vessels onto the lake through huge locks. At 610 feet high, its profile would be lower than the 726-foot Hoover Dam in the United States. But it will span 6,864 feet, dwarfing the Hoover's 1,244-foot breadth. With 26 sets of 700-megawatt turbines and generators, Three Gorges will have the capacity to generate 18,200 megawatts of electricity, which is 15 times as much as a standard 1,200-megawatt nuclear power station and almost twice as powerful as the Grand Coulee Dam.
Over the next 24 months, the project may well pass the point of no return, Mr. Yang asserted. "From a technical point of view, if we block the channel," as is planned for the fourth quarter of 1997, "it would be so difficult to stop construction," he said.
But critics say that any change in the political climate in Beijing would reopen the debate on the merits and science of the dam.
"For those of use who have spoken out and held different views, our actions have been labeled as counterrevolutionary," said Dai Qing, an influential Chinese journalist who was expelled from the Communist Party and imprisoned in 1989 in part because she sought to organize Chinese scientists opposed to the dam project. "If there aren't any problems, why are they afraid of an open debate on the project?"
A lack of openness and debate appears to be one of the reasons for the more vocal challenges from Chongqing's frustrated environmental bureau. Mr. Guo, for instance, was highly critical of the Government's environmental impact statement.
"Personally and bluntly speaking, that report was very roughly done and lacks in-depth analysis," he said. "That is my opinion as an engineer."
 
The Money
Shallow Pockets Add to Problems
Mr. Guo's concerns and those of his colleagues in Chongqing echo the reservations expressed by the Clinton Administration last fall and by international lending institutions like the World Bank, which have declined to provide assistance to the project.
In September Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser to President Clinton, told the United States Export-Import Bank, a Government-financed lending agency, that it should avoid supporting the project. Mr. Berger argued that it would be "unwise for the U.S. Government to align itself with a project that raises environmental and human rights concerns on the scale of Three Gorges."
But the bank, which has the authority to grant export loans to American companies, has asserted its right to decide the matter independently. It is considering loan requests from American companies like Caterpillar Inc., the heavy equipment maker, and Rotec Industries, a construction firm, to support their bids on dam contracts.
[Rita Trevino Flynn, a spokeswoman for the bank, said on Friday that the bank's "engineers and financial analysts are continuing the process of conducting an independent financial, technical and environmental review of issues surrounding this project." A date for a decision on those loans has not been set.]
Lack of money for a host of critical projects now seems to be the principal weakness of the overall Three Gorges plan, a number of experts say.
As Mr. Guo pointed out, "Waste-water processing facilities are not even on the agenda of the city government, and I don't think that even for the next 10 years these facilities are going to be on the priority list."
There is also no money to remove the 1,000-year-old landfills of solid wastes, garbage and toxic materials like mercury and arsenic in vast dumping grounds on river banks that will be flooded.
Referring to Chongqing, Mr. Guo said: "This city right now is facing urgent problems. We have electricity outages, traffic jams. We need bridges and roads and telecommunications and housing projects. They all need funds."
Mr. Guo pointed out that even if Chongqing raised the $500 million needed to build new sewers and 24 waste-water treatment plants, "the operational costs are going to be huge," amounting to tens of millions of dollars a day. "Even if we completed them, we don't have the money to operate them," he said.
"The Government doesn't have a single penny to control waste-water discharge from these cities," said Ms. Dai, "and there are several hundred pollution sources along the river from Chongqiing to Sandouping."
 
The Masses
Human Shell Game Earns Disaffection
Long before any foul tide of Three Gorges pollution confronts Chinese officials, the problems of relocating such a large population have already emerged.
In Wanxian, where a third of the city's 300,000 people must move to higher ground, thousands of residents who are part of the first phase of relocation have been living in tents. The local government's promise to provide jobs for farmers pushed off their ancestral lands has foundered on a shortage of money to start construction on the chemical plant that was to employ 20,000 of them.
Meanwhile, thousands of farmers whose homes were bulldozed to clear the way for the chemical complex are living on subsidies of $7.22 per month.
"If you get a chance to speak to the high officials, you ought to tell them that the resettlement program is not working very good," said Cheng Changhe, 28, who works for the Three Gorges Resettlement Construction Corporation in Wanxian. "When they demolished our houses, they said we would move to a new place in the same year, but then for three years there were no houses, and a lot of people had to live in tents. And they still haven't solved the problem of offering jobs.
"Wanxian is only a small city. If we can't solve a small number of resettlement problems here, just think about the overall project."
Past relocation programs involving more than 10 million Chinese have set off riots over compensation questions, and Prime Minister Li has warned provincial and local leaders that the success of the entire project rides on managing the relocation program.
Mr. Cheng's neighbors in Apartment Block No. 38 have not been able to find work to supplement their $14.44 monthly subsistence payment. "Right now we make and sell dumplings to make money," said 27-year-old Liu Jianmin. "When I was young, I looked forward to the Three Gorges, but with no job and so little money -- it's really not enough."
The Three Gorges project spans such a long time that more than 300,000 Chinese who have not even been born yet are among those counted to be relocated. The dam is to be completed in 2009, but anticipated problems with resettling the residents of 13 large cities, 140 towns and 326 villages have deferred the filling of the reservoir to its full capacity by another decade, to 2019.
Downstream, just above the dam site, Maoping, a town of several thousand residents, begun full-scale relocation in 1994. In August of that year, Cui Bangfen led a demonstration of 300 residents who sought to block the motorcade of leaders who came to inspect how the relocation program was going.
The 61-year-old Mrs. Cui is angry over the small amount of compensation she got for her land, her orange grove and her house, about $1,100 in all. And she is angry that her new house is too small and so poorly constructed that cracks already have appeared in the foundation and load-bearing walls.
"Some people in the neighborhood say my house is so small it looks like a toilet," she said.
So when the leaders came to her village, "We stood hand in hand and blocked the cars until the police came to push us away," she said, "but we would not move and the police said, 'If you don't get away, we are going to shoot.' "
"I'm old," she continued, "so I am not afraid, and I told them, 'If you shoot me then for sure I will not have to move.' "
In the end, she and her neighbors got no satisfaction. Mrs. Cui was fined $24, the equivalent of three months' subsidy. "It's not fair," she sobbed, "I am alone. My husband is dead. And I am the only one who got fined."
All along the river there are similar stories of disaffection. Many residents say they support the national policy to build the Three Gorges Dam, but they intensely mistrust their local leaders.
"I think the central Government should do an investigation to see whether the money has been spent wisely," said Xu Shikai, 37, whose family was relocated to Yichang.
Others, like 52-year-old Wang Zuozhu, suspect corruption. "In our village," she said, "the village committee leaders used part of the relocation money to buy a big transport boat, but only a few people are benefiting from the profits of that business.
"Since we moved to the city, no one can find those village leaders or the money the village was paid for enterprises and common property. We don't know where they are."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

G.O.P. Abandons Tactic In Budget Dispute
 The chairman of the House Budget Committee said Republicans would restore the Government's authority to borrow money, thereby abandoning what is potentially their strongest weapon in a drive to force a budget agreement with the Clinton Administration on Republican terms. "We're going to raise the debt ceiling, in my opinion," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio. "My sense is you don't want to mess around with defaulting here in the United States." 
 Speaker Newt Gingrich said on Friday that Congressional leaders would "find a way to take care of" the debt-limitation problem. The Republicans seem to have decided that with the debt-ceiling issue still unresolved, the risks of failure to reach a budget agreement with the Clinton Administration would be too great. The talks are expected to resume Wednesday, and Mr. Kasich said the two sides were still "universes apart." [Page A14.]
 
I.B.M. Wins a Big One
 Ray Ozzie who created the Lotus Notes software that allows multiple users wherever they are to work simultaneously on the same file, told I.B.M. that he would stay on, even as the fourth version of the program is released. I.B.M. had worried that Mr. Ozzie might join other Lotus executives who left after it bought the company. [D3.]
 
A Test for Organized Labor
 The 11-day strike that has left office workers to empty their own trash in 1,000 Manhattan buildings is presenting the first big test for John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president. Whether the strikers win or lose, the outcome could set a pattern for labor nationwide. News analysis. [B3.]
 
Display Space for Sale
 In a growing trend that treats books like tennis shoes, publishers are buying display space in bookstores. At Barnes & Noble, publishers can place authors in a "Discover Great New Writers" program that gets a special display for $1,500 a title. [A1.]
 
How Green Is the Valley?
 An annual survey of the economic health of the Silicon Valley, to be released today, finds the nation's leading high-technology region enjoying strong growth, reviving old strength in manufacturing and increasingly becoming an industrial and software design center. [D2.]
 
Investigation in Hollywood
 A Federal grand jury is investigating Andrew J. Vajna the producer of Oliver Stone's "Nixon" and the "Die Hard" action films and a founder of Carolco Pictures, to determine if he filed accurate income tax returns. [D5.]
 
Rebuilding CBS News
 As the new president of CBS News, Andrew Heyward has to acknowledge that the network has serious problems and, at the same time, rally his troops so that they feel confident in their ability to recover. Media. [D5.]
 
Zap! You're Dead Meat!
 Start-up companies are preparing Internet services that will allow multiple players to engage in electronic battle over the Internet. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. [D3.]
 
The Army Warms Up
 Granted, the United States Army in Bosnia is involved in peacekeeping, not war-making. Even so, its new attitude toward news coverage seems a sea change from Persian Gulf war days. Soldiers are being told that they can be "excellent unofficial" spokesmen. [D5.]

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Rangers (and Fans, Too) Get Even With Keenan

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Playoff memories blended with playoff intensity last night at Madison Square Garden when Coach Mike Keenan returned. His current team, the St. Louis Blues, met his previous team, the Rangers, in a gritty, thrilling game filled with nasty collisions and many loud sounds from the crowd. Both teams earned a grueling point in a 3-3 tie.
Pat Verbeek, who wasn't a Ranger when Keenan coached the team to the Stanley Cup in 1994, scored twice, bringing the Rangers back from a 3-1 deficit. He took over the team goal lead at 32, one ahead of Mark Messier. And Coach Colin Campbell gave Verbeek credit for exhorting his teammates on the bench when they fell behind by two goals. 
 "Pat got a little verbal," Campbell said. "And he did something about it. He showed a little leadership."
Verbeek said afterward that he couldn't remember what he had said. He added that it isn't fair to expect Messier, the captain, to make all the speeches and score all the important goals.
"We had to get desperate, we had to stir it up a little bit," Verbeek said. "You get a feel of when things are starting to slip. It was a great hockey game. It was very intense and hard-hitting, the kind of game you love to play, an uplifting experience."
Part of the reason was the subplot involving Keenan, who left the Rangers in a contract dispute shortly after the cup was clinched on June 14, 1994. This was his first trip back.
When Keenan took his place behind the Blues' bench, he was greeted by many deep boos and a few hands clapping in applause. He seemed to be struggling to keep a smile off his face. Several security guards stood behind the bench, often looking into the crowd. They remained in the vicinity throughout the game.
A few fans brought signs to comment on Keenan's departure. One of the signs said, "Keenan, You Traitor!" Another said, "You Lied to Every One of Us!" A third said, simply, "Rat."
During play, fans chanted crude insults, which grew in intensity as the pace and passion of the game increased.
"It's to be expected, I guess," Keenan said. "It really wasn't that bad. I can understand fans' reaction, but it doesn't mean I have to enjoy it, accept it or embrace it."
Neil Smith, the Rangers' president and general manager who feuded with Keenan, said: "You're only remembered for your very last act. I guess that's what the fans were thinking about."
He said the fans were emotional but not harsh and "almost playful." He said they weren't as harsh as they were in the playoffs of 1990. Smith was right. In that series, against the Islanders, Ranger fans attacked the ambulance of Pat LaFontaine after the Islander star suffered a concussion.
Messier, when asked about the fans at the Garden, smiled and said: "No place like it. I don't think anybody got cheated. A fun game to play in and be a part of."
Stephane Matteau, one of the Ranger heroes of the Stanley Cup season, scored once for his new team, St. Louis, and assisted on the other two goals, by Craig Johnson and Dale Hawerchuk. But he shot wide of the Ranger net in the final minute of overtime when he had a chance to score from the slot on a power play. All the St. Louis goals were on the power play.
Ulf Samuelsson, the Ranger defenseman, appeared to sustain a hip pointer but should return when the Rangers next play, after seven days off for the All-Star break, Campbell said. Leaving early for St. Louis was Shayne Corson, the Blues' captain, with a groin injury.
Grant Fuhr, the St. Louis goalie, stopped 41 of 44 shots, including a dangerous one in the final minute of regulation by Ranger defenseman Brian Leetch, who rushed to the slot and fired.
"I knew he had a good glove," Leetch said. "I tried to go against it. I guess he guessed glove, but it hit the leg that he left there."
Ranger goalie Glenn Healy stopped 34 of 37 shots and made a key save off Geoff Courtnall with a little more than a minute left in overtime, blocking a screened shot that was deflected en route, possibly by a Ranger.
The result extended the Rangers' home undefeated streak to 20 games, 4 short of the team record of 24 set in 1970-71. Over all, the Rangers' current undefeated streak, home and road combined, is five games (3-0-2). The Blues were playing their fourth game in six nights, all on the road. It was their third consecutive tie.
Before the game, Keenan said he experienced "the whole gamut of emotions" and some nervousness as he entered the Garden.
"It's not a normal night at the office," he said. "I was hoping I wouldn't make a wrong turn and I did. I wasn't quite sure where the visitors' locker room was."
Keenan also continued to talk about the possible acquisition of Wayne Gretzky from the Los Angeles Kings. Gretzky and his agent, Mike Barnett, have been openly discussing Gretzky's options.
"We're very interested," Keenan said when asked if he would try to get Gretzky if he becomes available. "Wayne fits into the economics of the industry and particularly our situation as an entity unto himself."
Gretzky's agent is expected to meet with the Kings' owners tomorrow. He has some leverage. If they don't accommodate his wishes to acquire new players and they don't trade him, Gretzky can leave the Kings without compensation in the summer.
"This won't take long," Gretzky said of the impending conversations. "We'll know on Tuesday."
Matteau, traded by the Rangers to St. Louis on Dec. 28, was involved in all aspects of the game. He scored the first goal and assisted on the next two as the Blues held a 3-2 lead after two periods.
The first, on the power play, tied the score at 1-1 at 15 minutes 3 seconds of the first period. He skated to the slot in front of Healy and put the puck past him after a pass from Brett Hull.
Hull had lost his helmet on the play, and, as he carried the puck down the right side of the ice, with his long blond hair flying behind him, fans of a certain age couldn't help but recall his father, Bobby Hull, who made similar plays for the Chicago Blackhawks in the 1960's and early 70's.
Hull fanned on the first shot attempt, but then put a spin move on Leetch before sending the puck across to Matteau. It was Matteau's fourth goal in his last three games.
Niklas Sundstrom scored the first Ranger goal, giving them a 1-0 lead at 7:00 of the first period with a backhanded shot from the slot past Fuhr, after he and Sergei Nemchinov had outworked the Blues in the left-wing corner for possession of the puck. It was his first goal since Oct. 31.
Verbeek scored his first with the teams playing four skaters each by knocking in a rebound from close range at 15:37 of the second period. He tied the score at 3-3 at 6:31 of the third period, also from close range, this one off the rush, after taking a pass from Ray Ferraro.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Coach Mike Keenan looking on as his St. Louis Blues played against the Rangers last night at the Garden. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Prisons Are a Bargain, by Any Measure

BYLINE: By John J. DiIulio Jr.; John J. DiIulio Jr. is professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
All 30 Republican governors elected or re-elected in 1994 promised to get tough on crime. Most, like George Pataki of New York, are keeping their word. But several, like Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin, who has said he would build no more prisons, are quietly promoting plans to put more convicted criminals back on the streets.
Most experts applaud Governor Thompson's new-found "wisdom" and lament Governor Pataki's "hard-line" approach. As these experts love to repeat, "incarceration is not the answer." 
 If incarceration is not the answer, what, precisely, is the question? If the question is how to prevent at-risk youths from becoming stone-cold predators in the first place, then, of course, incarceration is no solution.
But if the question is how to restrain known convicted criminals from murdering, raping, robbing, assaulting and stealing, then incarceration is a solution, and a highly cost-effective one.
On average, it costs about $25,000 a year to keep a convicted criminal in prison. For that money, society gets four benefits: Imprisonment punishes offenders and expresses society's moral disapproval. It teaches felons and would-be felons a lesson: Do crime, do time. Prisoners get drug treatment and education. And, as the columnist Ben Wattenberg has noted, "A thug in prison can't shoot your sister."
All four benefits count. Increased incarceration explains part of the drop in crime in New York and other cities. As some recent studies show, prisons pay big dividends even if all they deliver is relief from the murder and mayhem that incarcerated felons would be committing if free.
In two Brookings Institution studies, in 1991 and 1995, the Harvard economist Anne Piehl and I found that prisoners in New Jersey and Wisconsin committed an average of 12 crimes a year when free, excluding all drug crimes. In other studies, the economist Steven D. Levitt of the National Bureau of Economic Research estimated that "incarcerating one additional prisoner reduces the number of crimes by approximately 13 per year."
The economists Thomas Marvell and Carlisle Moody of William and Mary College found that "a better estimate may be 21 crimes averted per additional prisoner." Patrick A. Langan, senior statistician at the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics, calculated that tripling the prison population from 1975 to 1989 may have reduced "violent crime by 10 to 15 percent below what it would have been," thereby preventing a "conservatively estimated 390,000 murders, rapes, robberies and aggravated assaults in 1989 alone."
Studies by the Bureau of Justice Statistics found that 94 percent of state prisoners in 1991 had committed a violent crime or been incarcerated or on probation before. Of these prisoners, 45 percent had committed their latest crimes while free on probation or parole. When "supervised" on the streets, they inflicted at least 218,000 violent crimes, including 13,200 murders and 11,600 rapes (more than half of the rapes against children).
Most Americans are more likely to be a victim of violent crime than to suffer injury in a car accident. As estimated in a forthcoming National Institute of Justice study, the violent crimes committed each year will cost victims and society more than $400 billion in medical bills, lost days from work, lost quality of life -- and lost life.
Here's the revolving-door rub. Known felons whom the system has put back on the streets are responsible for about one in three violent crimes, and barely one violent crime in a hundred results in imprisonment. On any given day in 1994, about 690,000 people were on parole and 2.96 million were on probation. About 1.5 times as many convicted violent felons were on probation or parole as were in prison.
All told, research shows it costs society at least twice as much to let a prisoner loose than to lock him up. Compared with the human and financial toll of revolving-door justice, prisons are a real bargain.
Prison definitely pays, but there's one class of criminal that is an arguable exception: low-level, first-time drug offenders.
Most drug felons in state prisons do not fit that description. Instead, they have long adult and juvenile records involving plenty of serious non-drug crimes. And most Federal drug traffickers are not black kids caught with a little crack cocaine or white executives arrested for a small stash of powder cocaine. The average amount of drugs involved in Federal cocaine-trafficking cases is 183 pounds, and the average amount involved in Federal marijuana trafficking cases is 3.5 tons.
Still, though the numbers of petty drug offenders may prove small, it makes no sense to lock away even one drug offender whose case could be adjudicated in special drug courts and handled less expensively through intensively supervised probation featuring no-nonsense drug treatment and community service.
Thus, Governor Pataki needs to repeal undiscriminating Rockefeller-era drug laws as part of his campaign to keep violent and repeat criminals where they can't harm the rest of us.
Meanwhile, Governor Thompson should pursue whatever "alternative to incarceration" policies he fancies subject to one condition: He should agree to make public in a timely fashion the complete histories of all criminals released from custody because of his "reforms."
All elected leaders should reckon that those who break their promises to protect society from career criminals can count on voters to shorten their political careers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Traders Focus on New Data And Fresh Talks on Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
While the markets for Treasury securities were closed yesterday for the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., traders began looking forward to a greater clarity in trading this week.
They are waiting for the budget talks to resume in Washington on Wednesday and for the release this week of some long-delayed Government economic statistics. The Government shutdown prevented the gathering and compilation of economic indicators, meaning that many market participants postponed investment decisions or took smaller positions based on private statistics, which are typically less comprehensive. 
 Traders said yesterday that the debt market remained optimistic that the budget talks had a chance of reaching agreement.
James S. Collins, a senior vice president at Smith Barney in Chicago, who manages research for the institutional financial futures group, said the market was likely to be encouraged that the Republicans this weekend stopped linking the budget talks to a renewal of the debt ceiling.
Nonetheless, Mr. Collins said he did not rule out some pullback in the market this week, with the yield on the long bond possibly rising to between 6.20 and 6.25 percent, equating to a price of about 1188/32 to 10/32 on the March bond futures contract. On Friday the yield was 6.14 percent on the benchmark issue.
"The budget talks will apparently resume in earnest on Wednesday," Mr. Collins said, "and I think the tone of those meetings will be significant to the market. The last round was quite sour by the time it wound down."
The market will be vulnerable during the negotiations, he added. "If the tone of the meetings continues to suggest irreconcilable differences and nothing substantial is achieved until the election, I think that would put substantial pressure on the long bond," he said.
"The data mills are reopening," he said, and though the dates are uncertain, the market could see the housing starts report today and the trade balance tomorrow.
The weekly jobs data will be important, Mr. Collins said, particularly because the reports have been stalled for five weeks.
Today the Treasury will conduct its weekly sale of three- and six-month bills, postponed a day because of yesterday's holiday. At the close of Friday's abbreviated session, the rate for a three-month maturity was 5.01 percent and the six-month issue, 4.95 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Up in Light Trade On Remark Over German Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished slightly higher yesterday against leading currencies amid further speculation that Europe is headed for another round of interest rate cuts.
A German monetary official's comments that there was room for lower rates helped the dollar against the mark, which would suffer if German investments paid lower yields. 
 The dollar remained flat against the Japanese yen as traders speculated that political changes in Japan would lead to a stronger economy.
With holidays in Japan and the United States, only Europe was involved in anything approaching significant trading volume. Smaller trades took on greater importance in the market because of the low volume.
By late yesterday, the dollar sold for 1.4465 marks, up from 1.4420 late Friday. The dollar ended at 105.20 yen, unchanged from Friday.
In Paris yesterday, the head of the International Monetary Fund played down Europe's economic problems, saying there was currently no recession on the Continent.
But Hans-Jurgen Kobnick, president of the German regional central bank in Mainz, was quoted in a German newspaper as saying that there was room for another rate cut by the Bundesbank, but that the timing for such a cut was uncertain.
A country lowers its interest rates to spur lending and growth, though cuts weaken a currency because fewer investors acquire it to buy that country's assets, which are consequently less attractive.
Mr. Kobnick's remarks follow the recent release of economic data showing that Germany is in a slowdown. Traders are particularly watching monetary officials in Britain and France, where interest rates might be lowered this week.
"As a result of this, you have the dollar looking O.K.," Lisa Finstrom, an analyst at Smith Barney, said. "The dollar is benefiting from that right now."
In Japan, Ms. Finstrom said, the change in prime ministers and a shift in the leadership of a political party portends "positive movement toward achieving structural reform" and alleviating Japan's four-year economic slide.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Friday, included these: 1.1655 Swiss francs, up from 1.1625; 4.9585 French francs, up from 4.9494, and 1,574 Italian lire, up from 1,572. The British pound was quoted at $1.5460, unchanged from Friday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cocoa Prices at 4-Week High As Ivory Coast Deliveries Decline

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Cocoa prices jumped to their highest level in four weeks yesterday after shipments of beans from Ivory Coast, the world's biggest producer, began winding down.
Cocoa for March delivery jumped $30, to $1,286 a metric ton, rebounding from a low of $1,240 at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York. 
 In other commodity markets, coffee prices fell to less than $1 a pound; oil prices rebounded; natural gas prices sank and metals prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities fell 1.64 points, to 239.95.
New cocoa supplies have not kept up with global demand for several years, but analysts had expected a bumper crop in Ivory Coast to help balance supply and demand.
Traders in Ivory Coast said, though, that the pace of cocoa supplies pouring into its port cities had slowed. "Deliveries are maybe 10,000 tons less than in previous weeks," one trader said.
Coffee prices also fell sharply late in the session, with the March contract off 3.75 cents, to 98.95 cents a pound.
Analysts said the market had discounted worries about freeze damage to Mexico's coffee fields and were skeptical that global producers would succeed in manipulating supplies. "People who bought the market at $1 liquidated today," said Judith Ganes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Copper prices fell to 16-month lows on fears of rising inventories and weak economic growth. The March copper contract fell 1.05 cents, to 111.65 cents a pound, at the Commodity Exchange.
Japanese buyers were on a holiday, reducing buying interest, said Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential Securities.
"There is also a generally negative feeling about the macroeconomic outlook in terms of the U.S.," Ms. Raptopoulos said. Much of the demand for copper comes from industrial activity.
Crude oil prices broke a four-day string of declines, with February crude rising 13 cents, to $18.38 a barrel, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. February gasoline rose eight-tenths of 1 cent, to 53.90 cents a gallon.
Forecasts for warmer weather along the East Coast pulled February heating oil down 0.27 cent, to 53.30 cents a gallon, and February natural gas lost 30 cents, to $2.017 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The market predicts the Super Bowl and vice versa, so they say.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE bull market is good for another year, no matter which team wins this year's Super Bowl. And that is just as well, because the stock market right now sees the game as very close, although last week's sharp fall in share prices has given the Dallas Cowboys a small edge.
Those are the results of two theories relating the stock market to the Super Bowl. It is, of course, absurd to think there is any relation between the two, but that doesn't stop Wall Street from paying attention.
First, the future of the market. That theory has been around for years, occasionally tweaked to make it work better. In its current form, it says that if a team from the old National Football League wins the game, the stock market will rise during the year until the next game. But if a team from the old American Football League wins, share prices will fall. 
 The good news for the bulls was locked in a week ago: All four teams in the conference championship games played Sunday, including the two from the American Football Conference, were old N.F.L. teams. So the bulls clearly have it.
That theory has worked this year. A year ago, it was San Francisco (old N.F.L.) over San Diego (old A.F.L.) in the Super Bowl, which the theory said meant prices would rise. Sure enough, the Dow Jones industrial average is now 31 percent over the 3,857.99 level where it stood entering that game. That brings the record for the indicator to 25 of 29. The failures came after the 1970, 1987, 1990 and 1994 games. In 1970, the game falsely forecast falling share prices; in the other years it was wrongly bullish.
Dallas was the winner in the last of those games, but the market did go up after its other three victories. Similarly, share prices rose after each of Pittsburgh's four previous victories.
The newer theory, written about in this column seven years ago, attempts to use the stock market to forecast the game. It holds that if the Dow rises from the end of November until game day, the franchise from later in the alphabet will win.
In this case, that means the Pittsburgh Steelers will benefit from a bull market, while the Dallas Cowboys will be favored if share prices fall.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended November at 5,074.49, and subsequently got up to a high of 5,216.47. But last week's sharp fall, the worst week for the index in more than a year, left the average at 5,061.12, below the magic number, and it fell further, to 5,043.78, yesterday. But there are nine trading days left before the game, with a gain of just over 30 points needed to forecast a Pittsburgh win.
When the theory regarding the Dow forecasting the Super Bowl game was first written about in this column, it had correctly forecast 12 of the previous 14 games. Since then, it has gotten six of seven correct, bringing its total record to 18 of 21.
By contrast, the Las Vegas point spread has correctly picked the winner in 16 of 20 games over the same stretch, with one game, in 1982, going off with no favorite.
The three games in which the football theory has failed to forecast the Super Bowl game were in 1982, when San Francisco beat Cincinnati; in 1986, when Chicago topped New England, and in 1990, when San Francisco beat Denver.
People who buy or sell stocks or place bets on football games based on such indicators probably should not be allowed to manage their own money. But the existence of indicators with such apparently superb records nonetheless does serve a use, by reminding investors that the fact that two things are correlated may or may not indicate that they are related. That is useful to consider when looking at other indicators that seem to make more sense.
But if you are unwilling to accept that warning, here's another correlation to ponder. The last three times the economy had at least one quarter in which it did not show growth, after adjusting for inflation, were in 1982, 1986 and 1990. And, as it happens, they were also the years in which the stock market failed to forecast the Super Bowl.
Therefore, if this indicator does not get the game right on Jan. 28, you should watch out for a recession this year.

HEADLINE: Buses Using Natural Gas Do Well in Pilot Program

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
New York City buses have long been notorious for the black soot many of them spew out of their exhaust pipes. Now, as the Transit Authority is starting to convert the fleet to run on cleaner-burning fuels, several state legislators and environmentalists say the efforts fall far short of what is needed.
They are urging the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency, to convert all 3,600 city buses to alternative fuels like natural gas, methanol, ethanol and electricity. 
 The Transit Authority has already bought 100 buses that run on cleaner diesel fuel and has begun to test 34 others equipped to run on compressed natural gas, an effort some have criticized as paltry given the city's pollution problems.
"What the M.T.A is trying to do is bad public health, bad environmental policy and bad economics," Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, chairman of the Assembly's Committee on Environmental Conservation, said last week. "So far, they've done everything wrong."
Mr. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, released data from the State Department of Environmental Conservation showing that midtown Manhattan has experienced a sharp increase in soot, primarily from diesel buses.
Soot levels at Madison Avenue and 46th Street have worsened since hitting a modern-day low in 1992 of 42 parts per million. The 1994 average was 53, and for the first three quarters of 1995, the pollutants averaged 55 parts per million. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has ruled that soot levels above 50 parts per million are hazardous.
The city's experimental gas buses, which have been on the streets of Brooklyn since November, got good reviews the other day from riders on the B11 route, which goes through Sunset Park and Red Hook. The buses' tailpipes emit no polluting fumes.
"That's good," said one passenger, Pietra Madison. "There sure is a lot of smoke from these other buses that make you cough and all."
Anna Gonzalez said, "Whatever they can do to reduce the smoke is fine with me."
Many of the riders did not realize that the bus was running on natural gas. Aside from the square gas tank on the roof, and a modest sign, the bus looks like the standard model.
Despite the apparent advantages of compressed gas, New York transit officials warn against jumping on the bandwagon too quickly. Advanced diesel fuel, which is cleaner than the old diesel, they point out, satisfies Clean Air Act requirements and is cheaper and easier to handle than compressed natural gas.
"There's no question that C.N.G. is cleaner," said Vincent D. Pellegrin, the Transit Authority's chief of research and development. "What we're saying is, look at the total issue to see if this is the most economically effective way for us to clean the environment."
Transit officials are also studying buses powered by alternative fuels like methanol, ethanol and electricity.
With growing pressure from environmentalists, and mindful of a 500-year supply of natural gas in the United States, transit agencies and private transportation companies across the country are switching to compressed natural gas.
While diesel is still king for transit systems, compressed natural gas is the fastest-growing alternative fuel. In January 1994, there were 297 natural-gas buses nationwide; now, 1,000 of the nation's 52,000 municipal buses use gas. More than a dozen transit systems have pledged to stop buying diesel buses, including Los Angeles, Atlanta, Houston and Cleveland.
Still, Transit officials said there is no rush to convert the entire fleet to natural gas because of the huge amount of money it would require to modify depots and to train mechanics. The buses themselves cost $277,000, $42,000 more than a standard diesel bus.
Transit officials have spent more than $1.6 million to install a natural gas fueling station and modify air vents and other mechanical adjustments at the site of the experiment, the Jackie Gleason Depot in Sunset Park, named for the actor who played Ralph Kramden, the bus driver from Bensonhurst, in "The Honeymooners."
Officials said their most ambitious plan is to buy 100 more buses at the end of the compressed gas experiment later this year.
Through a $3 million Federal transportation grant, the Taxi and Limousine Commission plans to give incentives to taxi fleet owners to convert 157 of the city's 11,787 taxis to compressed natural gas. Fleet owners would receive up to $5,000 for the engine and fuel tank conversion and an extra $2,000 in tax breaks.
Minute particles of carbon and other compounds in the sooty clouds spewing from buses and heavy trucks are estimated to raise the annual death rate in cities with pollution levels like New York's 15 percent above those in cities with cleaner air, according to a 1995 study by the Harvard School of Public Health that has been cited by environmentalists.
The particles lodge deep in the lungs and can raise the risk of developing emphysema, asthma and cancer, the E.P.A. said.
Last June, the Natural Resources Defense Council started a "Dump Dirty Diesel" campaign, and filed a lawsuit against the M.T.A. after the agency refused to run an ad from the group. The ads were to be placed on the rear of the bus, and read: "Standing behind this bus could be more dangerous than standing in front of it."
The lawsuit was settled after M.T.A. officials agreed to run the ads.

HEADLINE: Peru Mocks Due Process

 BODY:
Lori Helene Berenson of New York City may indeed have conspired with violent terrorists, as the Peruvian Government claims, helping them obtain weapons, rent safe houses and gather information for guerrilla attacks. Or Ms. Berenson's activities with the Tupac Amaru revolutionary movement may have been strictly nonviolent, as she insists. A fair trial might have determined the answer. But a fair trial is exactly what she did not get.
Ms. Berenson's lawyers were not allowed to cross-examine witnesses or challenge evidence. The identities of her military judge was concealed. The court then convicted her of treason, an offense that, as a non-Peruvian, she cannot be guilty of, and sentenced her to life in prison, although the prosecutor had only sought 30 years. The United States Government has strongly protested the entire proceeding. 
 Peru began subjecting civilians to this kind of military trial as a weapon against the once-dangerous Shining Path guerrilla movement, a threat that has now been largely contained. But the military courts continue to deprive Peruvians and foreigners of their most basic rights to due process. They are among the more disturbing trappings of President Alberto Fujimori's authoritarian regime.
Mr. Fujimori was democratically elected to a second term last year. Voters rewarded his success in rolling back the guerrilla challenge and taming hyperinflation. But he still rules in partnership with a military that has never accepted democracy and is responsible for grave human rights abuses. Though there is once again an elected congress, replacing the one Mr. Fujimori dissolved in 1992, its powers are weak and are rarely exercised. Nor is there any longer much of an independent judiciary. Mr. Fujimori's power knows no real constitutional check.
Throughout the 1980's, Peru maintained a constitutional democracy on paper. But its blessings were negated by economic decline, violent terrorism and a notoriously parasitic bureaucracy. Now public order is much improved and the economy revived. But the Peruvian people are subject to arbitrary arrest, unfair trials and other abuses of their most basic rights.
Ms. Berenson's lawyers are appealing the verdict, asking that the treason charges be reduced, perhaps to terrorism or collaboration, and the trial sent to a civilian court. The State Department rightly deplores the conduct of the trial and calls for her appeal to be heard in an open civilian court. Whatever she may or may not have done, she is surely entitled to that minimal degree of due process.
Ms. Berenson is strongly committed to the Tupac Amaru cause. She wants no special help from Washington, asking to be treated no differently than her Peruvian co-defendants. They too are entitled to due process in an open trial. Peru's progress in other areas does not have to come at the expense of its people's elementary rights.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Here We Go Again

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WIESMAN 

 BODY:
F. Scott Fitzgerald said that there are no second acts in American lives, but the Republican Party aims to give it a try. The G.O.P. wants to recreate the glory days of 1981, when President Reagan pushed a budget through Congress by rallying enough conservative Democrats to his side to get a majority. Now the Republican Congressional leaders say they will attempt to persuade a handful of Democratic senators and at least 55 Democratic House members to provide a two-thirds majority for their seven-year balanced budget plan that could withstand a veto from President Clinton.
On the surface, the Republican scheme is plausible enough. There are plenty of Democrats in the House who are close to the Republicans on many issues and not too fond of Mr. Clinton. But the odds seem to be against the latest Republican gambit because of an important historical shift that, ironically enough, can be traced back to Mr. Reagan's budget adventures of 15 years ago. 
 Back then conservative Democrats were enthralled by the supply-side alchemy that a tax cut would pay for itself by producing growth in the economy. Now the conservative Democrats happen to be the most outspoken opponents of the tax cut that is the centerpiece of the Republican agenda. Many of them happily embrace the term "blue dog Democrats" -- a send-up of the old expression "yellow dog Democrats," referring to party members who are so loyal they would vote for a yellow dog over a Republican.
But the blue dogs, it turns out, are so far more loyal to fiscal conservatism than they are to either party. They are among the most articulate and vehement opponents of a tax cut, and many are concerned about the accompanying sharp cuts in social programs for children, the elderly and the poor.
To get the blue dog support, the Republicans would have to scale back their tax cut more sharply. Such a step would almost certainly be welcomed by Bob Dole and many of his fellow Republican mandarins in the Senate if they could get Mr. Clinton to move their way on cutting Medicare and some domestic spending programs. But the party seems unable to move in that direction because of opposition by conservative Republicans in the House, particularly those disciplined and zealous freshmen. One of the paradoxes of the current stalemate is thus the unbridgeable gap on the tax-cut issue between the conservatives of the two political parties.
How did we get here? In retrospect, Mr. Reagan's sweeping tax cut of 1981 looks like an even more important turning point than it seemed at the time. For one thing, it started a debate that rages today. On one side is the Republican orthodoxy that the tax cut spurred the "morning in America" that Mr. Reagan rode to re-election. On the other is the Democratic orthodoxy that the tax cut pushed the country toward mounting deficits and debt service burdens for future generations.
After their election triumph in 1994, the Republicans made a tax cut the highest party priority. To their credit, they have at least been intellectually honest enough this time to admit that the tax cut would not pay for itself. By embracing a tax cut along with a balanced budget, many acknowledge that their real objective is to force a historic retrenchment in domestic programs -- particularly welfare, Medicaid and Medicare.
The Republicans may well succeed in winning over some of the blue dogs and other conservative Democrats, but it will be hard. They are laboring, for example, without the warm, reassuring presence of Mr. Reagan that entranced Americans more than a decade ago.
Remember also that both Medicare and Medicaid pay for the health care of the older generation, Medicare directly and Medicaid because of the huge numbers of middle-class and working-class elderly who turn their assets over to their children in order to qualify for Medicaid-financed nursing home care. It is not even clear that Mr. Reagan would be able to cast the same spell if he suddenly reappeared on the scene. He did not try to remake Medicaid and Medicare when he had the chance in the first act. STEVEN R. WEISMAN

HEADLINE: Health Research, Once Facing Big Budget Cut, Gets an Increase

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
While cutting the budget for most other agencies, Congress has given the National Institutes of Health an increase of 5.8 percent, after Republicans concluded that biomedical research was an engine of economic growth.
A bill signed recently by President Clinton provides $11.94 billion for the institutes in the current fiscal year, an increase of $655 million from the $11.28 billion spent last year. 
 Although Congress has cut most of the President's budget requests, it approved $175 million more than he requested for the N.I.H. The increase, in a bill signed by Mr. Clinton on Jan. 6, won strong support from lawmakers of both parties, including Speaker Newt Gingrich.
The institutes finance biomedical research on their own campus and at universities around the country. But after taking control of the House last year, Republicans skeptically scrutinized the N.I.H. and told scientists to expect substantial cuts as part of the Republican effort to balance the Federal budget.
The institutes' budget grew an average of 14 percent a year in the 1960's and nearly 9 percent a year in the next two decades. But these days an increase of 3 percent or 4 percent, just to keep pace with inflation, is considered a major victory for any agency. The increase for the N.I.H. exceeds the rate of inflation, even for biomedical research.
Ralph A. Bradshaw, president of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology, an organization of 10 scientific groups with 44,000 members, said: "We are elated. This is a great day for biomedical research."
After the Republicans won control of Congress, many of them expressed doubts about the need for the Government to finance research on biochemistry, molecular biology and genetics. They said biotechnology companies could pay for more research themselves. But after hearing from many business executives, the Republicans concluded that Federal research spending was a smart investment because it fosters economic growth, creates high-wage jobs and contributes to a favorable balance of trade.
Republicans still generally oppose the kind of industrial policy under which the Government picks certain companies, products or industries for support. But many Republican leaders advocate Federal support for basic scientific research. The history of science is full of cases in which basic research, with no obvious practical application, led to useful products and medications.
Money for the National Institutes of Health is normally provided as part of an appropriations bill that finances the Departments of Labor, Education, and Health and Human Services. That bill is languishing in Congress, but lawmakers singled out the work of the N.I.H. for special treatment.
This is part of a Republican strategy of providing "targeted appropriations" for programs they like while leaving others to fend for themselves. Representative John R. Kasich, an Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said this tactic would "put some pressure on the President" to accept Republican priorities.
For many programs, Congress has provided money only through Jan. 26 or March 15, but the N.I.H. got money for the full fiscal year, through Sept. 30. At the same time, the House voted to cut programs for elementary and secondary education, for job training and for summer jobs for teen-agers from low-income families.
The budget plan adopted by Congress in the first half of 1995 assumed that N.I.H. spending would be trimmed significantly. The House voted to cut the agency's budget by 5 percent in 1996 and to freeze it at that level for the next six years. The Senate Budget Committee recommended a 10 percent cut, and the full Senate voted to restore most of that money. The conference agreement on the budget, endorsed as a blueprint for the guidance of Congress last June, assumed a 1 percent cut in 1996 and a 3 percent reduction from the 1995 level after that.
But the Appropriations Committees of Congress, which actually write the money bills, did not accept those recommendations and reshuffled money among agencies. Two influential Republicans, Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon and Representative John Edward Porter of Illinois, insisted on an increase for the N.I.H.
Mr. Hatfield is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, and Mr. Porter is chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for the health institutes. Mr. Porter said Mr. Gingrich had been "very, very strongly supportive of the increase for N.I.H."
In May, university researchers and executives from biotechnology and drug companies met with Mr. Gingrich to emphasize the importance of biomedical research to the nation and to their industries. In retrospect, they say that meeting was a turning point because they apparently won the Speaker's support.
Among those at the meeting with Mr. Gingrich were Dr. Bradshaw; Dr. Joseph M. Davie, vice president in charge of research at Biogen, a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass.; Thomas N. Urban, chairman of Pioneer Hi-Bred International, a plant genetics company in Des Moines; Dr. Leon E. Rosenberg, president of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Pharmaceutical Research Institute, in Princeton, N.J., and Dr. Edward E. Penhoet, president of Chiron Corporation, a biotechnology company in Emeryville, Calif.
Mr. Urban said molecular biology of the type financed by the N.I.H. was "extremely important to plant genetics." Knowledge gained from such research will increase the productivity of seeds and agriculture, he said.
Dr. Penhoet said the institutes had provided "the seed money from which America's worldwide leadership in biotechnology has sprung." Dr. Davie said that "probably more than half of the products being developed in biotech as a whole came from discoveries in university laboratories," many of which receive money from the N.I.H.
Republicans suggested to corporate supporters of the N.I.H. that their companies could increase research spending to make up for any Federal cutbacks. But Dr. Davie said, "The amount of money actually spent in the biotech industry in research rather than development is minuscule compared with the amount of basic research supported by the Government."

HEADLINE: If We're So Tired, Why Aren't We Rich?

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Madrick; Jeffrey Madrick is the author of "The End of Affluence."

 BODY:
An idea has been gaining currency lately that goes something like this. The source of frustration and anxiety for so many Americans today is that they simply expect too much. Although the income gap may have widened and real wages fallen over the last couple of decades, most people are still much better off than their grandparents or great-grandparents were. Even in the Roaring 20's, almost everyone worked longer and harder than they do today, comparatively few had pensions, people readily died of minor diseases and half the population didn't even have indoor plumbing. Americans simply became accustomed to an artificially high standard of living during the postwar era that can no longer be sustained.
What is lacking in this view is the recognition of a historical shift that gives Americans good cause for anxiety, and not just because they missed out on the high-living 1950's and '60's. 
 It is true that most workers did not live as well before World War II as they do today. Yet they made extraordinary gains in their standard of living over the course of their lives. In 1920, for example, only one of four families owned a car. By 1930, three of five owned a car. Americans not only bought cars in those years but also, as electricity became available, washing machines, phonographs, refrigerators and radios.
They also finished high school in astonishingly greater numbers, and nearly half owned a home by 1930. Most people's health was considerably better than that of their parents or grandparents; their wages were much higher. Exceeding one's expectations defined what it meant to be American. This relative success gave proof to a powerful new idea of the Age of Reason: an individual (a white one anyway) could shape his destiny.
Now consider what is happening today. In the past 20 years, the rate of economic progress, as measured by statistics like wages and family income, has slowed greatly compared with any time since the Civil War. The most important of these statistics is productivity, the output of goods and services the economy produces per hour of work and the source of our rising standard of living. The rate at which it grows makes us collectively richer or poorer.
Evidence analyzed by economic historians has shown that productivity has grown at an average annual rate of 2.25 percent a year since 1870, not much slower than its pace in the immediate postwar era of 2.7 percent. Since 1973, however, productivity has grown at an average rate of only 1 percent a year, less than half its historical rate. Productivity growth has been higher in the 1990's, as it typically is during expansions. But productivity hasn't grown nearly as rapidly as it did in the 1950's and '60's (or during the 1920's, for that matter).
Had productivity grown at more than 2 percent over the last 20 years, the typical American family would have earned roughly $60,000 more in that time and better than $5,000 more in 1995 alone. There would be no Federal deficit at all at current levels of government spending, but rather a substantial surplus from which to meet our social obligations or reduce taxes. Instead, average wages and salaries have more or less stagnated since 1973, something they hadn't done over so long a period since the Civil War.
As incomes have become less certain and have begun to fall (in real wages) for nearly a third of workers, taxes increasingly feel like an unfair burden. Both spouses must work, though high-quality day care is expensive and hard to find. As for the American dream, while most of us can afford inexpensive new products like VCR's and microwave ovens, a significantly smaller proportion of Americans under 45 own homes.
Most disturbing, rapid growth may raise all ships, but slow growth apparently does not. More and more Americans are being left far behind: children, the poor and workers with only high school educations (still a majority of workers overall), to name the most immediate victims.
Economists cite everything from low savings rates to competition from low-wage countries to explain the slowdown in growth, but there is no clear consensus. What is clear is that, if we hope to improve growth or even maintain current rates, we must place more of our resources in capital investments, research and development and education. Healthy growth has been the glue that has held an otherwise diverse and often discordant people together since the nation's beginnings. Without it, a growing number of citizens feel, with good reason, that they are losing control over their lives. This is not business as usual in America. It is a reversal of our national experience.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin's Assault on Chechens Meets Critics on Left and Right

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 15

 BODY:
If President Boris N. Yeltsin hoped that a last-minute show of force in the six-day hostage crisis in southern Russia would somehow quell his critics, he miscalculated.
By hints and recent personnel changes, President Yeltsin has been sounding more and more like a man preparing himself for a re-election bid. And that may help explain why, immediately after Russian troops began firing on the village of Pervomayskoye where 200 Chechen rebels held about 100 hostages, prominent political figures on his left and right began hammering at the President -- even before the toll was known. 
 The Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, whose party has more seats in the newly elected Parliament than any other, heaped scorn on the decision and called it a "tragedy" for Russia and for Mr. Yeltsin. Calling the assault "a shame for Russian democracy," Grigory A. Yavlinsky, leader of the liberal opposition group Yabloko, threatened to raise the issue of a no-confidence vote against the Government in Parliament.
Only the ultranationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky favored the assault, but then quickly complained that Mr. Yeltsin would lack the resolve to finish the job against the hostage-takers, led by Salman Raduyev.
"You'll see," Mr. Zhirinovsky predicted. "The storming will be stopped and what remains of Raduyev's band will flee back to its nest."
Mr. Yeltsin defended the assault by saying he had exhausted all peaceful means of ending the stand-off. "Talks have been held every day for six days," he told reporters today outside his Kremlin office. "Even this morning we sent them the last warning and shots were the reply. Only then were orders issued for the operation."
But as they waited for the outcome, ordinary Russians did not appear as steadfastly opposed to the assault as most politicians.
"I approve of what the federal troops are doing in Pervomayskoye," said Aleksandr Ignatyev, 44, editor at a publishing house. "If the bandits are unpunished it would become a common practice all over the country. I am sure that neither the United States nor any other country would allow anything like this to happen."
Those who were upset about the assault mostly spoke of their opposition to the yearlong war against the separatists in Chechnya that gave rise to the hostage-taking. "We should have withdrawn our troops to prevent all these deaths and horror," said a 20-year-old construction worker who declined to give his name.
Mr. Yeltsin insisted that the assault had been carefully planned.
"I can't say there won't be casualties, but there will be a minimum of casualties." He did not rule out other assaults on Chechen rebels. "If intelligence reports indicate the presence of armed bandits at certain locations, and there are no civilians there, they should be . . ." Mr. Yeltsin did not finish the sentence, but instead smashed his hand as if squashing a fly.
Even though he was in the middle of a highly risky and sensitive anti-terrorist operation, Mr. Yeltsin did not decline to address his own political future. "It is possible, but not for sure" he said when asked about standing for a second term as President. "I am still thinking."
But he has already moved ahead with key appointments that suggest he could be preparing for a re-election campaign. Today he stunned his critics by appointing as his new chief of administration Nikolai D. Yegorov, the former minister of nationalities who, after intense pressure from Parliament, was fired for his role in the botched hostage-rescue operation in Budyonnovsk last May.
Mr. Yegorov was one of the administration's more hawkish advocates of the Russian military intervention in Chechnya, and his return to favor, on the very day of reckoning in Pervomayskoye, was strangely timed. But Mr. Yeltsin seems suddenly intent on surrounding himself with people he trusts, regardless of what his critics may say.
Mr. Yegorov replaces Sergei A. Filatov, a liberal, who left the Kremlin to begin organizing the presidential elections scheduled for June. Russian political analysts say that if Mr. Yeltsin decides to run, Mr. Filatov would become a key figure on the President's campaign staff.
The Chechen rebels have just as much as Mr. Yeltsin to lose in the battle for public opinion.
Yegor T. Gaidar, a liberal economist and politician who has said his party, Russia's Choice, will not field a candidate for the presidency, described Mr. Yeltsin's decision as "an immense risk."
Referring to the rebel Chechen leader, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, who ordered the hostage-taking, Mr. Gaidar added: "I think that Dudayev and his people made a big mistake by having put a stake on terror. They gave a trump card to the advocates of a forceful solution."
