HEADLINE: Technology Stocks Drag Market Down, and Dow Falls 17.34

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market weakened yesterday in sluggish holiday trading, as investors remained worried about earnings shortfalls and the absence of a budget agreement in Washington.
"There was weakness in the high-tech stocks and that impacted the Dow industrials," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president of Tucker Anthony. "Concern spread that earlier earnings estimates may not come to pass." 
 Among the major market indicators, the largest decline occurred in the technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index, which fell 19.66 points, or 1.95 percent, to 988.57 -- its lowest closing level since Aug. 3, 1995. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 17.34 points, to 5,043.78, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, slipped 1.99 points, to 599.82.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange led advancers, 1,330 to 957. Big Board volume slumped to 306.2 million shares, from 383.4 million shares on Friday, as banks and the Treasury bond market were closed in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
Intel was the most actively traded stock yesterday, as traders awaited its fourth-quarter financial report, which is scheduled to be released late today. The semiconductor manufacturer tumbled 3 1/4, to 53 3/8.
Other computer-related companies were also hard hit by investors concerned about waning demand. Micron, the second-most-active issue, which was downgraded by Robertson Stephens & Company, fell 2 1/8, to 30 7/8.Applied Materials dropped 3 7/8, to 31 3/8, and Cabletron Systems declined 4 1/2, to 68. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index plunged 14 points, to 165.7.
Bank stocks were lower, with analysts citing the possibility of higher loan-loss provisions. J. P. Morganclosed at 75 1/2, down 3/4; Chase Manhattan at 57, down 7/8, and BankAmerica at 60 1/4, down 1.
On the other hand, drug stocks gained on expectations that their profits would not be significantly affected by slow economic growth in 1996. Merck rose 1 1/2, to 63 5/8; American Home Products increased 2 3/8, to 97 5/8; Elan advanced 3, to 52 3/4, and Becton Dickinson added 2 3/4, to 76 7/8.
Some insurance issues also managed to finish on the plus side. Aetna closed at 70 1/8, up 2 3/8, and Cigna finished at 111 3/8, up 1 7/8.
After Merrill Lynch raised its ratings for Oxford Health and Wellcare Management, both managed-care companies moved higher. Oxford Health advanced 113/16 , to 653/16 , and Wellcare advanced 2 1/8, to 21.
Maybelline surged 3 1/4, to 40, on prospects of a bidding war for the corporation between L'Oreal of France and Benckiser of Germany. Wisconsin Central Transportation soared 5 1/2, to 73 1/2, after announcing late on Friday that a consortium it leads was selected as the preferred purchaser of British Rail's three freight companies. And Accustaff increased 2, to 43 1/2, after saying that it plans to acquire Additional Technical Support Inc.
But General Acceptance plummeted 5, to 7, after William Blair & Company slashed its earnings estimates. Federal Express declined 3 1/4, to 69 3/4, after saying that profits in its fiscal third quarter will be below expectations. And W. H. Brady dropped 6, to 21, after Robert W. Baird & Company cut its profit projections for the fiscal year ending July 31.

HEADLINE: McCall Faults Job Agencies Under Cuomo

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The Pataki administration has found an unlikely partner in its efforts to portray former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's job development agencies as mismanaged: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, New York's top elected Democrat.
The unusual alliance with the Republican administration was formed last week, when Mr. McCall issued reports that attacked the lending practices of the Job Development Authority and the Urban Development Corporation during the Cuomo years. 
 "Every step of the loan review approval and monitoring process was done in a way that made J.D.A. vulnerable to losses," Mr. McCall said.
The move drew criticism from Cuomo supporters, who said that Mr. McCall and one of his aides were among those named to evaluate economic programs approved under the previous administration. The Cuomo supporters said Mr. McCall, who is considering a run for governor in 1998, was trying to distance himself from Mr. Cuomo as well as his own role in the two agencies.
Mr. McCall acknowledged that he served on an advisory committee that reviewed loans for the Job Development Authority from 1989 to 1991. His aide, Assistant Deputy Comptroller Alan C. Sullivan, was the deputy commissioner for economic development in the Cuomo years.
"It's ridiculous," said Vincent Tese, the commissioner for economic development in the Cuomo administration. "Maybe Carl forgot that he sat on the review board."
But Cynthia Munk, a spokeswoman for Mr. McCall, said the Comptroller had no recollection of having reviewed any loan that the report had criticized.
"He attended some meetings and participated in a small way on the advisory committee," she said.
The harshest criticism focused on the Job Development Authority, which has made loans and loan guarantees totaling $800 million for 2,000 projects since it was created in 1961. The report said the agency had accumulated a deficit of $57.8 million from April 1990 to March 1995 because of lax evaluations of loan applications.
The findings echoed complaints that the Pataki administration has repeatedly made about Mr. Cuomo's economic development programs. In December, Mr. Pataki's aides pulled back financing from 177 development projects that had been approved under Mr. Cuomo.
That move came several weeks after Charles A. Gargano, Mr. Pataki's Commissioner for economic development, said that the former Governor's staff had mismanaged its economic stimulus programs.
Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gargano, said the Comptroller's findings support what the Commissioner has been saying.
But Mr. Tese defended the agency's record under the Cuomo administration, saying the loans were made to projects that showed "tremendous promise." He said many of the defaults from 1992 to 1995 were due to the recession.

HEADLINE: On Deadline, Yale Students End a Strike

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Facing the loss of teaching jobs for the semester that began today, graduate students at Yale University who had withheld grades from classes they taught last fall gave in and ended their grade strike.
The students said they had not expected that Yale would carry through on its threat to deny them teaching jobs, which many depend on for living expenses. The grade strike was called to pressure Yale to recognize a union for graduate teaching assistants. 
 But Yale had responded to the strike -- the graduate students' most dramatic action in their five-year campaign for a union -- with a flat refusal to negotiate, disciplinary hearings against three leaders and a firm pledge to strip strikers of teaching assignments. And of more than 400 teaching assistants in the humanities and social sciences, only 83 had taken part, the administration said.
"We were met by a level of reprisals that nobody expected," said Gordon Lafer, research director for the graduate group, "and we thought it was irresponsible to put all of our membership in the position of losing all of their income for the spring semester. For quite a lot of people that would have meant leaving New Haven."
As classes resumed today, Yale's final deadline for the teaching assistants to turn in their grades, the university's position had not changed, said a spokesman, Thomas Conroy. Yale would never accept collective bargaining with the graduate students. "They are students, not employees," he said.
And as some graduate students turned in their grades late, they learned that they had, in fact, lost teaching assignments, and that their departments were not guaranteeing to find them new ones.
"It's not going to be resolved today," Mr. Conroy said of the semester's teaching assignments.
Graduate students, who teach nearly 10 percent of the undergraduate courses at Yale College and serve as section leaders in large lecture courses, have campaigned for Yale to recognize the Graduate Employees and Students Organization as their collective bargaining unit.
The organization contends that Yale, like many universities under financial pressure, is using teaching assistants and part-time instructors in place of more expensive full-time faculty, and that as long as Yale is relying on them for teaching it should negotiate with them over pay and benefits.
While Yale waives tuition for nearly all of its graduate students and says that its $4,900-a-semester stipends for teaching are a very small part of its financial aid to them, for many students the stipends are their entire income. To cover their living expenses, they say, they must either take second jobs, at the expense of their doctoral research, or add to their debt.
Feeding their anxiety is a depressed job market, as universities replace full-time faculty jobs with part-time instructors. The job market is worst for Ph.D.'s in the humanities and social sciences, the two divisions that the graduate organization is seeking to represent.
Given those economic circumstances, students decided in a close vote Sunday night to end the grade strike and save their teaching jobs, said Mr. Lafer, who also serves as research director for Locals 34 and 35 of the Federation of University Employees, which represents Yale's blue-collar and clerical workers.
He said the graduate students intend to honor picket lines of those locals if they strike when their contracts expire in two weeks. Local 35, the union for dining-hall and maintenance workers, is resisting a proposal from Yale that would guarantee current employees their jobs and salaries for four years but establish a lower pay scale for new hires.
The union locals have pressed Yale to recognize the graduate student union, but because the National Labor Relations Board does not recognize graduate students as employees, the unions cannot strike over that issue as Local 35 did in the 1980's to win recognition for the clerical union.
Graduate students said today that they might stage job actions this spring in support of their union. They have also filed an unfair-labor-practice charge with the labor relations board that could bring the board to re-examine the issue of graduate students for the first time since the early 1970's.
But administrators said they hoped the students could shift from the issue of collective bargaining to the issues directly concerning them.
"I very much hope that we can now get down to the business of reconsidering the many issues of graduate education and building a more fruitful structure of dialogue," the dean of Yale College, Richard Brodhead said.
"I'm glad for the sake of our undergraduates that we've been able to restore the usual educational process," he said. "And I'm glad for the many graduate students who I knew to be in agony over the decision to withhold grades."
Many undergraduates said today that they were relieved that the grade strike had passed and were critical of the graduate group for calling it. In a survey of undergraduates conducted by The Yale Daily News last year, more than 60 percent said they opposed recognizing a union for teaching assistants.
"The administration should have been more sensitive to their requests, but there's no way they should ever have withheld grades," said Merritt Lear, a junior and history major.

HEADLINE: Ailing Papandreou Resigns, Asking Quick Election of Successor

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Greece's Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, a towering political figure whose two-month hospitalization has paralyzed both his Government and his ruling Socialist party, resigned tonight.
"It is obvious that the country cannot remain incapacitated by my illness," wrote Mr. Papandreou, 76, from his hospital bed at the Onassis Heart Center outside Athens. The letter, the end of a long struggle to persuade the ailing leader to relinquish his grip on power, was addressed to the Central Committee of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, the party Mr. Papandreou founded in 1974 and first led to power in 1981. 
 His formal resignation clears the way for the party's 170-member parliamentary majority to elect a successor within three days. The behind-the-scenes battle for succession is said to have narrowed to former Industry Minister Costas Simitis and Defense Minister Gerassimos Arsenis.
In his letter, Mr. Papandreou said his party should "proceed immediately with the election of a prime minister because the country's problems cannot wait."
Even if, as some political experts expect, the still-ailing Mr. Papandreou stays on as leader of the party, his resignation signals the end of an era in Greek politics. A former American citizen who spent 20 years in the United States, Mr. Papandreou was a compelling if often self-contradictory maverick who during his early years in power fought United States policies despite Greece's continuing membership in NATO.
His election in 1981 was a watershed for the left in Greece, paving the way for reforms including broader rights for women and an array of generous welfare programs. But his economic policy was widely regarded as a failure that continues to cripple Greece's growth.
During his last two years, Mr. Papandreou, back in office after four years in the political wilderness, emerged with a different tune. "As the world changed, he changed," said one Western diplomat in Athens recently. "He couldn't play the Americans against the Soviets any more, or rant and rave about U.S. bases in Greece any more. That was then, and this is now. Now, Greece is drawn more and more into the web of Europe."
Above all, he is an artful survivor, a populist with a devoted following and many enemies whose attacks he manages to duck. The son of a former Prime Minister, he returned in 1961 from the United States, where he had married an American and served as chairman of the Department of Economics at the University of California at Berkeley. In 1967, when a military junta took power in Greece, he was put in prison for eight months.
His most remarkable political comeback was in 1993 after four years in opposition, having weathered a corruption scandal, open-heart surgery and a public affair with a mistress 36 years his junior.
For much of his last term in office, he has been dogged by ill health, but that did not prevent him from keeping tight rein on his party and his Government, and from appointing his new wife, Dimitra Liani, 40, the former flight attendant he married in 1989, as his chief of staff.
Admitted to the Onassis Heart Center with pneumonia on Nov. 20, Mr. Papandreou has since undergone kidney dialysis and has been on and off a respirator. In the absence of a designated successor and without guidelines for choosing one except in the case of death or resignation, Greek political life for the last two months has turned on daily hospital bulletins which have tracked the state of the Prime Minister's health in excruciating detail. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

COUNTRY: GREECE (96%); UNITED STATES (95%); EUROPE (79%);

HEADLINE: Another Budget Growls in the Wings

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Those Federal budget watchers who cringed last year at the thought of a political train wreck between the White House and Congress over the 1996 spending bills are not going to want to hear this.
Under a timetable set out by law, President Clinton is supposed to submit his budget request for 1997 in less than three weeks. 
 Nearly four months into the Federal Government's 1996 fiscal year, many of the agencies and departments are still without budgets for the year because the Clinton Administration and Republican Congressional leaders cannot agree on a broader plan to balance the budget by 2002. And if current positions hold, negotiations over the 1997 budget will be no easier than the wrangling over the 1996 spending plan.
"The other budget train has not even left the station," said Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee. "But we really have a demand to get the 1997 budget over with as quickly as possible, because coming up is an election year where both the President and Congress will be tied up with campaigning.
"But all my intelligence tells me that the Administration has not even begun to focus on 1997."
Neither have the Republicans.
"It is impossible to even think about 1997 until we get through this," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee and a lead negotiator on the Republican side in the budget talks with the White House.
So far, work on the 1996 budget has consumed nine months, hundreds of hours of committee and floor debate in the Senate and House and 50 hours of face-to-face meetings between President Clinton and the Republican leaders. And there still seems no solution in sight.
"If I drive the budget horses much harder, they are going to drop dead," Mr. Kasich said. "If I showed up in a room asking people to talk about next year's budget, it might be grounds for commitment."
The budget process usually goes something like this:
In late September departments and agencies submit their budget requests for the coming year to the Office of Management and Budget for review by the director. After the director checks the budget requests, they are sent back to the departments with recommendations, a process that is traditionally completed around Thanksgiving.
The President makes final decisions on the budget requests in December after consulting with senior economic advisers and Cabinet members. And under the 1974 Budget Act, the President presents the spending plan to Congress by the first Monday in February. For this year, that target date is Feb. 5.
The Administration initially stuck to that timetable last fall, with departments and agencies submitting their requests to the Office of Management and Budget and the budget officials beginning an informal review of the requests. But somewhere in the night, the process ran smack into the stalled budget talks of 1996.
"In essence, none of the internal decision-making for the 1997 budget has taken place," said Lawrence J. Haas, a spokesman for the budget office. "Obviously, the President cannot submit a fiscal 1997 budget until we have fiscal 1996 final decisions. Not only do we not have those spending bills, but we have potential changes to entitlement programs and tax policies."
Since 1980, the President has missed the budget deadline seven times -- at least twice because of changes in administrations and the other times because budget negotiations have stretched into the fall.
But the current budget impasse has lasted so long that it has taken the White House and Congress into uncharted waters.
The much-feared budgetary train wreck between the two forces has instead become a game of political chicken, with each side holding its ground in the face of public anger over the partial shutdowns of the Federal Government.
But the timetable for the budget process was thrown off long before now. After taking control of the Senate and the House in January 1995, the Republicans spent the first 100 days pushing through their Contract With America before turning to the budget.
And the Republicans radically changed the rules of the game, setting as their ultimate goal a budget that spanned seven years and ended in the black. The initial year's budget and succeeding ones through 2002 were to be merely components of the overall plan.
The Republicans plan to include in their 1997 budget the privatization of more Federal services and reductions in Cabinet departments -- they went after the Commerce Department in the 1996 budget, and Speaker Newt Gingrich has promised his impatient revolutionaries that the Department of Education would be on the hit list in 1997.
Mr. Kasich and Mr. Livingston said that among the options that Republicans were considering for the 1997 budget was melding it with what is left of the 1996 budget into a package covering a year and a half or so, using goals set out in their balanced budget plan.
"We might not even consider the White House budget," Mr. Livingston said. "Our own numbers are pretty much spelled out in our seven-year balanced budget plan."
That notion brought a sigh of resignation from one of the senior aides on the Democratic staff of the House Budget Committee.
"When you have 218 votes or more, you can do anything you want," he said, "just as the Republicans have done with the 1996 budget process."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
Acrimony Takes No Holiday
Celebrating the Martin Luther King holiday was a tricky business for Mayor Giuliani and Governor Pataki. The Mayor, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, found himself caught up in a public argument with the Rev. Al Sharpton, mostly over which of them was the most disrespectful of Dr. King's memory. And at his speech at a church in Harlem, some parishioners murmured criticism of the Governor's proposed budget cuts. [B1.]
 
A Dispute's Deep Roots
As with many of the recent fights over spending at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, New York City's pursuit of a legal claim for $400 million in back rent for La Guardia and Kennedy International airports is part of a deeper dispute. The city believes that the Port Authority has too often favored New Jersey and not invested enough to improve its economy. The Port Authority says the city's claim is "clouding the process" for nearly $2 billion in work at the airports. [B2.]
 
Attack Muddies an AIDS Issue
Many people are outraged that Colete Lopez, 6, of Sunnyside, Queens, who was jabbed in an attack with a hypodermic needle on the F train a month and a half ago, might have been exposed to H.I.V., the AIDS-causing virus. But should that anger be the basis for forcing some criminal suspects to take H.I.V. tests, as Governor Pataki has proposed? NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Inquiry Into Shooting Continues
Detectives continued to search for clues in the shooting death of an off-duty police officer in Brooklyn on Saturday night and said they still had not determined whether the death was a suicide, a homicide or an accident. The officer, Kimberly Rivera, 28, was shot once in the head outside the Bensonhurst home of her estranged husband, John. [B2.]
 
Salman Rushdie Steals a Visit
Salman Rushdie slipped into New York City this week to promote his latest book. Mr. Rushdie was sentenced to death in 1989 by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who said he had blasphemed Islam in his novel "The Satanic Verses." [B6.]
 
REGION
 
In Search of Warm Weather
Last week's great blizzard has spurred a great exodus as East Coast residents seek refuge in the Sun Belt and other warm-weather destinations in record numbers for this time of year. [Page A1.]
 
Ferraro Weighs Another Run
More than three years after losing a bruising Democratic Senate primary in a quest to become the first woman to be a United States Senator from New York, Geraldine A. Ferraro is openly talking about a possible run against Mayor Giuliani next year or Governor Pataki in 1998. The notion clearly energizes her. [B5.]
 
McCall Faults Cuomo Agencies
The Pataki administration has found an unlikely partner in its efforts to portray former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's job development agencies as mismanaged: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, New York's top elected Democrat. The unusual alliance was formed last week, when Mr. McCall issued reports that attacked the lending practices of the Job Development Authority and the Urban Development Corporation during the Cuomo years. [B5.]
 
Grade Strike Ends at Yale
Facing the loss of teaching jobs for the semester that began yesterday, graduate students at Yale University who had withheld grades from classes they taught last fall ended their grade strike. The grade strike had been called to pressure Yale to recognize a union for graduate teaching assistants. [Page B1.]
 
Ferry Proposal Divides a Town
A conflict in Nyack, N.Y., over a proposal by the New York State Thruway Authority for a high-speed ferry link to New York City offers cautions for government officials bent on promoting ferry travel. Supporters there argue that the ferry would lure day-tripping New Yorkers to savor a still largely undiscovered village graced by 50 antique shops, showcase homes and splendid views of the Hudson. But opponents worry that a daily invasion of more than 500 cars would deter regular customers from the downtown shops, offsetting any profits from the commuter trade. [B1.]
 
Couple's Sentencing Delayed
More than a year after they were convicted of stealing $35 million from some of the nation's largest banks, Robert and Susanna Scaretta, the former owners of an armored car company based in Bohemia, L.I., have yet to be sentenced. An unusually long presentencing hearing has come down to this: who will care for the Scarettas' four children, 4 to 16 years old, if both parents are sent to prison? Since the prosecutor asked for more time -- in part, to permit a court probation officer to interview other members of the family and to review finances and medical and psychiatric reports concerning the children -- sentencing is now scheduled for Feb. 23. [B5.]

HEADLINE: 2 Rivals, Worlds Apart, Vie for Packwood's Seat

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 15

 BODY:
They have been arguing about guns and taxes, salmon and jobs, abortion and homosexuals.
Still, it is not so much two visions of the United States' future that has shaped the contest for the open Senate seat in Oregon, a nearly monthlong, mail-in election to be decided by the end of January. Rather, it is two American personal narratives, worlds apart. 
 The Democrat, Representative Ron Wyden, is Jewish, a 46-year-old liberal from a big city, Portland. The Republican, State Senator Gordon Smith, is a Mormon, a 43-year-old conservative from a rural area near Pendleton.
Mr. Wyden's father fled Nazi Germany. Mr. Smith's family sent him abroad, as a Mormon missionary.
Mr. Wyden wanted to be a professional basketball player, but instead became a lawyer who helped found the Gray Panthers, a group that lobbies on social issues for the elderly.
Mr. Smith wanted to make money, and has become a millionaire many times over as the owner of one of the nation's largest producers of frozen peas and corn. It is estimated that 1 of every 7 peas grown in this country passes through his factory in Pendleton, in eastern Oregon.
Polls show that the race for the seat vacated last fall, when Senator Bob Packwood, a Republican, resigned amid a storm of controversy over ethics and sexual misconduct, is too close to call.
With an economy so strong that some parts of the state have worker shortages, Oregon would seem to be a prosperous prop for President Clinton's vision of a trade-dependent, environmentally conscious state. Indeed, Mr. Clinton is popular in Oregon, with an approval rating near 60 percent, just as Speaker Newt Gingrich is not, with only about 25 percent approving of how he is doing his job. But neither man has been much of an issue so far.
Both parties have flown in big-name outside help. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, was here on Saturday night, talking up the prospects of Republicans gaining enough seats to have a veto-proof Senate.
Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, was here today, warning that "if Mr. Smith goes to Washington, he will bring with him an anti-choice agenda" on abortion rights.
But as much as others have tried to make this race a referendum on the Republican agenda in Washington or the President, the focus remains on Mr. Wyden and on Mr. Smith.
"Barely half the people think this election is a referendum on anything except the two candidates," said Tim Hibbitts, an independent pollster.
Campaign disclosures have clouded the images that both candidates have tried to project. Mr. Smith has been dogged by questions about water pollution caused by spills from his food plant, Smith Frozen Foods, with one advertisement accusing him of fatal neglect.
Although he has campaigned on the principles of less government and unfettered free enterprise, Mr. Smith received $766,000 in Federal and state grants to bring his plant up to compliance with antipollution laws. State officials say that Smith Frozen Foods has illegally spilled waste into nearby creeks and ponds four times since 1993, and was fined more than $70,000 for one violation. One spill killed thousands of fish.
Mr. Wyden has seized on the cleanup record, calling Mr. Smith "a chronic polluter" who used taxpayers' money to comply with the law when his net worth exceeded $5 million. The Congressman says Mr. Smith, if elected, will be part of an anti-environmental Congress.
"The new majority in Congress is running a polluter's holiday," Mr. Wyden said, just after a televised debate in Portland on Sunday.
Mr. Wyden has built a 15-year career in Congress around an image as a friend of consumers, the elderly and the poor, and these are among the issues he has been pushing in this campaign.
But his link to blue-collar causes took a beating during the primary, when he could not answer questions about the price of milk, bread or gasoline. Mr. Smith ran advertisements suggesting that Mr. Wyden was out of touch, a Washington insider who never went shopping.
Mr. Wyden, while saying he "blew the quiz," has taken to joking about it. In Sunday's debate, he said one of the things he likes to do for fun in his spare time is "shop for groceries with the children."
Mr. Wyden's failure to price the staples of everyday life has taken away what could have been a powerful class issue against Mr. Smith, aides to both campaigns say.
While Mr. Smith has a salary of more than $2 million a year, he pays the workers at his food plant $7 to $15 an hour. He bought four antique golf clubs for $1.25 million and owns a $325,000 ski condo in Utah, a million-dollar home near Pendleton and a fleet of fast cars.
Mr. Smith says he is living the American dream. "The whole notion of the Oregon Trail is about the American Dream," he said in an interview. "People don't fault you for pursuing that."
Mr. Smith is also willing to spend some of his wealth to get elected. He says he will spend about $3.5 million, nearly twice the projected spending of his opponent, and about $2 million will be from his own pocket.
Oregon has had mail-in elections for years, but this is the first for national office. This year's mail-in vote is an experiment whose chief sponsor, Phil Keisling, the Oregon Secretary of State, says produces a better turnout and costs less.
Whether the experiment will help one party or the other remains an open question. Turnout in the vote-by-mail primary, just under 58 percent of registered voters, set an Oregon record for a non-Presidential primary. The Republican turnout was about two percentage points higher than the Democratic turnout.
In a race this close, when only about 15 percent of Oregon's voters have sent in sealed ballots since the vote-by-mail election started on Jan. 9, any gaffe or new disclosure could determine the outcome.
Sunday's debate, the last one of the campaign, was generally a low-intensity affair. Mr. Smith has tried to soften some of his conservative edges, playing up his editorial endorsement by The Oregonian, the state's dominant newspaper.
Oregon tends to elect socially tolerant, fiscally conservative, somewhat independent candidates. The newspaper endorsement, casting Mr. Smith as a centrist conservative, may be enough to sway a few thousand swing voters in the suburbs, Mr. Smith's supporters say.
"With The Oregonian saying that he's not some right-wing wacko, that may reassure a lot of people who are on the fence," said Pat McCarthy, a spokesman for Mr. Smith.
But outside groups trying to influence the race have been broadcasting television advertisements that are anything but reassuring. The teamsters union, for example, has sponsored advertisements implying that lax safety regulations at Mr. Smith's food plant were responsible for one death and more than a dozen serious on-the-job injuries.
Mr. Wyden has denounced the advertisements, asking that they be taken off the air. "Against the advice of my advisers, I've taken all negative ads off the air," Mr. Wyden said in the debate on Sunday.
Mr. Smith replied, "Yes, but you have a surrogate slandering me," referring to the teamsters ads.
Dan Lavey, campaign manager for the Smith campaign, said the advertisements had had "some impact," but he did say how much.
Oregon has not had a new member of the United States Senate since 1968. Now, with Mr. Packwood gone and the pending retirement of the state's senior Senator, Mark O. Hatfield, it will have two in one year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a tight race to fill the seat vacated by Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the Democratic candidate, Ron Wyden, left, shook hands with his Republican rival, Gordon Smith, at a debate in Portland on Sunday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stock Market Weakens, Particularly in Technology
The stock market weakened, particularly in technology issues, in sluggish holiday trading, as investors worried about earnings shortfalls and Washington's continued failure to reach a budget agreement. Intel, the most actively traded stock, fell 3 1/4, to 53 3/8, as traders awaited today's earnings report.
The technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index fell 19.66 points, or 1.95 percent, to 988.57 -- its lowest closing level since Aug. 3, 1995. Declining less severely, the Dow industrials dropped 17.34 points, to 5,043.78, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, slipped 1.99 points, to 599.82. [Page D12.]
 
Burlington Northern Plans Cuts
Burlington Northern Santa Fe announced plans to cut about 2,600 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, and shed thousands of miles of little-used track. Because of the cutbacks, the company will take a pretax charge of $585 million in its fourth quarter. [D4.]
 
Microsoft Plans to Buy Vermeer
Microsoft plans to buy Vermeer Technologies and incorporate Vermeer's World Wide Web publishing software into its top-selling suite of office programs. The move, expected to be announced today, could establish Vermeer's Front Page program as the leading way to write information for the Web. [D8.]
 
A Sudden Migration to the Sun
Like the birds that flew south in the autumn, there is now a second mass migration. But this time it's people. Northeasterners fed up with last week's blizzard are jamming the switchboards of travel agents, hotels and airlines, seeking a speedy trip to Florida, the Caribbean, Mexico and other sunny climes. Meanwhile, the human counterparts of snow birds are heading for the ski slopes. [Page A1.]
 
Bigger Biomedical Research Budget
Congress, while cutting most budgets, gave the National Institutes of Health a 5.8 percent increase, viewing that biomedical research as an engine of economic growth. [A13.]
 
Prodigy Endures a Family Squabble
Even as its parents -- Sears, Roebuck and I.B.M. -- haggle, the Prodigy Services Company, the on-line information service, is struggling to maintain life as usual. With Sears apparently seeking an outside buyer, I.B.M. is said to have brought in its own team of investment bankers and consultants. [D2.]
 
Texas Family to Buy Omni Hotels
Omni Hotels said the Rowling family of Corpus Christi, Tex., had agreed to buy its hotels in the United States from Wharf Holdings of Hong Kong for about $500 million. In addition to nine hotels, it would get management contracts or franchise agreements for 26 others. [D2.]
 
Brief Contradicts Philip Morris
A legal brief under seal in a Virginia state court argues that secret Philip Morris documents indicate the company runs a "tobacco extract factory" that adds nicotine to cigarettes in precise measurements. The brief, obtained by The Associated Press, disputes testimony by company executives. [D6.]
 
Of Tea Leaves And THE Game
The bull market is good for another year, according to Wall Street's much-discussed Super Bowl indicator, no matter whether the Dallas Cowboys or Pittsburgh Steelers win. Actually, people who buy or sell stocks based on such indicators probably should not be allowed to manage their own money. But the existence of indicators with such apparently superb records shows that even if two things correlate, they may not be related. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D12.]
 
Reebok's Ambitious New Ads
Ditching its nebulous "Planet Reebok" campaign, Reebok International hopes to reverse a serious slump in market share with an ambitious new campaign from Leo Burnett. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]

HEADLINE: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;
Gretzky Can't Lose Under New System

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
A year ago, when the National Hockey League lockout ended, management celebrated victory over labor. Despite failing to force a salary cap or a luxury tax, team owners seemed assured that other provisions of the agreement would lessen wage inflation while increasing their control over the players.
This may eventually prove true, but the most interesting employer-employee showdown at the moment seems to show one worker with most of the leverage. It is the negotiation between Wayne Gretzky, a veteran superstar and the game's highest-paid player, and the rookie owners of the Los Angeles Kings, Edward Roski and Philip Anschutz. 
 Gretzky's agent, Michael Barnett, was expected to meet with the owners today in Los Angeles. They will discuss Gretzky's short- and long-term future with the team, including the possibility of a trade before the playoffs this spring to a team that is in contention to win the Stanley Cup. Under terms of the new collective bargaining agreement, Gretzky can become a free agent after this season. He's more than 32 years old -- he turns 35 on Jan. 26 -- and his contract is expiring.
Last night, the Kings said they intend to sign Gretzky to a contract extension and end speculation that the superstar may be traded. "We are prepared to offer a contract extension as early as tomorrow to Gretzky's agent, Mike Barnett, to show our intent to keep him," Kings General Manager Sam McMaster told XTRA radio.
Under the old collective bargaining agreement, Gretzky would have been a restricted free agent. His team would have had either the right to match any salary offer or player compensation from the team that signed him. His mobility and his leverage would have been limited next summer. His power this season would have been nil.
Not so now. In the last two weeks, Barnett and Gretzky have launched an impressive publicity blitz that suggests an auction. Mike Keenan, coach and general manager of the St. Louis Blues, is talking openly of acquiring Gretzky. Toronto, Detroit and the Rangers are also mentioned, with less intensity, as possible bidders. The trading deadline is March 20.
The latest published rumors have him going to St. Louis in a multiplayer deal, with his salary to increase from its current $6.5 million a year to $9 million a year for two seasons after this one.
"Where there's smoke, there's fire," Gretzky said of the reports, published in Toronto.
Bob Goodenow, executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, said "there is no question that older players have better opportunities" than they used to. But he said he wasn't sure what Gretzky's leverage could create in the immediate future in terms of return in a trade.
"I don't know how much teams are going to give in trade now, when, come August, they can have him for free," Goodenow said.
Along with market forces, Goodenow predicted that Gretzky's next salary would be partly dictated "as a function of where he wants to be." Toronto would seem a good fit, if only because he is from near there and Gretzky might lift this veteran team from good to great.
But the Maple Leafs already sell all their seats. What new income could he generate? The Blues, on the other hand, have empty seats to sell. The Rangers and Madison Square Garden, with their in-house cable television network, could increase ratings and demand for commercial time with one more superstar. But they lead the league in payroll at $31 million.
 
Verbeek Lifts Rangers
 Another player in Wayne Gretzky's situation is Pat Verbeek of the Rangers, who will turn 32 on May 24. He is playing under a contract for $1.75 million after a contentious arbitration before the season. Unlike Gretzky, Verbeek isn't threatening to demand a trade if his team doesn't improve itself quickly to contend for the cup. The Rangers are probably a contender. Their 3-3 tie with the Blues on Sunday night at Madison Square Garden left them with 65 points, best in the Eastern Conference.
By scoring twice Sunday to erase a 3-1 deficit, Verbeek raised his goal total to 32, best on the team and one ahead of Mark Messier. His best total in a career that began in 1982 was the 46 he scored for the Devils in 1987-88. The money Verbeek gets with his free agency this summer will indicate the success or failure of the union strategy of sacrificing bargaining power of young players in exchange for increasing the clout of the veterans.
While Messier played an average game against the Blues, Verbeek surged and even took on a Messier-type duty by yelling at his teammates on the bench.
"You can't always rely on Mess to carry the load every time," Verbeek said.
The Rangers are idle until next Monday night, when they will play host to the Kings. Verbeek, Messier and Brian Leetch will represent the Rangers on the Eastern Conference team at Boston's new Fleet Center in the All-Star Game on Saturday night.

HEADLINE: Mayor Seeks $400 Million For Airports

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
In a new turn in the often stormy relationship between the Port Authority and the Giuliani administration, New York City is pursuing a legal claim for $400 million in back rent for the city's two major airports. But as with many of the recent fights over spending at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the dispute goes much deeper.
To Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, the fundamental issue is that the city believes that the Port Authority has too often favored New Jersey and not invested enough in projects to improve the New York City economy. Mr. Dyson said that, in particular, the authority should make immediate improvements to Kennedy International Airport. 
 The Port Authority chairman, Lewis M. Eisenberg, said the Authority plans to begin nearly $2 billion in work at Kennedy and La Guardia Airports. But he said the city's claim for back rent was "clouding the process."
"The Port Authority is anxious to sit down with the city and resolve this," Mr. Eisenberg said. "We have billions of dollars set aside and we would like to put it to good use."
The airport lease is set to expire in 2015, and the city and the Authority have been trying to negotiate an extension for several years. The Port Authority, which also runs Newark International Airport, has operated Kennedy and La Guardia airports under a series of leases dating to 1947.
The city, which owns the land under both New York City airports, says the Port Authority has systematically shortchanged New York in the long-term lease for the sites.
"Newark gets $17 million a year in rent, while we get $3 million for two airports," Mr. Dyson said. "Three million dollars equates to two floors on the Empire State Building -- not very high up."
For their part, Port Authority officials say the city's action is making it difficult to move ahead with nearly $2 billion in planned improvements at the two airports.
The city's claim stems from a provision in the lease that says the rent is a portion of the revenue from the airports, with deductions for operations and maintenance costs. The annual rent payments hovered around $80 million in the late 1980's, but dropped to as low as $3 million in 1993. Although the rent increased somewhat in 1994, to $6.2 million, the city ordered a review of the lease payments by its own accounting firm in January 1995.
On Dec. 14, the city served the Port Authority with a demand for arbitration, asserting that the Authority had failed to pay a correct portion of the revenue and had inflated operations costs at both airports. City lawyers have said their review indicated a $400 million shortfall between 1991 and 1994.
A large portion of the city's claim, about $126 million, is based on the Port Authority's decision not to include a special $3-per-passenger fee in Kennedy Airport's general revenue. The fee, a charge approved by the Federal Government, is dedicated solely to airport improvements and by Federal regulation is excluded from use in municipal projects. Port Authority officials say the Federal rules that established the special fee do not allow them to forward any portion of the money to the city.
"This money is very specifically authorized by the people in Washington for specific purposes," said Jeffrey S. Green, general counsel for the Port Authority.
Authority officials said the airport rent decreased after 1990 because the authority made over $1 billion in capital improvements to Kennedy and La Guardia, including roadway work at Kennedy and terminal improvement at La Guardia.
The city has asked the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants to arbitrate the rent dispute. And the Authority has asked a judge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to stop the arbitration.
"This is a small part of a larger issue with the Port Authority," said Mr. Dyson, who is Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development. "Two years ago, when I came into this job, the Mayor asked me to look around. The most frequent complaint I heard from business people was the quite terrible condition of our airports, in particular Kennedy Airport."
In fact, Port Authority officials said the Authority's nearly $2 billion improvement plan for the New York airports includes a new $700 million international arrivals building at the Kennedy airport.

HEADLINE: Old-Style Ward Politics Won For Turkey's Islamic Party

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: KONYA, Turkey, Jan. 11

 BODY:
In its campaign to win votes on the back streets of this provincial Anatolian city, Turkey's pro-Islamic Welfare Party left little to Allah and nothing to chance.
Long before last month's elections, in which this onetime fringe party made the leap to the country's No. 1 vote-getter and earned the chance to try, as yet unsuccessfully, to form a governing coalition, its workers fanned out across Konya's neighborhoods, deployed like soldiers in an old-fashioned, big-city party machine. 
 In the city's Meram area, home to new arrivals from Turkey's fast-emptying countryside, each street has its own six-member Welfare Party team that keeps a close watch on the lives of its inhabitants. The sick, the poor, births, weddings, funerals -- all are grist for the regular reports sent into the party district office and on to city hall, which for the last five years has been occupied by a Mayor from the Welfare Party.
Mayor Halil Urun, a civil engineer with a political manner closer to that of a ward-heeler's than an Islamic fundamentalist's, takes it from there. On any given Sunday, he attends between 10 and 15 weddings, greeting as many as 2,000 voters in a single day. "If you don't say hello to people," he said, in the English he learned during a stint in the United States, "they won't vote for you."
The Welfare Party's approach is not just sound politics; it is practically revolutionary here. While Turkey's traditional parties battled each other for ministerial portfolios in Ankara, the Welfare Party cultivated the grass roots, tapping into the widespread alienation that sent millions of Turks looking for an alternative to a political system they perceive to be inbred, corrupt and insensitive to their problems.
"Even if we don't promise them anything, a simple visit makes people happy," said Muzaffer Bolanyig, a local Welfare Party inspector who figures party workers visited every household in his district, encompassing 14 streets and 40,000 inhabitants. "Until now, no one else had ever visited them."
Mayor Urun's administration -- like those of Welfare Party mayors in Istanbul, Ankara and 22 other Turkish cities -- also has focused on clean streets, cheap bread, tram lines and -- in its one bow to the moral code of Islam -- the closing of local brothels.
On Dec. 24, the Welfare Party -- or Refah as it is called in Turkish -- inched past Turkey's main center-right parties to capture 21.4 percent of the national vote, giving it the largest bloc in the 550-seat Parliament. In the province of Konya, the home base of Necmettin Erbakan, the party's leader, the vote for Welfare was 43 percent, while in the city it was 55 percent and in the city's Meram area 60 percent.
The lure of Islam is part of the party's pitch. But according to local party leaders, it is more of an appeal to a common Muslim heritage, shared by 99 percent of Turkey's 65 million people, than a call to arms against Turkey's 70-year-old secular tradition. They tend to discount Mr. Erbakan's tough antisecular, anti-Western campaign polemics and point instead to his recent, more accommodating statements, made in the days since he was tapped by President Suleyman Demirel to put together a governing coalition.
[On Jan. 13, Welfare failed for a second time to form a coalition Government, The Associated Press reported. After meeting with Mr. Erbakan, Mesut Yilmaz, the leader of center-right Motherland Party, said it would be "unusually difficult" to reconcile the two parties' different political philosophies, though he added that Mr. Erbakan appeared to be softening some of his positions.]
Mayor Urun said that during the campaign, Mr. Erbakan "had to say some extremist things, but now that phase is over and our image will change."
Welfare Party leaders, here and in Ankara, are already resigned to the prospect that Mr. Erbakan's coalition-building efforts will fail, rejected by mainstream politicians fearful of letting Islamists get a foothold in government. And they say they are not sorry because, according to their calculations, the more months -- even years -- they spend in opposition, the stronger their appeal to voters disaffected by a rickety economy, with its high inflation and unemployment.
"If the other parties say they don't want to be seen with us, we will say thank you very much, and give the job back," said Abdullah Gul, deputy party chairman. "We are not supported by big banks, big interests. We are not corrupt, we are not involved in hanky-panky, so our expectations are not personal. We can wait two to three years, and then we will be back, with a big majority."
This message is not lost on the Welfare Party's political rivals, particularly on the local level. After sounding out the electorate, Ahmet Alkan, a newly elected deputy from Konya for the Motherland Party, is now convinced that it would be wiser to let the Welfare Party into a government coalition.
"There are two Turkeys," said Mr. Alkan, 42, a city planner. "The people in Ankara and the media want one thing, and the people want another. If Refah stays in opposition, they will get stronger."
Mr. Alkan and his colleague, Mehmet Kececiler, another Motherland deputy from Konya, do not fear the Welfare Party's pro-Islamic stands. Like many Turks, both men are convinced that Turkey's secular society is too strong to turn the clock back to the days before Ataturk, the republic's revered founder, who stripped the state of its ties to Islam.
But Mr. Kececiler does feel that Turkey should be more sensitive to religious yearnings. If, for instance, religious women were allowed to cover their heads at all Turkish universities, in courtrooms and in public offices where head scarves are still banned, then the Welfare Party would lose one of its most effective slogans, he said.
"Religion is a force all over the world," said Mr. Kececiler. "I am against Refah, but I am not against religion. And issues like the head scarf helped Refah. They used it like a flag."
But others are more wary of the ambitions of the Welfare Party.
"If, as they maintain, the essence of culture is religion and that doesn't change, what does that say about secularism, about Turkishness?" asked one top Government adviser, who insisted on anonymity. "Now what we hear is the sweet talk before the big fight. Once in power, they would use every means to install their ideology at critical points of statecraft."
For many who oppose a Welfare-led coalition, the biggest liability is Mr. Erbakan himself, a wily, witty and obstinate 69-year-old politician who served twice in Turkish coalition Governments in the 1970's. "It is very difficult to deal with Mr. Erbakan," said the official, who worked with him 20 years ago. "It is like a marriage where you have to give all the time and get nothing in return."
Here in Konya, the party's pro-Islamic platform has had little effect on daily life. A new Islamic school opened in 1990. It offers intense religious instruction together with an English-language curriculum. City residents say the popularity of the school owes more to its English-language instruction than to its teaching of the Koran, and it receives fewer applicants than the city's other foreign-language high schools.
"It is exaggerated to think of Refah as a party of fundamentalists," said Hasmet Oyken, managing editor of Yeni Konya, a local newspaper. "Refah was able to reach the population here because Konya is a closed, conservative city, with a low standard of living which fosters a kind of naivete among the people. If Konya were to open up to the wider world, then the influence of Refah would drop."

HEADLINE: Yes, Worry About the Budget Deficit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Budget Myths" (column, Jan. 12): Anthony Lewis blames the ballooning deficits of the 1980's and early 1990's on Presidents Reagan and Bush, ignoring that the Democrats controlled Congress throughout the period.
Mr. Lewis goes on to say that United States tax rates are not high compared with countries like France or Germany. But the countries he lists with higher tax rates than our own have anemic growth and unemployment rates that in some cases exceed 12 percent. Should we really be looking to France as a model for our economy? 
 While the budget deficit may not be the immediate crisis some in Congress would have us believe, it contributes to our country's borrowing needs and is a factor in keeping interest rates high relative to inflation.
It is not fair to characterize Republican budget proposals as aimed "to gut government medical and environmental programs." Let us not forget that the cost of these programs grows at double-digit rates annually while our economy has been growing at slightly better than 2 percent. The Republican proposal, for example, merely slows the projected growth of Medicare and Medicaid spending from 11 percent to 7 percent annually.
Mr. Lewis admonishes us to focus on our "real economic problems," one of which he says is the slowdown of growth and productivity. What are the causes of this slowdown? Heavy taxation, entitlement programs and excessive government meddling in the economy do nothing to spur economic or job growth. And that is not a myth.
 
ARTHUR S. PIER
New York, Jan. 14, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: New York's Wage Bill Violates No Principle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re " 'Living Wages,' Fewer Jobs" (Op-Ed, Jan. 12):
Heather Mac Donald's attack on New York City's living wage bill coincides almost point by point with the Giuliani administration's testimony at two City Council hearings on the bill. 
 Ms. Mac Donald says that the bill would "repeal the law of supply and demand" by requiring companies with city contracts to pay an hourly minimum of $12.10, including benefits, to their workers.
Giuliani administration officials and their scarce supporters on the City Council cited the "supply and demand" argument at both hearings.
New York City -- like most local, state and Federal government entities -- is governed by civil service rules and the Federal minimum wage law. Most of the city's direct employees also belong to unions. No doubt Ms. Mac Donald thinks that civil service rules or union contracts and the minimum wage are improper restraints of supply and demand in labor markets. Does Mr. Giuliani think so?
 
MIRIAM BENSMAN
New York, Jan. 16, 1996

HEADLINE: Wall Street Looks to Information Revolution

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Clyde Haberman's Jan. 12 column on Wall Street's cynicism toward its maintenance workers is an odd mix of sentiment and outdated impressions.
The downsizing of companies is taking a toll on blue-collar as well as white-collar employees. But it masks the fact that American and international high-tech companies are growing dramatically. 
 A recent meeting of information industry professionals at the new Information Technology Center at 55 Broad Street provided an example of what is happening when more than 1,500 people showed up to sell new products and to see this newly wired building, which is one-third leased after only six months.
Thanks to a major tax incentive program initiated by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and signed into law by Gov. George E. Pataki, the absorption of commercial space downtown has turned positive. Thousands of housing units are also now expected to spur Downtown's emergence as the trendiest new residential neighborhood in the city.
Residential developers have staked their claim to major buildings on Wall and Broad Streets, which are becoming the epicenter of the downtown economy's diversification.
There is no denying the financial industry's loss of jobs since the 1987 stock market crash. But Wall Street is in the midst of a transformation that will place it at the forefront of the information revolution, just as lower Manhattan as a neighborhood will emerge as New York's most exciting area.
 
CARL WEISBROD
Pres., Alliance for Downtown N.Y.
New York, Jan. 12, 1996

HEADLINE: A Flawed Flat Tax and the Way Out

BYLINE: By Patrick J. Buchanan; Patrick J. Buchanan is a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

 BODY:
The flat tax of Steve Forbes seems to have been rooted in the dictum that "what's good for Bohemian Grove is good for America." Indeed, it appears to have been drafted on the back of a menu, after a bibilous evening, with the boys down at the yacht basin.
Under Mr. Forbes's plan, the middle class loses all deductions for home mortgage interest and church contributions; the Federal budget would be thrown scores of billions of dollars deeper into deficit; and lounge lizards in Palm Beach pay a lower tax rate than steelworkers in Youngstown. 
 No wonder the Forbes plan is being toasted from Marin County, Calif., to Hobe Sound, Fla.
Under the Forbes flat tax, should Bill Gates, with a fortune estimated at $12 billion, decide to retire early, he would never again pay a dime in income taxes for the defense of his country. But the men and women who continued to work at Microsoft would have to pay at 17 percent. A tax idea that produces such inequity would be laughed out of Congress -- and not undeservedly.
Once dissected, Mr. Forbes's simplistic version of a flat tax may just bring into terminal ridicule an idea with immense merit and appeal. What should be done with Mr. Forbes's flat tax? It should be taken into the body shop for major overhaul.
First, restore the deductions for mortgage interest and contributions to charities, both of which are rooted in middle class values. Next, exempt from inheritance taxes only estates up to $5 million, covering family farms and family businesses, but keeping some inheritance taxes on the super-rich.
Third, impose "consumption taxes" on the imports of foreign nations that steal our intellectual property and impose tariffs on our goods, or, like Japan, use non-tariff barriers to run up annual $65 billion trade surpluses at our expense. Further, impose an "equalization tax" on the imports of third world countries where wage rates are so far beneath those of the United States that they have become meccas for transnational corporations eager to off-load their American workers on the junk heap of the "global economy," and hire Asians at a tenth the price. Corporations that close factories here, and open them up abroad, should pay a price of re-admission to get their goods back into the United States.
And every dollar of those tariff revenues should be used to cut taxes on American small businesses, which have been hiring the workers who have been riffed and fired in the millions by the corporations that provide the munificent ad revenues for Forbes Magazine.
The problem with the Forbes flat tax is that it is grounded in the idea that the best way to feed the sparrows is to first feed the horses. But we have entered a new world. What is good for General Motors is no longer good for America, if General Motors is shutting down plants in Michigan and Ohio, and opening them up outside Mexico City.
All four Presidents on Mt. Rushmore were economic nationalists. All four believed it was the duty of the national Government to produce policies that led to the economic independence of the United States, the industrial supremacy of the American nation, and the highest standard of living in the world for American workers.
The true measure of economic success is not whether America's gross domestic product is setting records, but whether the standard of living of America's middle class is steadily rising. And today, it is not. The middle class finds itself on a slippery slope, losing its grip on the American dream.
The great disputed province of American politics is this angry, alienated middle class that believes, not without justification, that its Government is run by and for powerful special interests who buy their influence with envelopes of PAC money. They are right. The Republican Party will not win them back with a "flat tax" that says David Rockefeller has paid his last dime into the Treasury of the United States.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Providence, R.I., is getting a $375 million shopping mall after nine years of planning.

BYLINE: By Susan Diesenhouse 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
THE development of a regional shopping mall in downtown Providence, nine years in planning, has moved into the site-preparation phase after final approval from the city.
The $375 million project will have 1.2 million square feet of shopping space designed to link the State Capitol with the municipal offices, shops and restaurants of downtown. The Providence Place Mall, as it will be known, has already received lease commitments for 675,000 square feet of retail space. 
 "This will bring retail back to southeast New England and jobs to Providence -- 3,000 construction jobs and 2,800 permanent jobs," said Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. "This is the linchpin in the downtown redevelopment we started 15 years ago."
Since the 1980's, a 40-acre Capital Center District established by the state has been administered by the Capital Center Commission, a quasi-governmental agency. With the use of Federal highway funds, the agency rechanneled the Woonasquatucket, Moshassuck and Providence Rivers to build a park called Waterplace, which opened in July 1994.
The state has also offered tax incentives and long-term ground leases, which encouraged the construction of two office buildings, an apartment building, a Westin Hotel, a new rail station and a road connecting two highways that run through the city -- I-95 and I-195.
The developer of the mall's 13.2-acre site is the Providence Place Group. Its majority partner, Robert J. Congel, has been a partner in 19 malls developed by the Pyramid Companies of Syracuse. The leasing partner is Peter C. Steingraber, also of Syracuse. The managing partner is J. Daniel Lougash of Dover, Mass., who helped develop malls in the area, and the project director is Richard W. Duggan 3d.
Financing for Providence Place is coming from state, city and private sources. The Fleet Bank will provide a $210 million construction loan, Mr. Lougash said.
Last November, the state agreed to defray the cost of an $80 million, 4,000-car parking garage. It passed legislation that allows the developer to retain two-thirds of the revenues from not more than a total of $5.5 million in state sales tax revenue over the next 15 years to help pay debt service.
The state also passed a law to permit the city to sign a property tax agreement with the developer. The city used the authorization to permit the Providence Place Group to collect property taxes from the mall tenants and use it to offset debt service. To repay the city over 30 years, the developer will eventually turn over about $9 million in mall revenues, Mr. Duggan said.
The Economic Development Corporation, the state agency that owns the land, will sign a 99-year ground lease with the developer. So far, the developer has invested $23 million.
Leases have been signed with three anchor stores. In December 1994, Filene's signed on for 200,000 square feet and Lord & Taylor for 120,000 square feet. Both are units of the May Department Stores Company. In November, Nordstrom signed for 200,000 square feet.
The red-brick mall will have three shopping levels and a nine-floor parking building, with four of the floors below ground. The project was designed by Friedrich St. Florian, a professor of architecture at the Rhode Island School of Design and the architectural firm of ADD Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. The New York firm of Philip Johnson Ritchie & Fiore will manage the architectural consultants and do the construction drawings. The mall is to open for Christmas 1997.
Providence Place will provide a pedestrian bridge to the Westin Hotel that opened early in 1995, have a shuttle bus and a connection to a future rail extension.
"We really need this," one pedestrian said on a recent chilly day. "Providence is a retail ghost town."

HEADLINE: One First Lady to Another

BYLINE: By Blanche Wiesen Cook; Blanche Wiesen Cook, a professor of history at John Jay College, is author of "Eleanor Roosevelt, Volume I."

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Until recently, Eleanor Roosevelt was unrivaled as the most criticized, ridiculed and reviled First Lady. Every speech, every step and every new hairstyle was held up for scrutiny and judgment. Every penny she made was counted and condemned.
No wonder Hillary Rodham Clinton once said she tries to hear Mrs. Roosevelt's voice when she needs advice. 
 Shortly after her 50th birthday, Mrs. Roosevelt experimented with lipstick and a new shade of nail polish. That bit of vanity got the attention of the press. Time magazine ran a picture of Mrs. Roosevelt's new manicure, overshadowing its accompanying story about her visit to homeless sharecroppers in California. It even quoted a migrant woman on her new nails: " 'My, ain't they nice! . . . . She's nice-looking, too -- just as homey as we are.' "
Her political activism, however, was what really made people angry. Mrs. Clinton's cause is, or was, health care. Mrs. Roosevelt's was housing.
In 1934, she championed Arthurdale, an experiment in sustainable community for unemployed families in West Virginia. With friends, she privately financed Arthurdale's school and health clinic and insisted that the new houses have indoor plumbing, root cellars, gardens and livestock. Arthurdale engendered nothing but contempt and was considered a costly failure to everyone but the First Lady and its residents.
Much of her political work was made possible by her paid work. Mrs. Roosevelt was determined to earn what her husband earned as President: $75,000 a year. Through her own writing and radio programs, sponsored by companies like Sweetheart soap, Simmons mattresses and Johns-Manville building materials, she succeeded.
Time magazine wrote: "An indignant citizen once figured that Mrs. Roosevelt got $3,000 for six minutes on the air, [and] said nobody could be worth $500 a minute."
These radio sponsorships confounded even her supporters. She wrote a friend that mail on the subject was divided: half felt she betrayed her principles, besmirched her station and were disappointed; the other half felt she betrayed her principles and besmirched her station, and were glad.
But the criticism did not sway her. "My own income is extremely small and has been cut to about one-third of what it was before the Depression," she wrote. "If I did not do work of some kind much of what I am able to do now would have to be given up."
Odd as it may sound, an activist First Lady had more support in the 1930's. There was an organized movement for better health care, affordable housing and education; reformers were active and appreciated.
In June 1936, during a breakfast in her honor given by the Women's Democratic Committee, Mrs. Roosevelt had words of wisdom for politically active women: "You cannot take anything personally. You cannot bear grudges. . . . You have to take defeat over and over again and pick up and go on. Be sure of your facts. Argue the other side with a friend until you have found the answer to every point which might be brought up against you."

HEADLINE: Pataki Brokers Timber Deal, Pleasing Longtime Foes

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
For the second time in two months, Gov. George E. Pataki has brought together longtime antagonists on an environmental issue and produced a plan that everyone appears to like.
Yesterday, his administration issued a revised permit allowing private landowners in the Adirondack Park to cut down tracts of forest damaged by a freak windstorm that pummeled the Vermont-size park in July. 
 But unlike an earlier version of the permit -- which was assailed by environmentalists in November -- the final "Governor's rewrite," in the words of Timothy J. Burke, an Adirondack environmentalist, should insure that the timber harvest on private lands will not harm adjacent public wilderness.
For 100 years, striking such a balance has been a major challenge for state officials.
The permit has also passed muster with timber and paper companies, as well, which can now begin harvesting trees that had lain for months where they fell.
"You have to give the Governor credit for dealing with this natural disaster pragmatically, and at the same time accommodating legitimate concerns about good forestry and environmental protection," said Robert S. Stegemann, a spokesman for International Paper, a Purchase, N.Y., company that has 305,000 acres of forest in the Adirondacks and is the area's -- and the state's -- largest private landowner. About 3,000 acres of the company's forests were damaged, he said.
Mr. Pataki said yesterday: "This shows that if you work hard to find common ground, you can meld the interests of the private sector and the need to keep the public trust."
Last November, Mr. Pataki's administration helped broker a deal to protect New York City's upstate watersheds that won praise from both environmentalists and upstate officials, who had long opposed regulations they feared might limit economic development.
Debate over logging in the Adirondack Park broke out in the wake of the intense mid-summer storm that toppled millions of trees and killed five people. Landowners appealed to the Adirondack Park Agency to drop normal paperwork requirements and allow the quick salvage of fallen timber before it rotted.
A blanket permit was prepared that would have allowed any landowner who claimed to have suffered damage to at least one of three trees to clearcut an affected tract.
But environmentalists threatened to sue the Park Agency because the permit would have allowed unsupervised cutting on steep slopes and in wetlands. In a park that consists of a complicated mosaic of private and public holdings, they said, erosion and logging-road construction on private land could damage wetlands, streams and forests on public lands.
Two days before the permit was to be issued in November, Mr. Pataki ordered the agency staff to pull it back and make changes that addressed the environmentalists' concerns.
Environmentalists joined with paper and logging companies yesterday in hailing the result. "The Governor has found the middle ground between protecting the critical resources of the park and the legitimate needs of landowners," said Sarah Meyland, executive director of Citizens Campaign for the Environment.
Under the revised permit, state foresters will inspect any proposed salvage site in a wetland, clearcutting will not be allowed on steep slopes and trees must be winched from slopes, not dragged across the forest floor. Also, permanent roads cannot be built in wetlands .
Gregory A. Hill, assistant director of the Park Agency, said the revisions were aided by satellite photographs that have pinpointed areas of heavy and moderate forest damage. With the images, state foresters can corroborate damage reports mailed in by landowners, he said. Despite landowners' fears that the downed timber would rot, he said it appeared that the cold weather and heavy snow have helped preserve it. The Park Agency has estimated that up to 15,000 acres of private forest were damaged badly enough to justify clearcutting, or stripping the land of all trees.
A separate dispute -- over the fate of fallen trees in the park's preserves, deemed "forever wild" under the State Constitution -- is close to being resolved, the Governor said yesterday. Forest ecologists had said the wind damage was part of the natural flow of life in the wilderness, but state firefighters had wanted to clear the timber to minimize the risk of future forest fires.
Governor Pataki said the final result will most likely be limited salvage of preserve timber where the fire risk might threaten nearby communities. "We're inclined to do the minimum consistent with public safety," he said. A final plan will be presented to his office later this week, state environmental officials said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up, Fed by Anticipation Of European Interest-Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against the major currencies yesterday, reaching nearly four-month highs against the German mark and Swiss franc on rising expectations that European interest rates would decline.
Traders said the rally gained momentum after German monetary officials said this week that there might be a need for lower rates in their country. 
 The demand for dollars intensified with the publication of a Swiss newspaper interview with the president of the Swiss central bank, Markus Lusser, who complained of a strong Swiss franc and unsatisfactory economic growth.
By late yesterday in New York, the dollar sold for 1.4638 marks, up from 1.4465 marks on Monday, and 1.1794 Swiss francs, up from 1.1655 Monday. Both dollar rates were the the highest since Sept. 19.
The dollar also gained against the Japanese yen, ending the day at 105.82 yen, up from 105.20 on Monday. It has been slowly rising against the yen for months and has not traded at this level since February 1994.
Traders said the primary motivation for dollar buying stemmed from the view that European economies were weakening and would require lower interest rates to stimulate growth. Lower rates tend to diminish a currency's appeal to investors.
The president of the German central bank, or Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, set the mood for yesterday's trading with remarks late Monday that lower rates might be needed because the growth in the German money supply had been anemic in 1995.
Another prominent German monetary official, Helmut Hesse, president of the regional reserve bank in Bremen state, added to rate-cut speculation yesterday after the German financial news agency VWD quoted him as saying that the Bundesbank might need to trim rates if money growth did not accelerate.
Traders said this strengthened a belief that interest rates would have to come down in Europe before they fell in the United States, where signs of economic sluggishness have also aroused speculation on lower rates.
Other late dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with late Monday, included: 5.0014 French francs, up from 4.9585 francs; 1,577.5 Italian lire, up from 1,574 lire, and 1.3684 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3630. The British pound was quoted at $1.5360, down from $1.5460.

COUNTRY: GERMANY (95%); EUROPE (93%); UNITED STATES (91%); CANADA (79%); JAPAN (79%);
