HEADLINE: Housing Gains as Economic Data Rebound

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The first in an avalanche of statistics on the economy showed today that home building was buoyant in November throughout much of the country. But in the Northeast, building slumped to its lowest pace in nearly two years.
Builders broke ground on new homes at a 1.42 million annual clip in the month, 5.7 percent higher than in October, according to the Commerce Department report, which had been scheduled for Dec. 19. The gain was entirely in multifamily dwellings, and compares with starts in October that were revised downward. 
 The figures did little to clear the fog that has enveloped the economy as the main Government statistical mills shut down for almost five of the last eight weeks because of the budget stalemate and the East Coast snowstorm.
But by this week's end, analysts will have mounds of fresh material to work over as the Labor and Commerce Departments bring out delayed tallies of jobs, foreign trade, sales of new homes, applications for unemployment insurance, export and import prices and an updated estimate of the gross domestic product for the third quarter of 1995.
Friday's report on the G.D.P. will be accompanied by a comprehensive revision of national income and product accounts for 1959 through the second quarter of 1995. In addition, the Federal Reserve, which was affected only by the blizzard, will report on industrial production and on the results of its periodic regional economic survey.
And the Conference Board, which has taken over from the Commerce Department compilation of the leading economic index, is to publish this predictive indicator, delayed from Dec. 29., on Wednesday.
Still, economists said, it will be hard to tell with any confidence whether the economy has slowed just enough to please policy makers and financial markets or whether it has weakened markedly while economic observation was so obscured.
"Even the more timely numbers will have limited information value since they will be distorted by the effects of the shutdown and the weather," James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan, told clients over the weekend.
Eugene J. Sherman, chief economist at M. A. Schapiro, said that despite the lack of evidence, he thought the economy was probably doing O.K.
"I think there's a basic undertone of strength," he said, adding that corporate investment and exports would provide enough support to offset lethargy among consumers.
In fact, he said, reports of a disappointing holiday season may be more a reflection of overbuilding by retailers and greater use of mail and phone shopping than a serious cutback in overall consumer spending.
Today's housing report found that builders started 1,102,000 single-family homes in November, the same pace as October's, while apartment houses and other multiunit buildings jumped by 77,000 at an annual rate.
Starts climbed 14.5 percent in the South, by far the most active region, and 13 percent in the Midwest. But they eased 5.4 percent in the West and tumbled 22.9 percent in the Northeast.
A Commerce Department aide, who said the Northeast's starts were the lowest since January 1994, could cite no reason for the drop.
Permits for new homes, meanwhile, rose 3.2 percent, to a 1,428,000 annual pace.
Joseph Blalock, senior financial economist for America's Community Bankers, a trade group for savings and loans, predicted that home building would decline about 7 percent in 1996, to about 1,275,000 units, with job worries looming larger than the affordability of housing.
Separately, the Commerce Department disclosed that it had managed with weekend overtime to equip workers around the country with the means to conduct its Current Population Survey this week. This, in turn, will allow the Labor Department to issue the employment report for January as originally scheduled, on Feb. 2. Last week, officials said the January employment report would probably be delayed.
The Labor Department confirmed today that the jobs report for December will be issued this Friday and said its reports on producer and consumer prices for last month are scheduled for Jan. 31 and Feb. 1, respectively. The Employment Cost Index, a quarterly tabulation, is now scheduled for Feb. 13.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Yields 6.05% After Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday, supported by a stronger dollar, which makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors; by lower oil prices, and by reports of weak retail sales.
Another upbeat factor among bond traders was the resumption of Government economic reports after the partial Government shutdown, but market participants remained focused on the budget negotiations, which resume today. Analysts note that yields have moved up considerably in recent weeks as hopes for a deal have faded, so if any encouraging news emerges this week, there could be renewed buying. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 1 11/32, to 111 8/32, bringing the yield to 6.05 percent, down from 6.14 percent on Friday (The market was closed Monday for the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.) For investors, it meant that every $1,000 of bonds they owned rose $13.44 in value.
Weak retail reports encouraged the buying of bonds. The Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim chain-store index declined 1 percent for the week that ended Saturday. The report underscored continuing economic weakness and low inflation, forcing some speculators to enter the market and buy to cover their bets that bond prices would decline. The other retail report, the Johnson Redbook, released in the afternoon showed a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent for the first two weeks of January, compared with December levels.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said yesterday's release of two other reports, the November housing starts, which were up 5.7 percent, and building permits, up 2.3 percent, had little impact. "The market yawned after the release of the statistics because the results were both largely expected and not very current," he said.
The statistics scheduled for release today -- the trade balance for October and the index of leading indicators for November (minus three of its components) -- are also outdated, he said, but that will not be the case for the Federal Reserve's "beige book" report on business conditions.
"For the most part," Mr. Fine said, "the beige book is usually a rehash of much of the data seen during three months prior to its release, but this time around there was little data released during that period, and as a result, the beige book looms larger than usual."
Some of the information will be anecdotal, he said, but "it will be the most comprehensive source of overall business activity available, and the market's reaction may well be stronger than normal."
"The second blizzard of 1996," Mr. Fine said, "will occur at precisely 8:30 A.M. Friday morning, when the Labor Department will release December's employment report while at the same time the Commerce Department will release revised, benchmarked G.D.P. statistics on the new chain-weight basis.
"This avalanche of numbers should keep everyone busy, with the employment report, as usual, being the major determinant of future market direction."
The market consensus for the number of jobs added in December is somewhere between 125,000 and 150,000. Mr. Fine's own estimate is more than 150,000.
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago, attributed yesterday's buying in part to George Soros, one of Wall Street's most influential investors, who encouraged Japanese money managers to buy United States Treasury securities yesterday. Bonds initially gained about half a point in overseas trading after Mr. Soros told Japanese managers a resilient dollar and higher interest rates would make Treasuries a good investment this year.
Mr. Hamilton also said that the still-strong European bond markets were also pulling the market higher. "Besides, the market is in a mood that if data show strength, it will ignore it, and if it shows weakness, it will believe it," he said.
At yesterday's regular weekly auction of bills, the three- and six-month bills drew good investor demand at an average discount rate of 5.02 percent and 4.93 percent, respectively. Traders said retail demand was healthy.

HEADLINE: Mayoral Aide Lowers Estimate on Property Tax Revenue

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration's rosy projections of an increase in property tax revenues turned grayer yesterday, increasing New York City's budget gap for the coming fiscal year and raising the likelihood of still deeper cuts in city spending.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, said the administration had overestimated revenues from property taxes -- the city's largest source of revenues -- by $165 million to $180 million for the fiscal year that begins in July. 
 The total taxable value of the city's real estate -- and thus the revenues -- remained relatively stable, although a slight decrease is expected once property owners conclude their challenges to the new assessments. The Mayor's office, however, had projected an increase of 1.62 percent and based its budget assumptions for the coming fiscal year on it.
The new, lower projection compounds the Mayor's difficulties in balancing the city's next budget. The city already faces steadily rising costs and a less than robust economy, coupled with shortfalls in aid from Albany and Washington.
The Mayor's aides have acknowledged a projected gap of $1.4 billion for the next fiscal year; the shortfall in anticipated property tax revenues means the gap has increased to nearly $1.6 billion, or nearly 5 percent of the total budget of $32.8 billion.
But the state's Financial Control Board recently estimated the gap to be at least $1.8 billion, while Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's office has said it could reach $2.3 billion. Neither projection includes the new shortfall in property taxes.
Kurt A. Richwerger, deputy director of the City Council's finance department, said the shortfall in property tax revenues could in fact be as high as $212 million, widening the budget gap still more. "It makes a painful situation even worse -- and more difficult to deal with," Mr. Richwerger said.
Yesterday's announcement underscored the extent of the city's financial woes. In his first two years in office, the Mayor has had to close budget gaps of $2.3 billion and $3.1 billion, mostly by reducing spending on welfare and Medicaid and by cutting spending for city agencies.
By the end of the month, Mr. Giuliani is expected to unveil his preliminary plan for dealing with a third straight budget crunch. Moreover, the city still faces a shortfall in the current fiscal year, which fiscal monitors warn could total $750 million or even more in the city's $32 billion budget.
The Mayor has already ordered the city's agencies to cut $200 million, or 18 percent, of spending on expenses not related to staff salaries. Mr. Giuliani had also planned a refinancing of the city's debt to raise $157 million to plug that hole, but Mr. Hevesi used his powers as the Comptroller to block the plan, saying it would hurt the city's finances in the long run.
Neither the Mayor nor his aides have said exactly how they intend to close the gaps. For the new year, the Mayor has only proposed $500 million in cuts to agencies and $675 million in additional help from the state, though the city appears unlikely to receive that amount given Gov. George E. Pataki's budget proposals.
The report of a drop in property tax revenues came as the city's Department of Finance announced its annual assessments of property values, showing a lingering stagnation in most parts of the real estate market from the downturn of the early 1990's.
In general, property values remained relatively stable, reflecting a bottoming out of the decline in the early 1990's, according to the Mayor's Commissioner of Finance, Alfred C. Cerullo 3d. "There may not be anywhere else for the market to go," he said.
The assessments showed a decline in values for commercial properties, including those for office buildings, signaling a continued stagnation in the real estate market in Manhattan. On the positive side, Mr. Cerullo noted increased values for stores outside of Manhattan and for hotels; he attributed the latter to the city's reduction in the hotel occupancy tax.
The assessed value of co-ops, condos and rentals also declined slightly, while that of one-, two- or three-family homes increased slightly, meaning those homeowners can expect higher tax bills.
The city's property tax revenues last year totaled $7.87 billion, or nearly a quarter of the total revenues. The city had projected an increase in the coming year to $7.99 billion; with Mr. Lhota's revision, those revenues are expected to be $7.81 billion to $7.83 billion.

HEADLINE: Blinder Plans To Leave Post As Fed's No. 2

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Alan S. Blinder has told the White House that he will leave as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve when his term ends in two weeks, Fed officials said yesterday.
Mr. Blinder, who was named to the Fed in June 1994, has been the chief voice within the nation's central bank for lowering interest rates to stimulate the economy. His departure comes at a moment when the economy appears to be weakening. The Fed's control of short-term interest rates gives it powerful leverage to try to stem any such weakness, which could become an issue in this election year. 
 The letter announcing Mr. Blinder's decision, sent to the White House yesterday, ended speculation that President Clinton might try to keep Mr. Blinder in place as the Administration's most influential appointee to the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Blinder, a widely respected academic economist from Princeton University, was Mr. Clinton's first appointee to the Federal Reserve's seven-member board of governors. There was some talk at the time that Mr. Blinder, who served on the White House's Council of Economic Advisers in 1993 and early 1994, would eventually be the President's choice to replace Alan Greenspan as chairman. Mr. Greenspan's current term ends in March.
The Republican Congressional victory in 1994 put an end to White House hopes that Mr. Blinder -- often regarded on Wall Street as too willing to tolerate some inflation to keep the economy growing -- could ever gain Senate approval to replace Mr. Greenspan. Recently, however, Administration officials had considered asking the Republican Senate to approve Mr. Blinder's reappointment as vice chairman as part of a package deal that would give Mr. Greenspan another term as chairman.
Mr. Blinder is expected to announce his departure today. A White House spokeswoman would not comment, saying it was up to Mr. Blinder to make public any announcement that he is leaving the Fed at month's end.
Wall Street, which traditionally prefers strong anti-inflationary policies from the Fed, is expected to be glad to see Mr. Blinder leave. "The constituency for easy money -- low rates -- at the Fed has just lost one of its most outspoken champions," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
In his letter, Mr. Blinder, who is 50, is said to have told Mr. Clinton that he must return to Princeton at the end of this month, when his Federal Reserve term expires. By law, he could have remained as vice chairman until Mr. Clinton appointed and the Senate approved a replacement. But by failing to return to Princeton now, he would risk losing his tenured position as an economics professor.
Mr. Blinder often said that he intended to return to Princeton, from which he has been on leave for three years, all of it spent working in the Clinton Administration. For a while, though, he considered giving up teaching for a career in Washington, an alternative now discarded.
His departure leaves two unfilled seats among the seven Fed governors. John P. LaWare, who had been named by President George Bush, resigned last year, and Mr. Clinton's attempt to appoint Alicia H. Munnell, a Treasury official, as Mr. LaWare's replacement met a storm of protest in Congress. The White House never formally submitted her name, sending Ms. Munnell instead to the Council of Economic Advisers.
That was more than six months ago, and the White House has made no new attempt to fill the Fed vacancy. Now Mr. Clinton will have two positions to fill, though it is not clear whether he can win Senate confirmation this year for any new member in Mr. Blinder's mold.
Within the next few weeks, Mr. Clinton is widely expected to announce the reappointment of Mr. Greenspan, who faces little opposition in Congress, to a third term as the Fed's chairman.
In addition to Mr. Blinder, Mr. Clinton had also placed Janet L. Yellen, an economist on leave from the University of California at Berkeley, on the Fed board. But he has never been able to tilt the balance of power toward his appointees.
If Ms. Munnell had become a Fed governor, three Democrats might have changed the equation, leading to greater pressure for lower interest rates than Mr. Greenspan might have preferred. The remaining governors, including Mr. Greenspan, were appointed by Mr. Bush or President Ronald Reagan, and fell readily in line with the chairman's views of what should be done.
Not that Mr. Blinder was so far apart from Mr. Greenspan. On basic issues, such as how rapidly the economy could expand or how much the unemployment rate could fall without creating shortages that would push up inflation, the two men did not really differ that much. More than anything, when Mr. Blinder argued at Fed policy meetings for lower rates, as he did late last year, or resisted rate increases, as he did in the fall of 1994, he did so because he sometimes saw less danger of inflation than Mr. Greenspan and more risk of recession.
Whatever the differences, they were not so great that Mr. Blinder ever went so far as to vote against Mr. Greenspan in the Fed's policymaking meetings. Such a dissent would have drawn headlines and roiled the bond market.
The Fed last cut rates, by a quarter-point, on Dec. 19. Mr. Blinder's decision to leave means that he will not participate at the Fed's Jan. 30 and 31 policy-making meeting. But with inflation low and the economy showing some signs of weakening, bond traders are betting that the Fed, with or without Mr. Blinder, will lower interest rates another half-point or so in the coming months.

HEADLINE: In Iowa, It's Organizing vs. Advertising

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Presidential politics may have lost its romance, but the Iowa caucuses are still the stuff of legend.
In other states, Presidential hopefuls rely on television advertising to bring supporters out. In Iowa, it is organization that counts the most. 
 Or so the legend goes.
In the last few months, Republican Presidential candidates have been waging the longest, costliest media battle in Iowa caucus history. Instead of starting after New Year's, as they have in the past, some candidates this time began advertising way back in July. And in recent weeks Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate, has by virtue of advertising alone -- he has almost no organization in the state -- managed to fight his way into second place in the polls, behind Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.
By now many political analysts, including even some longtime caucus participants, are questioning whether the Iowa legend can survive another election cycle.
"All the evidence I've seen indicates that Iowa's becoming much more a media event," said Bill Mayer, a professor of political science at Northeastern University who has studied Presidential caucuses. "And if Forbes does really well, it does away with the myth that you need organization in Iowa."
Keith Uhl, a Des Moines lawyer who has worked on several Presidential campaigns, most recently the abortive bid for the Republican nomination by Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, said, "I think it's been gradually changing, and it's truly changed this time."
There are still plenty of people, a good number of them Iowans, who maintain that nothing has changed. Advertising, this group says, can never replace personal contact as the way to pull voters out to the caucuses, which this year are on Feb. 12.
"This is retail politics," said Harlan D. Hockenberg, a Des Moines lawyer who was active in Ronald Reagan's campaigns. "I don't think anything materially has changed about the attitude of the voters or how you reach them."
Many Iowans also note that the flip side of a strong showing by Mr. Forbes that challenges the notion that organization counts would be a weak showing by him that bolsters it. And they argue that the Forbes campaign is more an anomaly than an indication of any trend, because very few candidates have Mr. Forbes's personal wealth.
Since Mr. Forbes is spending his own money and not taking any Federal matching money, he is not subject to the state-by-state spending limits that constrain other candidates' advertising. In Iowa, the spending limit is $1 million. The Forbes campaign has refused to say how much it is spending here, but rival campaigns estimate the figure at close to $2 million.
"Forbes is trying to reinvent the way you win the Iowa caucuses," said Brian Kennedy, chairman of Iowa's Republican Party. "But there's a structural impediment to anybody repeating that. There's just not that many billionaires."
Still, even before Mr. Forbes came on the scene there were indications that the Iowa legend was increasingly being viewed as just that, at least by the Washington-based consultants who tend to run national campaigns.
Advisers to Gov. Pete Wilson of California, for example, said that they, too, had been planning to rely mainly on advertising in Iowa if Mr. Wilson had not dropped out of the race early for lack of cash.
"The Forbes strategy is actually the Wilson strategy with money," one Wilson adviser said.
The reason many Iowans still see organization as pivotal is that the caucuses are high-commitment events. Unlike primaries, where voters come and go at will and register their choices in private, caucuses require an evening to register a preference, and voters must be willing to make their choices known to friends and neighbors.
Those Iowans who maintain that organization is crucial often cite the 1988 caucuses as proof. The surprise of the Republican caucuses that year was the unexpectedly strong showing by Pat Robertson, which was attributed almost entirely to his vigorous grass-roots support among Christian conservatives. But there was also another lesson to be drawn from the 1988 caucuses, and that is the lesson many in Washington seem to remember.
For years leading up to the caucuses, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, had been running a conventional Iowa campaign, visiting all of the state's 99 counties and even installing his wife in the state full time. Yet he appeared to be going nowhere -- until his television advertising campaign went on the air.
"The exit poll showed that the Gephardt campaign personally contacted more Iowa caucus-goers than any other campaign," said Bill Carrick, a Democratic consultant who worked on the Gephardt campaign. "At the same time, I don't think we could have won without the media lift.
"There's no question paid media has become more important each cycle in Iowa."
In 1992, there was virtually no contest in Iowa because one of the state's Senators, Tom Harkin, was running for the Democratic nomination and the other candidates conceded the state to him.
This time around, advertising in Iowa began with unprecedentedly early purchases of television time during the summer by two Republicans, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee and Morry Taylor, a wealthy businessman.
Hugh Winebrenner, dean of the College of Business and Public Administration at Drake University and an expert on the Iowa primaries, was so struck by the amount of advertising this year that he decided to see how it compared with previous election cycles. Since there are no central records of how much money candidates spent on advertising in the state, he looked at the books of one Iowa television station, WHO, the Des Moines NBC affiliate.
In 1988, he found, candidates for both the Democratic and Republican nominations spent a total of $189,000 at WHO, all of it after Jan. 1. This time, candidates for the Republican nomination had spent $281,000 just through the end of December. And the Iowa Democratic Party had spent $64,000 on advertisements touting President Clinton's budget.
Even accounting for inflation, Mr. Winebrenner said, "there is much more television money being spent." He quickly added that he did not think advertising alone could overcome organizational deficiencies.
"If you look at this historically, no candidate has ever done well in Iowa without an organization," he said.
According to many neutral observers, Mr. Dole has the most formidable organization in Iowa, followed by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas.
By far the most innovative attempt to build an organization has been Mr. Taylor's. Recently, he sent questionnaires to 100,000 Iowa Republicans offering those who sent the form back a chance to win $5,000. Five lucky winners are to be chosen on Feb. 5; the rest can simply look forward to calls from his campaign.
Mr. Forbes, too, has been trying to build an organization here through direct mail and professional phone banks. According to his organization director, Chip Carter, he now has coordinators in about a quarter of Iowa's counties.
Mr. Winebrenner said that because of Mr. Forbes's limited organization, he was skeptical that the publisher would come in second in Iowa, despite recent polls suggesting that he will.
But if Mr. Forbes does end up in second, Mr. Winebrenner acknowledged, "then all of us who have been at this for the last 15 years will have to rethink what we're doing."

HEADLINE: Fourth-Quarter Results Cap Off the Best Year Ever for the Nation's Big Banks

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The nation's biggest banks capped off their best year ever -- reporting sharply higher operating profits yesterday for the fourth quarter -- as nearly everything went right. Revenue from loans and fees rose faster than costs, while the levels of bad loans continued to be relatively low.
This year, the banks' fortunes may be weakened somewhat, analysts said, by falling interest rates, which will depress profit margins on loans, and by increased losses on loans to consumers. 
 The big New York money center banks -- Citicorp, the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation -- beat analysts' expectations. Profits were up at big regional banks, including Nationsbank, First Chicago NBD and Banc One, but these banks earned less than analysts expected, largely because loan losses increased.
"The money centers are doing very well because the credit picture is better than people expected," said Ronald I. Mandle, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
The biggest worry for bank stock investors remains the rise in bad loans to consumers, especially through credit cards. Citicorp, the nation's largest credit card issuer, said losses increased slightly, to 3.77 percent of receivables from 3.70 percent in the third quarter. Losses were similarly modest at Chemical and Chase. But at First Chicago, credit card losses increased to 4.5 percent in the fourth quarter from 4 percent in the third quarter.
"Credit cards will be a bigger problem for regional banks than money centers because the regionals have been growing quickly but don't have the experience," said David S. Berry, research director at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. "Next year the regionals will benefit from lower deposit insurance premiums, but it will be hard for them to maintain momentum in revenue."
Falling interest rates will hurt the banks, Mr. Berry said, because they cannot lower the interest paid on deposits as fast as they will have to cut rates on loans. Loan losses, he predicted, will also increase. The money center banks, with more international operations, will be hurt less by lower rates, he said.
Accordingly, share prices of the New York banks outpaced regional bank stocks yesterday. Citicorp rose 7.5 percent; Chemical, 7.1 percent; Chase, 6.8 percent; Banc One, 4.2 percent; First Chicago NBD, 4.6 percent, and Nationsbank, 0.6 percent.
In its final quarter as the biggest bank in the country -- because of the pending Chemical-Chase merger -- Citicorp beat analysts' expectations of earning $1.65 a share in the fourth quarter, reporting $905 million, or $1.89 a share. Citicorp's profits declined by 13 percent from a year earlier because it had used up tax breaks accumulated from its real estate losses in the early 1990's.
Before taxes, Citicorp's earnings rose 17 percent, to $1.44 billion from $1.23 billion.
Citicorp's decision to favor business with consumers, rather than corporations, was evident in the quarter. Its consumer profits rose 18 percent, to $544 million, led by the activities in the United States and Europe. Profits from corporate banking and trading fell by 9 percent, to $382 million.
Citicorp also said that it had increased its quarterly per-share dividend to 45 cents from 30 cents, restoring it to a level higher than in 1990, the peak before it started to cut back to preserve capital to cover bad real estate loans.
Now flush with capital and averse to making acquisitions, Citicorp is using its profits for dividends and to buy back its stock. The company said yesterday that six months into a two-year program to buy back $3 billion in stock, it had bought $1.5 billion worth. As a result, the program was increased to $4.5 billion.
Since other United States banks will continue to make acquisitions, John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, told analysts yesterday that Citicorp's relative position would continue to fall.
"We assume that in the foreseeable future we will end up as No. 4, 5 or 6 in terms of size," he said. Mr. Reed defended Citicorp's strategy, contending that the emphasis on international consumer banking, for which the bank has little competition, will earn a higher stock market value than if it made acquisitions in the crowded regional banking or investment banking businesses.
Chemical earned $490 million in the quarter, up 170 percent from a year earlier, but the earlier quarter included a $152 million charge to pay for cost-cutting initiatives. Chemical's operating earnings were up 48 percent for the quarter. And the earnings of $1.81 a share were well above the $1.61 analysts expected.
Chemical reported a gain of $25 million in the fourth quarter from the sale of half of its 40 percent stake in the CIT Group to Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and the sale of its southern New Jersey branches to PNC Bank.
For its last independent quarter, Chase said its profit rose 48 percent, to $340 million, or $1.70 a share; analysts expected $1.41. The bank earned $137 million from its consumer businesses and $158 million from corporate business and trading. Other items, mainly its real estate portfolio, earned $45 million.
"The Chase-Chemical deal is billed as a merger of equals, but most of us see it as an acquisition of Chase by Chemical," Mr. Berry of Keefe, Bruyette said. "So we could have expected that people at Chase would be more interested in circulating their resumes than doing business, but they worked hard," he said.
Chase's cost-cutting campaign eliminated 4,415 positions during 1995. A total of 12,000 jobs will be eliminated in the merger, which is expected to lead to a $925 million after-tax saving. Chemical announced yesterday that it was closing its municipal-bond operation in a cost-cutting move associated with the merger that would eliminate about 50 jobs in municipal underwriting, trading and investment banking. On a combined basis, the two banks earned $3.0 billion in 1995, up from $2.5 billion in 1994.
Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., the country's fourth-biggest bank, said its fourth-quarter earnings rose 26 percent, to $510 million. But it disappointed analysts, earning $1.87 a share, compared with the $1.92 predicted. The bank was hurt by a 58 percent increase in charge-offs of bad loans. Consumer loan charge-offs increased by 25 percent. And the bank used some of its profits to charge off $43 million in bad commercial and real estate loans.
Over all, First Chicago NBD, the combination of two Midwest banks that merged last December, said its earnings fell 60 percent, to $126 million, in the fourth quarter after taking $192 million in charges for merger costs and securities losses.
First Chicago's profit, before the merger charge, increased by 1 percent, to $318 million.
First Chicago's fourth-quarter earnings of 96 cents a share, before the merger charges, were less than the $1 estimated by analysts. First Chicago, now the country's seventh-largest bank, set aside $210 million for future credit losses, more than double the $96 million loss provision of its predecessor banks a year ago.
Profits at Banc One, the ninth-biggest bank, increased fourfold, to $337 million, because it took a charge of $220 million a year earlier to cover losses from investments and the cost of job cuts. Operating income increased 32 percent. Its profit of 85 cents a share matched analysts' expectations, even as its loan-loss provision shot up to $165.9 million from $35.6 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Aide to Rep. Maloney Wins A Special Council Election

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
A. Gifford Miller, a top aide to Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, won a special election last night for the City Council seat representing the Upper East Side and Roosevelt Island.
Mr. Miller, a Democrat, defeated Judith G. Marcus, a Republican and an aide to Charles Millard, who left the Council in December to become president of the Economic Development Corporation in the Giuliani administration. 
 The 26-year-old Mr. Miller is the youngest person ever elected to the Council.
Although the City Charter forbids candidates from running under the names of established parties, the two candidates were assisted by the strong support of their respective parties. Mr. Miller's election will increase the Democratic majority to 45 of the Council's 51 members.
"This is an indication of the revival of the Democratic Party on the East Side and across the city," Mr. Miller said last night. "People are concerned, and they feel that a Democratic agenda is vital to this city on issues like health care, mass transit and public education."
According to unofficial results from the Board of Elections, Mr. Miller received 6,098 votes, or 57 percent, with Ms. Marcus receiving 4,661 votes, or 43 percent.
The election in the Fifth Council District had been closely watched in part because of its echoes of the East Side Congressional race in 1994, in which Mr. Millard, a Republican, failed in a bid to unseat Ms. Maloney, a Democrat.
Mr. Miller was assisted by a battery of Democratic officials who campaigned on his behalf. They included Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, Public Advocate Mark J. Green and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. He was also aided by telephone bank campaigning conducted by District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the city's largest municipal employees' union.
For her part, Ms. Marcus, 51, had the help of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who gave her an enthusiastic endorsement and sent a letter to registered voters in the East Side district in which he is also a resident. She was also assisted by the East Side Republican organization headed by State Senator Roy M. Goodman.
Throughout the 45-day campaign, Mr. Miller sought to paint his opponent as an ideological soul mate of House Speaker Newt Gingrich. In a district with a large number of elderly residents, he repeatedly argued that Ms. Marcus, who switched from being a Democrat to a Republican two years ago, had joined the party responsible for cuts to growth in Medicaid and Medicare spending.
The Upper East Side, the home of many of the city's wealthiest residents, is nicknamed the Silk Stocking District. While registered Democrats account for more than half the registered voters in the area, Republicans have had several successes in recent years, although they represent only a fifth of the registered voters.
Mr. Miller is expected to be sworn in at a City Council meeting tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Yale Student Strike Points To Decline in Tenured Jobs

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The restructuring of the American work force has come to campus, and at Yale University it is fueling a bitter labor dispute over the making of one of the nation's most arcane products: Ph.D.'s.
Facing bleak job prospects when they complete their doctoral study, some Yale graduate students are trying to form a union to improve their lot during their six or more years of research and apprentice teaching here. 
 Threatened by Yale with losing their teaching jobs, the students decided on Sunday to end a strike in which they had withheld grades from courses they had taught last semester. But the battle is focusing new attention on why universities are producing so many Ph.D.'s when financial pressures are prompting them to hire fewer for permanent tenured positions.
Supporters of the Yale students say the answer is obvious: graduate teaching assistants are cheap labor for universities, especially public ones, which rely on them much more than Ivy League institutions like Yale do. An average teaching assistant at Yale is paid $4,970 a semester; a full professor, $90,000 a year.
The idea that the students are serving apprenticeships is delusory, these critics say, because jobs are not waiting for them at the end; increasingly, new Ph.D.'s, particularly those in the humanities and social sciences, join a permanent pool of cheap labor that universities hire as part-time adjuncts in place of full-time professors. And since the job market turned down with the recession in 1989, the number of humanities doctorates awarded annually has increased 20.7 percent, according to the National Center for Educational Statistics.
"The changes in the job market are changing apprenticeship into exploitation," said Prof. Cary Nelson of the University of Illinois at Urbana. Professor Nelson, who teaches liberal arts and writes often about the economic quandary of graduate students, said that as long as universities can not do without graduate teaching assistants, they should at least pay them a living wage.
Yale counters that it cares about both the prospects of its students and their well-being during their years in New Haven. But graduate students are just that, not employees, Yale insists, and the university will never recognize a union for them.
"It's not that there's no problem here with graduate education," Richard C. Levin, president of Yale, said. "Graduate students have some legitimate concerns, and we're prepared to address them through reasoned conversation -- which is different from their idea of negotiation for a written, binding agreement.
In many ways, Yale might seem an unlikely campus for a union struggle by graduate students. Nearly all of them study tuition-free within some of the nation's most prestigious academic departments. Stipends cover most of their living expenses. Teaching loads are relatively light. Of the 11 graduate-student unions that have been recognized, all are at public universities, including Rutgers, the University of Wisconsin and several campuses of the University of California.
"They really are among the blessed of the earth," Prof. Peter Brooks, chairman of the department of comparative literature, said. "So I sometimes feel annoyed at them seeing themselves as exploited." Nevertheless, he said, his students' concerns over employment and financial aid were just.
It is unclear how many of the 1,200 graduate students in the humanities and social-science divisions support the union. In an unofficial vote, 600 of 766 students polled said they wanted it to represent them.
But the sense of graduate students as exploited, with little hope of a tenured reward later, has met with more than sympathy from a union already on campus, the Federation of University Employees, an affiliate of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees International Union. Increasingly, blue-collar unions in search of white-collar workers to organize are financing campaigns for graduate-student unions; in California, for example, the unions are supported by the United Auto Workers.
And as universities trim departments and substitute cheaper part-time labor for full professors, the industrial union model is finding an audience among students who see ivory towers acting more like corporate headquarters.
"I was shocked to find all kinds of people who got Ph.D.'s from Yale taking adjunct positions while they look for a tenure-track job," said Gordon Lafer, who turned down a tenure-track job after taking his Ph.D. in political science from Yale last spring. Instead, he became research director for the Federation of University Employees, which represents 3,800 blue-collar and clerical workers at Yale and supports the graduate-student group.
"The universities are at a critical point," he said. "Either everyone is going to continue to be driven down to the lowest common denominator -- and right now everyone is so desperate they are willing to underbid each other -- or we're going to find a way to pull up the bottom of the market by organizing teaching assistants or organizing adjuncts."
The nightmare of graduate students is to become academic nomads, commuting among campuses, paid by the course.
As that group grows, its members will be trapped in their lower status, while the nature of university teaching itself changes, said Robin Brown, a fifth-year graduate student in comparative literature who is president of the Yale group, the Graduate Employees and Students Organization.
"It's very hard for me to conceive of being an adjunct for the next 40 years," she said.
Statistics on part-time faculty are sketchy, though some estimates put the proportion at 40 percent of all people teaching college courses. What is clear is that the collapse of the job market and the end of mandatory retirement at age 70 delayed thousands of expected openings, and the number of new Ph.D.'s grew.
In 1993, for example, 4,481 Ph.D.'s were awarded in the humanities, compared with 3,500 in 1987, according to the National Center for Educational Statistics.
Since 1992 Yale has reduced its graduate admissions in humanities and social-science departments by as much as a third. (Its science departments, by contrast, are growing, and graduate students there, with more generous stipends provided by research grants, have shown no interest in a union.)
The reduction in admissions has allowed Yale to spread $55.5 million in financial aid among fewer students, said Thomas Appelquist, the graduate dean. And only $5.5 million of that, he said, is paid to students for teaching. Through their first five years, they are expected to teach in only the third and fourth years.
While students want stipends raised to cover full living expenses, so they can devote summers to research instead of working, Mr. Appelquist said Yale's aid was competitive with other leading research universities.
"We provide enormous amounts of financial aid, but it should not be expected, and it was never promised, that we will cover all costs," he said. Of $30,000 a year in tuition and expenses, he said, Yale gives the typical student $26,000 to $27,000.
Yale has hired nontenured lecturers and adjuncts mainly to teach basic foreign-language courses, he said. Students, he said, are the primary instructors for about 9 percent of the enrollment in Yale College, little changed over the last decade.
Supporters of the graduate students acknowledge that many of their complaints will strike the public as whining unless the institution's quality declines by use of the students in place of professors.

HEADLINE: Citing Security, China Will Curb Foreign Financial News Agencies

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Citing national security, China's Government announced on Tuesday night that it would further restrict the flow of information into the nation by more closely regulating international agencies that supply financial news to China.
International wire agencies selling economic information in China -- namely Reuters and Dow Jones -- will now be "supervised" by the official New China News Agency for the content of their reports as well as the subscriptions they sell to Chinese customers. 
 While the full ramifications of the decision may not be clear for days or weeks, it appears to have been prompted by concern among Chinese leaders about growing access to information from abroad, both from international news agencies and from the Internet, although the Internet is not yet used widely in China. At the very least, the decision seems intended to intimidate foreign news organizations.
"Foreign economic information providers will be punished in accordance with the law if their released information to Chinese users contains anything forbidden by Chinese laws and regulations, or slanders or jeopardizes the national interests of China," said the announcement, as reported by the news agency itself. It described the decision as having been issued by China's Cabinet in the form of a circular.
In addition to the Government's desire to limit information it deems unwelcome, however, a driving force in the decision was apparently the New China News Agency's desire both for hands-on control over information networks and, perhaps even more, the right to charge fees to users and sellers of information.
An American news media executive in Beijing said the Chinese news agency has been "trying to do this for months."
"I can't believe the Government finally went along with it," the executive said. "It's this current climate of paranoia that allowed it to happen."
If the New China News Agency stands to gain, Chinese banks and securities firms that trade currencies, commodities, stocks and bonds may suffer badly, if their access to market information is blocked or slowed.
Although the announcement did not spell out how the New China News Agency intends to vet all the market information, company news and analysis that are available from news organizations each day, it implied that adding a new layer of "supervision" may involve delays.
Of the many issues left fuzzy and uncertain by the announcement, perhaps the largest is whether the news agency will actually try to vet all the market news that Reuters and Dow Jones report each day. Although both news services are oriented toward financial news, they also include political coverage that reaches subscribers.
Access to international news in China has grown steadily in recent years as the fax machine and international travel became common, but there remain strict controls on what can be broadcast or printed within China. Reuters quoted an unidentified Chinese official early today as saying that the new restrictions would not mean a slowdown in up-to-the-minute financial news, and would not constitute censorship.
On Tuesday, executives at Dow Jones and Reuters expressed great surprise at the announcement, in part because it runs counter to a steady trend of allowing more financial information to be available, and allowing agencies to sell freely to Chinese institutions.
"The open flow of economic information is good for China," said James McGregor, who is both chief representative for Dow Jones in Beijing and president of the American Chamber of Commerce. "Abundant information makes markets stable."
A Reuters executive in Hong Kong read from a prepared statement, saying: "On the face of it, this has extremely serious implications for Reuters, as well as for many other organizations active in China."
In recent years, Reuters and Dow Jones have each won thousands of customers among China's banks and securities firms that use up-to-the-minute market information to trade on international and domestic capital markets. Neither company will say exactly how much it earns in China, but one executive said it was in the tens of millions of dollars each.
The financial information business boomed along with China's securities markets in 1993 and 1994, but has fallen since then, in part because a series of scandals led to tighter Government regulation. Bloomberg, a supplier of financial information in much of the world, has just begun to enter China.
"This certainly runs counter to the grand objective of making Shanghai an international financial center," John Pinkel, chief representative of H. G. Asia, a Hong Kong-based securities firm, said on Tuesday. He also questioned whether the official news agency's monopoly on financial information would allow its staff to use it to their advantage.
Other Western executives questioned whether members of China's Cabinet fully understood how damaging their decision could be.
Nor does the decision bode well for Hong Kong, the vibrant financial and trading center over which China will resume control on July 1, 1997.
"I am afraid this latest move will only send the signal that Chinese leaders still do not understand how the freedom of information underpins economic success," Martin C. M. Lee, leader of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, told Reuters.
The announcement did not specify when supervision would begin, but said that foreign wire services already in China would have to apply to the news agency within three months for permission to continue.
Although the announcement was couched in political terms, saying the overall aim was to "safeguard state sovereignty," much of it was concerned with controlling the business side of news distribution. It specifies, for example, that international wire services will no longer be able to sell services directly to customers, and must determine subscription rates together with the New China News Agency.
Part of the reason may be that the agency, which retains considerable political clout, has watched its revenue fall in recent years because of its heavy reliance on Government funding. In contrast, state-run television stations and newspapers that sell their own advertising during a booming economy are doing far better.
Yet another issue raised by the announcement is how badly it might affect China's bid to enter the World Trade Organization. Although Chinese leaders are determined to join, they have been blocked so far because efforts to open their economy have only gone partway.
In the long run, even if China's leaders somehow succeed in limiting information that is available from financial news organizations, it is hard to imagine how they could prevent freer communication via the Internet. Though the Internet craze has not hit China yet, when it does, it will be far harder to control.
"It's a lot easier to control a commercial service, because they're trying to keep track of you so they can charge you," Esther Dyson, chairman of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, an independent group in New York, said on Tuesday. "They can't control the Internet any more than they can control what people say in their own homes."
Chinese leaders are still grappling with how to control information over the Internet. Last week, one media executive said, all of China's Internet providers were called to a meeting with Government officials, who lectured them on the dangers of pornography on the Internet.
"They're well aware of the Internet, and they're scared," said Ms. Dyson. "In the long run, there's nothing they can do about it."

HEADLINE: Senator Cohen, G.O.P. Centrist, Plans to Retire

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The corps of Senate moderates dwindled further today with the unexpected announcement by Senator William S. Cohen of Maine that he would not run for a fourth term this year.
The retirement of Senator Cohen, the Republican who made his mark in national politics as an anguished House newcomer voting to impeach President Richard M. Nixon, is the 13th this election year, a Senate record for disenchantment with incumbency. 
 "The recent budget stalemate in Washington over the past several weeks has been instrumental in crystallizing this for me," Mr. Cohen told a gathering of constituents. He said he needed "new challenges" after 24 years in Congress and would seek a role in improving the nation's international trade.
With his announcement at City Hall in Bangor, Me., where the 55-year-old Senator began in politics a generation ago as a Councilor-Mayor, Mr. Cohen broke the Senate retirement record of 1896, a watershed year for American political change that followed the national depression of 1893. By his own account, the polarizing political mood on Capitol Hill was a significant factor in his choice to leave.
He described a sudden change of mind over the New Year holiday when he visited Malaysia, where he has succeeded in establishing commercial links for Maine companies in recent years.
"I had planned on running and had no real opposition at home to speak of," Senator Cohen said in a telephone interview.
But on the trip, he said, he pondered his future along with a mixture of factors. They included the larger implications of the budget standoff for the realignment of politics, as well as the economic need and personal satisfaction he found in creating job opportunities rooted in the global economy.
"The whole budget debate has been necessary and has framed the issues," he said, adding that for him, the greater satisfaction seemed to lie in helping shape global economic ties. "I mulled it over and decided after a quarter of a century in Congress that I'm still young and I want to engage in the international field in an intense way."
that I'm still young and I want to engage in the international field in an intense way."
Mr. Cohen said that in politics he sensed an uncertain, "evolutionary" period of realignment between liberal and conservative forces.
"Right now, the center is more or less disappearing," he said, speaking of voters facing the question of whether they prefer a one-party-dominated government or greater compromise from the antagonists in the present alignment.
Among the many Maine voters shocked at the Senator's announcement was his mother, Clara, whom he said he called last weekend and told, "I've decided I want to do something else." The influential factors in his decision, the Senator said in the interview, included his intended marriage to Janet Langhart, a television journalist.
Senator Cohen, a leader of the slender, dwindling group of Republican moderates, has written novels and poetry. He once wrote of a fictitious senator: "Politics is a life of artifice. You become, through press releases and self-promotion, a figment of the public's imagination."
His real standing, as a moderate bridge between the parties, is such that speculation began immediately about his becoming a Republican Vice-Presidential contender, or a Cabinet member in the next Administration, whether Republican or Democratic. But he said his decision was entirely rooted in personal, not political, factors.
The Senator warned that the current budget stalemate between the Republican Congress and President Clinton was a crucial test of whether the nation returned to "the virtues of self-discipline and fiscal prudence."
"It is a moral imperative that we stop engaging in flagrant consumption and then hand over a $5 trillion debt to our children with little more than a slap on the back and an expression of 'good luck,' " he said.
Of the 33 senators up for re-election, 5 Republicans and 8 Democrats have announced their retirement. Several moderates are among them.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said that with Mr. Cohen's departure, the President was "concerned that the center in American politics not lose the capacity to govern."
Kevin Mattson, executive director of the Maine Democratic Party, said Senator Cohen's announcement turned state politics on its head. "Nobody is ready to take that seat," Mr. Mattson said.
Christian P. Potholm, professor of government and legal studies at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., who is the Senator's close friend and was the campaign manager in his first Congressional race, in 1972, noted that Mr. Cohen had a popularity rating of more than 70 percent and no significant challenger or successor in sight.
"He's been very wistful about turning 55 and looking to the future," Professor Potholm said, adding that the "disappearance of civil discourse" in the Senate was another factor Mr. Cohen had cited. "It's unbelievable the way people are rushing around up here today thinking, 'Hey, I can be U.S. Senator!' " Professor Potholm said in describing the frenzy touched off by the announcement.
As a freshman representative, Mr. Cohen was catapulted into the spotlight as a member of the House Judiciary Committee, agonizing on national television over the Watergate scandal even as he carefully questioned witnesses. He was the only Republican who voted to request the White House tape recordings that incriminated Mr. Nixon.
Mr. Cohen ultimately voted for impeachment. "The most difficult decision of my life," he said.
In 1986, Senator Cohen, as a member of the Intelligence Committee, challenged another Republican President, Ronald Reagan, in the Iran-contra affair involving arms sales to Iran and the diversion of some of the money to Nicaraguan rebels. He pressed for full disclosure, asserting that the Administration "in effect took foreign policy underground."
Senator Cohen took comfort in that record as an independent. He said he had few regrets, including the fact that "there was a limit to what level I could achieve" as a moderate in a Republican Party increasingly dominated by conservatives.
"That's been a very liberating thing for me," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Biggest Banks Report Their Best Year Ever
Profits soared at the nation's biggest banks for the fourth quarter, capping off their best year ever. Revenue grew for loans and fees, and bad loans remained relatively low. But in 1996, analysts said, the banks' fortunes may fade somewhat, because of falling interest rates and increased losses on consumer loans.
Citicorp, Chemical and Chase all beat analyst expectations. Profits did not meet forecasts at big regionals, like Nationsbank, First Chicago and Banc One, though their profits rose, nonetheless. [Page D3.]
 
Stocks Surge in Late Trading
After seesawing, stocks climbed in late trading, after a rally in the bond market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 44.44 points, to 5,088.22, after being down almost 25 points earlier. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities jumped, supported by a stronger dollar, lower oil prices and weak retail sales. The long bond's yield fell to 6.05 percent from 6.14 percent. [D18.]
 
2,000 More Jobs Lost at AT&T
AT&T dismissed about 2,000 employees, just weeks after the company accepted voluntary departures by thousands of others. The workers are victims of the company's plans to cut its worldwide work force by 48,500. One man who lost his job said, "I've had to downsize people myself, and now it's happening to me." [B5.]
 
Housing Activity Rose in November
Builders broke ground on new homes at a faster pace in November, according to the first report in a deluge of pent-up Government data. But in the Northeast, building slumped. [D2.]
 
Orange County Case May Settle
The S.E.C. is close to settling charges against two former top officials of Orange County, Calif., stemming from its bankruptcy. [D3.]
 
Economic Liberal Leaves Yeltsin
Boris N. Yeltsin accepted the resignation of Anatoly Chubais, a pillar of economic reform and the last liberal left in Russia's increasingly hard-line Cabinet. [A1.]
 
China to Restrict News Agencies
China plans to curb the inflow of information further by closely regulating news agencies like Reuters and Dow Jones. [A1.]
 
A Changeover at Cosmopolitan
Helen Gurley Brown, left, will step down as editor of the magazine she made into a legend, Cosmopolitan, which she had led for more than three decades. Hearst said she would leave in 18 months, after working with her designated successor, Bonnie Fuller, the founding editor of the U.S. edition of Marie Claire, who was named deputy editor of Cosmopolitan. [D7.]
 
Airplane Makers End Talks
McDonnell Douglas and Boeing broke off talks, at least for now, about a possible merger or combination of some businesses, people with knowledge of the talks said. [D3.]
 
Court Deadlocks in Software Case
The Supreme Court deadlocked on what was expected to be an important copyright case, leaving Lotus Development without copyright protection for the menus and commands in its spreadsheet program. [D2.]
 
The Court refused to hear a case challenging an exclusive patent on the leading AIDS medication. [A14.]
 
For the Frequent Flier, a Computer
Portable computers are popular, and the best customers seem to be executives, who relish them on trips. Business Travel. [D5.]

HEADLINE: At the Nation's Table: Terlingua, Tex.;
Dinner Out, In the Desert

BYLINE: By ANNE S. LEWIS 

 BODY:
In remote Terlingua, Tex., in the mountainous Chihuahuan desert near the Mexican border, where basic amenities like indoor plumbing are not taken lightly, dinner matters. That's why "What's tonight's special?" usually refers to the Starlight Theater among the mix of locals, Rio Grande rafters and the on-location film crews who frequent this restaurant that was once a movie theater.
Five years ago, Angie Dean, then an eight-year resident of Terlingua, and Rob Dean, then her husband and partner, rehabilitated the dilapidated and roofless Chisos Theater, an adobe relic of this ghost town's heyday as a cinnabar mining town in the 1920's and 30's. 
 The renamed Starlight Theater, one of only a handful of restaurants in the area, seats up to 100 diners, who can order drinks at the mesquite-wood bar -- with cow skulls hanging from the ceiling -- and dance to live music.
A kitchen crew of two turns out fresh, reasonably priced nightly specials, ranging from shrimp Mexicano and chicken in green-chili cream sauce to a cilantro-spiked tortilla soup; beef features heavily in the regular menu. Dinner ranges from $3.50 to $16.25. Dessert is an assortment of pies ($3.50 a slice).
Ms. Dean welcomes the seasonal swell of tourists from Big Bend National Park and movie people during the temperate winter and early spring months, and she tries to accommodate their varying tastes. "When the Californians are here on film shoots, I'll add more greens, salads and fish to the menu because they're not all that fond of the Texas diet," she explained.
Ms. Dean, who is now the sole owner of the restaurant, stays attuned to the needs of her regulars -- gray-haired men with weathered faces and ponytails and names like Fish and Black George, the local postal and park employees, and river guides. Her restaurant is closed for only one day a year -- for a local school event -- because, she said, "these people have to eat." And she always serves an economical ($2.50) but filling bowl of pinto beans and tortillas for those short on cash.
Starlight Theater is at 2 Ivey Lane, Terlingua, Tex. 79852; (915) 371-2326. Open seven days from 5 P.M. to midnight (1 A.M. on Saturday). Dinner is served until 9. ANNE S. LEWIS

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angie Dean outside her restaurant, the Starlight Theater, in Terlingua, Tex., where people take dinner seriously. (Anne S. Lewis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 700 Jobs, Some From Jersey, Moving to Lower Manhattan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a modest sign that New York City's effort to revitalize lower Manhattan is bearing fruit, the New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it would move 700 employees to a building in the shadow of the World Trade Center. In doing so, the company will receive $6.5 million in tax incentives.
Most of the 700 employees now work at the company's headquarters at 26th Street and Madison Avenue, but 125 will be moved from New Jersey. The decision is a coup for the city's efforts to retain insurance jobs, since companies like New York Life have long been a major source of white-collar employment. 
 The company said it had leased four floors of the building, at Broadway and Liberty Street, for the new headquarters of Nylcare Inc., a newly formed subsidiary that combines its group health care businesses.
Although New York Life executives had been negotiating for space in the lower Manhattan building for almost a year, they said yesterday that they had waited to sign a lease until the city's revitalization incentives, first announced by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in December 1994, were approved by the State Legislature, which passed them in October.
Under the program, open to any company that moves to a lower Manhattan building constructed before 1973, it will receive incentives worth $3 million in its commercial occupancy tax, real estate tax and electric bills. It negotiated $3.5 million more in so-called discretionary tax breaks from the city.
Mayor Giuliani said yesterday that the deal reinforced "our message to the world, which is that New York is a business-friendly town."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Utility Seeks Shift on Rates

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's biggest utility company asked state regulators yesterday to change the way its rates are set, anticipating the day when consumers -- especially big ones -- can pick their power supplier. 
 Under one part of the plan presented by Public Service Electric and Gas Company, electric rates would drop when the state Board of Public Utilities approved. The company said the cut would translate into $1.30 a month on a $100 bill, or $50 million a year. Both gas and electric rates would be frozen until the end of the year; after that, the company said, it would base its rate requests on a formula involving the national inflation rate and "uncontrollable" costs of things like environmental cleanups.

 BODY:

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Gain Despite Budget Block

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of fresh economic data and on-again, off-again budget negotiations, prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, especially in the long maturities.
The price of the 30-year bond gained 22/32 of a percentage point, to 111 30/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 6.01 percent, from 6.05 percent on Tuesday. 
 Included in the economic statistics released yesterday were the trade balance numbers for October, leading indicators and the Federal Reserve's so-called beige book of business activity as reported by the 12 regional Fed banks. The Fed report showed the economy growing at a slow pace and almost inflation free.
Analysts say the beige report is forward looking and therefore may carry more influence than usual at this month's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee because of the partial shutdown that delayed the release of economic indicators from the Commerce and Labor Departments, meaning those reports are unusually lagging. The meeting will take place on Jan. 30 and 31, about six weeks after the last meeting, when the committee lowered the Federal funds rate for overnight bank loans by a quarter of a percentage point.
Leading indicators for November posted their third consecutive monthly decline, as the index dropped by three-tenths of 1 percent, though the components were incomplete. The Federal shutdown delayed the release of the new orders, contracts and orders, and unfilled orders data, excluding these components from the November index.
Economists said an announcement by the Fed that the vice chairman, Alan Blinder, would step down and return to the academic sector had little impact on the market, since few thought it would change anything very much at the Fed.
However, the market did sag when it learned that the Republicans had canceled yesterday's scheduled budget talks, then recouped when Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, indicated that he and Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, did talk with the President on the phone and that the talks were "frank and useful."
Louis G. Brien, an analyst with Rand Financial Services in Chicago, sees the budget stalemate as bullish, not bearish, for bonds. He believes that once a deal is struck, regardless of whether it favors Republican or Democratic policies, it will not actually reduce the deficit for a couple of years. "The stalemate, which has been perceived as such a bond market negative, might be bullish," he said.
Both sides in the negotiations, Mr. Brien said, are on the record that a Government shutdown is not in the cards. "This should remove any worry of default," he said.
"And if Newt Gingrich is correct and there is not a resolution until November, it means all funding will be stopgap," he continued. "All funding will have to come through the Republican House of Representative. This could create a de facto budget cut this year, not 1998. The house can than be counted on to fund the bare minimums. This may be restrictive on the economy."
Other dips in the session came on the release of the October trade deficit, which caused shorter maturities to drop. The deficit, which was reported at $8.04 billion, compared with a downwardly revised $8.25 billion for September, raised the likelihood that the nation's gross domestic product may be better than expected.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said: "I think the market is saying that despite the fact we have not had Government economic numbers in a while, the economy is weakening as evidenced by the anecdotal numbers leading up to the latest batch of data. Market participants hope that will spur another easing by the Fed.
"The dollar is solid and is drawing foreign investors into the U.S. financial markets. Equities are in a pivotal phase over the short term, as there may be more concerns about corporate profits. But over the longer term the lower interest rate environment should generate increased economic activity and raise corporate profits, thereby boosting equities."
Doug Burtnick, a fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said, "It only took two weeks for domestic investors to completely shrug off the idea that there are a lot of risks for the long end of the bond market if a balanced budget agreement isn't reached soon."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Mark and Pound On Signs of European Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied to move higher against most other leading currencies yesterday after overcoming a brief but sharp selloff on word that the Federal budget talks in Washington had broken down.
Traders attributed the dollar's resilience to expectations of lower European interest rates that undermined the German mark, weak British economic statistics that hurt the pound, and a narrower United States trade deficit that suggested the dollar has room to strengthen further. 
 "There's a lot more negative economic data coming out of Europe and Japan," said Elena Shperling, chief currency dealer at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia. "By comparison in the United States, we're looking pretty good."
In late trading yesterday in New York, the dollar bought 1.4715 marks, up from 1.4638 on Tuesday. It also rallied against other European currencies, notably the British pound, which fell to $1.5205, from $1.5360 on Tuesday. The dollar has not been that strong against the pound since May 1994.
The dollar ended slightly lower yesterday against the Japanese yen, to 105.42 yen from 105.82 yen on Tuesday. But yen dealers said the underlying demand for dollars remained strong.
The dollar and Amerian securities markets faltered in the early afternoon when Republican Congressional leaders scrapped planned budget talks with President Clinton. But the weakness wore off as buyers stepped in. "Within 10 minutes, it was as though nothing had ever happened," Christopher Low, an economist at HSBC Securities in New York, said.
An early catalyst for dollar demand came from the German central bank, which allowed an important short-term interest rate to decline yesterday. That bolstered speculation the central bank would take broader steps to reduce rates at its regular meeting today.
The dollar also derived strength from a big selloff in the pound, spurred by the release of data showing the British Government's deficit and the national unemployment rate have not shrunk as much as expected.
The dollar was further helped by a Commerce Department report that the American trade deficit shrank in October to the smallest imbalance in nearly a year.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.1890 Swiss francs, up from 1.1794; 5.0273 French francs, up from 5.0014, and 1,584.75 Italian lire, up from 1,577.50.

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Sees 'Modest Pace' of Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The economy was growing at a "generally modest pace" at the turn of the year, a Federal Reserve survey showed today, but an index intended to predict turning points in the economy suggested an increased possibility of a downturn this year.
The Fed's periodic pulse-taking of business conditions in all 12 of its regions found a mixture of disappointing holiday sales, uneven factory activity and subdued inflation. 
 It also found some rebound in commercial real estate and continuing shortages in various areas of the labor market.
The anecdotal findings were over all a bit less buoyant than in the preceding report, which mainly covered November. But analysts took comfort in the fact that the economy had not slumped since mid-December -- during the period when the Government shutdown idled the keeping of statistics by the Labor and Commerce Departments.
The Fed's beige book signifies that growth has slowed from its annual pace of 4.2 percent in the third quarter, said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank in Pittsburgh. But he added that "the economy is still advancing" and would most likely continue to do so even though the predictive index, now compiled by the Conference Board, a business research group in New York, seems to be flashing "a yellow light."
The board reported today that the index of leading indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the second straight decline and seventh of 1995. At 100.4, the index has retreated to the lowest point since December 1993.
Indeed, only a small upward revision that lifted the September result to no change prevented a third straight decline in the index, a string sometimes taken as a signal of impending recession.
But analysts were unusually reluctant to draw such a conclusion since three components accounting for 20 percent of the index were not yet available and the declines have not been particularly severe or widespread among index components.
Nor was the Conference Board able, because of missing figures, to publish companion indexes of coincident and lagging indicators that themselves can be used to forecast.
Nonetheless, the persistent weakness of the leading index is somewhat unsettling, analysts said, and would not go unnoticed by the Federal Reserve policy makers as they meet at month's end to set an economic course that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, will lay out before Congress next month.
The Fed's deliberations "may be particularly intense," Joel L. Naroff, chief economist for the First Union National Bank in Philadelphia, said today.
Another somber note was struck by the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, which reported that its quarterly poll of 3,000 American businesses found them "expecting significantly slower growth in sales, profits and employment levels during the first quarter of 1996."
Executives throughout industry said optimism for first-quarter sales was at a three-year low, while the outlook for profits was the lowest since the fourth quarter of 1993, the company said. Still, "this weak expectation of growth is not an indication that a recession is likely in the near future," said Joseph W. Duncan, Dun & Bradstreet's chief economist.
Four of the eight available components in the leading index were negative, the Conference Board's report showed. The biggest effect by far was a decline in prices of materials especially sensitive to the business cycle. Lesser factors were faster deliveries by suppliers, higher first-time claims for unemployment insurance and lower consumer expectations.
Pushing up the index were modest increases in stock prices, building permits and the money supply. The eighth item, the length of the factory work week, was unchanged.
With the latest report, the Conference Board took over the main responsibility for putting together the index, though it still relies on the Commerce Department for some data, and that was incomplete.
The Fed's survey, prepared this time by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, was based on information collected through Jan. 7 and thus did not include any effects of the East Coast snowstorms.
"Holiday sales were generally reported to be below expectations, with extensive discounting," the survey said in its summary. "Manufacturers saw uneven growth, with weakness noted in auto-related production. The Federal Government shutdown hurt winter tourism at national parks, but other areas reported increased activity.
"Single-family home sales are experiencing some seasonal slowing in most of the country. However, commercial real estate contacts in many areas report strengthened markets. Loan demand is steady in most areas. Firms say that prices are generally remaining stable, but some areas still report shortages of skilled workers."

Chart: "Leading Indicators: Component Analysis" lists components of the index of leading economic indicators and their net weighted contribution to the index's change from October to November. (Source: The Conference Board)
