HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Republican Leaders Call Off Budget Talks With Clinton
Republican Congressional leaders abruptly called off the budget talks scheduled at the White House and said they would not resume them until President Clinton produced a budget proposal that moved in their direction.
The move, which followed a 40-minute phone conversation with the President, left Congress and the Administration stalemated over how to balance the Federal budget, yet reluctant to declare the impasse intractable. [Page A1.]
 
Fed Cites Modest Economic Growth; Indicators Point to a Slowdown
The economy was growing at a "generally modest pace" at the turn of the year, a Federal Reserve survey showed, with commercial real estate rebounding and holiday sales weak. But the Index of Leading Indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in November, suggesting a downturn is likely this year. [D4.]
 
The nation's trade deficit fell to $8.04 billion in October, the lowest level in 10 months and the fourth straight monthly decline. [D4.]
 
Sales Lagging for Windows 95
Microsoft, five months after introducing Windows 95 in the computer industry's biggest consumer-marketing blitz ever, has found sales of the operating system lagging far below last summer's rosy projections. [A1.]
 
Wal-Mart's Shares Tumble
Wal-Mart Stores stock slid $2.125, or 9.4 percent, to $20.375, on the Big Board, after the company, the nation's largest retailer, warned that it would report lower quarterly earnings for the first time in more than 25 years as a public business. Wal-Mart predicted earnings of 40 to 42 cents a share, down from 45 cents a year earlier and less than analysts' forecasts of 47 cents a share. [D5.]
 
Paine Webber to Settle With S.E.C.
Paine Webber was said to have agreed in principle with the S.E.C. to pay $25 million to $50 million to settle charges that it misled investors in the sale of risky limited partnerships during the 1980's. [D4.]
 
Dow Slides as Nasdaq Edges Up
The stock market zigzagged, moving up in response to the economic news but sliding after the budget talks were called off. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 21.32 points, to close at 5,066.90, but the Nasdaq composite index edged up 2.43 points, to 998.30. [D10.]
 
Airline stocks rallied after AMR, the parent of American Airlines, posted a 78.4 percent rise in operating profits. Its own shares gained 25 cents, despite a net loss of $281 million after $372 million of charges. [D2.]
 
For Wolf, a Challenge at USAir
Investors applauded USAir's selection of Stephen M. Wolf, the former UAL chief executive, as chairman, bidding USAir's shares up $1.875, to $14.50. But analysts warn that he faces the challenge of his career. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Liquor Resales Investigated
A reputed Ponzi-like scheme, run by a New York lawyer, that offered returns of 60 percent in a liquor resale business is being investigated by the S.E.C. and the Manhattan District Attorney's office. [D5.]
 
Steaming Noodles For Times Square
Lehman Brothers, owner of One Times Square, famed for its New Year's Eve ball-dropping extravaganza, wants advertisers that fit that gaudy legacy. Its newest promotion is a steaming, 60-foot-high, red neon advertisement, for Nissin Cup Noodles. Advertising. [D8.]
 
Tobacco Class Action Is Assigned
A giant class-action lawsuit against the nation's largest tobacco companies has been assigned to Judge Helen Ginger Berrigan, a nonsmoking former criminal defense lawyer, journalist and head of the American Civil Liberties Union of Louisiana. [D6.]

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
D.H. Complicates Interleague Play

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17

 BODY:
With club owners on the verge of approving regular-season games matching teams in the American League against teams in the National, the issue of the designated hitter threatened today to undermine the revolutionary concept before it can be implemented.
The owners plan to vote on interleague play, something that has never existed in Major League Baseball except for the World Series, at their joint meeting Thursday. The ruling executive council voted unanimously Tuesday night to recommend its adoption on an experimental basis for the 1997 season, and the owners discussed the plan at their separate league meetings today. 
 But even if the owners vote for the plan, which they are expected to do with perhaps only minor opposition, they would have to negotiate it with the Players Association. By itself, interleague play most likely would not present any problems for the union. But the status of the designated hitter would be another matter.
In a possible scenario suggested today by comments from people on the two sides of the labor fence, the union could propose, as a way of creating the same rules in both leagues, adding the designated hitter to the National League instead of eliminating it from the American League, and the N.L. owners could opt to scuttle interleague play instead of adopting the d.h.
Under the plan presented to the owners for interleague play, teams in one league would match up with teams in the same division in the other league. Teams in the five-team East and Central Divisions would play three games with each of their counterparts in the other league for a total of 15. This would allow, for example, the Yankees and the Mets to meet three times, as well as the White Sox and the Cubs.
Teams in the four-team West Divisions would play four games with each other for a total of 16. The 162-game schedule would be maintained, with a team playing 11 or 12 games with the other teams in its league.
"I'm sure the players will be sensitive to what the fans want in terms of interleague play," Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said by telephone from New York. He also said the union would discuss with the owners the elimination of the designated hitter if they propose it.
But noting there would be "enormous complications" in taking that step, Orza then said: "It never comes up in the context of instituting the d.h. in the National League. If the elimination of the d.h. is proposed toward alleviating a problem, it's equally eliminated by not eliminating the d.h. but doubling it. It's interesting that that side of the case is never raised. Why is the elimination of the d.h. the proposed solution rather than the expansion of the d.h. the proposed solution?"
But some National League owners and executives quickly rejected that notion when it was presented to them.
"I'd be less interested in interleague play if we had to keep the d.h.," said Peter Magowan, owner of the San Francisco Giants, who favors interleague play. Asked if the d.h. could be a make-or-break issue, he said, "I think so."
Larry Lucchino, president of the San Diego Padres, who previously served the Baltimore Orioles in that capacity, said he would like to see interleague play on the limited basis that has been discussed but not if the plan would mean the d.h. in the National League.
"We wouldn't be inclined to accept that compromise, just speaking for the Padres," he said. "I'm not sure the National League adopting the d.h. is a compromise. That's a major change."
Few on the management side would acknowledge it, but the desire to eliminate the designated hitter is more an economic issue than one of the sanctity of the nine-man lineup. By adopting wild-card playoff teams and their intention to adopt interleague play, owners have expressed their contempt for traditionalist thinking in baseball in light of their need to generate additional revenue.
The designated hitter has been used in the American League since 1973, and those who serve in the role are generally veteran, productive players who are among the highest-paid in the game. Last season, the average salary for 10 regular designated hitters was $3,458,573, second in the American League only to the average pay for first basemen of $3,570,603. The previous two seasons the average d.h. salary was the highest in the league.
Among last season's regular designated hitters were Edgar Martinez, Eddie Murray, Paul Molitor, Juan Gonzalez, Jose Canseco and Chili Davis.
The working plan for the 1997 season, said Drayton McLane, the Houston Astros' owner and chairman of the strategic planning committee, is to follow the system that is used in the World Series: The d.h. is in the lineup for American League home games but not for National League home games.
Many people in baseball find that system a poor compromise because it creates two sets of rules for the World Series, and it penalizes the A.L. teams because they use the d.h. all season, then cannot use him for the most important series of the year, while being forced to use pitchers who often have not batted for years.
Marge Schott, owner of the Cincinnati Reds, said she doesn't like the d.h., but she said she wasn't sure she liked interleague play either.
"I think we're making a lot of changes too fast," she said. "We should give some more thought to what's good for the fans and everything. I think people were very confused in the playoffs. Who's playing who and what's what? I was confused by that. I guess tradition is what I think baseball is all about. I think you have to be very careful on this type of thing."
Pat Gillick, the senior general manager in the major leagues, said it would "make more sense" to add the d.h. to the National League but offered two reasons why it probably wouldn't happen: money and N.L. stubbornness.

HEADLINE: When AIDS Patients Confront the Managed-Care System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Managed care companies and other health insurers have incentives to provide a lesser quality of care to chronically ill patients (front page, Jan. 15). If a managed care company were to provide superior care to its sickest patients, it would be flooded with such patients during the next enrollment period, raising its costs relative to competitors'. 
 Countries like Israel and the Netherlands provide reimbursement subsidies to managed care plans that enroll a greater number of elderly in their case mix and are devising methods to provide additional reimbursement to plans that enroll a greater number of the chronically ill. The United States should follow their lead.
 
WARREN GREENBERG
Prof. of Health Economics
George Washington University
Washington, Jan. 15, 1996

HEADLINE: Gramm Adds Voice to Calls In the G.O.P. for Flat Tax

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Formally joining the Republican chorus calling for a flat tax, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas today proposed taxing income at 16 percent, edging a rival Presidential candidate, Steve Forbes, by one percentage point.
While Mr. Forbes would tax only earned income at 17 percent, Mr. Gramm said he would tax investment income as well. Unlike Mr. Forbes, Senator Gramm would preserve deductions for mortgage interest and for donations to charities. 
 The proposal was included in what Mr. Gramm called "an eight-year program to change America, to bring back the American dream and to share that dream with people who missed it the first time around."
The program, which he outlined in a speech to the Cato Institute, a conservative research organization, brought together many ideas that Mr. Gramm, a former economics professor, has proposed before. He has been offering them piecemeal in Iowa and New Hampshire as he has scrambled to elbow aside Mr. Forbes and establish himself as the most credible challenger to Senator Bob Dole, the clear front-runner in the two states and nationally. Mr. Dole has said he might support a flat tax but has yet to propose his own plan.
Today, Mr. Gramm projected numerous, specific benefits from his economic plan. He said that by the end of the eighth year of a Gramm administration, his plan would expand the number of jobs nationally to 142 million from 125 million; would raise average income for a family of four to $57,500 from $45,000, in 1994 dollars, and would move 9.7 million people out of poverty.
In a recent interview, Mr. Gramm denied that he was advocating a flat tax to horn in on what has proved a potent issue for Mr. Forbes. "I was for a flat tax, a variant of it, in 1976," he said, when he taught economics at Texas A&M. Asked if he would be raising the idea now if Mr. Forbes had not, he said, "I didn't even know Forbes in 1976."
But Mr. Forbes took credit for the idea today, saying in a prepared statement: "I'm delighted that Senator Gramm has finally seen the light on the flat tax, even if it's an election-year conversion. I hope his conversion is more than poll deep."
Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator who is seeking the Republican nomination, has proposed a version of a flat tax, and other candidates have discussed the idea. A commission headed by Jack F. Kemp today supported one without specifying a rate.
Like Mr. Forbes, Mr. Gramm would not tax inheritance. But in other respects, the two tax plans differ significantly, in part because Mr. Gramm would tax unearned income, like capital gains. Mr. Forbes, a multimillionaire, has been attacked by his rivals for proposing a plan that would enable wealthy investors to escape tax on a large part of their income.
"I reject the idea that income derived from labor should be taxed, and that income derived from capital should not be taxed," Mr. Gramm said. He called Mr. Forbes's approach "totally unfair, totally indefensible" and argued that it would distort investment.
Mr. Gramm posed the example of a father who sends one child to Stanford to become a doctor, while giving the other an equal amount of money to invest. Why, he asked, should the first child pay taxes on income, while the second does not?
In his statement, Mr. Forbes said: "Although Senator Gramm doesn't understand it, one of the virtues of a flat tax is that all income is taxed at its source, including investment income. Investment income is effectively taxed at the corporate level, not the personal level." In other words, Mr. Forbes would tax corporate profits only when the company earns the money, not again when it pays it out to stockholders in the form of dividends.
For a family of four, Mr. Gramm's rate of 16 percent would apply on income over $32,000, an amount he said could rise to $40,000 over eight years. For the same family, Mr. Forbes's 17 percent tax would start on income over $36,000.
Mr. Gramm said that his plan could cause a shortfall in Federal revenue of about $40 billion in its first year but that spending cuts would take care of the gap.
Critics of flat-tax proposals have argued that they could raise taxes for some middle-income families. But Mr. Gramm said his plan was "structured to try to guarantee that no middle class American will pay more taxes than they do now."
Mr. Gramm also said his program would balance the budget in four years and then enact a "spending pause" over the following four years to limit the Government's growth to the rate of inflation. He also called for a one-year moratorium on Federal regulations, beginning in 1997, except in cases of imminent danger to human health and safety.
And Mr. Gramm defended his support of free-trade agreements. "If there's anything we've learned in American history, it is that trade produces prosperity and opportunity," Mr. Gramm said. "Trade won the cold war."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 19, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A headline yesterday about one Republican Presidential candidate's proposal for a flat tax misspelled his surname in some editions. He is Senator Phil Gramm, not Graham.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Gain Despite Budget Block

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of fresh economic data and on-again, off-again budget negotiations, prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, especially in the long maturities.
The price of the 30-year bond gained 22/32 of a percentage point, to 111 30/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 6.01 percent, from 6.05 percent on Tuesday. 
 Included in the economic statistics released yesterday were the trade balance numbers for October, leading indicators and the Federal Reserve's so-called beige book of business activity as reported by the 12 regional Fed banks. The Fed report showed the economy growing at a slow pace and almost inflation free.
Analysts say the beige report is forward looking and therefore may carry more influence than usual at this month's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee because of the partial shutdown that delayed the release of economic indicators from the Commerce and Labor Departments, meaning those reports are unusually lagging. The meeting will take place on Jan. 30 and 31, about six weeks after the last meeting, when the committee lowered the Federal funds rate for overnight bank loans by a quarter of a percentage point.
Leading indicators for November posted their third consecutive monthly decline, as the index dropped by three-tenths of 1 percent, though the components were incomplete. The Federal shutdown delayed the release of the new orders, contracts and orders, and unfilled orders data, excluding these components from the November index.
Economists said an announcement by the Fed that the vice chairman, Alan Blinder, would step down and return to the academic sector had little impact on the market, since few thought it would change anything very much at the Fed.
However, the market did sag when it learned that the Republicans had canceled yesterday's scheduled budget talks, then recouped when Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, indicated that he and Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, did talk with the President on the phone and that the talks were "frank and useful."
Louis G. Brien, an analyst with Rand Financial Services in Chicago, sees the budget stalemate as bullish, not bearish, for bonds. He believes that once a deal is struck, regardless of whether it favors Republican or Democratic policies, it will not actually reduce the deficit for a couple of years. "The stalemate, which has been perceived as such a bond market negative, might be bullish," he said.
Both sides in the negotiations, Mr. Brien said, are on the record that a Government shutdown is not in the cards. "This should remove any worry of default," he said.
"And if Newt Gingrich is correct and there is not a resolution until November, it means all funding will be stopgap," he continued. "All funding will have to come through the Republican House of Representative. This could create a de facto budget cut this year, not 1998. The house can than be counted on to fund the bare minimums. This may be restrictive on the economy."
Other dips in the session came on the release of the October trade deficit, which caused shorter maturities to drop. The deficit, which was reported at $8.04 billion, compared with a downwardly revised $8.25 billion for September, raised the likelihood that the nation's gross domestic product may be better than expected.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said: "I think the market is saying that despite the fact we have not had Government economic numbers in a while, the economy is weakening as evidenced by the anecdotal numbers leading up to the latest batch of data. Market participants hope that will spur another easing by the Fed.
"The dollar is solid and is drawing foreign investors into the U.S. financial markets. Equities are in a pivotal phase over the short term, as there may be more concerns about corporate profits. But over the longer term the lower interest rate environment should generate increased economic activity and raise corporate profits, thereby boosting equities."
Doug Burtnick, a fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said, "It only took two weeks for domestic investors to completely shrug off the idea that there are a lot of risks for the long end of the bond market if a balanced budget agreement isn't reached soon."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Mark and Pound On Signs of European Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rallied to move higher against most other leading currencies yesterday after overcoming a brief but sharp selloff on word that the Federal budget talks in Washington had broken down.
Traders attributed the dollar's resilience to expectations of lower European interest rates that undermined the German mark, weak British economic statistics that hurt the pound, and a narrower United States trade deficit that suggested the dollar has room to strengthen further. 
 "There's a lot more negative economic data coming out of Europe and Japan," said Elena Shperling, chief currency dealer at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia. "By comparison in the United States, we're looking pretty good."
In late trading yesterday in New York, the dollar bought 1.4715 marks, up from 1.4638 on Tuesday. It also rallied against other European currencies, notably the British pound, which fell to $1.5205, from $1.5360 on Tuesday. The dollar has not been that strong against the pound since May 1994.
The dollar ended slightly lower yesterday against the Japanese yen, to 105.42 yen from 105.82 yen on Tuesday. But yen dealers said the underlying demand for dollars remained strong.
The dollar and Amerian securities markets faltered in the early afternoon when Republican Congressional leaders scrapped planned budget talks with President Clinton. But the weakness wore off as buyers stepped in. "Within 10 minutes, it was as though nothing had ever happened," Christopher Low, an economist at HSBC Securities in New York, said.
An early catalyst for dollar demand came from the German central bank, which allowed an important short-term interest rate to decline yesterday. That bolstered speculation the central bank would take broader steps to reduce rates at its regular meeting today.
The dollar also derived strength from a big selloff in the pound, spurred by the release of data showing the British Government's deficit and the national unemployment rate have not shrunk as much as expected.
The dollar was further helped by a Commerce Department report that the American trade deficit shrank in October to the smallest imbalance in nearly a year.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.1890 Swiss francs, up from 1.1794; 5.0273 French francs, up from 5.0014, and 1,584.75 Italian lire, up from 1,577.50.

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Sees 'Modest Pace' of Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The economy was growing at a "generally modest pace" at the turn of the year, a Federal Reserve survey showed today, but an index intended to predict turning points in the economy suggested an increased possibility of a downturn this year.
The Fed's periodic pulse-taking of business conditions in all 12 of its regions found a mixture of disappointing holiday sales, uneven factory activity and subdued inflation. 
 It also found some rebound in commercial real estate and continuing shortages in various areas of the labor market.
The anecdotal findings were over all a bit less buoyant than in the preceding report, which mainly covered November. But analysts took comfort in the fact that the economy had not slumped since mid-December -- during the period when the Government shutdown idled the keeping of statistics by the Labor and Commerce Departments.
The Fed's beige book signifies that growth has slowed from its annual pace of 4.2 percent in the third quarter, said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank in Pittsburgh. But he added that "the economy is still advancing" and would most likely continue to do so even though the predictive index, now compiled by the Conference Board, a business research group in New York, seems to be flashing "a yellow light."
The board reported today that the index of leading indicators fell three-tenths of 1 percent in November, the second straight decline and seventh of 1995. At 100.4, the index has retreated to the lowest point since December 1993.
Indeed, only a small upward revision that lifted the September result to no change prevented a third straight decline in the index, a string sometimes taken as a signal of impending recession.
But analysts were unusually reluctant to draw such a conclusion since three components accounting for 20 percent of the index were not yet available and the declines have not been particularly severe or widespread among index components.
Nor was the Conference Board able, because of missing figures, to publish companion indexes of coincident and lagging indicators that themselves can be used to forecast.
Nonetheless, the persistent weakness of the leading index is somewhat unsettling, analysts said, and would not go unnoticed by the Federal Reserve policy makers as they meet at month's end to set an economic course that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, will lay out before Congress next month.
The Fed's deliberations "may be particularly intense," Joel L. Naroff, chief economist for the First Union National Bank in Philadelphia, said today.
Another somber note was struck by the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, which reported that its quarterly poll of 3,000 American businesses found them "expecting significantly slower growth in sales, profits and employment levels during the first quarter of 1996."
Executives throughout industry said optimism for first-quarter sales was at a three-year low, while the outlook for profits was the lowest since the fourth quarter of 1993, the company said. Still, "this weak expectation of growth is not an indication that a recession is likely in the near future," said Joseph W. Duncan, Dun & Bradstreet's chief economist.
Four of the eight available components in the leading index were negative, the Conference Board's report showed. The biggest effect by far was a decline in prices of materials especially sensitive to the business cycle. Lesser factors were faster deliveries by suppliers, higher first-time claims for unemployment insurance and lower consumer expectations.
Pushing up the index were modest increases in stock prices, building permits and the money supply. The eighth item, the length of the factory work week, was unchanged.
With the latest report, the Conference Board took over the main responsibility for putting together the index, though it still relies on the Commerce Department for some data, and that was incomplete.
The Fed's survey, prepared this time by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, was based on information collected through Jan. 7 and thus did not include any effects of the East Coast snowstorms.
"Holiday sales were generally reported to be below expectations, with extensive discounting," the survey said in its summary. "Manufacturers saw uneven growth, with weakness noted in auto-related production. The Federal Government shutdown hurt winter tourism at national parks, but other areas reported increased activity.
"Single-family home sales are experiencing some seasonal slowing in most of the country. However, commercial real estate contacts in many areas report strengthened markets. Loan demand is steady in most areas. Firms say that prices are generally remaining stable, but some areas still report shortages of skilled workers."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Economic Weakness Stirs Gloom in Europe

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Grim economic reports that include soaring unemployment, bigger budget deficits and lower economic growth, have many in Europe wondering, for the first time in more than two years, whether the Continent is once again heading toward a recession.
Ominous news from Germany, considered the engine of European economic growth, has sent economists back to their forecasting models over the last week to lower their growth figures. 
 The sharpness of the European slowdown, which has emerged over the last two months, has taken economists and government officials by surprise. The last recession was a steep one, and the last two years' recovery has been only moderate, doing relatively little to cut into Europe's high unemployment.
Though no major forecaster is openly predicting a recession yet, economists say that much of Europe is in a spell of no growth or even shrinkage that could persist well into the year.
Some are beginning to label the European economic phenomenon a "growth recession."
"We don't see the classic signs of a recession, but the point for 1996 is that growth will be so low that it is going to feel like a recession to a lot of people," said Richard Reid, chief economist at the Frankfurt office of the Union Bank of Switzerland.
The slowdown comes as the United States economy also appears to be weakening, and it could cut the profits of American multinationals.
The gloom has sent politicians across Europe scurrying to come up with proposals to generate jobs and growth. And they seem to be bending over backward to rebut assertions that only a month after national leaders finally mustered the political will to give a name to the new single currency, the Euro, their economic plans are no longer on track.
"The gloom over the past week has been wildly exaggerated," a senior official of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government said, adding that "we will meet the Maastricht criteria, without a doubt." He referred the treaty on European union that sets the terms for adoption of a single currency and central bank.
Skeptics say that plans to introduce the first stage of a single currency in 1999 are highly unrealistic because the low growth will so increase budget deficits that countries will not meet the standards required by the treaty for participation in a single currency. "Maastricht no longer exists," said Jacques Calvet, chairman of the French auto maker Peugeot, an outspoken critic of the single-currency plan. "Maastricht is obsolete. Maastricht is dead."
Even Germany last week, the paragon in Europe of budgetary restraint, conceded that its deficit had jumped to 3.6 percent of the gross domestic product, well above the 3 percent limit required by the Maastricht terms. But Finance Minister Theo Waigel promised to have the budget under control by next year.
Economists including Mr. Reid say that in Germany, the third and fourth quarters of 1995 registered no growth at best. They predict that the economy is likely to remain limp through the first half of this year.
The economy of France, Europe's second largest, is essentially not growing, either, and those of Belgium and the Netherlands are slowing considerably. Even in Italy and Spain, where economic output in 1995 was among the strongest in Europe, it is markedly slowing.
Britain appears to be the exception. Its gross domestic product is predicted to remain at the level of 1995 -- about 2.5 percent after inflation -- and may even grow a little faster this year. The Government announced in London today that the number of unemployed fell in December by about 10,000.
But for the rest of Europe, the anemic economic activity will be helpless in combating what almost everyone agrees is the big problem -- 17.5 million unemployed, an average rate of 10.6 percent.
"Not only will growth not be enough to reduce unemployment, it will be so low that unemployment will continue to go up," said Armin Sorg, senior director for economic policy at Siemens A.G. in Munich.
Since Germany accounts for almost 30 percent of the European economy, its performance gets the closest scrutiny, and the slowdown here has generated deep pessimism.
Much of the slowdown has been attributed to the high exchange rate of the German currency. Businesses are struggling with a mark that many say is 25 percent overvalued against the dollar. This has raised the cost of exports and generated losses at companies dependent on export earnings.
Beyond that, German factory wages are the highest in the world and the labor laws, rigid. Mr. Sorg of Siemens argued that an engineer in Germany works three months a year less than one in the United States. And because of union opposition to weekend work, he said, factories have the shortest running times in Europe. As in France and the Netherlands, a worker, once hired, is difficult to let go, so in uncertain times, companies do not hire.
All this has helped create a struggling economy. Normally, a government might consider an antidote of big tax cuts and higher public spending. But the restrictions of a single currency mean that Bonn would have to either raise taxes or cut spending to meet the budget targets, and neither of those avenues is attractive to the Kohl Government. This leaves the task of economic revival to the Bundesbank.
Economists say the central bank is the one institution that has substantial power to pull Germany and Europe out of a slowdown, by lowering interest rates. Today, the Bundesbank lowered the securities-repurchase, or repo, rate -- the one at which it does most of its lending to banks, to 3.65 percent from 3.73 percent. The German discount rate stands at 3 percent, near an all-time low, and economists predict that it will be cut further.
In a television interview on Tuesday night, the Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, said he saw room for further cuts in interest rates. Lower rates in Germany mean that central banks across Europe can lower their rates, over the long run generating employment and economic activity.
"These lower interest rates have enormous potential in getting Europe out of its hole," said Steven Englander, international economist at Smith Barney in Paris. "It's not going to happen overnight. But optimism will start to rebound in the second half of this year."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Reverse Their Slide As Prospects Fade for Iraqi Sale

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices climbed yesterday as doubts emerged about whether Iraq would be allowed to sell oil for humanitarian purposes.
Natural gas prices also surged on expectations of colder-than-normal weather in the Northeast and a snowstorm in the Midwest, key gas-heating regions. 
 Traders spent most of the session trying to decipher Iraq's intentions, said John Saucer, an oil analyst at Smith Barney Inc. in Houston. Prices fell on Tuesday after Iraq surprised investors by announcing it would seek talks with the United Nations on oil sales despite a longstanding embargo that came with its invasion of Kuwait.
Mr. Saucer said traders now believed Iraq would not be allowed to increase production because it was becoming clear that it was insisting that there be no preconditions from the United Nations on how it spent its oil revenue.
On other commodity markets, copper futures prices dropped to 15-month lows. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 1.23 points, to 240.21.
Crude oil for February delivery rose 47 cents, to $18.52 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. February heating oil rose 0.70 cent, to 53.13 cents a gallon, and February unleaded gasoline rose 1.65 cents, to 54.98 cents a gallon.
Crude oil futures prices fell to the lowest level since Nov. 22 on Tuesday after the Iraqi announcement. Traders were reassured yesterday after United Nations officials indicated terms of the deal would remain the same and Iraq would have no control over how the proceeds are spent.
The plan would allow Iraq a $1 billion sale every 90 days. Analysts said that would add about 700,000 barrels a day to bloated world markets.
February natural gas rose 26.2 cents, to $2.336 for 1,000 cubic feet, because of a belief that supplies would fall, a development confirmed by the American Gas Association after the close. Price also rose on the predictions for colder weather.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Winning Hand

BYLINE: By Matthew Miller; Matthew Miller, economics editor of The New Republic, was senior adviser in the Office of Management and Budget from 1993 to 1995.

 BODY:
It's only human for Republicans to sulk now that the President has outmaneuvered them by pressing for a balanced budget deal while attacking their "excessive Medicare cuts" -- which are similar in size to savings he had previously proposed. But the G.O.P. should put frustration aside and realize that the good of the country and its own political survival argue for a deal largely on his terms.
The Republicans complain that, despite the Congressional Budget Office's verdict that the latest Administration plan would achieve balance by the year 2002, Mr. Clinton puts off hard choices. But consider that in the first five years of its own balanced budget bill, the G.O.P. hopes to reduce the deficit by $337 billion. By contrast, President Clinton's 1993 budget package sought to reduce the deficit over five years by $500 billion. Even if Republicans dropped their foolish tax cut, their five-year deficit reduction would rise to only $486 billion. 
 The Republicans also accuse the President of "backloading" his budget savings -- meaning that they would take effect so far in the future as to be illusory. It's true that in his seven-year plan, he would achieve 58 percent of his savings in 2001 and 2002. But the G.O.P. plan passed in November puts off 48 percent of its savings until then. Imagine the campaign battle cry: "We put off half the heavy lifting till tomorrow, but the President puts off a little more!"
Politicians fall prey to the delusion that their side represents Good and the other side Evil. But while Republicans deserve credit for making a balanced budget a priority, they should remember that their plan, like the President's, is deeply flawed. For political reasons, both leave defense, Social Security and most "welfare for the well-to-do" off the table -- areas that together constitute half the budget and from which reasonable people in both parties know savings can be found.
Both parties thus myopically take about half their savings from annually appropriated domestic spending, which makes up only 16 percent of the budget and where needed money for research and development and education, among other things, comes from.
But in walking out on the budget negotiations, it's the Republicans who look worse. Whether there's a deal or not, Bill Clinton can argue honestly in the campaign that after 12 years of rising deficits, he's cut them nearly in half without a single Republican vote.
What's more, the President has a plan that the Republican-controlled Congressional Budget Office says will finish the job. In addition, if there's no deal, Mr. Clinton will be able to label the G.O.P. majority a "do-nothing" Congress since the entire G.O.P. agenda is wrapped up in the budget. This would leave 73 Republican freshman heading to the stump touting only the vague accomplishment of having "changed the debate," which may not stack up well against real, live votes that their opponents will say "slashed Medicare to give big tax cuts to the rich." In the absence of a disaster in Bosnia, the prospect for a big Democratic victory on these terms is real.
In November, many observers (like myself) thought the fiscal endgame would pit the G.O.P.'s politics of balanced budgets against the Democrats' politics of "Mediscare." The genius of the President's recent moves is to co-opt the balanced budget argument without relinquishing the Medicare attack. This strategy carries harsh consequences for the Republicans. They now need a deal more than the President does. That may be frustrating, but it's also reality.
If the G.O.P. is sincere about the national interest, this is no time for sour grapes about not getting enough credit. Instead, it's time to deal. A compromise plan will not be perfect -- the deficit probably won't be eliminated, hard choices will be deferred and taxes may unwisely be cut -- but it will be progress. The Republicans should call the President's bluff, claim joint victory and accept something close to the deal he's offered.

HEADLINE: Essay;
State of the Union

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton and a small cadre of aides are feverishly finishing the State of the Union address for presentation to an opposition Congress next Tuesday.
Here is a guide, nonpartisan to the point of Olympian, providing criteria to help viewers judge the only reporting event mandated by the Constitution. 
 1. Does he inspire confidence? We remember Reagan for morning-in-America optimism, Carter for eat-your-peas pessimism. With Republicans deliberately downbeat about budget talks, to remind the President of a recession if he fails to make a deal, Clinton must counter with confidence, in rhetoric and demeanor, without misleading.
2. Does he speak to the politicians in the hall or the people at home? In the television era, Presidents have used the House of Representatives merely as a colorful forum for a speech to the camera. But this time the oratorical challenge to Clinton, in the midst of the budget negotiations, is to play to both hall and home. People in their living rooms are both the target audience and onlookers at a dramatic confrontation; Clinton must be able to carom off Congress to land the ball in our pocket.
3. Does he put the story in the key word? Traditionally the President says "The State of the Union is (fill in adjective)." In hard times, the word is a reassuring "sound"; in better times, the word of choice, in both its senses, is "good." Gerald Ford's assessment in troubled 1975 was stunningly honest: "Not good." Clinton cannot be too honest ("The State of the Union, as we all know, is pretty confused"); more likely, he will go for a word like "strong."
4. Does he look backward or forward? George Bush's failure of vision in his election-year S.O.T.U. made his Presidency seem to have run out of gas. Beyond taking credit for a low-inflation economy, for Clinton to offer a litany of domestic achievements in this year of gridlock and shutdown would be risible; this speech must focus on the future, showing why a second term is needed -- without insulting Congress to its face.
5. Is he just political enough without appearing partisan? His fall campaign theme will be "Without me and my veto, those G.O.P. richies would savage our helpless old folks, pollute the environment and slam the schoolhouse door." But in next week's dignified setting, he must put his vetoes positively, as invitations to improve legislation to more painlessly bring about an agreed goal of a balanced budget. In this regard --
6. Does he inoculate himself from valid campaign criticism of preserving the failed welfare system? This is the place, looking ahead, to try to redefine "ending welfare as we know it" -- when the nation knows he stymied that promised reform this year.
7. Does he in a nonpartisan way exploit the foreign-affairs schism in the Republican ranks? Last weekend's 31-hour photo op in Bosnia, posing in a military jacket, was done just in time to set up a claim of world leadership and defense readiness in this speech. The peacemaker of the Middle East, Ireland and Haiti will publicly praise internationalists like Dole and Gingrich -- they'll smile but hate it -- thereby driving deeper the wedge between them and G.O.P. isolationists.
8. Will he develop his centrist theme of personal responsibility or start running prematurely as the defender of the needy against the greedy? If he can remind us of our duties to one another as individuals, and of our collective duty to educate the young and fight crime and respect our differences, then he can stay on that high road until it becomes necessary for him, later in the campaign, to exploit fear and foment class division.
9. Is he straining to milk applause? Fourteen interruptions of applause and one spontaneous standing ovation from Democrats is about right for a 40-minute S.O.T.U.
10. Does he have a heartstrings-tugger in the balcony? Reagan was master of this visual pointmaker. Look for something like a salute to the First Lady seated next to our first Bosnian casualty, which may be schmaltzy but is entirely appropriate in this patriotic setting.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
When economists talk, few listen if the subject is health policy.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to public policy, does anyone listen to economic experts anymore? Judging from the rise and fall of the Clinton national health care plan -- the Edsel (this is the 90's: make that the "Waterworld") of public policy rollouts -- the answer is discouraging. And economists may have only themselves to blame. Indeed, economic professionals appear to pay little attention to the most knowledgeable people within their own ranks.
That's the bleak message from Victor R. Fuchs, a health care economist at Stanford University and the departing president of the American Economic Association. He tackled the subject last week in his farewell address at the association's annual meeting in San Francisco. And while his words are hardly cheerful reading, Mr. Fuchs touches sensitive points that economists can ignore only at their own peril. 
 The big surprise for political scientists in the health reform debacle was that the first genuine policy wonk to battle his way to the White House proved to be such an amateur at policy-making, according to Theodore R. Marmor of the Yale School of Organization and Management.
"President Clinton had no reason to believe there was a popular consensus for radical change," Mr. Marmor said. But the new President, elected with a bare plurality in a three-way contest, acted as if he were prime minister in a British-style parliamentary system in which party discipline would be decisive.
Seriously misreading the way things work in Washington, Mr. Clinton did all his interest-group bargaining in secret, presenting a finished version to Congress with little room for horse-trading. In the end, Mr. Marmor says, the plan, intricately fiddled and faddled to placate everyone, pleased no one.
For health care economists, there was an even bigger slap in the face. After three decades in which health economics had come into its own as a serious discipline, the research and advice from such experts were virtually ignored in the White House drafting of the bill.
To find out why, Mr. Fuchs put together an opinion survey on health policy, eliciting responses from 46 health economists, 44 economic theorists with no special interest in health care and 42 practicing physicians. While the design of the survey and the choice of experts surveyed may not meet the standards of scientific polling, some of the results are striking.
On the 7 out of 20 questions that Mr. Fuchs labels "value free," the health economists spoke with virtually one voice. For example, 81 percent agreed that "the primary reason for the increase in the health sector's share of G.D.P. over the past 30 years is technological change in medicine." Fully 91 percent took issue with the assertion that "the high cost of health care in the United States makes U.S. firms substantially less competitive in the global economy."
But many of the views of health economists, grounded in solid research, proved to be well-guarded secrets. By contrast to the 89 percent of the health care economists who rejected the idea that "widespread use of currently available screening and other diagnostic techniques would result in a significant reduction in health care expenditures," 83 percent of the economic theorists accepted it. And while not one of the health economists agreed that "differential access to medical care across socioeconomic groups is the primary reason for differential health status," 34 percent of the physicians did.
Perhaps one reason few people paid attention to health economists was that they did not always speak with one voice on fundamental policy issues. The group was split 54 to 46 on whether "the U.S. should seek universal coverage through a broad-based tax with implicit subsidies for the poor and the sick." By the same token, the split was 51 to 49 on whether "insurance companies should be required to cover all applicants regardless of health condition and not allowed to charge sicker individuals higher premiums." While 42 percent agreed that "national standardized health insurance benefit packages should be established," 58 percent did not.
If health economists can't get their research findings across to physicians and other economists, Mr. Fuchs asks, what chance do they have to influence politicians and voters? Not much. And it doesn't help that health economists do not seem to share common objectives, diluting even further their impact on the policy debate.
Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, draws a yet-more-sober conclusion. The closer economists get to the corridors of power, he suggests, the more they are influenced by careerism and ideology. And in straying ever further from the more objective standards of science, they have left themselves open to the public's view of them as experts for sale. "We are self-immolating as a profession," he concludes.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Gap Narrowed Again in October

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit fell to $8.04 billion last October, the lowest level in 10 months and the fourth straight monthly decline, the Commerce Department said today in a delayed report.
The numbers solidified a view among economists that the trade deficit had peaked, but the latest figures also raised new concerns about the nation's trade with Japan and highlighted a lack of progress in opening parts of China's vast market more widely to American goods. 
 And some economists cautioned that these and other problems, including growing United States trade imbalances with Canada and Mexico and a slowdown in Europe's economy, could keep the country's overall trade deficit from dropping significantly next year.
In its report, which was delayed at least a month by the Government shutdown, the Commerce Department said the trade deficit decreased 2.5 percent in October from $8.25 billion in September. That marked the fourth straight monthly fall since the deficit hit $11.39 billion last June.
But even with those gains, several private economists projected that the 1995 deficit would total $150 billion to $165 billion, making it one of the highest in history.
Still, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the overall trend "is obviously helpful." He added that the trade total, fueled by strong United States exports, "have been moving inextricably in the right direction over the last several months.
"I perceive that is going to continue, but how strongly I can't tell," he said.
Several economists said they were troubled by a jump in the United States trade deficit with Japan, which rose 11.1 percent in October to $4.79 billion from $4.31 billion in September, ending a seven-month stretch of declines.
But Mr. Kantor said in an interview that the overall trade deficit with Japan had dropped 4 percent in the first 10 months of 1995 over the same period in 1994.
He said he was more concerned about trade with China. Hinting that the Administration may seek to reimpose trade sanctions against China next month, Mr. Kantor said: "Things are not going in the correct direction with China. We have focused on China with some intensity, and we intend to be even more intense over the next several months. This goes beyond trade rules to the rule of law. We expect them to live up to their agreements."
Last February, the Clinton Administration suspended $1 billion in tariffs on imports from China to encourage the Chinese Government to crack down on piracy of American movies and computer software and to halt other discriminatory trade practices.
But some trade experts contended that China has not changed many of its practices, and the Commerce report showed that America's deficit with China climbed to $29.09 billion in the first 10 months of 1995 from $24.59 billion in the same period in 1994.
Mr. Kantor and several economists said new trade agreements with other countries and a renewed competitiveness by American companies had helped to increase exports. But, noting that exports dipped slightly in October, they also said that any strengthening in the dollar's value, making United States goods more expensive, and the sluggish nature of the Japanese and European economies, could choke out some of that growth.
Gary C. Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said the latest trade numbers were "slightly better than one might have expected," and he said he expected a continued decline in the overall deficit.
But he also said that "the bigger story is the softness of the U.S. economy," which is improving the balance of trade by slowing purchases of imports by American consumers.
Indeed, the Commerce Department report showed that while exports of American goods and services rose from $64.68 billion last June to $66.75 billion in October, imports dropped from $76.06 billion to $74.79 billion over the same period.
Others, such as Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former Commerce Department official and a critic of some of Japan's trading practices, said they found the Commerce Department report to be "discouraging" because it showed that the United States deficits were still growing with several of its leading trading partners.
Besides the problems with Japan and China, the report showed that trade deficits had worsened with both Canada and Mexico, the country's partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
In addition, America's trade deficit with Western Europe jumped to $1.15 billion in October from $125 million in September, possibly reflecting Europe's growing economic woes.
Commerce Department officials cautioned that such figures could be misleading because the total trade deficit is adjusted for seasonal variations in economic activity, but the country-by-country figures are not.
But Mr. Prestowitz, now president of the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington, said he was concerned by the numbers.
"Mexico's economy is slowing," he said, "and the forecast is that it will not be robust and Europe will not be robust." In addition, he said, "We have a chronic, big trade deficit with Canada."
Among industrial sectors, some of the biggest declines in October occurred in exports of autos and auto parts, which slipped to $4.77 billion in October from $5.6 billion in September. Imports dropped even more, to $9.51 billion from $10.42 billion.
Imports of foreign oil also declined, to $4.25 billion in October from $4.78 billion in September.
Given the delay in releasing the October figures, economists expect the Commerce Department to follow in early February with the November totals, bringing the trade picture more up to date.
The Japanese Government is expected to report its 1995 trade figures soon, and most experts believe they will show that Japan's huge trade surplus shrank for the first time in five years. If that is so, it could ease trade tensions between Japan and the United States and help keep the dollar strong.

HEADLINE: Panel Proposes a Flat Tax But Fails to Specify the Rate

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
A private commission on tax reform created last year by Republican leaders in Congress today stepped into a central issue in the campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination and recommended that the wages and salaries of all Americans, from corporate magnates to manual laborers, be taxed at a single, low rate.
But the commission stopped short of proposing what that rate should be and avoided, as have the Republican candidates, the politically delicate matter of who might owe more taxes and who might owe less under what is known as a flat tax. The commission also did not address what the effect would be on the budget deficit and whether tax deductions for mortgage interest payments and charitable donations should be retained. 
 This lack of specificity means that the report will have little effect on the flat tax debate among Republican candidates, and probably even less on Congress.
Because the flat tax became such a hot political issue within the party, the commission, officially called the National Commission on Economic Growth and Tax Reform, was unable to satisfy what Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich originally saw as its objective, which was to unify Republicans on the question of taxes.
Republican Presidential candidates are already offering rival versions of flat taxes.
Steve Forbes, the publishing executive, gained attention in Iowa and New Hampshire, where the first contests for the nomination will be held next month, with his proposal for a flat tax of 17 percent. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas tried to gain an advantage over Mr. Forbes today by proposing a 16 percent rate. Patrick J. Buchanan, the commentator, would favor a flat tax if it continued tax deductions for mortgage interest payments and charitable contributions, but he places greater emphasis on high tariffs on imports.
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee oppose the idea of a flat tax but favor other sweeping changes in the tax system.
Senator Dole of Kansas, the front-runner for the Republican nomination, said today at a news conference where the commission report was made public that he could not support any measure that would increase the Federal budget deficit or shift the tax burden toward the middle class and away from the wealthy. And every plan that has been offered so far would almost certainly do one or the other or both.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin issued a statement saying, "Every Republican flat tax we have seen either explodes the deficit or raises income taxes on middle-income families."
Even the most ardent proponents of overhauling the nation's tax system acknowledge that despite all the political talk about taxes, Congress will not vote on the matter this year. The commission report, said Jeff Levey, who follows tax policy developments for Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, "is just another sort of blip in a lot of blips we're going to see in the next year about tax restructuring."
Under the current system, Federal income tax rates range from 15 percent for taxpayers with modest incomes to nearly 40 percent for the wealthiest.
Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich, who together created the commission, tried to put the best face on its report today, not endorsing any proposal specifically but saying it provided an opening for a full-scale debate over how to change the tax system.
Perhaps to draw attention away from divisions within the Republican Party, Mr. Gingrich challenged President Clinton to join a Republican effort to change the tax system or to defend the current system, a challenge the President could hardly accept.
Asked at the news conference why the commission had avoided dealing with specifics, its chairman, Jack F. Kemp, the former Housing Secretary and Republican Congressman from Buffalo, replied, "We're not going to get sidetracked into issues like which deductions are most important."
Mr. Kemp said his personal preference was that the flat tax rate be no higher than 19 percent. The commission said only that the rate should be "as low as possible."
Others on the 14-member commission, a cross-section of Republicans who have been successful in fields outside the Federal Government, included two former Governors, Pete du Pont of Delaware and Carroll Campbell of South Carolina; Theodore J. Forstmann, the investment banker, and John Snow, chairman and president of the CSX Corporation in Richmond.
In a step that would be especially beneficial to upper-income taxpayers, the commission proposed abolishing altogether taxation of interest, dividends, capital gains and estates.
For those less well-to-do, the commission would allow a large personal exemption and permit workers to deduct from their income taxes the money withheld from their paychecks for Social Security and Medicare.
It would thus appear that almost everyone would have lower taxes, obviously a politically attractive proposition. There were no suggestions of where spending might be lowered to offset the tax cuts.
In the 1970's, Mr. Kemp was one of the first prominent politicians to embrace the supply-side theory of economics, which holds that lower tax rates would lead to such growth in the economy that tax receipts would actually increase.
The theory became less fashionable when the Federal budget deficit mushroomed after President Ronald Reagan's deep tax cuts in the early 1980's.
But Mr. Kemp said today that if the commission's recommendations were adopted, economic growth in the years ahead would double, leading to lower interest rates, more jobs and higher revenue for the Government.
The six principles advocated by the commission could hardly be objected to by anyone: economic growth through incentives to work, save and invest; fairness for all taxpayers; simplicity so that anyone can figure it out; neutrality so that people rather than the Government make economic decisions, visibility so that taxpayers know the cost of government, and stability so that the future can be planned for.
The problem is that some of those bromides are contradictory. For example, as a rule, the simpler a tax code is, the more unfair it tends to be; the fairer the law, the more complicated it is likely to be.
There is no mystery to why the idea of a flat tax is appealing. The existing tax system can be maddeningly complicated and expensive to comply with. It rewards consumption and penalizes savings, exactly the opposite of economic common sense. And in many cases it is clearly unfair -- for example, many working couples pay substantially higher taxes on their joint return than do unmarried couples who live together and file separate returns.
But as is the case with balancing the budget and improving the health care system, the problems with the tax law cannot be fixed easily. The more the layers of the problem are peeled away, the less attractive each proposed solution becomes.
The flat tax tends to founder politically because in the end, voters are more interested in what happens to their own taxes than they are in the principles of taxation.
Unless one accepts supply-side economic principles in full -- and relatively few economists do -- then someone's taxes must be increased to offset those whose taxes are cut or the deficit will expand again as it did in the 1980's.
Lowering the top rate substantially and ending taxation of interest, dividends, capital gains and estates is bound to help the wealthy. So the tax increases must be borne by those who are not wealthy -- as is the case with most voters.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Sense of Where He Is and Why He Stays There

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

TIME PRESENT, TIME PAST
A Memoir
By Bill Bradley
Illustrated. 442 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.
What raises Bill Bradley's new book above the usual public figure's memoir is the engagingly fluid way the narrative moves from the personal to the historical to whatever message Senator Bradley wants to convey. 
 For instance, early in "Time Present, Time Past," in a chapter titled "The Garden," the author recalls returning to Madison Square Garden in 1992 to deliver one of three keynote addresses at the Democratic National Convention. This allows him first to touch upon his career as a professional basketball player with the New York Knicks and how he "emerged as role model for many slow-footed white boys"; then to digress at candid length on his "deficiency as a speaker and as a television performer," and finally to deliver the point of his convention speech, which is also the message of this book: that "our challenge as a party and a nation" is to "stop the random violence of our cities, rebuild economic opportunity and jobs for all and provide the moral leadership worthy of our ideals."
 Or, for another example, in a chapter called "The Creedal Society," he moves from the German ancestry of his mother to the history of German immigrants in America, to the German background of his wife, Ernestine, to the experiences ofother nationalities in this country, to his position on immigration policy, to his hopes for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Out of this emerges an appealing portrait of a public figure who seems real, with passions and ideals rooted in his upbringing and heritage. In the best passages he doesn't just advocate positions; he explains how large ideas can be translated into effective action. His several chapters on the United States Senate are fascinating mixtures of gossip, history and advice on how to get things done.
Surprisingly, senators still depend on the currency of one another's word. "But listen very carefully," Senator Bradley advises, "so that you don't hear only what you want to hear." Surprising too is the question he raises of how many votes have been sold within the Senate "for extra paper, more space or an additional pay line for a staff member." His answer: "more than the public knows." Yet if he's good on such details, he's equally engrossing in a chapter called "The Big Picture," where he describes the strategies he used to push legislation on tax reform, third world debt and the distribution of water in the West.
Unfortunately, after a while his mix of memoir and advocacy begins to seem schematic, and you get the sense that you're reading well-crafted position papers on subjects like the role of the United States as a leader in the world, the failure of labor unions, the future of race relations, the excesses of the media, the emergence of women in politics, what we owe American Indians and the plight of the middle class.
What Senator Bradley has to say on these subjects may well be compelling, as is his concern over the pressures being exerted on American society by the transition we are undergoing from a manufacturing economy to an information-based economy. In the new era, "neither capital, labor nor raw materials will be as important as knowledge -- its use and application."
Yet his delivery is just preachy enough to make you wonder if there is a hidden purpose behind "Time Present, Time Past," the title of which comes from T. S. Eliot's "Burnt Norton." Could the book be the announcement of a campaign for the Presidency, as the publication of Gen. Colin L. Powell's memoir, "My American Journey" was at one time thought to be? This was certainly a speculation when Senator Bradley announced last August that he would not run for re-election to the Senate this year.
But such speculation seems scotched by a chapter in the memoir called "Night Thoughts," where Senator Bradley spells out the various complex reasons he chose not to seek the Democratic nomination for President in 1992. Among these are his "skepticism about what any President could accomplish at our current national moment," his concern for his family's well-being, his "natural antipathy to the invasion by the press of all aspects" of his life, his continuing stage fright and "inability to rouse people as a speaker" and his "ingrained assumption (in refutation of which lay a lifetime of achievement) that this small-town boy could never win the biggest contest of all." Unhappily for his admirers, these reasons for not running are so convincingly a part of his self-portrait as to be persuasive.
On the other hand, at the same press conference at which he announced his decision not to run again for the Senate he described himself as "an inveterate scribbler" who for years had been recording his thoughts in college-rule notebooks with No. 2 pencils. So maybe this memoir really was written as a venture of self-discovery. Certainly the results are at once honest and complexly shaded enough to make this charming possibility seem altogether plausible.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 815 words

HEADLINE: Gramm Adds Voice to Calls In the G.O.P. for Flat Tax

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Formally joining the Republican chorus calling for a flat tax, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas today proposed taxing income at 16 percent, edging a rival Presidential candidate, Steve Forbes, by one percentage point.
While Mr. Forbes would tax only earned income at 17 percent, Mr. Gramm said he would tax investment income as well. Unlike Mr. Forbes, Senator Gramm would preserve deductions for mortgage interest and for donations to charities. 
 The proposal was included in what Mr. Gramm called "an eight-year program to change America, to bring back the American dream and to share that dream with people who missed it the first time around."
The program, which he outlined in a speech to the Cato Institute, a conservative research organization, brought together many ideas that Mr. Gramm, a former economics professor, has proposed before. He has been offering them piecemeal in Iowa and New Hampshire as he has scrambled to elbow aside Mr. Forbes and establish himself as the most credible challenger to Senator Bob Dole, the clear front-runner in the two states and nationally. Mr. Dole has said he might support a flat tax but has yet to propose his own plan.
Today, Mr. Gramm projected numerous, specific benefits from his economic plan. He said that by the end of the eighth year of a Gramm administration, his plan would expand the number of jobs nationally to 142 million from 125 million; would raise average income for a family of four to $57,500 from $45,000, in 1994 dollars, and would move 9.7 million people out of poverty.
In a recent interview, Mr. Gramm denied that he was advocating a flat tax to horn in on what has proved a potent issue for Mr. Forbes. "I was for a flat tax, a variant of it, in 1976," he said, when he taught economics at Texas A&M. Asked if he would be raising the idea now if Mr. Forbes had not, he said, "I didn't even know Forbes in 1976."
But Mr. Forbes took credit for the idea today, saying in a prepared statement: "I'm delighted that Senator Gramm has finally seen the light on the flat tax, even if it's an election-year conversion. I hope his conversion is more than poll deep."
Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator who is seeking the Republican nomination, has proposed a version of a flat tax, and other candidates have discussed the idea. A commission headed by Jack F. Kemp today supported one without specifying a rate.
Like Mr. Forbes, Mr. Gramm would not tax inheritance. But in other respects, the two tax plans differ significantly, in part because Mr. Gramm would tax unearned income, like capital gains. Mr. Forbes, a multimillionaire, has been attacked by his rivals for proposing a plan that would enable wealthy investors to escape tax on a large part of their income.
"I reject the idea that income derived from labor should be taxed, and that income derived from capital should not be taxed," Mr. Gramm said. He called Mr. Forbes's approach "totally unfair, totally indefensible" and argued that it would distort investment.
Mr. Gramm posed the example of a father who sends one child to Stanford to become a doctor, while giving the other an equal amount of money to invest. Why, he asked, should the first child pay taxes on income, while the second does not?
In his statement, Mr. Forbes said: "Although Senator Gramm doesn't understand it, one of the virtues of a flat tax is that all income is taxed at its source, including investment income. Investment income is effectively taxed at the corporate level, not the personal level." In other words, Mr. Forbes would tax corporate profits only when the company earns the money, not again when it pays it out to stockholders in the form of dividends.
For a family of four, Mr. Gramm's rate of 16 percent would apply on income over $32,000, an amount he said could rise to $40,000 over eight years. For the same family, Mr. Forbes's 17 percent tax would start on income over $36,000.
Mr. Gramm said that his plan could cause a shortfall in Federal revenue of about $40 billion in its first year but that spending cuts would take care of the gap.
Critics of flat-tax proposals have argued that they could raise taxes for some middle-income families. But Mr. Gramm said his plan was "structured to try to guarantee that no middle class American will pay more taxes than they do now."
Mr. Gramm also said his program would balance the budget in four years and then enact a "spending pause" over the following four years to limit the Government's growth to the rate of inflation. He also called for a one-year moratorium on Federal regulations, beginning in 1997, except in cases of imminent danger to human health and safety.
And Mr. Gramm defended his support of free-trade agreements. "If there's anything we've learned in American history, it is that trade produces prosperity and opportunity," Mr. Gramm said. "Trade won the cold war."
