HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Weak Reports Bolster Prices Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities returned close to their two-week highs yesterday. For the third consecutive day, market participants bought on weak economic data that pointed to continued low inflation.
The market began the day with overseas buying as the French and British cut interest rates, making dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bonds fell to 5.98 percent, from 6.01 percent on Wednesday, as the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose by 13/32 of a point, to 112 11/32. 
 A Philadelphia Fed survey of regional business activity for January showed a weaker economy, with an index compiled from the survey falling to a negative 16.6 from a positive 11.3 in December. That is a big swing, and the survey was taken before the blizzard.
Data about jobless claims for the five weeks ended last Saturday -- delayed by the partial Government shutdown -- were issued yesterday. Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that "since the claims data were last released, the series has clearly established an ascending trend," with unemployment-benefit claims approaching 400,000. In the latest week, the number of new claims fell by 67,000, to 367,000. But lately the figure has been close to 400,000, a level that has been associated with recessions, she said. Bad weather may have contributed to the drop of 67,000 in new claims last week.
"The jobless claims," said John Burgess, managing director at Bankers Trust Investment Management, "were consistent with what we already knew but still in line with moderate growth."
He said his expectations for today's report on nonfarm jobs were in the area of increases from 100,000 to 150,000.
"My feeling is that the employment number certainly needs to be on weaker side to justify the prices of the shorter maturities along the yield curve," he said.
Mr. Burgess said he believed that the market had decoupled from the Washington budget talks and was now focused on the economy, with jobs and consumer data the keys. But he said he did not think that a clear picture was possible until February or March, when the data would not be clouded by weather-related factors.
Margo Evashevski, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International, San Francisco, agreed that the focus of the market had shifted to fundamentals. She said the market held up in the wake of no-progress comments on the budget yesterday from Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, and President Clinton.
"Sentiment has been underpinned by expectations for a near-term rate cut," Ms. Evashevski said, "either in January or March. Late afternoon rallies have been commonplace this week and a late push could get the March bond through stiff resistance at a price level of 112 20/32."
A Fed governor, Edward G. Kelly Jr., said in the morning that the Federal Open Market Committee, which meets on Jan. 30 and 31, would have enough data for a decision on interest rates. He said monetary policy was in "zone of neutrality" and that inflation was "benign." He also said that fiscal policy was not a big factor in Fed deliberations and that budget negotiations would not "inhibit" a policy move.
While it appeared that prices could have gone higher, anticipation of an important number like today's nonfarm payroll for December kept investors from getting to far ahead of themselves, traders said..

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Cuts in European Interest Rates Spur Broad Gains by the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most major currencies, bolstered by interest-rate cuts in Europe.
Rate reductions by Britain, France and the Netherlands spurred speculation that Germany would follow suit with another cut soon in key rates to bolster its flagging economy. The German central bank held rates steady at a policy meeting yesterday, after lowering a money-market rate on Wednesday. Lower rates in Europe often lift the dollar by making American deposits more attractive. 
 "Interest rates in Europe are continuing to come down, and that should help the dollar," said Mark Fitzsimmons, strategist at the Millburn Ridgefield Corporation, a money-management firm. "France and the U.K. today are a good indication."
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.4740 German marks, up from 1.4715 marks late Wednesday, and at 105.60 yen, up from 105.42 yen on Wednesday. The British pound sold for $1.5182, down from $1.5205.
Britain cut its benchmark minimum lending rate by a quarter-point, to 6.25 percent, while France lowered two interest rates and the Dutch central bank cut its special loan rate. On Wednesday, the German Bundesbank reduced its 14-day securities repurchase rate. It is expected to cut its discount rate later this quarter, traders said.
The dollar also drew strength from a rally in United States stock and bond markets. Bonds rose for a third day, driving the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond below 6 percent for the first time in two weeks. Stocks also rallied. Foreign investors need dollars to buy American assets.
"This is the right time to get into the U.S. markets," said Dimitri Balatsos, portfolio manager at Furman Selz Capital Management, which supervises investments of $6.5 billion.
Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin reaffirmed his support yesterday for a strong dollar, in advance of a meeting in Paris this weekend of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations. But most analysts doubt that the group will adopt a plan to support the dollar.

HEADLINE: With the G.I.'s in Bosnia: Money Wins Serb Hearts

SERIES: WITH CHARLIE COMPANY: Dollar Diplomacy

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: SEKOVICI, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Vladimir Lazic, 33, a Serbian carpenter who has worked little since the war began, said he and his friends were taken by surprise when Company C set up camp in a cornfield outside town. No one knew they were coming, he said, and there was plenty of suspicion.
"Now," he said in Serbo-Croatian, grinning, "the opinion is better." 
There was a reason behind the smile: A local wood-working company hired him to help build latrines and wooden pallets for the peacekeeping encampment. And as the Americans on this NATO mission look for local workers to bake bread, cut hair, fit pipes, haul trash and clean clothes, the word has spread that there may be more to peace than just an end to fighting.
Mr. Lazic summed it up in one of his few words of English. "Money," he said. "Money."
The economics of peace at camps around the American sector is not a central pillar of American strategy in Bosnia, but a side benefit that officials see as another tool to keep soldiers safe.
"It always makes it easier if you can go in and say: We are here because we have to be but we're going to give a little bit and you are going to benefit," said Lieut. Col. William F. Briscoe, commander of the Fourth Battalion, 12th Infantry. Company C of the Fourth Battalion set up its tents last week in Ninici, about six miles outside Sekovici.
The Muslim industrial city of Tuzla, roughly 50 miles northwest of here, had expected a major economic boom as the center of American operations. But business leaders there have complained that the presence has not been as lucrative as they had hoped.
In this depressed farming town of 11,000 people the expectations are not as high. This is a country town with little to offer: a few dim restaurants, a bar with an antiaircraft gun parked on a camouflaged truck in front, a woodworking and a metal fabricating plant. There are expectations, nonetheless.
"If they don't want trouble, they will put us to work," said Vujadin Celic, 48, a personnel manager, said at a cafe. He did not imply a threat, but rather a horse-sense suggestion.
Radinka Starcevic, 28, a clerk in a chilly store with many bare shelves, said she is the only person in her family who has a job.
"There is no money," she said. "There is nobody working." She would love to see Americans infuse jobs and money into the town and, more to the point, her store.
"We will see," she said. "We will see if they help us to build the things that were destroyed in the war."
Soldiers are banned from shopping, eating or drinking in local towns.
So far, much of the dealing with local residents has centered on money. Military officials began with the premise that they would try to spend as much money on the Serbian side as the Muslim side, and Company C and Army civil affairs negotiators have been working to find nearly all that the soldiers need locally.
Already on the Serbian side, the company that Mr. Lazic works for is supplying nine latrines for $615 each and up to 260 wooden pallets, used as tent floors, for a total of $6,137. Today, Charlie Company picked up its first daily delivery of bread, 200 loaves at about 54 cents each. The civil affairs negotiators are seeking drain pipes, trash haulers, squeegees and spotlights. In total, Colonel Briscoe estimated that $500,000 may be spent on this camp alone, one of perhaps two dozen in the American sector.
In anticipation, a certain entrepreneurial spirit is blooming. In town earlier this week, two Serbian policemen tried to sell their nightsticks, and a soldier, in a hopeful sign for peace, offered to sell his uniform, a snazzy black jumpsuit.
This morning, Capt. Hugo Jackson, the commander of Company C, and Capt. Dennis Greenwood, a civil affairs negotiator, began a meeting with a baker who turned out not to be the one they had agreed to work with. The baker, Milan Markovic, nonetheless offered to undercut the competition by 20 cents a loaf.
Nearly all contracts on the Serbian side have to be made through the Mayor, Veljko Stupar, 34, and members of the town council.
After a meeting on Wednesday, Mr. Stupar said relations with Company C were "so far, so good." He said foremost on his mind was making sure the peace held, but like Mr. Lazic, he cracked a big smile when asked if the financial opportunities for Sekovici were also important.
"Yes," he said, "I think so."

LENGTH: 565 words

HEADLINE: Rubin Sees the Big Powers Focusing on Effect of Slump

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
With growth slowing in the United States and Europe and anemic in Japan, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said today that a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations this weekend would focus on what to do if economic weakness worsened.
One danger of a softening economy in Europe is the possibility that it could derail a move toward a common European currency, Government officials said. The Clinton Administration is also concerned for reasons closer to home: slowdowns abroad could become a drag on the domestic economy, an unnerving prospect in an election year. 
 Still, Mr. Rubin said the talks in Paris with the finance ministers of Britain, France, German, Italy, Canada and Japan, would be low key, centering on how "to respond to slower growth if that proves necessary."
Even so, recent signs that Europe's economic growth is fading will lend some urgency to the talks, particularly because the slowdown could keep Germany and France from reaching economic goals crucial to a European single currency scheduled to start in 1999.
"Perhaps the most important goal for all seven of the countries is growth," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Paribas Capital Markets in New York.
"It's slipping away in Europe, and they're very concerned about it," he said. "It's falling in the U.S. and Canada. And Japan has been concerned about its growth rate for three years."
As a result, the critical theme at the talks could be a call for a stronger dollar, which might increase exports from European nations and Japan, helping to rekindle their economies, Mr. Fabbri said. He added that he would not be surprised to see some "official jawboning" by some of the finance ministers aimed at increasing the dollar's exchange rate.
Indeed, United States officials might be willing to go along with such a move, given a recent narrowing of the nation's trade deficit, some economists said. Mr. Rubin seemed open to that possibility, saying at a news briefing today that "it has been the view of this Administration that a strong dollar is in the best interest of the United States."
But if pushed too far, any effort to lift the dollar could carry a risk of choking off a surge in American exports at a time when the economy is looking less buoyant.
And to some extent, Mr. Rubin seemed to minimize the seriousness of the problems in Europe. He said at the briefing that economic conditions had "softened a tiny bit" there.
Statistics released earlier this month show that the unemployment rate in Germany had risen to nearly 10 percent. Some economists have slashed their projections for German growth this year to 1 percent from 2 percent.
France endured a wave of public-employee strikes last month. And leaders in both countries are concerned about whether they will be able to meet budget-cutting targets required under the ground rules of European economic union.
Mr. Rubin said the finance ministers also plan to assess progress toward goals set in Canada last year to strengthen the world financial system and improve the effectiveness of agencies like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
He said that in response to a series of resignations of reform-minded ministers in Russia, he also expected the Paris talks "to emphasize how critical it is for Russia to stick firmly" to its transition to a market economy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
4th-Quarter Comeback For I.B.M.

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Delivering some welcome news to edgy technology investors, I.B.M. reported a 39 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, surpassing Wall Street forecasts and sparking a rally in its stock price.
The results seemed to allay concerns about the International Business Machines Corporation's future that had been growing since last summer. Its stock price had been depressed by disappointing earnings, product delays, and fears that its $3.5 billion purchase of the Lotus Development Corporation was a mistake. 
 "It was a very solid quarter, and the fact that there was no surprise was the surprise," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York.
Investors responded enthusiastically sending I.B.M. shares soaring 10.2 percent, or $8.625, to close at $96.25 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The sharp rise also contributed 25.65 points to the 57.45-point rise in the Dow Jones industrial average and appeared to lift other technology stocks as well. The Nasdaq index, heavily weighted in the technology sector, rose nearly 1 percent, ending the day at 1,007.24, up 8.94.
The Microsoft Corporation, which reported its results after the markets closed yesterday, also exceeded analysts' expectations, cheering investors who were disappointed by weaker-than-expected earnings from the Intel Corporation earlier in the week. [Page D2]
I.B.M., which is the world's largest computer company, saw its highest growth come from its services and software businesses; sales of its mainstay hardware products, which include mainframe, midrange and personal computers, were also strong, rising nearly 8 percent in the final quarter.
The company's total gross profit margin was 41.9 percent in the quarter, up from 40.6 percent in the comparable 1994 period. But Richard Thoman, I.B.M.'s chief financial officer, warned that profit margins may decline because I.B.M.'s fastest-growing businesses, like services, have lower margins than its slower growing operations.
I.B.M.'s net earnings for the quarter, including a previously announced one-time charge of $663 million and a one-time gain of $175 million related to the 1994 sale of its Federal Systems Company, were $1.7 billion, or $3.09 a share.
Excluding the two special items, earnings rose 65 percent, to $2 billion, or $3.66 a share, from $1.2 billion, or $2.06 a share, a year earlier. The average earnings forecast of analysts polled by First Call had been $3.45 a share.
Some analysts suggested that the results were actually closer to their estimates after accounting for an earnings increase of about 20 cents a share because of a plunge in the company's effective tax rate to about 34 percent from nearly 41 percent (largely a result of a surprise reduction in the company's tax rate in Brazil). An additional 10 cents a share in earnings came from favorable foreign currency rates.
The company continued to see strong demand for new, lower-cost versions of its traditional mainframe computers, a business that only a few years ago many connected with the industry predicted would disappear. But by recasting its mainframes as computer "servers" and drastically lowering the total cost of buying and operating them, I.B.M. has convinced many customers to trade in their old, water-cooled models.
The company's troubled personal computer business, which had heavy losses in 1994, saw double-digit revenue growth in the quarter and was one of the largest contributors to I.B.M.'s profit improvement this year, Mr. Thoman said in a telephone interview. Nevertheless, he still rated the business "a B- or C+."
Sales of software grew 9 percent, largely because of the acquisition of Lotus. Revenue from I.B.M.'s mainframe software was flat, but Lotus sold 1.2 million copies of its Notes software, which allows businesses to share data among far-flung offices over networks. The sales were a surprise because a long-awaited new version of Notes was released earlier this month. But Mr. Thoman said that many corporate customers decided to buy the old version rather than wait six months to begin setting up their networks with the new version.
Revenues from the company's fast-growing services business grew 25 percent in the quarter, to $4.1 billion. At $12.7 billion in sales for 1995, Big Blue's services revenues surpassed software as the second-largest source of income for I.B.M. after hardware sales.
As a result of the huge job reductions it made in the early 1990's, Big Blue continued to generate a large amount of cash, ending the year with $7.7 billion, despite the $3.5 billion it spent on Lotus and $4.9 billion buying 51 million shares of its own stock.
Mr. Thoman declined to comment on specific acquisition targets, but he said that the company would look to acquire services and software companies that would add immediate value to I.B.M.'s existing businesses and not dilute its stock.
One attractive buy, he said, at least before yesterday's rally, was I.B.M. stock.
Mr. Thoman made a special effort to convince analysts at a meeting yesterday that I.B.M., which has been trading at a low price-earning ratio, was on a solid growth track. "Nearly all our businesses have been transformed for leadership," he told the analysts. "If you go down our product categories, we are pretty competitive."
But some analysts worry about 1996, when the global economy is set to slow down and I.B.M. won't be able to command premium prices for its products.
"They had a very good quarter, but frankly that is really of zero interest at this point," said David Wu, an analyst at the Chicago Corporation. "The real interest is: What are they going to do for me tomorrow?"

HEADLINE: Clinton and 7 G.O.P. Candidates Make Their Appeals to Elderly

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton and seven of the Republicans who want his job outlined starkly different proposals today on Medicare, Social Security and other issues of particular concern to elderly people.
In written responses to questionnaires from the American Association of Retired Persons, six of those Republican candidates for President -- Lamar Alexander, Patrick J. Buchanan, Robert K. Dornan, Steve Forbes, Phil Gramm and Richard G. Lugar -- said the Government should let the elderly obtain health insurance through medical savings accounts. 
 Such accounts, a feature of Republican budget legislation vetoed by Mr. Clinton, would be an alternative to the standard Medicare program. Beneficiaries would receive a lump sum from the Government each year, buy private health insurance policies with high deductibles and deposit the remainder in savings accounts that could be used to pay medical expenses that the policies did not cover.
Supporters of medical savings accounts say they would encourage elderly people to be more conscious of costs, since beneficiaries would be permitted to keep some of the unspent money.
Mr. Clinton, whose responses to the questionnaire restated positions he has taken during the three years of his Administration, opposes such accounts, saying they would appeal mainly to healthier, wealthier people and would leave the sick, poor elderly in the standard Medicare program.
At a news conference today where a voters' guide with the candidates' responses was issued, Eugene I. Lehrmann, president of the A.A.R.P., said, "We see medical savings accounts as a real threat to the safety net" provided to the elderly by Medicare.
Senator Bob Dole, the front-running candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, voted for the legislation that would have created such savings accounts. But he did not mention them when asked by the association what changes he proposed for Medicare. Aides said he generally supported the idea of the accounts but had raised some questions about them and wanted to make sure they would not undercut the standard Medicare program. In his response to the A.A.R.P., he said he would slow the growth of Medicare, but he did not say how.
Medicare's future and health policy in general are expected to figure prominently in this year's elections. Under current law, Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, which pays hospital bills, is expected to run out of money in 2002.
Senator Gramm boasted that he "led the effort to defeat" Mr. Clinton's ambitious plan for universal health insurance coverage in 1994. "The American people," he said, "do not want greater government involvement in issues like health care."
Democrats, on the other hand, say Mr. Clinton has made political gains by attacking the Republicans on the ground that they would undermine Medicare and so jeopardize the coverage now provided to 37 million people who are elderly or disabled.
Most of the Presidential candidates were predictably reluctant to suggest any changes in Social Security. But Mr. Forbes recommended a major change, which would increase the use of private savings and investments as a source of retirement income. He proposed creating "a new system for younger people, whereby a portion of their payroll taxes would go directly into their own retirement accounts, along the lines of individual retirement accounts."
Under current law, the payroll taxes of active workers are used mainly to pay Social Security benefits for people who have already retired.
Senator Lugar expressed concern about what might happen in 15 years, when baby boomers start to retire. "The aging of the baby boom generation," he said, "requires that changes be made to insure that the Social Security trust fund will remain solvent in the long run."
Specifically, Mr. Lugar said, "it will be necessary to continue the very gradual increase" in the age of eligibility for Social Security benefits, to reflect increases in life expectancy.
Mr. Alexander, Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Dole, Mr. Forbes and Mr. Gramm all supported a simpler tax system, with fewer rates. Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Forbes and Mr. Gramm said they supported a flat tax. Senator Dole and Mr. Alexander said they favored a flatter, fairer, simpler tax system.
In contrast, Senator Lugar said, as he had before, that he would scrap income taxes entirely, in favor of a national retail sales tax of 17 percent. Such an approach, he said, would increase savings, productivity and economic growth.
Several Republicans, including Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm, said they would reduce Federal estate taxes. Mr. Buchanan said, "We should abolish the inheritance tax on family farms and small businesses by increasing the standard exemption on estates to $5 million."
Under current law, estates valued at $600,000 or less are exempt from Federal tax. The budget bill passed last year by Congress and vetoed by Mr. Clinton would have gradually increased the exemption to $750,000. The Administration contends that this proposal would have benefited a small number of wealthy people at a high cost to other taxpayers.

HEADLINE: In Uneasy Time, Saudi Prince Provides a Hope of Stability

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Every Tuesday they come, petitioners by the hundreds -- bearded sheiks, tribal elders, impoverished Saudis and some of the country's elite -- to seek out the man who is poised to become the next king.
With burning incense, vast carpets and crystal chandeliers, the nighttime gathering is unquestionably a royal affair. But as even the humblest visitors step forward, each is allowed a moment to make his case face to face. 
 At a time when living standards are falling and religious militancy is on the rise, these are uneasy days for Saudi Arabia, whose 74-year-old ruler, King Fahd, suffered a stroke in November and has transferred power to his half-brother.
But tribal traditions like the weekly councils remain an important cohesive force in the conservative kingdom. And many Saudis have come to regard the heir, Crown Prince Abdullah, as a leader whose careful attention to the rite and to public concerns may be a sign of his capacity to head off trouble.
In a Government portrayed by critics as corrupt, the ascetic-looking Crown Prince, 72, carries a reputation for probity. And while relations between the royal family and the powerful Islamic religious establishment remain strained, the Crown Prince's standing is enhanced by the fact that he has played no part in a crackdown on suspected militants that remains a source of tension.
"Abdullah is more a Bedouin than a city dweller," a leading Saudi businessman said. "Since he was a child he has liked to sit with the people, and he has been used as a conduit to the religious leaders. By background and by temperament, he will at least be better able to deflect some of the criticism."
For now, Saudi officials have minimized the seriousness of King Fahd's illness, saying he suffers only from overwork. Even since being handed power on Jan. 1, Crown Prince Abdullah has emphasized that he is acting only on his brother's behalf.
"He's in good health, and now he's convalescing," the Saudi Information Minister, Fouad Farsi, said of King Fahd in an interview last week. "But it was thought advisable that he should delegate his power to the Crown Prince while he is convalescing because, after all, running a country is not a trivial affair."
The West, with its heavy reliance on Saudi Arabia for oil and as a bulwark against regional antagonists like Iran and Iraq, has nevertheless already focused on what many diplomats here expect to be a permanent transfer of power.
And after the shock of a bombing in the Saudi capital in November that killed five Americans and two Indians, many Saudis also admit to paying closer heed to the implications of a handover that would make the Crown Prince the fifth son of King Abdel Aziz to succeed his father to the throne, which was established 64 years ago.
Despite the discomfort expressed by many here about Saudi Arabia's reliance on Western security guarantees, Western diplomats and many Saudis have expressed confidence that Abdullah will not cut back the ties that his family has long described as a necessary evil.
But while these experts said they believed that the 200 American, British and French warplanes and several thousand American military personnel now in Saudi Arabia will remain, they said the prince might prove more resistant to future American requests for Saudi help.
Describing the Crown Prince as even more attuned than King Fahd to domestic public opinion, the experts say they see no chance that he would approve a long-frustrated American quest to place an armored brigade's worth of military equipment in Saudi Arabia as a contingency against new Iraqi aggression.
"I don't expect somersaults, and I don't expect any unraveling," a Western ambassador said. "But I do expect some questioning of certain aspects of American policy that have tended to take Saudi Arabia for granted."
At a time when the ruling Saud family is being portrayed by dissidents outside the kingdom as increasingly remote, the prospect of such hiccups is not seen as alarming by those who believe that the most important priority for the Saudi Government is to find a way to quell domestic dissent.
"Everyone knows that Fahd had an ill-spent youth," a Western diplomat said of the King, who had a reputation as a playboy before he took power in 1982. "The same cannot be said about Abdullah. That makes it almost impossible to accuse him of hypocrisy, and it makes it possible that he will look less kindly on royal overindulgence."
It remains an open question how far any Saudi leader can or will go to address the country's underlying problems. While Saudi Arabia remains the world's largest oil producer and exporter, declining oil revenues and a fast-growing population have seen the country's per-capita income plunge from $21,000 in 1981 to just $6,800 today. And with half the population under 15, unemployment looms as the next big crisis.
In one important response, the royal family moved last June to shuffle the Cabinet, replacing several long-serving ministers with younger, better educated successors in the most extensive shake-up in 20 years. Austerity measures that increased the cost of electricity and other basic services have been introduced in an attempt to close the country's yawning budget deficit.
But this year's budget included no new cost-cutting, an apparent concession to growing social discontent that opposition figures led by Mohammed al-Massari, a , London-based Saudi dissident, have sought to exploit.
In a country accustomed to oil wealth, the new financial pressures have complicated the royal family's task of maintaining public support. But Saudis and Western diplomats have expressed hope that Crown Prince Abdullah, by background and instincts, may be well equipped to ease some of the tensions.
A committed horseman who has commanded the Saudi National Guard since 1962, the Crown Prince, who vacations in Morocco and has a stutter, would bring a very different image to the Saudi throne than the glib King Fahd, who has long favored European escapes and is seriously overweight.
The son of a Bedouin mother, the Crown Prince is not part of the Sudeiri clan that bonds King Fahd and his full brothers, including Prince Sultan, 68, the Defense Minister, who is second in line for the throne; Prince Salman, the Governor of Riyadh, and Prince Nayef, the Interior Minister.
Because the Crown Prince is already well into his 70's, the long-term relationship between the Saud family and the Saudi people may not be determined until the mantle passes from the sons of King Abdel Aziz to the grandsons, a shift that is not expected for at least a decade.
Abdullah has been spared attacks from critics like Mr. Massari, whose broadsides against the Saud family have found an avid audience among Saudis who read them via fax and electronic mail.
The dissident, who has been ordered to leave Britain, said last week that he remained determined to topple the Saudi Government no matter who headed it. But Mr. Massari has also gone out of his way to describe Abdullah as "less corrupt" than other members of the royal family, including Prince Sultan, whom the dissident has made his favorite target.
Since King Fahd was hospitalized in late November, there has been no sign of a jockeying for position among his surviving sons, continuing an orderly tradition that has withstood crisis and assassination.
From King Abdel Aziz al-Saud, who took power in 1932, the crown has been handed to his sons Saud in 1954, Faisal in 1962, Khalid in 1975 and Fahd in 1982, and Saudi officials say it has long been clear that it would be passed in turn to Crown Prince Abdullah, who holds the title of First Deputy Prime Minister.
In a country whose leaders draw legitimacy from their role as protectors of the Islamic holy sites in Mecca and Medina, the Crown Prince has maintained good relations with the religious establishment, whose traditional alliance with the Saud family was strained by the arrests last year.
At least 100 people remain behind bars, including the suspected leaders of the Muslim militants, Salman bin Fahd al-Audeh and Safar bin Abdel Rahman al-Hawali, and some Islamic activists say they believe that anger over the crackdown may have given rise to the Nov. 13 bombing here, for which three Saudi opposition groups have claimed responsibility.
Many Saudis who hold strong Islamic views believe that the militants are being unfairly punished for criticizing the Government. Because Crown Prince Abdullah did not play a public part in the roundup, some of these Saudis say he may be in a position to mend fences with the critics and with religious leaders sympathetic to their complaints, some of whom he has made a habit of visiting at times of Islamic feasts.
For now, the most visible evidence of those skills is on display at the weekly council, or majlis, in which the Crown Prince opens his palace gates virtually to all comers.
Other members of the royal family also play host to the traditional gatherings, to which citizens carry crumpled written appeals for intervention and assistance, but none are on the scale of Abdullah's and none carry so common a touch. With no visible sign of security -- although King Faisal was shot dead by a nephew during a similar reception in 1975 -- as many as 500 men took turns before him last week, each stepping forward to perch atop a stool and explain face to face why he had come.
Some bent to kiss the Crown Prince's right shoulder in a gesture of respect, but in a response that is unusual here, a court chamberlain tried to quash such signs of deference.
"Shake hands only," he directed, over and over again.

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS LACK CONSENSUS ON HOW TO BAR SHUTDOWN

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
United in disdain for President Clinton's latest budget proposals and convinced that no deal is in sight, Congressional Republicans acknowledged today that they had not agreed on how to keep the Government open and avoid defaulting on its bonds.
The current stopgap spending authority will expire next Friday, and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, pleaded ignorance of House plans at a news conference. 
 "I don't know precisely what they have in mind," Mr. Dole said.
Representative Robert L. Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee, said he was having his staff prepare a bill that would provide money only for programs that Republicans favor. But he might not put it forward, Mr. Livingston said, because the Senate might reject it or the President might veto it.
"The situation is rather dynamic and fluid right now," he said. "It's changing every minute.
At the White House, President Clinton insisted that an overall budget deal was "clearly within our grasp right now." [Page B7.]
But Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee, said, "It appears as though we have some irreconcilable differences."
The Republicans seemed content to forget further negotiations and make the budget their chief election issue in the fall. The party's Congressional leaders, who have had at least three desultory discussions by telephone conference call since their last session with Mr. Clinton on Jan. 9, plan several face-to-face meetings beginning Monday to develop a spending strategy. They also intend to consider how to deal with raising the ceiling on the national debt, whose statutory limit of $4.9 trillion was reached on Nov. 15.
Since the limit was reached, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has met Government financial obligations by juggling pension accounts, angering Republicans who thought they had a fool-proof weapon to force capitulation from a President who would not risk default.
Republican leaders have pledged not to shut down the Government again, and some of them, like Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia and Mr. Kasich, have promised action to raise the debt limit. Mr. Dole clearly favors such action, too, as does a big majority of senators.
In the House, however, Republicans disagree sharply about how to get that done, particularly since most of them feel revulsion about voting to allow a bigger debt.
"I don't think we can pass a clean-debt limit," Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania, a longtime Gingrich ally, said today. But Mr. Walker said that a bill raising the limit, while prohibiting Mr. Rubin from any more creative trust-fund borrowing, could pass.
Such a restriction might prompt Mr. Clinton to reject the bill, said Representative Steve Gunderson, Republican of Wisconsin, but in that case "we can say, 'Don't blame us. Clinton vetoed it.' "
That is almost certainly the sentiment among a majority of House Republicans, although it also has some sharp critics in the party.
"I don't believe it works politically," said Representative Marge Roukema of New Jersey, "and it certainly doesn't work as a responsible financial tactic. A fiscally responsible Republican Party should never be associated with that kind of a tactic. It's not a question of blame; it's a question of responsibility."
Mr. Dole said he had discussed the debt issue on Wednesday with Mr. Gingrich and other Republican leaders, "but we reached no final resolution." House leaders had not decided what conditions to attach to an increase in the debt ceiling, he said, adding, "They are going to have to attach something to it."
The majority leader was reported by aides to be considering asking the Senate to pass both a bill increasing the debt limit without conditions and a straight one- or two-month stopgap spending bill for all Government programs for which regular appropriations have not been passed, rather than picking and choosing among them. Mr. Dole might do so as early as Tuesday to blunt anticipated complaints in Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Message, which will be delivered that night.
Mr. Dole's press secretary, Clarkson Hine, declined to discuss those reports by aides.
The President remained the most publicly enthusiastic about prospects for resuming negotiations on the budget, and his attitude prompted Republicans, as it has before, to speculate that he wants an agreement but is held back by his Democratic allies.
Representative David L. Hobson, Republican of Ohio, said, "A number of people feel the President's in a box, that he really wants to make a deal. Our guys want to make a deal, but they can't get him removed from his handlers."
Referring to Vice President Al Gore and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, Mr. Hobson said: "Nobody believes Gore wants to make a deal or Gephardt wants to make a deal. They want capitulation."
Whatever their true estimates of the prospects, neither side wants to be in the position of proclaiming all prospects dead for reaching agreement on balancing the budget in seven years.
Even Mr. Kasich later hedged his "irreconcilable" phrase to say, "I have never in my mind ever written off the possibility that one day they will march in a room and lay down something that really will balance the budget and save the next generation and guarantee the children an opportunity."
Not only would proclaiming failure hurt in the polls by suggesting a lack of purpose, but it could carry economic risks, too, and neither side wants to be blamed for a decline in the markets.
For the past few weeks, Secretary Rubin has been repeating the same message to all participants in White House meetings: If the talks collapse, let the news out gently.
"We just need to soften the effects on the market," he warned a week ago after a 160-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average in two days.
Mr. Rubin's strategy seems to have worked. Day by day, the prospects for a deal have receded. But the gradations of warnings have been so subtle that the breakdown on Wednesday came as no surprise; today the market climbed substantially.
Republicans also continued to say that even if they did not succeed in negotiating a balanced budget or legislating one, their hopes would not die.
"If we can't override a veto, we'll go to the country in November," Mr. Gingrich said today while raising money for Republicans in Goldsboro, N.C. The party's message, he said, would be, "Give us a Republican President with a signature pen instead of a veto pen in the White House, and we'll finish the job."
Later, in Raleigh, N.C., Mr. Gingrich said he might bring the President's last budget proposal up for a vote in the House next week to show that it could not pass. That would also measure how much Democratic discontent the proposal engendered; it might well not get a majority even of House Democrats.
House leaders will confer among themselves on Monday and with the entire Republican membership on Tuesday. The spending question is likely to be central, rather than budget talks, which are in limbo, or even the debt limit, because the real deadline on that remains uncertain.
Mr. Livingston, the Appropriations Committee chairman, said that there was no way the President could get more money in any spending bill without a budget deal, and that there was strong sentiment to tighten already restrictive temporary spending levels.
But, he said, "in order to avoid a shutdown, we've got to find something that will pass," not only in the House, but also in the Senate, and then be signed by the President.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Caterpillar Earnings, in a Surprise, Rise by 7.5%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 18

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said today that earnings rose 7.5 percent in the fourth quarter, surprising analysts, who had expected a decline, and sending the company's stock up 10 percent.
At the same time, however, the maker of heavy equipment warned that growth may slow this year. 
 Caterpillar said net income rose to $300 million, or $1.53 a share, in the quarter from $279 million, or $1.38 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Analysts had expected the company to report a decline in per-share earnings to $1.26, according to a survey by First Call, and Caterpillar's stock rose $5.375, to close at $59.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was about 4.9 million shares, more than six times the stock's average daily volume.
Caterpillar's strength helped pull up the stock market over all.
Revenue rose 7.3 percent, to $4.21 billion from $3.93 billion. Caterpillar said that revenue in the latest quarter matched the highest level for any quarter in its history and that the sales increase was the biggest reason for the profit gain.
While sales in the United States fell 2 percent in the quarter, sales abroad rose 15 percent.
This year, Caterpillar said, a weaker economy in the United States, combined with a drop in demand for replacement equipment, is expected to result in a lower appetite for the machines and engines the company makes. In particular, Caterpillar said, demand for heavy-duty trucks is expected to drop sharply from its 1995 peak.
Caterpillar added, though, that sales could increase if moderate economic growth continued in the United States throughout the year, rather than weaker growth and a mild recession.
Gary McManus, an analyst at J. P. Morgan, said: "It was a good quarter, but we still believe that going forward it's going to be difficult. We're looking for construction equipment to be down domestically."
Mr. McManus said that Caterpillar was aided by the dollar's weakness last year. A weaker dollar makes Caterpillar's exports less expensive in terms of other currencies. "I'm not willing to bet the dollar goes down from here," Mr. McManus said.
In reporting earnings, Caterpillar said that almost all its striking employees had returned to work. A 17-month strike was called off in December.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strong Microsoft Profit Exceeds Wall St. Estimates
Microsoft earnings exceeded Wall Street estimates for the latest quarter. Profits came in at $575 million, or 90 cents a share, up 54 percent from $373 million, or 60 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Wall Street analysts had forecast a profit of about 84 cents. On a day when technology stocks rose sharply, Microsoft was up $2.75, to $87.625. [Page D2.]
 
Dow Jumps on Good Earnings
Stocks climbed as surprisingly strong fourth-quarter earnings overcame traders' pessimism about the stalled budget negotiations in Washington. Strong earnings at I.B.M. and Caterpillar led the Dow. I.B.M. rose 8 5/8, to 96 1/4, and Caterpillar increased 5 3/8 to 59 1/4; together they were responsible for almost 70 percent of the gain in the Dow average, which climbed 57.45 points, to 5,124.35. [D6.]
 
New Bidding for Maybelline
L'Oreal increased its offer to buy Maybelline, to $41 a share, outdoing a bid of $37 from Benckiser of Germany. Maybelline shares jumped $2.875, to $42.375. [D2.]
 
Hilton to Keep Gambling Unit
Hilton Hotels said it was no longer considering spinning off its gambling operations. The company's shares rose $1, to $69.125. [D2.]
 
Paine Webber to Pay $175 Million
Paine Webber agreed to settle charges that its brokers misled investors in limited partnerships and will provide $175 million to settle the claims. [D2.]
 
G.E. Ends Strong Year
G.E. had strong earnings in the fourth quarter, lifted by NBC and its finance and plastics divisions. Net rose to $1.87 billion. [D2.]
 
Kodak earned $375 million, in line with expectations, but its stock fell sharply. [D6.]
 
McDonnell Douglas had a net loss in the fourth quarter, after a $1.12 billion charge, but profit from operations rose 13 percent. [D17.]
 
Xerox Selling Insurance Division
Xerox agreed to sell its property and casualty insurance subsidiary, Talegen Holdings, to a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Talegen management for $2.7 billion. [D3.]
 
Republicans Search for Strategy
Congressional Republicans conceded that they had not found a way to keep the Government open and avoid defaulting on its bonds. [A1.]
 
Beta Carotene Found Ineffective
Beta carotene is ineffective in preventing cancer or heart disease, two studies found. One said it may even be harmful. [A16.]
 
Bacterium Genome Traced
A biotechnology company said it has detailed 99 percent of the genome of a common bacterium. Its stock rose 26 percent. [A14.]
 
Ailes Resigns From CNBC
Roger Ailes, the former Republican media consultant who joined CNBC in 1993, resigned yesterday as president of the cable business news channel. And NBC, which owns CNBC, announced a restructuring of the channel's management. Mr. Ailes said one reason for his resignation was NBC's decision to move CNBC under a company-wide sales department instead of allowing it to run its own sales operation. [D4.]
 
A Buying Opportunity in Apple?
Apple Computer shares tumbled to a 52-week low after the company lost $69 million. But one analyst, citing Apple's "terrific product franchise," sees it as a good contrarian buy. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: On Trade, Buchanan Strikes a Chord

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Patrick J. Buchanan (Op-Ed, Jan. 17) writes that the true measure of economic success is "whether the standard of living of America's middle class is steadily rising." 
 Many middle-class families have two homes and two cars and far better than adequate food. Is their increased well-being really the standard of our economic success rather than the increased well-being of our neediest people, who lack adequate housing and nutrition?
The poor don't vote and finance politicians, as does the middle class. The poor aren't where the money or the votes are.
Mr. Buchanan suggests that if a flat tax is adopted, it should incorporate a deduction for mortgage interest, which he says is "rooted in middle-class values." But the deductibility of interest on mortgages imposes an unfair burden on those who pay rent, which is not tax deductible.
I've rented an apartment for 38 years and am unlikely ever to own a home. Are my values any less wholesome or worthy of support?
My point here is the hypocrisy of Mr. Buchanan and other flat-taxers, who would have us believe that theirs is an equitable plan devoid of politics.
 
RICHARD ROSENTHAL
New York, Jan. 18, 1996

HEADLINE: A 'Living Wage' Law Would Benefit New York

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re " 'Living Wages,' Fewer Jobs" (Op-Ed, Jan. 12) by Heather Mac Donald: 
 I am the prime sponsor of New York City's "living wage" bill, which would require companies with city contracts to pay their workers $12.10 an hour, including benefits. When Ms. Mac Donald refers to Baltimore's living wage law, she says the hourly wage is $6.60. She omits that it will be raised to $7.70 in two years and also guarantees health benefits, bringing the hourly wage to above $10 an hour.
Contrary to Ms. Mac Donald's assertions, the cost to Baltimore has been negligible, and there is no evidence that it has led to fewer jobs or has harmed the poor.
Ms. Mac Donald asserts that New York's living wage law would cost taxpayers at least $500 million. This is an inflated estimated provided by City Hall, which opposes the legislation. Actually, it would save the city millions because many of the workers would receive health benefits and would not wind up in our emergency rooms when they get sick.
There are tangible benefits of the law: Workers would have more money to recycle in their communities and more time to spend with their families and to contribute to the civic life of their communities.
Ms. Mac Donald implies that the city's use of private contractors is efficient and cost effective. However, she ignores that Constance Cushman, former executive director of the city's Procurement Policy Board, estimates that abuses in the city's contract budget cost taxpayers about $2 billion a year.
Ms. Mac Donald is correct in saying there is no legislative short cut to creating good jobs at decent wages. However, government does have an obligation to insure that people who work full time are not mired in poverty.
 
SAL F. ALBANESE
Council Member, 43d Dist., Brooklyn
New York, Jan. 12, 1996

HEADLINE: Egypt Downplays News Of Sheik's Sentencing

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
After years in which Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman was a symbol of this country's turbulence, the apparent end of the militant cleric's career has been met here with a satisfaction that is reflected in official silence.
In not gloating at the life sentence given to the sheik in a New York courtroom on Wednesday for his role in an assassination and bombing plot, the Government may have been reluctant to inflame those who may sympathize with Mr. Abdel Rahman's view that the trial against him was part of a Western war against Islam. 
 But the low profile given to the case here has also displayed the determination of the Egyptian Government to show it has put the worst of the country's instability behind it. Although Mr. Abdel Rahman's fiery preachings had for more than a decade given inspiration to those trying to overthrow the secular Government and replace it with Islamic rule, the Government believes that they have become increasingly isolated.
While the charges on which Mr. Abdel Rahman was convicted in New York included plotting a 1993 assassination attempt against President Hosni Mubarak, the country's main Government-controlled newspaper, Al Ahram, carried the news of his sentencing today on an inside page devoted to crime.
"We do not want to comment on this issue," a senior Government official said. "We want to concentrate on more important things: foreign investment, development and our economy."
After failing five times to convict the sheik for crimes he allegedly committed in Egypt, including conspiring in the 1981 assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, Egyptian officials are plainly relieved that a court has finally put Mr. Abdel Rahman behind bars. That it was an American court has also simplified matters for Egyptian authorities, who by imprisoning Mr. Abdel Rahman here might have handed the militants a kind of living martyr.
But while Mr. Abdel Rahman's use of the United States as a platform for his views was infuriating to Egyptian authorities, the threat that he and his followers pose has clearly faded in Egyptian eyes as the Government has scored major successes in suppressing the militants' four-year-old campaign of violence.
Under the leadership of the Islamic Group, the most violent of the anti-Government organizations, the militants remain a dangerous force and have recently demonstrated a capacity to carry out attacks abroad. Among the operations for which the Islamic Group has claimed responsibility were an assassination attempt against President Mubarak in Ethiopia last June and the bombing in November of the Egyptian Embassy in Pakistan, which left 16 dead.
But in Egypt itself, the militants have continued to pose a major challenge to the authorities only in the country's south. And while the Government still imposes strict emergency powers, a Government that has been preoccupied with internal security has begun to turn some of its attention to spurring the country's slow-growing economy.
Since the trial of Mr. Abdel Rahman and his followers began, the official line has been that the United States gave undue notoriety to the sheik and his followers, and playing down his sentencing was clearly intended to convey the impression that the Government has been successful in putting down the terrorist threat.
"It is the American media that made another Ayatollah Khomeini out of Omar Abdel Rahman," a senior Egyptian official said. "The issue is of no direct concern to us."
The extent of the Government's crackdown on militants and their backers has made ordinary Egyptians wary of expressing views that might be interpreted as endorsing the militants. Since Mr. Abdel Rahman's sentencing, a spokesman for Egypt's largest and most popular Islamic group, the Muslim Brotherhood, has declined to comment except to question whether the defendants received a fair trial.
Independent analysts here have said they believe that the current weakness of the militant groups in Egypt makes it unlikely that either the Islamic Group or its smaller shadow, known as Jihad or Holy War, will retaliate for the sentencing.
"Here we have a state throwing its whole weight behind the fight against these groups," said Negad al-Borai, the secretary general of the Egyptian Organization for Human Rights, who said the groups' capacity to wage violence had been "severely reduced."
But a lawyer who led the legal team that defended Mr. Abdel Rahman in each of his five trials in Egypt said he believed the outcome of the American trial would ultimately strengthen the hand of the Islamic movement here.
"Let the Americans know that exterminating Omar Abdel Rahman will not put an end to the Islamic revival," said the lawyer, Abdel Halim Mandur. "The numbers of people joining the Islamic reawakening is multiplying whether America likes it or not. It is a matter of faith."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 23; Column 3; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 660 words

HEADLINE: A New Kind of Party Animal

BYLINE: By Michele Mitchell; Michele Mitchell writes a political column for the Transom, an on-line service for 18- to 35-year-olds.

DATELINE: Washington

 BODY:
To Dick Morris and the rest of the Presidential packagers taking over the country in the coming months, 27-year-old Matt Myers is a nightmare.
 In 1986, the college student from Orange County, California, registered as a Republican; in 1992, he registered as a Democrat. By the 1994 midterm elections, Mr. Myers had become so disgusted with both parties that he signed up as a member of California's newly formed Green Party.
 
 Mr. Myers exemplifies the under-35 voter. They have no pparty loyalty, but they can make a difference in an election. In 1992, 37 percent of those registered voted, the highest turnout for that age group in any election since 1972. Bill Clinton, who chatted with Tabitha Soren on MTV during the campaign, won more than 40 percent of that vote. Ross Perot, running strongly with the older half of this bloc, won 19 percent.
 But President Clinton cannot necessarily count on the same level of support this year. Although he has fulfilled some of his campaign promises, like establishing a national service program, he has failed young voters on bread-and-butter issues.
 For instance, according to the latest numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, people under 25 have the highest unemployment rate, 11.3 percent, of any group. And the President's health-care plan drew protests in 1993 from many groups representing young voters because they felt that the economic burden would fall disproportionately on young workers.
 But the under-35's have not become Republicans. In the 1994 Congressional elections, many stayed home (only 16 percent voted), or, like Mr. Myers, they registered with an independent or alternative party.
 After 1994, membership in the Libertarian Party increased by 20 percent; as many as 40 percent of the newcomers are under 35. The Green Party, established in California in 1990, has a membership of more than 100,000 made up almost entirely of people between the ages of 18 and 35. Most of them, the party's organizers admit, joined not because they believed in the party's environmentalist agenda, but because they wanted political change.
 This could spell trouble for President Clinton. He need only look to political arithmetic in the Republican stronghold of Orange County. In 1988, Vice President Bush took the county by more than 500,000 votes. But four years later, the returns were mixed: 427,000 voted for Mr. Bush, 307,000 for Mr. Clinton and 232,000 for Mr. Perot. Thanks to strong support for Mr. Clinton in Northern California and Los Angeles, the state went Democratic.
 The critical factor, says Kim Alexander, executive director of the California Voter Foundation, was the under-35 vote. This group voted in record numbers in California (23 percent went to the polls, a turnout higher than that of senior citizens) to support Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot.
 No one knows what this group will do in 1996, says Curtis Gans, director of the Center for the American Electorate, which researches voting behavior. "They have no party affiliation or loyalty," he explains, "and they don't see voting for someone other than a Democrat or a Republican as throwing away their vote. They see it as an investment in change."
 A recent Field poll asked Californians whom they would vote for in a three-way Presidential election: President Clinton, Senator Bob Dole or the Green Party candidate, Ralph Nader. Eleven percent of Californians said they would vote for Mr. Nader. Even if he ended up with 3 percent to 5 percent of the vote, that might be enough to cost President Clinton the state.
 Meanwhile, Matt Myers of Orange County says he is listening to the Republican Presidential candidates. "None of the candidates are very good," he told me. "I don't know what I'm going to do in November." The Republicans and Democrats should be forewarned. If Mr. Myers and sizable numbers of voters under 35 do turn out at the polls, they are not likely to waste their opportunity.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Europeans Move to Cut Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday amid expectations of further interest rate cuts in Europe and speculation that leading industrial nations will endorse a stronger dollar at a weekend meeting.
The dollar surpassed 1.48 German marks for the first time in four months. It also rose to four-month highs against the Swiss and French francs and a 19-month high against the British pound.
Britain, France and the Netherlands trimmed official interest rates yesterday and many investors are betting that Germany will soon follow suit. The Bundesbank left its discount rate unchanged yesterday, after lowering a key money-market rate Wednesday. Lower rates in Europe often help the dollar by making United States deposit more attractive. 
 "Interest rates in Europe have been coming down even faster than here," said Ray Goodner, who helps manage $1 billion in international bonds at American Express Financial Advisers in Minneapolis. "There's widespread concern about the European economies."
Ricardo Gomes, head of foreign exchange at Republic National Bank in New York, said the dollar could rise to 1.55 marks during the next month, a level not seen in a year. "The mark is not quite the star it was, especially with the German economy so weak," he said.
So far this year the dollar has gained 3 percent against the mark, after falling 7.2 percent last year. Yesterday, it rose as high as 1.4845 marks, its highest since Sept. 20, when it reached 1.4897 marks.
It was last quoted at 1.4802 marks, up from 1.4750 late Thursday in New York, and 105.32 yen, little changed from 105.63 yen late Thursday. Against the French franc, the dollar rose to 5.0536 francs from 5.0370 francs Thursday. The pound fell to $1.5120 from $1.5163.
The dollar also drew strength from speculation that finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrial nations would discuss ways to push it higher when they met this weekend in Paris. The mark's chronic strength against the dollar has hurt Germany's economy by making the country's exports less competitive.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin reiterated yesrterday that the Clinton Administration favored a strong dollar, fueling talk that the ministers might endorse a further rise in the dollar. On Thursday, he said the Group of Seven would "examine what policies are appropriate to reinforce the recovery" in Germany and Japan. The group is made up of the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada.
The dollar rose against most other major currencies, rising to 1.1933 Swiss francs from 1.1896 francs. It held steady at 1,583.5 Italian lira. The Canadian dollar rose to 73.19 United States cents from 73.31 cents.

HEADLINE: Jobs Data Send Most Bond Prices Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of all Treasury securities except the 30-year bond were down yesterday, as many investors sold on what is considered negative economic news for the bond market, although it is good for most everyone else.
A batch of Government reports painted the jobs situation as healthy, showed improvement in the troubled manufacturing sector and suggested moderating overall growth. For market participants the stronger-than-expected data suggested that a rate cut at this month's Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Jan. 30-31 was not automatic.
The price of the 30-year benchmark bond gained 4/32 , after being down as much as 17/32 in morning trading, to finish the New York session at 11215/32 , sending its yield down to 5.97 percent from 5.98 percent on Thursday. 
 The Labor Department's report on the number of jobs added to the economy -- 151,000 in December -- was called conservative by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich on CNBC yesterday.
Mr. Reich said seasonal adjustments more than compensated for striking Boeing employees, depressing the December estimate of nonfarm payrolls. "Because of seasonal factors, this is a four-week reporting period as opposed to the usual five-week reporting period," he said. "It actually may be higher than 151,000." Analysts also note that because of surges in employment over the holiday period, seasonal adjustments tend to hold down December's payroll numbers.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said the market had been looking for about 125,000. So while the economy is slowing, he said, it is not slowing as much as many thought.
"Year-over-year payroll growth in the fourth quarter dropped to a level of 1.6 percent as compared to 2 percent in the third quarter, and 3.1 percent at this time a year ago," Mr. Fine said.
In similar fashion the revision of the gross domestic product figures also displayed a slowing of economic growth, but with virtually no signs of recession.
"After all these revisions year- over-year G.D.P. growth is 1.9 percent, which is less than previously estimated by the Commerce Department and very much in line with the slowdown we saw in payroll growth," Mr. Fine said.
"I think it is important," he continued, "for people to distinguish between an economy that is slowing as opposed to one that has stopped in its tracks. At the same time with numbers such as these this morning, the Fed is still likely to lean toward ease. But at this juncture it seems more likely that any further easing move would come at the March F.O.M.C. as opposed to the upcoming meeting this month."
And as for consumer and inflation numbers, Mr. Fine said, the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index and the Columbia University leading inflation index, both out late in the morning, had little impact on the market.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, "One has to remember that while the market consensus viewed the economy as being in critical condition prior to the release of this morning's payroll numbers, the actual results of the employment report suggested that the economy was in fact in stable condition."
He added that that was a surprise that "was generally not well received by the bond markets."
The market did manage to experience a small short-lived rally in the afternoon, as buyers were encouraged by lower oil prices, thanks to expectations of a resumption of Iraqi oil sales. With prices down there is less fear of inflation accelerating.
Volume was thinner in the afternoon and price changes were exaggerated. There were reports of a few large hedge funds in the market buying maturities of 10 years and higher, and that led to some short-cover buying by those wanting either to protect profits or cut their losses.
Next week the Treasury will be selling $30.25 billion of new two- and five-year notes in addition to $23 billion of new three- and six-month bills at its regular weekly Monday auction.

HEADLINE: Pataki and Legislative Leaders Agree on Interstate Banking Bill

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders have agreed on a bill that would open up banking in New York by bringing the state into line with new Federal regulations.
Under the bill, banks chartered in New York would be able to operate in states that have also agreed to the Federal regulations, while banks from these states would be able to buy banks in New York.
The Federal regulations, part of the Riegle-Neal Interstate Banking and Branching Efficiency Act of 1994, are intended to increase competition in the banking industry. They automatically go into effect for the entire country in 1997, unless states specifically choose not to take part. 
 By adopting the provisions before then, officials said they hoped to give New York banks a jump on those in the states that have not done so.
The bill now goes to the Senate and the Assembly, where passage is assured.
Twenty states, including Connecticut, have agreed to the provisions of the Riegle-Neal Act, according to the Conference of State Bank Supervisors. The New Jersey Legislature is considering a bill similar to the one in New York.
New York officials, including Governor Pataki, Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said the bill announced on Thursday would prepare the state's banks for an era of fewer regulations.
"Passage of the interstate banking and branching provisions contained in my legislation will help New York maintain its worldwide pre-eminence in the banking field," Mr. Pataki said.
Federally chartered banks can already operate in New York. Under the bill, banks from other states could do business in New York only by buying existing state-chartered banks, not by opening up their own branches.
The bill would also require surveillance cameras, reflective mirrors, adequate lighting and other security measures at most automatic teller machines in the state. The legislation would set fines of $2,500 for violations of these new security rules, which were developed with Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco. They do not apply to teller machines in places like supermarkets or airports.
The security provisions in the bill would not take effect in New York City, which already has stricter security rules for teller machines.
"A.T.M.'s are a convenient source for cash and unfortunately a growing target for crime," Mr. Silver said. "This bill seeks to increase the safety and security of consumers who rely more and more on A.T.M.'s for banking services."

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear S.& L. Case

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the Federal Government's appeal in a case that could add billions of dollars to the cost of cleaning up the residue of the savings and loan disaster of the 1980's.
In a closely watched case, the Government is appealing the finding of a Federal appeals court here that a Congressional change of heart over how to value the liabilities of failed savings and loans amounted to a monumental breach of the Government's contracts with those healthy institutions that Federal regulators had invited to take over the ailing ones.
The accounting changes, included in the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989, turned healthy balance sheets overnight into ones that could not meet minimum capital requirements. 
 Some savings and loans failed as a result and others, like Glendale Federal Bank, the only survivor of the three savings and loans involved in the case before the Court, managed to raise money in the private markets and emerged weakened and in debt.
Glendale, which is owned by GlenFed Inc., based in Glendale, Calif., is seeking $1.5 billion from the Government for losses involved in its acquisition of an insolvent institution, First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Broward County, Fla. If the Supreme Court upholds the lower court's decision, after an argument to be held in April, the case will return to the Court of Federal Claims for a trial on damages. There are some 100 similar cases in the pipeline, leading Solicitor General Drew S. Days 3d to tell the Justices in the Government's appeal that its ultimate liability would be approximately $10 billion.
The two other savings and loans in the case are Statesman Savings Holding Corporation and Winstar Corporation. Both no longer exist. Statesman, based in Iowa, had acquired a failing savings and loan in West Palm Beach, Fla. and three in Waterloo, Iowa. Winstar was an investment partnership formed in 1984 to acquire the Windom Federal Savings and Loan Association in Minnesota.
Glendale stock fell today on the prospect that the Supreme Court might reject the appeals court ruling that favored the company. The stock fell more than 6 percent, losing $1.125, to $16.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange..
In one respect, this is a straightforward breach-of-contract case, albeit one with high stakes. The legal issues, as framed by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in its 9-to-2 decision last August, are not particularly complex. But the case also raises interesting questions about how much discretion the Government should have in its role as a regulator to change course and leave the private sector to pay the bills.
The case, United States v. Winstar, No. 95-865, has its roots in the savings and loan crisis of the 1980's, when high interest rates and bad management caused hundreds of institutions to fail. Two regulatory agencies, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, sought out healthy savings and loans that could acquire the insolvent ones and relieve the agencies of the staggering cost of closing them and paying off the depositors' insurance.
Because the huge liabilities of insolvent savings and loans made them unattractive merger candidates, the bank board permitted the acquiring institutions to carry the liabilities as an intangible asset, to be known as "supervisory good will." One of the judges on the Federal Circuit later referred to this phrase as "a euphemism for spinning straw into gold." The liabilities were suddenly deemed to be assets that could be counted as capital and amortized over a period as long as 40 years.
As problems in the industry continued to mount and the regulatory agencies' approach came under increasing criticism, Congress set a new direction by passing the 1989 law. The law increased capital requirements and required the liabilities of the failed institutions to be acknowledged rather than carried as assets.
Glendale, which had capital of only $277 million when it was permitted by Government regulators to count as good will the nearly $750 million of its merger partner's deficits, was required to raise more than $450 million in private capital to stay alive.
The three institutions brought and won lawsuits against the Government in the United States Claims Court here in 1992. Those rulings were overturned the next year by a three-judge panel of the Federal Circuit, a specialized appeals court here that hears financial claims against the Government. The full appeals court then reheard the consolidated case and issued its ruling against the Government last Aug. 31.
In its Supreme Court appeal, the Government is arguing that the appeals court made two basic errors. First, the Government's brief says, the appeals court failed to apply the "unmistakability doctrine," under which the Government should not be contractually bound to exercise its regulatory authority in a particular way unless the contract explicitly promised that a law or regulations would not be changed.
The appeals court said the doctrine did not apply in a case such as this, in which the plaintiffs were not trying to stop the Government from changing its regulations but were seeking monetary damages for their injuries.
In its second argument, the Government said the appeals court failed to apply the "sovereign acts doctrine," under which the Government is immune from liability for enacting a "public and general" policy. The appeals court said the 1989 law was not general policy but rather was intended to "abrogate specific contractual rights."
In another action today, the Court agreed to decide whether suits for injuries from medical devices, in this case a pacemaker, can be brought under state law, or whether such lawsuits are pre-empted once the device has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration and has complied with applicable Federal regulations.
The case, Medtronic Inc. v. Lohr, No. 95-754, is an appeal from a ruling last year by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta. That court permitted a lawsuit contending that a pacemaker that suddenly failed, necessitating emergency surgery, had a defective design.
At the same time, the appeals court ruled that the plaintiff could not challenge the manufacture and labeling of the pacemaker, finding those areas pre-empted. The Justices will also review those aspects of the decision in an appeal brought by the plaintiff, Lohr v. Medtronic, No. 95-886.
