HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Reports Strong Earning on Its Mini-Van Sales

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Buoyed by brisk mini-van sales, the Chrysler Corporation announced unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter earnings today, producing a sharp jump in its stock price and strengthening the hand of the auto maker's management in its efforts to retain control of the company.
Chrysler said it earned $1.04 billion, or $2.70 a share, on sales of $15.06 billion in the quarter. Profits were down slightly from the company's best-ever quarter a year earlier, which included a $132 million one-time tax gain. But profits were considerably above the top Wall Street prediction of $2.30 a share. The company's pretax fourth-quarter earnings set a record.
In the fourth quarter of 1994, Chrysler earned $1.17 billion, or $3.20 a share, on sales of $14.27 billion. 
 Investors welcomed the earnings, bidding up Chrysler's shares by as much as $2.50 a share in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock closed at $54.125 a share, up $1.875.
But Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman, warned that the company might not fare as well this year unless politicians and the Federal Reserve act soon to help the American economy. He said that if the Federal Reserve did not act within 90 days to reduce short-term interest rates by at least half a percentage point, auto industry sales this year would fall below last year's levels.
The earnings, and the investor reaction, appeared to bolster Chrysler's executives in dealing with Kirk Kerkorian, the wealthy Las Vegas, Nev., investor whose company, the Tracinda Corporation, has taken a 14 percent stake in Chrysler. Tracinda has sought a seat on Chrysler's board, questioned whether the company is managed aggressively enough and argued that the company should pay out more money in dividends and stock buybacks.
Anna Cordasco, a spokeswoman for Tracinda, said this evening that the company had no specific reaction to Chrysler's profits. "We are evaluating Chrysler's fourth-quarter results to gain a deeper understanding of the longer-term trends that will affect its business," she said.
Another person in Tracinda's camp said that Tracinda was trying to determine whether Chrysler's results may have been unusually strong because of possible changes in pension assumptions, vehicle inventories and accounting for certain costs. The person spoke on the condition of anonymity.
But Wall Street analysts said that they had underestimated Chrysler's earnings because the company sold more of its redesigned mini-vans than they expected. Chrysler has been particularly successful in offering an optional sliding door on the driver's side of most mini-van models -- a feature chosen by 90 percent of its customers, especially those with small children who like the convenience of buckling babies into child seats from either door.
Chrysler sold 123,764 mini-vans in the United States alone during the fourth quarter of 1995, up from 97,930 in the corresponding quarter of 1994. The Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation do not offer a similar door for their mini-vans.
The extra volume of mini-vans reduced the production cost per vehicle, while profits were high because Chrysler was able to sell the mini-vans without rebates or other discounts, said Michael P. Ward, an auto analyst at Paine Webber. "Clearly the biggest impact on earnings in my opinion was the mini-van," he said.
The mini-vans at Chrysler are particularly profitable because they appeal to highly affluent families who can afford to pay the big sticker prices the vans carry, said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz. "This is a life-style vehicle that is an alternative to luxury cars," she said.
Chrysler's fourth-quarter profits were impressive despite the drop from the final quarter of 1994, said David M. Garrity, an auto analyst at Smith Barney. Chrysler shipped an unusually large number of cars and trucks to dealers during the 1994 fourth quarter in the misplaced expectation that showroom sales would be exceptionally brisk in early 1995. Because car companies count a vehicle as sold when it goes to a dealer, the extra shipments improved the results for the fourth quarter of 1994, Mr. Garrity said.
For all of 1995, Chrysler earned $2.03 billion, or $5.30 a share, on sales of $53.195 billion. In 1994, the company earned $3.71 billion, or $10.11 a share, on sales of $52.24 billion.
Late last year, Chrysler said it changed its accounting treatment for certain sales that caused it to restate its earnings for the first quarter of 1995 to show an after-tax charge of $96 million. The full-year 1995 results were also affected by previously announced pretax charges of $263 million for production changes at one assembly plant and $115 million to replace the rear door latches on mini-vans sold from 1984 until 1994.
Mr. Eaton also said today that the economic slowdown in Mexico had cost the company $300 million in lower pretax earnings. The Mexican economy slumped and car sales there collapsed when the Mexican peso plunged a year ago and monetary authorities raised interest rates steeply.

HEADLINE: U.S. Payrolls Expand but Jobless Rate Remains at 5.6%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Easing fears for the moment that the economy is on the verge of sliding into a recession, the Labor Department reported today that employers added a moderate 151,000 jobs to payrolls in December. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.6 percent.
The first major report on economic performance last month -- delayed two weeks because the Labor Department was closed first by budgetary stalemate and then by a paralyzing blizzard -- was hailed by the Clinton Administration as evidence that the economy continued to expand solidly.
"These numbers show strong and broad-based job growth," contended Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "The economy continues to operate at full capacity with steady growth and low inflation." 
 Nonetheless, many private analysts pointed to disquieting elements of weakness in the monthly tally that might lead to the economy's stalling in the months ahead. To help avoid that, they said, the Federal Reserve may well make another cut in short-term interest rates at its policy meeting at the end of the month.
"The December employment report confirms other data pointing to sluggish activity," Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, told clients. The latest soundings, he said, are "weak enough to induce the Fed to ease policy" at its Jan. 30-31 session.
Susan M. Hering of Salomon Brothers also cast a dubious eye on the job figures even though the increase in payrolls surpassed Wall Street's expectations.
"Job growth seems to be losing some oomph," she said. "One has the sense that things are faltering."
Separately, the Commerce Department formally switched to its new method of appraising the economy that was expected to make growth appear weaker than before. Gross domestic product during the July-September period, now calculated under a more accurate methodology, grew at a pace of 3.2 percent over the summer instead of the 4.1 percent first estimated in late October under the old method.
The new way of measuring the economy also prompted a re-examination of the recent past. Some experts suggested that more accurate data at the time of the 1990-91 recession might have improved President George Bush's re-election prospects by prompting the White House and the Federal Reserve to respond more aggressively to the downturn. The labor market in the Northeast appeared especially weak, its jobless rate climbing five-tenths of a point to 6.2 percent. In New York, the rate rose to 6.4 percent from 6, while unemployment in New Jersey surged to 7.3 percent from 6.1 percent.
But figures for individual states are usually erratic, prompting the Bureau of Labor Statistics -- which was denied funds to enlarge its sampling -- to announce today that it would no longer include figures for 11 major industrial states in the monthly employment situation report.
Officials noted that the California unemployment rate gyrated wildly in recent months, registering 7.8 percent in October, 8.8 in November and 7.7 in December. Monthly changes large enough to be statistically meaningful, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said ruefully, tend also to defy belief.
A large factor swelling payrolls last month was the jump of 52,000 in factory jobs, but 30,000 of those workers were strikers at the Boeing Company and other companies returning to their jobs. An additional 10,000 worked in automobile assembly plants, offsetting November declines involving temporary furloughs while producers cut inventories.
There were several items that tended to undermine the more upbeat interpretations of the report. Aggregate weekly hours worked declined for a second straight month. The number of temporary jobs failed to increase for a third straight month. And the department's household survey, which sometimes varies widely from the generally more reliable payroll data, showed back-to-back declines in employment.
"These figures send a chill up the spine for anyone with a sense of history," said Kenneth T. Mayland, chief financial economist at KeyCorp in Cleveland. "This is a fragile economy," he added, declaring that both the payroll and household surveys now show 12-month job growth at or below the pace prevailing when the country entered recessions in 1980 and 1990.
The prolonged shutdowns of the Labor Department resulted in fewer household interviews than usual but officials said that the results should not have been appreciably affected. As for the payroll data, the delay provided more time for fuller collection from states and thus greater reliability of the preliminary estimates.
Generally less processing time, however, meant an inability to revise figures for November.
Hourly average earnings advanced 5 cents, to $11.63, in December after no change in November, today's report also showed.
For the year, gains in pay were modest. Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, fretted that paychecks rose only 2.3 percent in 1995, not enough to keep up with consumer inflation that ran at a 2.6 percent pace for the 12 months through November.
For the full year, payroll jobs rose 1.7 million, about half as many as in 1994, the report also showed. The household survey, diverging more than usual, posted a job gain of 335,000, barely enough to keep up with growth of the labor force, which has slowed markedly.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the third quarter of 1995 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. The Commerce Department figures are computed using the new "chain weighted" system, which tries to accurately reflect real changes in the economy by accounting for inflation in a continuous manner. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: No Respite From Murder;
City Decline in Killings Is Not Echoed in Bedford-Stuyvesant

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

 BODY:
From the stoop of Junior's bodega in Bedford-Stuyvesant, New York's falling crime rate seems like nothing more than a mirage to Jose Arapioamnou.
Last July, his father-in-law and brother-in-law were killed by a gunman in a robbery outside the store that his in-laws ran at Stuyvesant Avenue and Madison Street, and several months earlier a store down the block had been robbed by five gunmen. 
 "They talk about crime going down on the television," Mr. Arapioamnou, 32, said as he stood in the store's doorway, his arms crossed and eyes undaunted as if he could ward off criminals by sheer force of will. "But every day, all I hear about is more shooting. Every night, my wife kisses me goodbye, I don't know if I'll be coming home alive."
 Despite a variety of community projects intended to revitalize the area and a citywide trend of sharply falling crime rates, Mr. Arapioamnou's Brooklyn neighborhood had the unenviable distinction of having one of New York City's fastest-growing murder rates in 1995.
While much of New York enjoyed something of a respite from the violence that has plagued the city since crack cocaine appeared a decade ago, the 81st Precinct has been terrorized by drug trafficking, gunfire and a 34 percent rise in homicides, according to police statistics. After registering 26 homicides in 1994, the precinct was the scene of 35 murders last year. A street-corner dice game ended in a fatal gunfight. Inside a stately Victorian brownstone, an 80-year-old woman who weighed less than 90 pounds was beaten to death with her cane during a robbery.
There were 13 drug-related killings -- many near Bedford-Stuyvesant's storefront drug locations -- including that of a 35-year-old woman slain by a stray bullet as she pedaled by on a bicycle.
The police say they are beginning to reverse the neighborhood's surge in homicides.
In the fall, they began using more aggressive crime-fighting techniques and have been coordinating narcotics investigations with the Brooklyn District Attorney's Office and the Drug Enforcement Administration. John Maple, Deputy Police Commissioner for Operations, said he was pleased that the 81st Precinct had no homicides between Nov. 4 and year's end. "We're on the right road," he said.
Moreover, other types of crimes have dropped sharply: Auto thefts have decreased by nearly 50 percent in the last two years, and shootings have declined by about a third in the same period. On the other hand, assaults and rapes were up in 1995 over the previous year. And 1996 has begun on an ominous note. The driver of a livery cab was shot and killed on Jan. 4 during a robbery on Gates Avenue. On Thursday night, an off-duty police officer was shot and killed during a dispute at his former girlfriend's house. Some residents fear the neighborhood's crime problem will not ease anytime soon.
"After a while, it just makes you numb," said one resident, Freddie Hamilton, who began a youth anti-violence group after her son was killed in 1993.
There is no consensus on why the 81st Precinct, a diamond-shaped area that encompasses the eastern half of Bedford-Stuyvesant, has defied New York's stunning statistical drop in murders and other violent crimes.
Lewis Watkins, district manager of Community Board 3, said he had expected the increase in crime because the police have been cracking down on drug dealers in nearby precincts and have not put enough officers on patrol in the 81st.
Lieut. Joseph Pollini, head of the 81st Precinct detective squad, said there has also been a cultural change by some neighborhood drug dealers.
"The dealers used to live in this area and consider it too sacred to deal in," Lieutenant Pollini said. "Now they're bringing their activity here, too."
Others say it is misleading to blame the increase in homicides solely on drug dealers. The Rev. Fred A. Lucas, pastor of the Bridge Street African Methodist Episcopal Church, points out that drug-related killings account for only a third of the homicides. He says the scarcity of jobs, educational opportunities and services in the neighborhood have left some residents so despondent they turn to crime.
"There's a listlessness and despair that's beginning to pervade inner urban America," Mr. Lucas said.
Whatever its causes, the rise in homicides has had a demoralizing effect on this community of about 60,000 residents struggling to renew itself. The 81st Precinct is a predominantly minority community -- 85 percent black and 13 percent Hispanic, according to census figures -- and a neighborhood of extremes. It is home to some of Brooklyn's most prominent African-Americans, yet plagued by an unemployment rate of 30 percent, Mr. Watkins said.
Several blocks contain magnificent homes, and many streets are lined with meticulously kept brownstones. More than 5,000 units of middle-income housing have been built or renovated in the last five years. But more than 40 percent of the population receives some sort of public assistance, according to the community board, and in the neighborhood's northern end, there are blocks pocked by burned-out buildings, vacant lots and waist-high weeds.
Residents of the 1.7-square-mile precinct have had to cope with a high crime rate for decades. Despite last year's increase in homicides, the 35 victims were still fewer than in 1990, when 49 people were killed there, and in 1991, when 48 were killed.
Capt. Michael Gabriel, who became precinct commander last September, said he is optimistic that the community can achieve the same crime reductions felt in the rest of the city. Using the techniques he learned as a Manhattan narcotics detective, Captain Gabriel has stepped up the use of vehicle checkpoints, transit sweeps and warrant sweeps to search for fugitives, drugs and handguns. Narcotics detectives are tracking the drug gangs suspected of many homicides.
In December, 25 cadets were assigned to the neighborhood for street patrol, helping ease the common complaint that the 81st Precinct simply does not put enough officers on the street. To some critics of the department, like Sherri Cox, that is an encouraging start.
"Now we just have to train the police officers to treat the community with more respect," Ms. Cox, president of a block association, said.
The precinct's response to homicides has also become more aggressive, officials say. After a shootout at 1625 Fulton Street on Nov. 4 left one man dead and another wounded, the police descended on the street in force. The victim who survived the attack would not cooperate, but detectives and anti-crime officers saturated the neighborhood and within three days arrested a suspected gunman.
Along the way, they also arrested the brother of the suspect and the brother of the slain man -- both of whom had illegal guns and both of whom were suspected of planning separate retaliatory attacks, Captain Gabriel said.
"I may not be able to stop the first shooting, but I can prevent the payback shootings," Captain Gabriel said.
Perhaps the most visible, if ironic, sign of hope in the neighborhood is the collection of newly shuttered storefronts. Shortly after arriving in the precinct, Captain Gabriel surveyed the neighborhood and determined that as many as 40 bodegas were acting as fronts for crack-cocaine dealers. With the help of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, the police have used the city's nuisance abatement laws to close down 10 shops that had three or more arrests involving complaints of drug trafficking.
Helen Lauster, who lives with her 7-year-old grandson in the Brevoort housing project, said her block improved dramatically when the police closed two illicit businesses on Fulton Street and Ralph Avenue.
"On the one hand, we need all the businesses and the jobs we can get in this neighborhood," she said. "But those were not businesses. They were disaster areas, and I'm glad they're shut down."
At Junior's bodega on Stuyvesant Avenue, neighbors have managed to do the opposite -- saving a business which was nearly destroyed by crime. In late July, after an armed robber killed Perceo Melo, a store owner, and his son, Julio Antonio, neighbors held a candlelight vigil and walked to the precinct to demand better police protection. They persuaded Mr. Arapioamnou not to sell his in-laws' business, and when the doors reopened three weeks later, neighbors held a tearful reception to welcome him back.
Come closing time, six neighbors were waiting outside to make sure Mr. Arapioamnou got out safely.
"I've worked in a lot of stores, but I've never seen a neighborhood where people are so together," Mr. Arapioamnou said. He said he hopes "we can get the police to come by more often and keep the criminals away." Then, he said, "this will be a beautiful place."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK REGION REGISTERS A SURGE IN UNEMPLOYMENT

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a sudden downturn that reflects the continuing impact of corporate cutbacks, unemployment in the New York region worsened significantly in December, with New Jersey having the second-worst rate of joblessness of any big industrial state.
Experts said the report was particularly worrisome because its statistics do not account for the impact of last week's blizzard, which cut deeply into sales, construction and other economic activity, nor the recently announced layoffs of 7,000 AT&T workers in New Jersey. 
 Although the monthly data are based on a sampling that some regard as suspect and even the Federal Government describes as volatile, economists said the report clearly reflected a regional economy that is slowing down and performing more poorly than is most of the nation.
"What you are looking at is a broad pattern of corporate downsizing that has not come to an end," said David Hensley, a regional economist for Salomon Brothers. "This region in particular is looking sluggish."
The Government said New Jersey's unemployment rate rose to 7.3 percent in December from 6.1 percent the month before, with the number of unemployed state residents rising by 48,000, to 295,000.
The rate also rose in New York State, to 6.4 percent from 6 percent the previous month. In New York City, where recent gains in tourism and retail sales have produced a more robust economy than in most of the region, unemployment also rose, to 8.1 percent from 7.8 percent.
Although the Federal report did not specify which industries or companies had made job cuts, it came as deep-seated problems that have faced the region for more than a decade appear to be intensifying.
In New York and New Jersey -- as in Connecticut, whose December employment numbers have not been released -- growth has been slowed by the states' high concentration of headquarters for banks, insurance companies and large corporations.
Although the headquarters have historically endowed the region with great wealth and continue to employ many highly paid executives, they have recently borne the brunt of the mergers and management downsizing in corporate America.
The region has also been hurt because its largest manufacturers, including the chemicals and pharmaceuticals industries of New Jersey, have faced intense global competition, cut workers sharply and shifted production to other states and other countries where labor costs are lower.
Although those problems have plagued the region for years, particularly since it sank into a four-year recession in 1988, economists said the December figures show the troubles have not abated.
"The December numbers show a very large negative shift in the New Jersey labor market," said John L. Wieting, the New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which prepared yesterday's report. "There certainly has been a softening, the dimensions of which remain to be seen."
However severe or long lasting, the downturn in the region stands out because it comes as unemployment has stabilized or improved in most of the nation. The only state that had higher unemployment than New Jersey in December was California, where the rate was 7.7 percent.
Yesterday's report comes at a sensitive time for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, who has built a reputation as a supporter of business expansion. On Jan. 27, she is scheduled to announce her state's 1996 budget, including fiscal projections that could be affected by a downturn in employment.
"We feel that the December numbers are an anomaly, perhaps just a blip," said Gene Herman, a spokesman for Ms. Whitman. Nonetheless, he said her advisers would consider what impact the December data might have on the projections before the budget is announced.
Joseph Seneca, an economist at Rutgers University and one of Governor Whitman's advisers, said yesterday that he also thought the December data exaggerated the problem, but that the state's economy was clearly slowing.
"We are at the center of the storm of corporate downsizing," he said, adding that December data "reflects a need to work even harder at business retention and expansion."
The Federal report was based on a survey of households, conducted by the Census Bureau for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. New York, in which 4,200 homes were surveyed, and New Jersey, where 2,400 homes were surveyed, are among the 11 largest industrial states.
Economists say the monthly report on the 11 states is of limited value because the survey is too small to prevent distortions. Mr. Wieting said he usually avoided concluding that a trend in employment patterns had occurred in any state until the monthly data moved in the same direction for three consecutive months.
But by that measure, the December numbers for New Jersey are part of a trend, since the state's unemployment rate rose, albeit slightly, from 5.8 percent, to 6.1 percent, in November; in October, it rose to 5.8 percent from 5.7 percent.
Many experts also criticize the attention paid by Government officials and the news media to unemployment rates because they only measure the number of people who are actively looking for jobs and unable to find them. Huge numbers of people who have simply stopped looking for work are not counted.
A more reliable measure of economic performance, many say, is the total of people employed. By that accounting, New York and New Jersey also suffered a downturn.
The report yesterday said New York State employment in December was down 48,000, to 7,903,000. In New Jersey, it said, employment dropped 73,000, to 3,732,000.

HEADLINE: Labor Dept. Agrees to Aid Voter Efforts

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The State Department of Labor agreed in a court settlement today to begin providing voter registration services to people who use its offices, ending a yearlong debate over whether the department should comply with legislation designed to expand the state's voter rolls.
Plaintiffs in the case said the agreement would set an important precedent for groups trying to enforce compliance with the National Voter Registration Act, known as the Motor Voter Law. It requires states to help people to register while obtaining driver's licenses or conducting other business in state offices.
"Now all state agencies are on notice to live up to their voter registration obligations," said Jonathan Feldman, associate counsel for the Community Service Society of New York, the nonprofit antipoverty group that brought the suit against the Labor Department. 
 Under New York State's version of the law, about a dozen state agencies, including the Labor Department, must provide voter registration forms and assistance to anyone who comes into their offices. The other major state agencies required to dispense voter services are Health, Social Services and Motor Vehicles.
More than 307,000 people have been registered under the law since it took effect in New York a year ago, most of them at Motor Vehicles or Social Services offices.
But the Labor Department refused to provide any of the voter registration services, arguing that it had not been given enough state money to administer the program and was barred under Federal laws from using Federal grants for those purposes.
Under today's agreement, the Department of Labor must begin in February to give voter registration forms to anyone who applies for unemployment insurance, job training or other services -- unless he or she refuses to be registered.
Department of Labor employees will have to help people register and then send their completed forms to the Board of Elections. The department will also be required to pay for 20 full-time positions to administer the registration services.
About 180,000 people visit Department of Labor offices each month.
Even with the agreement, the State Labor Commissioner, John E. Sweeney, still argued today that Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget calls for exempting the Labor Department from the requirements. "I want my agency and staff to focus on job services," he said, "and I believe there are state and local agencies that already provide voter registration services."
Mr. Sweeney said that unless the legislature exempted his agency from the program or gave him the money to administer it -- about $1 million a year, he said -- he might ask the court for relief from today's settlement. "There may be a time or place where we have to go back to the court and say, 'We don't have the money,' " he said.
Mr. Feldman said that although the Department of Labor was the only state agency to disregard the law completely, some other agencies had been spotty in their compliance. He said his group was planning to file suit against the Health Department and several other agencies unless they improved their voter registration services.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Job Growth in December Quiets Fears of Recession
 
The economy added a moderate 151,000 jobs in December, stilling for the moment fears that the economy was on the verge of sliding into recession. The unemployment rate remained at 5.6 percent. The first major report on economic performance last month was hailed by the Clinton Administration as evidence that the economy continues to expand solidly. 
 But many analysts pointed to disquieting elements and said the Fed may well cut interest rates again this month. [Page 36]
 
The regional economy worsened significantly, with New Jersey having the second-worst jobless rate of any big industrial state. And the report did not even take into account the blizzard and the AT&T job cuts. [1.]
 
I.B.M. Jump Lifts Market
 
I.B.M. again led the stock market much higher. I.B.M. itself was up 5 3/4, to 102, still benefiting from Thursday's report of strong earnings, and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 60.33 points, to 5,184.68. Over a billion shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq. For the whole week, the Dow rose 123.56 points, making up for its plunge last week. [39.]
 
Impressive Profit at Chrysler
 
Chrysler earnings were unexpectedly high in the quarter, strengthening the hand of management in its efforts to retain control of the company. Profits of $1.04 billion, or $2.67 a share, were well above the top Wall Street prediction of $2.30 a share. Chrysler's stock jumped $1.875, to $54.125. [37.]
 
Time Warner Drops Satellite Bidding
 
Tele-Communications and Time Warner dropped plans to bid together in an F.C.C. auction next Wednesday of two valuable satellite licenses. Instead, Tele-Communications will bid on its own against MCI and perhaps others. Time Warner dropped out, apparently concluding that it would be cheaper and more practical to use a less ambitious technology. [37.]
 
Rohatyn Mentioned for Fed Post

Robert Maxwell's Sons Acquitted
 
Robert Maxwell's sons Kevin, shown at left, and Ian were acquitted in London of fraud charges, as was one of his former executives, Larry Trachtenberg. [38.]
 
Dollar at Highest Levels in Months
 
The dollar surpassed 1.48 German marks for the first time in four months and rose to four-month highs against the Swiss and French francs and a 19-month high against the British pound. The gains reflected expectations of further interest rate cuts in Europe and speculation that leading industrial nations will endorse a stronger dollar this weekend. [45.]
 
Grain prices surged on indications of vibrant export demand and on a forecast that farmers will plant relatively few acres of corn. [45.]

HEADLINE: Maybe It Wasn't the Economy in the '92 Election After All

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Could inaccurate Federal data have cost President George Bush a second term? Have they led some economists to proclaim a surge in worker output that may well be a statistical illusion?
The comprehensive revisions in the numbers that track the economy's performance, released today by the Commerce Department, are sure to be welcomed by professionals. But unlike earlier efforts to refine the Government's analysis of economic data, this one offers an intriguing new view of recent history that is bound to spark doubts, if not stir controversy.
For one thing, the revisions suggest that the downturn of 1990-91 was nearly twice as deep as Washington knew at the time, raising the possibility that the Federal Reserve and the White House would have reacted more aggressively to dig the economy out of a recession. Such a response, coming much earlier than it actually did, might have changed the impression among many voters that President Bush did not care. 
 Michael Boskin, the chief economic adviser to President Bush, argues that "evidence of a steeper recession would have moved the center of gravity toward those who wanted the President to engage more aggressively on the economy." In the end, President Bush was insisting that a sluggish recovery was under way until an about-face in December 1991, when his press secretary acknowledged: "People are unemployed. People are hurting." And his effort to bolster the economy did not come until just before the 1992 election.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, also acknowledged to Congress at the end of 1991 that he had underestimated the weakness of the economy.
The new figures also show that economic growth in 1993 and 1994 was considerably slower than previously reported, casting grave doubt on the view that the wrenching process of corporate downsizing has been paying off in big gains in efficiency. Although there are economists who dispute this conclusion based on the revised data, plenty of others are pointing to it as proof of the need for a new look at recent history. "Anybody who thinks there was a resurgence in productivity in the 1990's has to think again," argues John B. Taylor, an economist at Stanford University.
The accounting revisions change the way the components of national output are measured in a dozen ways. Some are straightforward -- for example, applying more realistic measures of depreciation to business equipment. But the most important is a shift in the way the statisticians compensate for changes in the prices of individual goods and services in making year-to-year comparisons in the value of output.
Under the old method of indexing, the prices from a single base year (most recently, 1987) were used to add up total value. With the new indexing system, the price weights are changed continuously. This "chain weight" indexing method is more accurate. What's more, says Van Doorn Ooms, director of research at the Committee for Economic Development, it spares those who use the numbers "from rewriting history every five years" -- when the price weights are updated to a new base year.
The data, revised back to 1959, show the annual growth of G.D.P. has averaged 3.2 percent for the last quarter-century, two-tenths of a percentage point faster than previously believed. A closer look, though, shows that the faster growth was confined to the 1959-1987 period. Growth between 1987 and 1994 has been revised down from 2.4 percent to 2.3 percent.
Look still closer, and the results are truly striking. While the revised data do not change the timing of the 1990-91 recession, they do show that the dip in output was greater than previously understood. In the first three months of the recession, the third quarter of 1990, G.D.P. fell at an annual rate of 1.9 percent -- twice the rate reported at the time. The decline was also steeper in the fourth quarter of 1990 (4.1 percent compared with 3.2 percent) and the first quarter of 1991 (2.2 percent compared with 2.1 percent).
Mr. Boskin, the former economic adviser, called for action to stem the recession in late 1990. But he was ignored, in large part because the contemporary numbers were suggesting a mere stumble, one akin to the single flat quarter in the autumn of 1989.
The President might have negotiated a temporary tax cut with the Democratic majority in Congress, Mr. Boskin suggests. At the very least, the White House would have proposed a fiscal-stimulation package in 1991 rather than a few months before the 1992 election. And it would have given the Federal Reserve a strong incentive to cut interest rates more rapidly in 1991, producing a shallower recession and a faster recovery in 1992.
Whether that would have changed the 1992 election is anybody's guess. But it would have quieted criticism that President Bush was the "foreign policy president" who couldn't be bothered with the travails of ordinary Americans until his re-election prospects seemed in jeopardy -- criticism that probably led some Republicans to vote for Ross Perot.
The remaining irony is that when Mr. Bush in December 1991 finally switched his stance and said the economy was still in trouble, the economy was actually growing again.
The big news for today's policy makers, though, is the distressing message about productivity growth. Business economists, notably Allen Sinai of Lehman Brothers and Steve Roach of Morgan Stanley, have been celebrating a surge in productivity -- output per worker -- which they view as the gain from the pain of corporate downsizing in the 1990's. Using the old numbers, annual productivity growth has been running 2.2 percent a year, double the rate of the 1970's and 1980's.
But the numbers released today show that output per worker was growing considerably slower in 1993 and 1994 than previously known. And that chops the productivity growth rate for the 1990's to about 1.4 percent, hardly better than the 1980's when rapid economic expansion was largely driven by rapid increases in employment.
William Nordhaus, an economist at Yale University, is not surprised. "It always looks like productivity is turning up before a revision in the fixed-weight index," he notes. And while the transition to chain weighting will eliminate this distortion in the future, it was bound to show up this one last time.
But Mr. Sinai is unconvinced. He suggests that the revisions are misleading because they fail to account for a major offsetting factor -- the unmeasured, and thus undervalued, improvements in the quality of computers and other electronic business equipment. "When I look at markets and prices -- the combination of low inflation and exploding corporate profits -- I see productivity growth," Mr. Sinai says.
This controversy will simmer until the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis improves measurements of quality changes in assessing output -- notably in electronics, medical care and financial services, where it is widely suspected that output is systematically undervalued. But that end is not in sight: Everett Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, acknowledged this week that anticipated budget cuts would hobble the bureau's efforts.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS; How a Flat Tax Would Work, For You and for Them 

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
The big issue in these first weeks of the 1996 Presidential campaign has been how Americans should tax themselves. And most of the talk is about a flat tax on incomes, with a large deduction for individuals so that lower-income people would pay no income tax.
There are about as many flat tax variants floating around as there are would-be occupants of the White House. But all derive from "The Flat Tax" (Hoover Institition Press, 1995), by Robert Hall and Alvin Rabushka, both economists at the Hoover Institution, who devised the concept in 1981 and have been refining it ever since. 
 The two economists say their proposed tax, which would be 19 percent, would spur investment and growth by taxing income only once, eliminating taxes on capital gains and taxing individuals only on wages, salaries and pensions. Interest and dividends would not be taxed directly, but would be affected by a business tax, also at 19 percent. (Businesses would no longer be able to deduct the cost of fringe benefits, except pensions, for their employees, however.) 
 So how would a flat tax affect the typical family? And how would it affect the tax bills of the Presidential candidates who have pushed the issue to center stage? 
 The New York Times recalculated the taxes that some of the major candidates would have owed in 1994 had a flat tax been in effect that year, consulting with the Republican candidates' advisers and making minor adjustments to eliminate anomalies in the complex tax returns that are irrelevant to a flat tax. 
 The two candidates most closely identified with the flat tax -- Steve Forbes, the magazine owner, and Patrick J. Buchanan, the television commentator -- would not make their tax returns available. Mr. Forbes said he would never disclose his returns; Mr. Buchanan said he would make his public if he wins the Republican nomination. 
 President Clinton and three prominent Republican candidates -- Senators Bob Dole and Phil Gramm and Lamar Alexander, the former Education Secretary -- made available copies of their 1994 Federal income tax returns. (Mr. Clinton opposes the flat tax, as does Mr. Alexander. Mr. Dole has said he would go along with a flat tax. Mr. Gramm favors a 16 percent flat tax.) 
 All four candidates, whose incomes place them among the top 1 percent of Americans in terms of personal income, would enjoy considerable savings in personal income taxes under the Hall-Rabushka flat tax. A comparison also requires calculating the effect of the Hall-Rabushka business tax on business income, but even with both taxes, all four candidates would see their tax bills decline -- although probably none would save as much as Mr. Forbes, a fervent flat-tax advocate who is one of the wealthiest men in the United States. 
 Senator Dole and his wife, who had $607,000 in income in 1994, would save about $49,000, and the Clintons, whose income was $267,000, would save about $21,000. 
 Senator Gramm, who with his wife reported $305,000 in income, would save about $40,000; his aides acknowledged that under his own proposal, which differs considerably from the others, the Senator's taxes would decline even more sharply. 
 Mr. Alexander's savings would be about $184,000 on an income of about $1 million. The savings would presumably be significantly greater for Mr. Forbes, who has an income of $1.4 million as chief executive officer of Forbes Inc. and a net worth that Fortune magazine last week estimated at $439 million. 
 The picture is not so bright for the Smiths, a hypothetical family of four used by the Tax Foundation in its analyses of the various flat-tax plans floating around Washington. The Smiths, who have $50,000 in total income, nearly all from wages, would see no change in their individual tax bill if the Hall-Rabushka proposal were put into effect. And if interest rates decline as predicted, the Smiths, who collected $1,425 in interest in 1994, would come out a few dollars behind.

HEADLINE: SUNSHINE STATES;
Markers of Arizona History

BYLINE: By JUDITH ANDERSON; JUDITH ANDERSON lives in Tucson.

 BODY:
IN the Santa Cruz River Valley of southern Arizona, history worked its way north in the wake of European colonization, leaving two important markers at the foot of the Santa Rita Mountains: a mission at Tumacacori and a presidio at Tubac, the latter now reconstructed and surrounded by a thriving artists' colony. In a day trip from Tucson a visitor can mix 300 years of the past with the crafts and designs of tomorrow, side by side there on the frontage road of Interstate 19.
The mission at Tumacacori (toom-a-KAH-kuh-ree), 45 miles south of Tucson, is just a ruin now. The 20-foot walls have been stabilized, but the exterior plaster has fallen away in many places, exposing the tiers of mud adobes beneath. The roof fell in decades ago; the wind and rain blow freely through gaping door and window frames. The bell tower rises raggedly because it was never finished in the first place. But over the ravaged sanctuary walls floats a perfect small white dome, freshly washed with lime plaster and topped with a tiny wooden cross. Glimpsed from the Interstate, gleaming against the intense blue desert sky, it looks as if it belongs on Santorini. 
 This is one of a chain of outposts established by Spanish missionaries. The site was designated a national monument in 1908 and is now administered as a national historic park. Here the policy of the National Park Service has been to preserve but not restore. Visitors can explore the shadowy interior of the stabilized mission church and prowl through the crumbling remains of the convento, the compound containing the workshops and priests' living quarters, as well as through the substantially intact round mortuary chapel and its surrounding campo santo, or holy field, imbued with that peculiar intimacy of all abandoned cemeteries. An adobe visitors' center built in 1937 and a modest museum both house absorbing exhibits that explain the technology and arts of the era under the gaze of five of the original Mexican Baroque statues from the interior of the church.
The mission had three incarnations, each dedicated to a different patron saint. In 1691, Father Eusebio Kino, an Italian-born, German-educated Jesuit, arrived in Tumacacori and founded a mission. He named it for San Cayetano. By the end of the 17th century, the local Pima Indians, attracted by metal tools, new livestock, new crops -- including fruit trees and wheat, which, unlike corn, could be grown in winter -- were converting in substantial numbers.
For 50 years they were impressed for forced labor in mines and on ranches, and in 1751 they rebelled. It took the Spaniards four months to quell the uprising. To control the territory better, they began building a presidio three miles north, at Tubac, and moved the mission to the same side of the river. This second incarnation was dedicated to San Jose.
The mission's third version came after Spain expelled the Jesuits from its New World holdings in 1767. They were replaced the next year by the gray-robed Franciscans, who immediately began to redecorate. At Tumacacori they walled in the mission and spent the 1770's building adobe dwellings for the Pimas. In 1802 Fray Narciso Gutierrez and his Indian laborers began building a permanent church, this time called the Mision de la Purisima Concepcion de Tumacacori. These are the ruins that stand today. The church was originally patterned on San Xavier del Bac in Tucson, one of the finest examples of Spanish colonial architecture in the United States.
Even though plagued by money problems and never finished, the mission must have been a stunning landmark in the flat Santa Cruz valley 150 years ago. Its eroded double columns and pediment still retain a large degree of their dignity. The plaster exterior walls were embedded with crushed red brick and designs were painted on them. Inside were paintings of the Apostles, symbols of the Virgin Mary, carvings depicting the Stations of the Cross, elaborate Mexican wooden statues; visitors must depend on exhibits in the museum, however, to appreciate the black dado on white walls, the band of pendant half-circles near the ceiling, the floral stencils and painted curtains, the dark red plaster on the floor.
In 1828, in a gesture of independence, the Mexicans expelled the last Franciscan friar from Tumacacori. Without a priest, the mission began to deteriorate. When the presidio at Tubac was overwhelmed by Apaches in 1848, survivors helped the two dozen people remaining at Tumacacori to pack up the sacred relics, santos and vestments and transfer them to San Xavier del Bac for safekeeping. Tumacacori was abandoned.
And it is uninhabited still. Yet on any quiet day it is possible to imagine -- almost impossible not to -- those Pimas and their friars in their peaceful daily rounds of cultivation and meditation. You can work out the positions of the grist mill, the granary, leather workers' shops, pottery kilns and the monjeria, the place where young women learned crafts (and the site of the only indoor toilet apart from the one in the priests' quarters). Wandering through the sun-drenched remains of the walled garden east of the convento, touching the bark of gnarled fruit trees, it is easy to imagine the abundance of pomegranates, figs, quinces and peaches from the friars' five-acre orchard. It is a simple place, yet it is one of those unexpectedly evocative spots that project us for a moment into the past and leave us with some respect for hardship and faith.
A trip to Tumacacori almost always leads to Tubac as well, where history can be leavened with gallery-hopping and shopping. Energetic visitors can get there on foot: connecting Tumacacori National Historic Park to the Tubac Presidio State Historic Park is the Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail, which marks the route of the expedition that eventually established the first European colony in San Francisco. From the Tumacacori trail head, on the south side of the picnic grounds, to the Tubac trail head near the presidio gate, the distance is four and a half miles. It is not a strenuous outing, but the trail crosses the Santa Cruz River several times and can be dangerous when the water is high.
Anybody worried about wet feet or snakes can drive the three miles north to Tubac, and stop on the way at a little Mexican place called Wisdom's Cafe, easily recognized by the two 10-foot white chickens in the front yard. (When the Wisdom family opened the restaurant in 1944, it was called Chicken Taco and the portly pullets were on the roof.) The decor is very basic -- sports trophies, antique typewriters and notes from happy customers -- and so is the menu (no credit cards, and salsa costs extra). But some green corn tamales and one of their "world famous fruit burros" -- apple, blueberry, cherry or peach -- are enough to fortify anybody for an afternoon in Tubac.
Tubac is a town with energy, though that may not be apparent at first glance. Seven or eight dusty streets are studded with low-slung buildings, and some are still the original unplastered adobe of the 1860's. Later editions, built over the Spanish colonial foundations, kept the same tone, largely because they were constructed of the same materials, recycled from a ruin next door. Today more than 1,000 residents of the town and surrounding ranches make sure Tubac keeps its old adobe character intact.
Originally a small Pima farm that supplied the mission, Tubac became, in 1752, the first European settlement in what is now Arizona, when 50 calvarymen garrisoned the Presidio de San Ignacio de Tubac. The restored presidio in turn anchored Arizona's first state park, dedicated in 1959. A museum displays an array of spurs and spoons and other domestic artifacts that emphasize the homely details of everyday life at a military outpost. Part of it is a glassed-in underground archeological exhibit.
A free brochure offers a history of the presidio and a 25-cent map lays out a self-guided tour that includes the Old Tubac schoolhouse, St. Ann's Church and a dozen historic houses, as well as a visitors' center and a picnic area. Every Sunday afternoon from 1 to 4, October through March, a volunteer group called Los Tubaquenos recreates 17th-century daily life in the plaza.
Tubac was an unpredictable and frequently hellish place to live, what with water problems and political turmoil and relentlessly marauding Apaches. Eight times the citizens decamped. When Tubac became part of the United States through the Gadsden Purchase in 1854, it was a ruin. Five years later it was a boom town, as prospectors and investors responded to reports of gold and silver mines in the Santa Ritas.
But its heyday was brief. When the Civil War began, the troops headed east (most to support the Confederacy), the Apaches descended, and the residents fled. Later, when the Indians had been finally subdued, resettlement was discouraged by legal disputes over Spanish land grants that were not resolved until well into the 20th century.
Tubac was a town in limbo for nearly a hundred years.
In 1948 the painter Dale Nichols chose the village as the site for an art school. The school survived for only a year, but it attracted other artists to the village. The colony flourished, and in 1958 Will Rogers Jr. and his wife, Collier, bought the school building, the old Garrett House, and remodeled it. Other Hollywood personalities modernized adobe buildings as well, or bought ranches nearby, introducing an era of expansion. In the 1960's the golf club and the Tubac Inn were built, the annual Tubac Festival of the Arts and the state park attracted tourists, and the Santa Cruz Valley Art Association built the Tubac Center of the Arts. Somewhere along the way the town invented its motto: Where art and history meet.
AND that's pretty much the spirit of the place now. It's still a one-story town. There are about a hundred businesses tucked into the mellow adobe buildings, and at least half offer arts or crafts of some sort: fine art, folk art, art jewelry, pottery, basketry, sculpture, carved wood, wrought iron, blown glass . . . and of course there's kitsch. Make no mistake, there's some bad art in Tubac. A few years ago, when the economy was so grim, it looked as if the kitsch might prevail, as more and more low-end items appeared to appeal to limited pocketbooks. But art is making a comeback, especially in the rejuvenated Old Tubac area east of Burruel Street, near the presidio.
There's almost always something amusing to be found in the courtyard between Dos Perros and Los Portales, at 8 Burruel. The art in Los Portales tends to be established if not serious (it's set off by an expansive, quirky selection of furniture, tableware, linens and gifts), while the pieces at Dos Perros, one of the newest shops in Tubac, seem to have been selected to make you grin. Sophisticated works by artists with national followings, including Andrew Rush and Fox McGrew, are displayed next to folk art from Mexico and sage angels or gathering pots by local artisans. Rene Siqueiros, grandson of the celebrated Mexican muralist David Alfaro Siqueiros, is making his own name with primitive acrylics displayed here. It's a light-hearted space with a humane mark-up policy.
Down the hill past St. Ann's Church -- worth a visit for its dignity and simplicity and the charming figure of the Virgin of Guadalupe mounted over the doors -- La Paloma de Tubac displays a collection of 10,000 items of Latin American folk art. The proprietors have been dealing with the same families of folk artists in Peru, Ecuador, Guatemala and Mexico for years, and snapshots of several generations peer through the counter glass by the cash register. At the other end of the spectrum, and of the village, AuSi Gallery (its name taken from the symbols for gold and silica), at 38 Camino Otero, specializes in art glass. In between, at 18 Plaza Road, Lee Blackwell displays his metalwork in a garden of copper fountains. Hal Empie can almost always be found at his easel creating western paintings at 242 Tubac Road, while Leroy Doyle and Curry Johnson work on modern abstracts in their studio at 12 Placita de Anza.
During the Tubac Festival of the Arts (the 37th annual event begins Feb. 3 and lasts nine days), the wild variety of art gets considerably wilder. About 100 stalls crowd the streets. Artisans are screened for entry, but the kitsch holds its own. Elegant hand-crafted armoires sit in the dust right next to the Navajo tacos and corn on the cob. This isn't Santa Fe. It's not high end or hard sell. This is Tubac, and it's fun.
 
Spoons, spurs, art glass and tacos: where to find them
 
Tumacacori
 Tumacacori National Historical Park, Post Office Box 67, Tumacacori, Ariz. 85640, (520) 398-2341, is at Exit 29 on Interstate 19, 48 miles south of Tucson and 19 miles north of the Mexican border. Self-guided walks lead through the garden, church and museum; tours guided by rangers can be arranged..
 During the winter season, rangers and docents present programs for visitors; the schedule is posted in the visitors' center. Open every day except Thanksgiving and Christmas, from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission $2; children and seniors free.
 Wisdom's Cafe, Frontage Road, Tumacacori, (520) 398-2397, is open noon to 3 P.M. and 5 to 8 P.M. Monday through Saturday. Entrees, such as beef or turkey chimichangas or a beef burro with red or green chili, range from $4 to $8. Wine and beer are served. No credit cards, but personal checks are accepted.
 
Tubac
 Tubac Presidio State Historic Park, Post Office Box 1296, Tubac, Ariz. 85646, (520) 398-2252, at Exit 34, is open 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. every day except Christmas. Bob Barnacastle, the manager, or Cindy Krug, his assistant, can answer any questions. Admission $2; 12 to 17 $1; under 12 free.
 Hours at the shops and galleries in Tubac are very flexible. Most are open daily from midmorning to dusk , but it pays to call ahead to be sure. A gallery guide and a map prepared by the chamber of commerce are available free in most shops.
 AuSi Gallery, 38 Camino Otero, (520) 398-3193, specializes in contemporary art glass.
Dos Perros, 8 Burrell Street, (520) 398-0101, mixes fine art with crafts and folk pieces. Closed on Thursdays.
At La Paloma de Tubac, 1 Presidio Drive, (520) 398-9231, Latin American folk art includes santos, pottery, textiles and collectors' items.
Karin Newby Gallery, Mercado de Baca (520) 398-9662, exhibits paintings, sculpture, art glass and objets d'art.
At Lee Blackwell Fountains, 231 Plaza Road, (520) 398-2268, visitors can call ahead to arrange to watch Mr. Blackwell making his desert-themed fountains in copper.
 
Places to Stay
 There are several inns and bed-and-breakfast establishments in the area, but the number of rooms at each is limited and rates fluctuate. Call ahead for about reservations.
 The Old Mission Store Bed and Breakfast, Post Office Box 1471, Tumacacori (520) 398-9583, a charming old adobe, is across the road from Tumacacori National Historic Park. A suite that includes a double bed in the bedroom and single beds in two adjoining rooms is $65 a night per couple, including breakfast.
 Tubac Secret Garden Inn, Post Office Box 1561, Tubac, (520) 398-9371, is tucked into a spacious walled garden on Placita de Anza, near the historic district in Tubac. Recently refurbished double rooms ($79 with breakfast and newspaper) carry the airy, floral feeling indoors.
 Valle Verde Ranch B & B, Post
Office Box 157, Tumacacori (520) 398-2246), is just outside Tubac, down a dirt lane from the frontage road. It was once a rancheria, and offers three rooms with private baths inside the main house ($80 to $90 for a double) as well as separate casitas with kitchens ($115 for a single, $135 for a double). No pets, no smoking, no credit cards.
 Rio Rico Resort and Country Club, 1069 Camino Caralampi, Rio Rico (800) 288-4746, is about 10 minutes south of Tubac on Interstate 19. Offering swimming, tennis, golf and riding, the resort charges from $120 to $150 for a double but will negotiate corporate rates. J. A.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 27; Column 5; Magazine Desk
