HEADLINE: Seeing Red

BYLINE: By Sean Wilentz; Sean Wilentz is a professor of history and the director of the American studies program at Princeton University.

 BODY:

NOT WITHOUT HONOR
The History of American
Anticommunism.
By Richard Gid Powers.
Illustrated. 554 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $30. 
 History, which is supposed to belong to the victors, has not been kind to the American anti-Communist movement -- not yet, anyway. Numerous influential scholarly and popular books, written in a spirit similar to that of Lillian Hellman's memoir "Scoundrel Time," have left the impression that American anti-Communism was thoroughly irrational, indecent and reactionary. College textbook treatments of the subject commonly highlight the great Red Scare, a wave of indiscriminate arrests, detentions and deportations in 1919 and 1920, and the McCarthyism of the 1950's, and emphasize how anti-Communism threatened the nation's civil liberties. Portions of the intelligentsia still regard "anti-Communist" as a synonym for "extremist," "militarist" and "authoritarian."
In "Not Without Honor," Richard Gid Powers develops a very different view. "There was no one thing that was American anti-Communism," he writes; "there were many American antiCommunisms." Some anti-Communists were certainly scoundrels, he allows; others were hatemongers, and still others were thugs. But Mr. Powers, who is a professor of history at the City University of New York, insists that these people were the exceptions, and that they did far more to harm the anti-Communist cause than to advance it. He would have his readers instead consider -- and honor -- the more typical idealistic Americans who spoke the truth about Communist tyranny and fought the good fight, fiercely but fairly.
Mr. Powers's honorable anti-Communists turn out to be a diverse group, and one of the contributions of his provocative narrative history is to bring to life certain segments of anti-Communist opinion that have largely been forgotten. Socialists and trade unionists march across Mr. Powers's pages, determined to stop the Communists from hijacking labor's cause. There are black anti-Communists, Roman Catholic anti-Communists and Jewish anti-Communists; anti-Communists from the cities and anti-Communists from small towns. The anti-Communists often disliked one another, but they laid aside their differences to fight the common foe.
In the first half of the book, leading up to the McCarthy period, Mr. Powers describes a recurring three-sided story, in which "responsible anti-Communists" found themselves pitted against reckless Red hunters (whom he calls "countersubversives") and also against the Communists and their sympathizers. After the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, the countersubversives, led by Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer and the young J. Edgar Hoover of the Justice Department's Bureau of Investigation, mounted an all-out attack on American radicals that culminated immediately after World War I in the Red Scare. Fed by the provincial prejudices of the old-stock middle class, and compromised by the lies and exaggerations of Government officials, the crackdown quickly backfired, making anti-Communism look like an assault on constitutional freedoms while casting the Communists as pitiable, innocent victims.
Only in the 1920's, Mr. Powers explains, did a more temperate anti-Communist mainstream emerge, one that was populated largely by the sorts of working-class ethnic people whom the countersubversives distrusted. It was invigorated by knowledgeable leftists like Abraham Cahan, the socialist editor of The Jewish Daily Forward. In political campaigns and trade union struggles, these mainstream anti-Communists tried to wipe away the stigma of the Red Scare and expose the Communists as dissemblers who posed as civil libertarians while upholding a ruthless and despotic political ideology. This pattern persisted during the Great Depression and then during World War II, as anti-Communists fought Communists in the labor movement and rival writers' congresses, only to see their efforts undermined by the countersubversives' mayhem.
The background to these parts of Mr. Powers's book will be familiar to readers of Daniel Aaron's "Writers on the Left," John Patrick Diggins's "Up From Communism" and other works. Various key figures, notably the anti-Communist philosopher Sidney Hook and the trade union leader David Dubinsky, will also be familiar. Unfortunately, Mr. Powers says practically nothing about some of the most interesting anti-Communists of the period, like the Harlem writer and disillusioned Communist sympathizer Claude McKay and the extraordinary Italian-born agitator Carlo Tresca. But Mr. Powers does unearth other important individuals, many of whom eventually wound up on the conservative end of the anti-Communist political spectrum, including the black journalist George Schuyler (who tirelessly attacked the Communists' efforts to manipulate black causes) and the renegade leftist writer Eugene Lyons. (His expos of Stalin's Soviet Union, "Assignment in Utopia," elicited an enthusiastic response from, among others, the anarchist Emma Goldman.)
Mr. Powers is equally informative about the more destructive countersubversives from the Popular Front years of the 1930's, ranging from Representative Hamilton Fish, the gullible isolationist from New York, to the anti-Semite Elizabeth Dilling, whose crackpot opus of 1934, "The Red Network," is still revered and studied in some right-wing circles. And Mr. Powers takes pains to criticize those "responsible" groups, particularly on the Catholic right, whose uncritical anti-Communism contributed to the popularity of demagogues like Father Charles Coughlin, the notorious radio priest.
In the late 1940's, yet another round of jostling between honorable and dishonorable anti-Communists prepared the way for the rise of Joseph McCarthy. After defeating the Communist-influenced Progressive Party, led by the former New Dealer Henry Wallace, liberal Democratic anti-Communists forged a seemingly powerful postwar consensus, based on the containment of Soviet expansion abroad and the enlargement of Keynesian social reform at home. Embittered countersubversives, excluded from the consensus, lashed out with mad conspiracy theories while they quietly built a base for themselves inside the Republican Party.
BY 1950, the liberal consensus had begun to crack under the pressure of events like the Alger Hiss trial, and new credibility flowed, Mr. Powers says, "to some of the most bizarre and irresponsible figures in American politics, the right-wing countersubversive anti-Communists of the prewar isolationist movement." The stage was set for Senator McCarthy to amplify the reactionary hysteria and set in motion the inquisitions that would bear his name -- "the greatest disaster in the disastrous history of American anti-Communism," Mr. Powers writes.
Until he fell in disgrace in 1954, McCarthy lent the dignity of his office to the worst kinds of anti-Communist abuses, destroying careers and fouling political debate. But to Mr. Powers, McCarthyism had some important additional ramifications, and at this point the author's story line and his political sympathies begin to veer dramatically to the right.
The liberals, whom Mr. Powers greatly admired in his coverage of the late 1940's, now turn out to have been snobs, motivated less by patriotism or religious faith than by "the elite values they held most dear," including "constitutional guarantees of due process, limited government and the freedom of the individual." (Mr. Powers is vague about why these values are "elite.") The liberalism that Mr. Powers had earlier praised as a bulwark against the countersubversives' desire "to restore laissez-faire capitalism with all its iniquities" now begins to look ambivalent in its anti-Communism, repelled by the Communists' undemocratic tactics but attracted to many of their goals -- "a planned economy, a social welfare net and the like." Fearful of the benighted masses, Mr. Powers contends, liberals muted their anti-Communism. The anti-Communist movement in turn found fresh leaders among hard-line conservatives, including former supporters of McCarthy like William F. Buckley Jr., who managed to distance themselves from the right-wing lunatic fringe.
According to Mr. Powers, the liberals' loss of ideological nerve became increasingly apparent during the Kennedy Administration. Although John F. Kennedy and his advisers pursued an aggressive foreign policy -- one that, Mr. Powers claims, "far exceeded in its militance anything proposed by avowed anti-Communists" -- they rejected anti-Communist rhetoric and eschewed domestic anti-Communist crusades. With their amoral, rationalist view of world affairs, the Kennedy men casually moved the country into what would soon become the Vietnam disaster, a war fought by Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon against a Communist enemy but without, Mr. Powers asserts, any explicit anti-Communist justification. Whereas other writers have called America's intervention a mindless, reflexive impulse to battle Communism on every front, no matter the cost, Mr. Powers attributes it to a loss of focus among many traditional anti-Communists. (Presumably, he believes that the oft-repeated domino theory and other standard anti-Communist rationales for the war lacked sufficient clarity and fervor.)
As the war dragged on, many Americans -- unfairly, in Mr. Powers's view -- turned against anti-Communism. Liberals, having enlisted in the antiwar movement, virtually abandoned their old anti-Communist commitments. New Left protesters loudly, and sometimes violently, declared their allegiance to the Vietnamese Communists. Other critics viewed the conflict outside of any reference to Communism, as if Ho Chi Minh were at heart a heroic nationalist and not really a dictator at all.
By the time Mr. Powers has reached the Vietnam era and its immediate aftermath, two of the major groups from his earlier chapters -- the American Communists and the right-wing countersubversives -- have virtually fallen apart. (J. Edgar Hoover did, of course, indulge in one last rampage, involving the F.B.I. in political surveillance of civil rights and antiwar leaders.) Instead, Mr. Powers describes a fight to the finish between unyielding anti-Communist conservatives and the spineless, regnant liberals, joined by Nixon and Henry Kissinger, the architects of dtente.
Mr. Powers leaves open the question of how the hard-line anti-Communists would have avoided the Vietnam catastrophe or staved off a Communist victory. He brooks no sympathy with the view that America's support of repressive and corrupt regimes, as counters to Communist expansion, may have compromised democratic ideals and actually played into the Communists' hands. Nor does he say much about how the prospect of nuclear warfare affected the cold war political calculus. Rather, he grimly reports how, amid the revulsion over the war, the anti-Communist movement became scattered and ostracized, and how, by the mid-1970's, all seemed lost.
Then, wondrously, things began to change:
"During those bleakest winter days of American anti-Communism, there was, however, the first faint stirring of new life, of rebirth, a sign of vigor at odds with the uncertainty and pessimism that pervaded the tired veterans of the old cause. One man summoned the will, the strength and the imagination to commence the giant task of rebuilding the anti-Communist coalition. This was Norman Podhoretz, editor of the American Jewish Committee's Commentary."
After the creation in 1976 of the Committee on the Present Danger, with Mr. Podhoretz as its most articulate spokesman, American anti-Communists regained their footing, challenged the defeatist policies of the Carter Administration and helped elevate Ronald Reagan to the White House -- "the culmination of the long history of American anti-Communism," Mr. Powers writes. Influenced by members of the committee, the Reagan Administration reversed the liberals' foreign policy, pushed the Soviets into a costly arms race, equipped anti-Communist insurgents and played a leading role in Communism's eventual destruction.
Mr. Powers has good reasons to credit American anti-Communism's contributions to the overthrow of the Soviet empire, including President Reagan's rhetoric of solidarity with the dissidents in the Soviet bloc. Still, in his enthusiasm for Mr. Podhoretz, the other neoconservatives and their friends in the Reagan White House, Mr. Powers slights some important ironies and overlooks some others.
The events that led to Communism's demise actually raised serious questions about the central neoconservative axiom, advanced most forcefully (in the pages of Commentary) by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, that Communist regimes, unlike right-wing dictatorships, closed off the possibility of peaceful evolution to democracy. Likewise, the Reagan doctrine, as shaped by the neoconservatives, was deeply flawed. Of the doctrine's three major components, one, the rapid arms buildup, was based on vast exaggerations of Soviet strength and, by draining the treasury, may have done tremendous damage to America's economic strength. A second component, military aid to anti-Communist insurgents, subverted democratic procedures and caused a constitutional crisis, the Iran-contra affair, that could well have led to Mr. Reagan's impeachment.
It was the third and by far the smallest component of the Reagan policy, nonmilitary aid to dissidents in the Communist countries, most famously the leaders of Solidarity in Poland, that proved most effective. This aid was administered chiefly by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the labor wing of the anti-Communist alliance, and, as Mr. Powers notes, grew out of the old liberal anti-Communist idea of fostering the non-Communist left. (Yet another source of anti-Soviet inspiration came, irony of ironies, from the American counterculture, an influence that the Reaganites and the neo-conservatives detested but that, in Central Europe, made Frank Zappa one of the heroes of anti-Communist revolution.)
Mr. Powers's story might have been told in a very different way. That telling would describe how the encouragement of oppositionist workers and intellectuals in Communist countries and international appeals to human rights were at least as important in felling Communism as nuclear saber rattling and guerrilla warfare. It would expand the anti-Communist honor roll to include such organizations as Human Rights Watch, the PEN American Center and Freedom House, among many other groups. It would make larger allowances for the contributions of labor leaders like Walter Reuther and A. Philip Randolph, religious spokesmen like Bishop Bernard J. Sheil and Reinhold Niebuhr, and intellectuals like Mary McCarthy, Dwight Macdonald and Irving Howe. It would examine much more closely how anti-Communism became a pretext for discrediting dissent at home and underwriting sordid covert operations abroad, from Guatemala to Iran. Minimizing these elements, Mr. Powers's book comes perilously close to conflating the triumph of the West with the triumph of Commentary.
Still, these are matters for historians to debate in the years to come. "Not Without Honor" clears the way for such a debate, and especially in the book's early chapters, Mr. Powers starts the job of rescuing the history of American anti-Communism from some lingering stereotypes. What remains to be seen is which kind of American anti-Communism -- and which accounting of history -- will endure.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2992 words

HEADLINE: The Perils Of Owning A Home In Splitsville

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
IN the rugged give and take of almost every divorce or separation, there is one solid and usually quite valuable asset that cannot be hidden or denied: the couple's house or apartment.
In many divorces, these brick or stone or wood walls that once sheltered a happy couple are disposed of amicably, or, if not amicably, at least definitively, with a clear decision on who will end up living in the house, or whether it should be sold, with who gets what percentage of the proceeds spelled out for all time. 
 But in a substantial number of other divorces, the house or weekend house or co-op or rent-subsidized apartment becomes the major bone of contention -- perhaps because it is the only asset in a cash-poor marriage or because it is a beloved object.
"There is a strong minority of people who are very seriously attached to their house and will not budge," said Gary N. Skoloff, a divorce lawyer in Livingston, N.J. "There are people who say to me -- and they're dead serious -- do you understand my husband, or my wife, whichever, loves this house more than he loves me?
"They know the other one absolutely must have the house and they work around that," he said. In other cases, he said, "they both really put their life and soul into designing and building or renovating the house together; they spent every weekend for three years riding through the countryside picking up antique bricks for the pathways; they planted the trees and watched them grow. Neither will give it up."
The house can also become the pawn of an angry spouse who -- even after the decree -- refuses to sign the necessary papers for selling a co-op, or refuses any offers on a jointly owned house, or otherwise deliberately sabotages deals.
"Here's what happens," said Chris Thomas, who runs William B. May's two Brooklyn real estate offices, discussing the difficulties agents have in showing clients such homes. "The first battle was over the children; now it's over the house. The spouse in custody doesn't want to show it, because chances are, once the house is sold, that spouse will have to give half the money to the other spouse and therefore, will have to live in someplace half as good -- so where's the incentive to sell it?"
So the spouse cancels appointments to show the property, or leaves the place a mess. "One guy called me, frustrated after a couple of years," said Mr. Thomas. "He said: 'The next time that happens, call me, I'm right here on Wall Street; I've got a court order.'
"But listen -- what realtor wants to bother with court orders and breaking the door down when they've got customers sitting right in front of them," Mr. Thomas said. "The place becomes known as trouble, and if it ever does sell, it sells for a lot less than it would've."
In Manhattan, JoAnne Kennedy, a partner in Hunt-Kennedy Real Estate, labels the "absolute worst case" the times when a divorced or separating couple still share the same apartment. "You have a DMZ," she said. "You can feel the intense hostility in the air. I have seen one partner retreat to one wing and stake out a camp." Mrs. Kennedy, who said her office was "never without divorces, or gay couples splitting, or non-gay couples breaking up," said simply: "Divorce creates real estate business."
Mark Zimmerman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said he was seeing more cases of disputes between legally divorced people whose names still linger jointly on co-op mortgages and proprietary leases -- disputes that can scare away potential buyers.
"Even if one side can produce a divorce settlement showing that he or she has been awarded the apartment," Mr. Zimmerman said, "the co-op boards still demand that both parties still on the lease sign the papers prior to transferring that apartment. We're seeing more cases where -- just for spite -- the one who didn't get the property refuses to cooperate."
In one case, the husband "blackmailed" the wife, who had ended up with the apartment and was trying to sell it, according to Mr. Zimmerman. In return for his signature -- he had been left on the proprietary lease even though she had been awarded the apartment -- he demanded a painting he knew had great sentimental value to the wife -- all this after the decree became final. The deadline for the closing was approaching, the lawyer said, and the woman felt she had no choice but to give it to him.
Lawyers concede that such legal squabbling costs money. The reformed divorce laws, which almost two decades ago introduced the concept of "equitable distribution" of assets in New York -- a concept that mandates that both tangible and intangible contributions of spouses, including such services as child-rearing, be considered by a judge -- can result in a system full of good intentions that occasionally backfires, lawyers say.
The old system, which relied heavily on who actually held title to the disputed property, was less complicated. The new system, while designed to be fairer and more flexible, can result in mountains of depositions and claims and counterclaims.
Sometimes, when the parties are finished establishing their every contribution, they have used up a substantial part of their equity on lawyer's fees.
"Some lawyers, in order to get paid, have taken mortgages on people's residences," said Peter E. Bronstein, a Manhattan divorce lawyer. Jean O'Sullivan, a mother of two grown children who lives in Albany, did exactly that; she says she gave her lawyer both mortgages on her home. "He had to have some security," she said, of her lawyer. "I couldn't pay him."
Before she parted with the mortgages, she estimated she "left $300,000 on the table" in lawyer's fees.
In rare cases, the spouse who has less money can be rendered homeless -- even though he or she wound up in possession of the family home -- because he or she is left without the money to pay for it.
One 61-year-old woman lost the East Side apartment she brought to her short marriage -- her home for almost three decades -- because she gave up her career to please her multimillionaire husband. He left after less than a year.
She said that she pawned her jewelry and sold her paintings but that it wasn't enough to keep paying the mortgage; the apartment was foreclosed. She was evicted from the big house they had rented in the Hamptons; she is currently staying with friends, working on her appeal. She has no more money for a lawyer, she said, and is representing herself.
TONY GILIBERTO is an artist, once a painter of fine-lined abstractions and now, increasingly, large, vaguely organic motifs. When he and the woman with whom he was living, also a painter, came to New York City from Chicago in 1980, they looked for months for a loft they could rent that would be big enough for two studios.
"We looked in the Flower District, in TriBeCa," he recalled. "The prices were ridiculous; then one day we saw an ad for a raw loft with 4,000 square feet."
The landlord was asking $1,000 a month; it seemed like a lot of money.
"Our friends from Chicago who had come here before us told us the price looked too high," Mr. Giliberto said. "I told them, 'O.K., yeah, wait two years.' "
The couple rented the loft, and began turning an empty, vast space -- the whole floor in a brick building near the Public Theater on Lafayette Street -- into a house. They both worked, lugging massive panels of sheetrock, carting in a toilet and shower tiles and kitchen appliances. "It was a black pit," he said.
They built two separate studios -- her 1,000-square-foot studio in front, his 1,200-square-foot one in back -- and designed the living space in the middle. Like many lofts, its strength was its huge open spaces; there were just a few walls, to enclose the bathroom, the one bedroom and some closets.
Now there are more walls. They broke up in 1985, and neither wanted to give up the rent-stabilized apartment. Neither had the money to buy the other out.
"At the time we didn't know what would happen," said Mr. Giliberto. "She talked about moving out, then she decided to stay. We really had no choice. Loft space of this nature has become very precious; you can't find another 4,000-square-foot loft rental -- landlords have made two 2,000-square-foot lofts."
Such lofts are rarely available for purchase, and very expensive; in that location, a raw loft that size might go for $500,000 or more.
After they split up, Mr. Giliberto and his former woman friend lived in the big loft alone, separated by a big new wall they both built to separate them. The division is awkward and completely removes the feeling of spaciousness.
Part of the awkwardness -- both physically and otherwise -- is due to the fact that there is only one bathroom. And, as in most lofts, it is impossible to build another one because of the layout -- the existing bathroom is sandwiched between the elevator and the kitchen -- and because there is only one set of plumbing risers. The big kitchen, with its center island, is also shared.
The division became even more awkward when, several years later, Mr. Giliberto married. The man and the two women lived in the loft, and shared the bathroom and the kitchen.
Now that marriage has broken up, and the loft's two original renters are living there alone again -- in the space that is both shared and separate.
"Is it awkward? Was it awkward?" Mr. Giliberto said. "Yeah, it was; but in New York, after a point you learn to live with those kinds of things."
MONICA GETZ was married to the late Stan Getz, the musician. While she was married, she bought -- with, she said, her own money that was put into a joint account -- a grand house with a gardener's cottage, stables and other outbuildings, overlooking the Hudson River in Irvington, N.Y. Throughout her 32 years of marriage, she raised five children and, she said, managed Mr. Getz's career. After he left, she said, he and his lawyers sought to take the house away from her.
Even though Mr. Getz is dead, she is left with a court order to sell the house and divide the proceeds 50-50 with his heirs. After 16 years of litigation, she said, she has reached a settlement and, she hopes, will continue to live in the house. The musician's widow said the house was once actually placed under contract against her wishes, but, hearing of the controversy, the would-be buyer, a developer, backed out.
"It was a great surprise to me the way the system functions," she said. "It is not a user-friendly system but an abuser-friendly system. When it comes to real estate, the moneyed spouse too often gets his way; the more money to employ lawyers that can thwart the system."
Mrs. Getz, the founder of the Coalition for Family Justice, a lobbying group formed to address these concerns, criticizes the equitable distribution bill that became law in 1980 in the administration of Gov. Hugh L. Carey.
"We have a 'no-fault' attitude even though we supposedly don't have a 'no-fault' system," she said, referring to the fact that New York is one of a dwindling number of states that still relies heavily on establishing "fault" in a divorce. (There is a "no-fault" provision after a waiting period of one year in certain cases.)
"One spouse can walk out and leave the other in the lurch and then hide his assets and stall," Mrs. Getz said. "Judges take a like and dislike to one side, and barracuda attorneys know how to play the judges."
"Without any other assets, the court will order the house sold, and the family living there is put at a disadvantage," she said, "and because the house is sold under duress, you get a lot less. The moneyed spouse can escape with all the assets intact, and the non-moneyed spouse can end up homeless."
"Is the law perfect?" asked Eleanor B. Alter, a well-known Manhattan divorce lawyer. "No, but it works pretty well." She, too, knows of a wall: one spouse built a wall to separate two warring factions. "He left the wife and children with no windows," Mrs. Alter said. "We went to court and got her money to move out."
"Downstate, in cases of long marriages -- over seven years -- we've had relatively equal treatment," Mrs. Alter continued. "Upstate, it varies a little more."
The real problem, she said, "is what the real problem always is: for the very rich, it's great -- there's large amounts of money and property to divide -- but where it gets harder is for the middle class, because people don't have a lot of assets."
"Mortgage payments become a problem," she said, "if the dwelling is given to the non-income-producing spouse and the other has to provide the money. It's hard."
Divorce lawyers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut agree that their divorce laws were reformed precisely to avoid unfairness and economic hardship. New York was the last of the three states to introduce "equitable distribution" of assets.
And although they say their separate and varying systems generally work well, they concede the systems' strongest point -- its flexibility -- depends on impartial judges and honest disclosure of assets. Lawyers themselves say that each judge has different prejudices, and that, according to one lawyer, "you have to pitch the case differently depending on the judge."
"Everybody has to deal with the baggage of different judges," said William T. Fitzmaurice, chairman of the Family Law section of the Connecticut Bar Association, generally applauding his state's flexibility in determining spousal contributions. "You take a case of inherited property to five different judges, and you'll get five different opinions," he said. "It puts a lot of pressure on having a very wise judiciary."
Divorce lawyers freely admit that good representation costs money, sometimes a lot of money. "As a practical matter, equitable distribution has a lot of problems," said Mr. Bronstein, a Manhattan divorce lawyer who represents both men and women. "It's burdensome to litigate; many people have the family home and pension funds and not much money in the bank -- and that's everybody in the world. For those people to have to hire a lawyer -- well, frequently the bills, and I'm not talking about overcharging, just the real amount of work -- can consume a good part of the equity."
To many of the divorced people interviewed, their problems were caused by judges who did not understand the real facts. The emotionally charged atmosphere surrounding many divorces is reflected in charges of corrupt judges, dishonest lawyers and lying spouses. But even in the case of the two artists who bisected their rent-stabilized apartment, all share one condition: their living arrangements have been vastly changed -- arguably for the worse -- by the divorce or separation.
Divorce lawyers argue that it does not have to be that way. Some suggest having prefiling conferences with a lawyer, to plan strategy; the strategy may include establishing residence in a neighboring state because the differing states treat property brought into the marriage or inherited differently. And the laws may vary as to the amount of flexibility a judge can use.
If one spouse does not have the money to buy out the other, a long-term pay-out can be calculated, according to Mrs. Alter. Several lawyers emphasized the importance of a prenuptial agreement laying out who will get the house and other property in case of divorce or break-up. "It may be unromantic," said Mr. Bronstein, "but it certainly pre-empts the judge."
To eliminate wrangles over signatures on jointly held co-ops and houses, Mrs. Alter recommends making sure names are removed from leases and deeds and mortgages at the time of the settlement. (If the non-moneyed spouse is left with the house, and is worried that because his or her income may not be enough to stand scrutiny by a co-op board or mortgage company, Mr. Zimmerman suggests getting the documents signed to accomplish the transfers before the divorce but not submitting them to the board or the bank until necessary -- when the property is to be sold.)
In the most extreme case, Mrs. O'Sullivan, the mother in Albany, said if the house is about to be foreclosed, it may be possible to file for bankruptcy to stop the action.
Mrs. Getz says her organization would like to see spousal support guidelines: mathematical formulas for computing support, just as in child-support cases -- with prison sentences for those who lie about their assets.
Until then, she advises spouses to keep their assets completely separate, although lawyers agree that is not always a guarantee of their protection. With the reforms to divorce laws, judges have more flexibility in distributing assets regardless of title. In Connecticut, even separate property brought into a marriage or inherited during the marriage -- or even after the separation but before the decree -- can be taken away. Even pension funds are vulnerable, lawyers say.
Others counsel couples that, no matter how angry they are, it's better to work out the divisions -- including the house -- themselves before bringing in the lawyers and running up the bills.
Mr. Thomas, the real estate agent, advises the partner with the money to be more generous -- so the other spouse won't have to resort to obstinate and self-destructive behavior like refusing offers and neglecting the property.
But in the end, there probably will always be wrangling over real estate. And Mr. Skoloff, the divorce lawyer from New Jersey, said he thought the fairest way to award the house when the two parties each refuse to give it up was the oldest way.
"They toss a coin," he said. "Really. The judge orders it. Or they have their minister -- someone they trust -- draw a name out of a hat. All or nothing -- although the other one gets reimbursed for his or her share.
"It's funny," he said. "After all that gut-wrenching and struggling, they seem to accept it that way. They walk away, they accept it, knowing they won or lost the house because of dumb luck."

HEADLINE: Man of the Century

BYLINE: By Robert Klein; Robert Klein will appear on Broadway this spring in A Thousand Clowns.

 BODY:

GEORGE BURNS and The HUNDRED-YEAR DASH
By Martin Gottfried.
Illustrated. 327 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $23.
 
100 YEARS, 100 STORIES
By George Burns.
224 pp. New York:
G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95. 
 It is a daunting task to write accurately about a man as prone to hyperbole as George Burns is. He tends to give delicate or unpleasant matters his vaudeville shine. He will omit or change facts regarding a previous marriage here or a case of gonorrhea there, but always with a joke and a cigar-puffing change of subject. As a centenarian, and a gregarious one at that, he has provided a host of witnesses to the latter portion of his remarkable life -- but, alas, few to its beginnings.
What Martin Gottfried, the author of several show business biographies, can tell us in "George Burns and the Hundred-Year Dash" is that Mr. Burns, the remaining one of 12 children, appears to have had three lives: pre-Gracie, Gracie and post-Gracie. Born Nathan Birnbaum on Jan. 20, 1896, in New York City, he has managed to live through the entire century so far. He enjoyed success in vaudeville, teamed up with Gracie Allen in 1923 and made intelligent and timely leaps to radio, movies and television. Later, he became a hands-on producer of hit television shows like No Time for Sergeants and Mr. Ed. (One learns in passing here, somewhat distressingly, that Mr. Ed's mouth was manipulated by tugging a nylon mesh cloth, but that is another story.)
Natty, as Gracie called him, could barely read, yet he earned a fortune. Despite his wealth, he kept in touch with his old vaudeville pals. He also had a best friend in Jack Benny, adoring children and a wife and career he loved. The wife and career were one and the same. Still, Mr. Gottfried explains, he lived with a fear that Gracie would retire and he would once again be exposed as a straight man without a comic. She did and he was.
In a Job-like reversal, Gracie's death in 1964 sent George into a prolonged depression. What saved him was the discipline he had learned in vaudeville, especially the importance of routine. Just as the routine of impeccable preparation was the key to performance success, so it would be the key to his life. Go to the office even with nothing to do there. Lunch at the Hillcrest Country Club, lightly, of course, with all the comedians. Play cards. Take a nap. Drink martinis. Visit Gracie's burial place regularly. He carried on a kind of psychotherapeutic monologue with her. One would love to have heard it.
The stuff of George Burns's soul is humor. It is a way of coping, it is a way of life. By all accounts, including Mr. Gottfried's, his best stuff was delivered in the living room rather than on the stage. The opposite was the case with Jack Benny.
Some of the book's funniest moments deal with George Burns's mystical power to make Jack Benny laugh -- any time, anywhere. Jack would physically collapse laughing in response to even an inane Burns remark about ice water or sidewalk grates. The grand irony of both their lives is that Jack's demise was the seminal event in George's remarkable film career in his later years.
Too ill to work, Jack suggested to the director Herbert Ross that George take his place in The Sunshine Boys (1975). George memorized the lines for the audition and was perfect. Here was the ever-dapper straight man, shorn of toupee and flashy vaudeville pretense, giving a brilliant portrayal of an old man. The old man won an Oscar and began several new careers, including movie star and America's beloved gerontology poster boy.
HE was finally a solo hit at 80. His social life, never boring, now took an especially positive turn. Despite a lot of hilarious patter about being feeble and old, he apparently enjoyed a steady sex life with women who were more than half a century younger than he was. This was part of his routine, too -- and nice work if you can get it. As he strode into his 90's several 100th-birthday engagements were set, and the hype was on. He insisted that he couldn't die. "I'm booked," he said.
So why is this well-written, good-natured, admiring book a little depressing? As George would know, timing is everything. On his dash to 100 he stumbled, literally, at 99, injuring his head in a bathroom fall and having to endure brain surgery. Since that event, and despite physical healing, he has begun to fail. He must use a wheelchair and has apparently lost much of his considerable wit to age. A surprise? Hardly. Yet we were hoping he could overcome nature like a talented old athlete beating the odds. It will not be. Especially moving is Mr. Gottfried's report that he sometimes shows his frustration with his memory loss. Enfeeblement is a scary thought for someone whose acuity was a trademark. It turns out that show business, his greatest love, is double-edged. What a pity to contemplate him at 99, tiny and infuriated about having to cancel some gigs.
"100 Years, 100 Stories" will serve as a sort of professional farewell for George Burns. The book is composed of 100 short anecdotes, plus two as a "bonus," none longer than two pages. They are clearly oral in origin, well told and very economical in the manner of George Burns's monologue style. It is easy to hear his cadence in the words, which were presumably spoken into a tape recorder. Many of these stories are funny, and literally history. Some have been heard several times before. A few are broad, like vaudeville routines, while others are more personal, like the ones about his delightful torment of Jack Benny. George Burns has thousands of them but only 100-plus are presented here, for obvious reasons. Happy birthday, George.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry

BYLINE: By JAMES POLK 

 BODY:

SHOCK WAVE
By Clive Cussler.
Simon & Schuster, $25. 
 Ian Fleming used to write books with plots like this: an odd-looking, sinister fellow without redeeming qualities but with unlimited resources threatens to disrupt life as we know it by unleashing a high-tech cataclysm -- and there is only one impossibly competent, impeccably tasteful, finely chiseled man who can possibly stop him, although it's hard to imagine just how. In "Shock Wave," the sinister one is an Australian diamond magnate named Arthur Dorsett, "a troll from Teutonic folklore who'd just crawled from an underworld cave." His scheme is to cause the collapse of the worldwide diamond market and, in passing, to kill every living thing in Honolulu by means of a convergence of ultrapowerful, low-frequency sound waves emitted from four sites around the Pacific rim. On our side is Dirk Pitt, master of derring-do, who (when he's home) lives in an abandoned airplane hangar with his stunning collection of antique machinery and an ample supply of tequila, and who works for the National Underwater and Marine Agency, a vague but well-funded organization headed by Admiral James Sandecker. Pitt (who seems blessed with more lives than several cats) and Dorsett start down the inexorable road toward confrontation when our hero, accompanied by his faithful sidekick, Al Giordino, rescues the villain's estranged daughter Maeve Fletcher from a test run of daddy's "acoustic convergence" off Antarctica. No sooner has she been brought to safety than Maeve realizes she "found Pitt immensely attractive and wanted him, yes, feverishly and shamelessly wanted him." The feeling is mutual, but first there is the matter of saving millions of lives and preserving the world's economic order. Had he cared more about characterization than about his extravagant plot, Mr. Cussler (the author of a dozen previous novels, most recently "Inca Gold") might have had a stronger book, for the relationship between Fletcher and Pitt, beneath its exaggerations, offers possibilities. He might also have spared us some really unique similes -- when, for example, Pitt flashes one of his foes "a smile as hard as the handle on a coffin." JAMES POLK

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:

FRANCO: A Biography
By Paul Preston. Basic Books, $25.
He was a ruthless dictator who profited from luck, but he was also a shrewd strategist who rebuilt Spain's postwar economy, our reviewer, Paul Johnson, said last year. Although Mr. Johnson felt this biography overly emphasized Franco's evil, he found it "full of fascinating details . . . like Boswell on Johnson."
 
A SON AT THE FRONT
By Edith Wharton. Northern Illinois University, $14.
The war at home is the theme of this novel, first published in 1922 and never before available in paperback. Drawing on the author's experiences, it portrays the collision between the aloof sensibilities of American expatriates living in Paris and the ardent desires of the French to defend their land in World War I. John Campton, a divorced American painter, is loath to have George, his French-born son, join the fighting at the front. But George's desires intervene. M. F. Egan, writing in The New York Times in 1923, said of Wharton's novel: "So far she has done nothing that equals it. She sounds the finest depths of sentiment without becoming sentimental."
 
THE BELL CURVE: Intelligence and Class Structure
in American Life
By Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray.
Free Press, $16.
Engendering furious debate when it was first published, this book contends that intelligence can be effectively measured, that it correlates with future success and that its presence among the country's elite is a matter of genetics. It "makes a strong case that America's population is becoming dangerously polarized," Malcolm W. Browne said here in 1994.
 
WONDER BOYS
By Michael Chabon. Picador USA, $13.
Set at a literary festival, this novel stars Grady Tripp, a former prodigy who now faces writer's block, a troubled marriage and a pregnant mistress. "Mr. Chabon is that rare thing, an intelligent lyrical writer," Robert Ward wrote in the Book Review last year.
 
SCHOOLGIRLS: Young Women, Self-Esteem,
and the Confidence Gap
By Peggy Orenstein in association with the American Association of University Women.
Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.
Spurred by a report on adolescent girls' dwindling self-esteem released in 1991 by the American Association of University Women, the author interviewed and observed students in two middle schools -- one suburban, the other in a low-income area. Ms. Orenstein found both groups of eighth-grade girls less assertive and confident than their male peers. "This important book should be read by parents raising children of all ages and of both sexes," David Halberstam said in these pages in 1994. A more hopeful picture emerges from IN THESE GIRLS, HOPE IS A MUSCLE, by Madeleine Blais (Warner, $11.99). This book chronicles the 1992-93 season of the Lady Hurricanes, a Massachusetts high school team that finally won the state championship that had long eluded them. "Ms. Blais vicariously joins the girls in their joyful discovery of physical and emotional strength," Gail Shister wrote here last year.
 
COCONUTS FOR THE SAINT
By Debra Spark. Avon, $11.
If love is perfect knowledge of another, then Maria Elena, a young Puerto Rican woman, feels shortchanged. Enlisting the help of her fianc's triplet daughters, she struggles to find out the history of the widowed baker she has promised to marry. In 1994 our reviewer, Abby Frucht, found the story "enough to secure Debra Spark's future as a novelist."
 
AGUIRRE: The Re-Creation of a Sixteenth-Century Journey Across South America
By Stephen Minta. Owl/Holt, $11.95.
In 1560 a rebellious Basque murdered the leader of a Spanish expedition on a quest for El Dorado and took over his troops. The author retraces the steps of the adventurer, Lope de Aguirre, using original documents to penetrate the mystery of his mind. "It's a highly dramatic story, and the author tells it well," Rand Richards Cooper said in the Book Review in 1994. Another enigmatic explorer is portrayed in CHARTING THE SEA OF DARKNESS: The Four Voyages of Henry Hudson, by Donald S. Johnson (Kodansha Globe, $14). Drawing on ships' logs and journals, the author reconstructs Hudson's poorly documented life, which ended in 1610 with the mutiny of one of his crews. It offers "fascinating material," Douglas A. Sylva wrote here in 1993.
 
MIZ LIL AND THE CHRONICLES OF GRACE
By Walter Wangerin Jr. Harper Paperbacks, $5.99.
In this autobiographical collection of stories, the author travels between his Midwestern childhood and his years as the white pastor of a mostly black inner-city church. He "seems to have discovered a lot about how people are put together and what satisfies and stirs our hearts," Peggy Payne said here in 1989.
 
DEAD LAGOON
By Michael Dibdin. Black Lizard/Vintage Crime, $12.
The author's detective hero, Aurelio Zen, returns to his native Venice, where he contends with kidnappers, drug smugglers and possibly supernatural forces. Mr. Dibdin "has transcended his own superb craftsmanship," Marilyn Stasio wrote in the Book Review last year. Laurel Graeber

HEADLINE: Why Economic Growth Won't Melt the Iceberg

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert Eisner disputes the overwhelming consensus that Social Security and Medicare are facing an imminent demographic crisis ("These Figures Spell Good Times, Not Bad," Viewpoint, Dec. 24). Instead, he argues, economic growth will take care of everything. 
 Mr. Eisner is like an officer on the Titanic, telling us all is well even as the iceberg comes into view. The iron logic of population demographics cannot be evaded, and the old notion that growth will somehow allow us to escape the consequences is plainly wrong. The "growth" we enjoyed over the last 15 years was largely restricted to the highest links in the economic food chain; the majority of workers have seen real wages stagnate or steadily decline.
The coerced rise of two-income households, persistent low savings rates and continued high consumer debt are convincing evidence that most families already live close to the edge. Worse yet, our increasingly regressive tax system has abandoned any effort to tap the beneficiaries of growth to finance Government obligations, preferring instead to impose ever higher indirect and payroll taxes on the disenfranchised working poor. Under these circumstances further growth will continue to enrich people and corporations at the tip of the pyramid, while everyone else loses ground.
Dominated by powerful corporate and financial interests, fearful of angering some voters, our Government lacks the political will to make even the smallest meaningful reform -- even if it might head off the coming calamity. Rather than making our tax code more progressive, compelling those who have benefited most to contribute in kind, our "leaders" now talk about an even more regressive flat tax. It boggles the mind. Franz Kafka would understand, but I don't.
As our ship of state approaches the iceberg, Mr. Eisner shouldn't claim everything is just fine. It may already be too late to avoid the collision.
 
GEOFFREY WITTIG, M.D.
Dansville, N.Y., Dec. 26

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Into an Income Portfolio Some Risk Should Fall

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
WITH a portfolio of more than $500,000, Johnny Byrd of Norfolk, Va., seems to be the kind of investor who could afford to relax.
Instead, Mr. Byrd, with the help of his financial planner, Robert Tull of Chesapeake, Va., has spent the last three years searching for ways to bolster the small returns from his income investments like certificates of deposit. 
 So far, Mr. Byrd, who used to supply dry cleaning services to the Navy and is now in his late 70's, hasn't fared badly as an income investor.
Last January, for example, he put some of his money into two-year Treasury notes, locking in an impressive coupon rate of 7.5 percent. At the same time, he turned to a local credit union to buy a one-year C.D. that yielded 6.25 percent. This month, he rolled over that certificate into one yielding 6 percent, about one percentage point above the current average for one-year C.D.'s.
Mr. Byrd's investments in bond funds have also done well. Last year, his investment in the Vanguard Fixed-Income Intermediate fund returned more than 20 percent, while his total investments in Vanguard bond funds returned almost 18 percent. By contrast, the average taxable fixed-income bond fund returned 16 percent last year.
"I'm conscious of my investments every day," said Mr. Byrd, who meets with his adviser a few times a month and watches investment programs on television most days. "You always try to learn something."
Income investing does not have to be an oxymoron. Investors can get an adequate return if, as Mr. Byrd does, they shop around. Financial planners also say investors can bolster returns by trying investments that are a bit riskier than certificates of deposit, like preferred stock, bond funds, real estate investment trusts and even junk bonds.
Tim Kochis, a financial planner in San Francisco, urges income investors holding longer-maturity products to move "down the maturity curve," probably to the three- to five-year range, especially now that short- and intermediate-term investments have unusually high yields relative to longer-term ones.
And Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., says income investors should not ignore the stock market. Investors should focus on total portfolio returns, he said, instead of immediate interest and dividend payments. And that might mean putting a significant part of their money into stocks, even if the risk makes some income investors uncomfortable.
If an investor put $100,000 into the Fidelity Intermediate Bond fund in December 1985, the portfolio would have grown to $113,000 by December 1994, Mr. Evensky said. If the investor had split the money equally between Fidelity's bond fund and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the portfolio's value would have reached $169,000. "Over time, equities simply have better returns," Mr. Evensky said.
To encourage his clients, two-thirds of whom are retired, to focus on total return, Mr. Evensky recommends establishing two accounts. One would be highly liquid, holding about two years of cash flow in a combination of money market and bond funds. The other would be for more growth-oriented investments, like stocks. To build in a second tier of liquidity, Mr. Evensky advises his clients to put perhaps 20 percent of the money in the second account into bonds of under five years' maturity, so that even if stocks made up 50 to 60 percent of their total assets, his clients would be able to sleep comfortably at night.
When it comes to bonds, Mr. Evensky recommends that income investors stick to high-quality products and diversify them. He advises investors not to buy individual bonds, but to stick to bond funds.
"In order to diversify adequately, you need to diversify by issuer, and here you need at least 10 different positions, which takes a lot of money to do adequately," he said.
Stephen Janachowski, an investment adviser in San Francisco, also urges caution on bonds, especially when investors buy them to hedge an equity-laden portfolio, rather than to provide a steady stream of income. "With the former investors, I typically see them become too opportunistic, often trying to pump up their returns with an aggressive junk or foreign bond, even though the yield difference may be just 1 percent," Mr. Janachowski said.
"Don't try to get cute with a bond portfolio," he added. "If you need more income than you're getting right now, that probably means you either have to reduce your expenses, or go for a growth investment like stocks."
For a income investor who wants a well-diversified bond fund, Mr. Janachowski's current top pick is an intermediate-term fund, the Harbor Bond fund. Mr. Tull likes the Vanguard Wellesley Income Fund, which had a 26.3 percent return last year, as well as the Sogen International fund from Charles Schwab, where investors pay no sales charge.
Benefits may also be found in municipal bonds, which offer tax advantages -- especially for investors in higher tax brackets.
"Municipals are priced pretty attractively," said Marilyn Gunther a financial planner in Southfield, Mich. "If a good-quality one were paying 5 percent, and if a taxpayer were in the 28 percent tax bracket, the effective yield would be 6.95 percent."
Ms. Gunther has also been telling her income clients to invest in preferred stocks, because many yield more than 7 percent. She is recommending Morgan Stanley preferred and also the trust-originated preferred securities offered by the Ford Motor Company.
What about junk bonds, many of which are yielding a relatively staggering 10 percent?
Despite the possibility that a stable economy could bring even higher yields for junk bonds, Mr. Tull said they remained too volatile for many investors. Ms. Gunther, however, suggested including junk bonds in a portfolio through higher-quality funds like Kemper High Yield or Fidelity Advisor High Yield.
To reduce the volatility of the investment, she recommends that investors withdraw no more than 80 percent of their annual interest every year.
Financial advisers seem less divided on the potential benefits of real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, which buy property and return most of the income to shareholders. They yield far more than most stocks, averaging 7.7 percent. But when real estate prices collapsed in the 1980's, investors in these trusts lost millions of dollars.
Ms. Gunther is convinced that the underlying value of the trusts will keep climbing as the real estate market improves. She recommends that investors look at REIT's like Walden Residential Properties, with a yield of 8.7 percent, and BRE Properties, at more than 8 percent.
Mr. Janachowski called REIT's "an interesting play for people who want an inflation hedge." As inflation increases, he said, so should the value of a REIT's property. But despite the popular assumption that REIT's are conservative investments, he cautioned that they "really act like equities."
Mr. Janachowski said investors should stick to REIT mutual funds, like Cohen & Steers Realty Shares. Mr. Tull adds that in order to endure any unpleasant surprises, like another collapse of the real estate market, most investors probably should not commit more than 5 to 7 percent of their portfolios to the trusts.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 9; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 487 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Imploding Windows, Rent Increase and Exploding Tempers

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON 

 BODY:
Like hundreds of his neighbors at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, Harold Levine was frightened and furious when newly installed windows in his apartment began shattering two years ago. Because of a defect, nearly 2,000 windows, each with argon gas between their two panes, imploded soon after installation in the two complexes.
The landlord, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, had all 147,000 windows fitted with capillary tubes to equalize the pressure on each side of the glass. Now, the sound of breaking glass has been replaced by the hue and cry of tenants furious about a rent increase to pay for the windows, including a lump sum each is charged for the period between installation and repair. 
 Last month, the commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, Joseph Holland, granted Met Life a rent increase to cover the windows' $30 million cost. And he ruled the increase could be retroactive to the installation date, which varies by apartment. The permanent increase will be about $36 a month per apartment and the retroactive payment about $800.
The ruling by Mr. Holland, an appointee of Gov. George E. Pataki, reversed a decision by his Cuomo-appointed predecessor, Donald M. Halperin, who had rejected Met Life's request for a rent increase to pay for the windows. Residents of the complexes, with a total of 10,000 units, vowed to fight Mr. Holland's decision in court. "They installed a lemon at a Cadillac price," said Mr. Levine, 79, who has lived in Stuyvesant Town since it opened in 1947. "We're getting bamboozled."
Like many elderly tenants in the middle-income complexes, Mr. Levine, a retired zipper salesman who lives on Social Security, says the rent increase will be a burden. The $700 rent for his two-bedroom apartment will rise to about $790 for two years, to cover the retroactive charge, then go to $736 a month. He and many other residents also insist the new windows do not protect against noise and cold air because the argon gas once sandwiched between the panes has been released. "I get drafts and more noise than I had with the old windows," he said.
But a spokeswoman for Met Life, Nancy Peskin, said the windows function as intended. "We've been assured by two independent consultants that the capillary tubes haven't reduced the windows' thermal qualities," she said.
Jack Lester, a lawyer representing the tenants, says that Mr. Holland's ruling "is contrary to law, logic and fairness," and that he will file a lawsuit in State Supreme Court arguing that Met Life should get far less than the $36 monthly increase because the repaired windows are defective and that any increase should not be retroactive.
Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a lifelong Stuyvesant Town resident, agrees. "Who ever heard of collecting money for defective merchandise?" he asked. "If these were cars, they would have been recalled."
 ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Way to Cash In as Insurers Get the Urge to Merge

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
THE life insurance industry, its growth sputtering, has not been a big player in the recent surge in mergers and acquisitions. Investment bankers aren't breaking their spears on the shields of opposing investment bankers. There are no rapacious raiders, no blustery moguls. No barbarians. No Gates.
Even so, insurance-industry analysts say, there are opportunities for investors who are willing to be patient and a bit nontraditional. Instead of hoping for huge gains by trying to figure out which companies may be acquired, the experts say, it may be smarter to buy the acquiring companies, like SunAmerica, which bought three life insurance companies last year. 
 And although a few publicly traded companies, like the U.S. Life Corporation in New York, could become tempting takeover targets, most deals are likely years away.
For now, however, investors can participate in only a limited way in any deals brewing in the life and health insurance business, whose 1994 assets totaled $1.9 trillion, or roughly the gross domestic product of Spain and Germany combined. Industry assets probably reached $2.1 trillion last year, according to A. M. Best, an insurance rating service in Oldwick, N.J.
Publicly traded insurance companies making aggressive, even hostile, bids for other insurance companies is a little distant, so there is little for investors to buy.
Of the 20 or more life insurance deals in 1995, most involved companies selling their noncore insurance businesses, said John A. Hall, a senior insurance analyst at Northington Partners in Avon, Conn. Ford Motor, for example, sold its life insurance unit to SunAmerica last November for $172.5 million.
The insurance companies that bought the units got a good, even cheap, price. "They bought from motivated sellers," Mr. Hall said. "The next phase is insurance companies selling specialized units to other insurance companies for better fits, like a life insurance company that wants only life insurance or a property and casualty company that wants only property and casualty. The price goes up for that group.
"But the highest price of all," Mr. Hall continued, "is when a public company goes after another public company, and that won't happen in earnest until all the other cheaper subsidiaries are bought up."
Analysts say that as many as 20 percent of the more than 1,500 public and privately owned life and health insurance companies face consolidation. Many of these merging companies will be mutual companies, which are owned by the policyholders, rather than shareholders. Eventually, public companies will also join the fray.
Several forces compel the consolidation. The insurance business has been slow to computerize, so operating costs have grown and profit margins have narrowed. Industry return on equity was 16 percent in 1990, 11.5 percent in 1994, and is expected to have dropped as low as 11 percent last year.
About a third of all life insurance is still sold through the old-fashioned -- meaning expensive -- way of distribution known as the door-to-door sales agent. An agent's commission can total as much as the first year's premiums on a policy.
And with overall interest rates low, the return on investment for insurance policies is 8 percent or less. With mutual funds posting double-digit returns, insurance policies lack allure. The industry has therefore expanded its sale of investment products with tax advantages, like tax-deferred annuities that yield as much as 1.25 percent above certificates of deposit.
Perhaps the biggest force behind consolidation is that Americans are simply living longer and see less need for life insurance.
"When you buy life insurance, you are trying to protect certain assets," said Lawrence G. Mayewski, senior vice president for Best's life-health division. "But there is less compelling need to purchase, or if you have purchased, retain a policy once the kids have left school."
Health care has become a far more important issue for a graying population, and life insurance companies have responded by selling long-term disability insurance to provide for nursing-home and home health care coverage. 'You're really looking at the risks of living too long," Mr. Mayewski said.
Despite the innovations, the industry is growing slowly and some companies are stagnating. Best says the amount of new insurance premiums written has risen between 1 percent and 3 percent annually for the last five years, compared with 4.5 percent to 8 percent annually between 1980 and 1987, the last period of robust growth.
For investors, it is difficult to figure out which life insurance companies are likely to become acquisition targets, especially because many of these will probably be privately owned mutuals whose transactions differ in accounting procedures from those of publicly owned companies.
Andrew Kligerman, an insurance analyst at Schroder Wertheim, said an exception is U.S. Life, which has a strong balance sheet with some $7 billion in assets in 1994.
Mr. Kligerman has a buy recommendation for U.S. Life based on its potential attractiveness as a takeover target. While U.S. Life's earnings have been flat in recent years, its earnings potential appears sustainable over the next five years. At 11 times earnings, Mr. Kligerman thinks its stock is cheap. It closed Friday at $32.375, off 62.5 cents.
Whether an investor will see a big run-up in the price of a stock that looks like a takeover target is unclear because few public insurance companies are taken over. Mr. Kligerman said he thought a takeover premium of 15 percent was reasonable. That compares with 10 percent to 20 percent for banking, according to George A. Bicher, a banking analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons.
It is far easier to look at insurance companies likely to do the acquiring, because of the efficiencies a round of consolidations will probably bring to the industry over all. Mr. Hall of Northington Partners likes five companies -- American Bankers Insurance, American General, Jefferson-Pilot, Penncorp Financial and SunAmerica -- that bought insurance companies in 1995 and, he says, are likely to buy more in the near future.
But he notes that even these companies have been only making smaller acquisitions of a few hundred million dollars each. The big acquisitions will probably come in an industry shakeout that may last five to seven years.
Washington is part of the reason. A revamping of the health care system will affect profit margins at life and health insurance companies as well as hospitals and H.M.O.'s. A cut in the capital-gains tax would make mutual funds even more attractive, hurting the insurance business even more.
"Nobody wants to pull the trigger on a deal with that hanging over your head," said Mr. Mayewski of Best.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Acquirers' Stock Also Rises"
Contrary to the market's usual reaction when a company makes an acquisition, Wall Street has generally bid up the stock of the listed insurance companies when they have bought other insurers.
