SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 4; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3092 words

HEADLINE: All You Need to Know About All You Need to Know

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
New York has always been a place where people will tell you where to go. What's remarkable is what a business it has turned into.
The first guidebook to New York City dates from 1807. Its author was Dr. Samuel L. Mitchill, and its title was "The Picture of New-York: or, The Traveller's Guide through the Commercial Metropolis of the United States. By a Gentleman Residing in this City." A compendium of municipal data (it notes eight daily newspapers, five semi-weeklies and six weeklies), descriptions of the urban landscape (the park in front of City Hall, then under construction, was planted "with elms, planes, willows and catalpas"), annotated journeys on foot and by boat along the Hudson, and the occasional review (Mechanic Hall, on Broadway, was "one of the most genteel Hotels in the city"), the city's initial guidebook was, in short, a worthy and recognizable progenitor of the genre. 
 Still and all, Dr. Mitchill would probably be astounded at what he eventually wrought, a veritable flood of published instruction, reflection, direction and suggestion aimed at both visitors to and residents of "the Commercial Metropolis of the United States." At this point, whole bookstore sections devote themselves to city guides, both of the comprehensive and the specialized varieties. Books in Print, under the headings "New York City: Description," and "New York City: Description-Guidebooks," lists more than 300 titles. In October 1994, City and Company, a brand-new publishing house devoted to city guides, offered the first four specialty volumes (including "How to Meet a Mensch in New York" and "The New York Dog Owner's Guide") of a list that has now grown to 16.
For a browser, even a dedicated one, the sheer variety is daunting, much in the manner of the city itself. (A guide to guides would be helpful.) And for many specific purposes, there is little choice -- I could find only one dog lover's book: take it or leave it. But many of these books overlap in their territory, so what do you do then?
The reasons for the proliferation are manifold, but together they speak to the traditional appeal of New York: the variety of cultural and intellectual life keeps the people living here and creates curiosity everywhere else.
"First of all, there are just so many people in New York, intelligent, curious people who know enough about New York to know there's a lot about new York they don't know," said Karen Cure, editorial director of Fodor's Travel Publications, which published two New York City guides in 1989, and this year will publish eight different volumes, aimed at both visitors and residents. "And these are people who know there is a lot they can learn from a book. Society's getting more complicated, and people are feeling overwhelmed and guidebooks do organize and systematize the world for them."
She continued: "There are a lot of niche markets in New York; in Atlanta, there may be people interested in pet cemeteries but not enough pet cemeteries to do a book about. There are in New York, and there are also enough people who'll go out and buy the book."
Actually, the marketplace had taken over enough by the turn of the 20th century that niches in the guidebook market had sprouted. You could find information about city rail and steamboat schedules, the locations of churches, banks and insurance offices, and cursory descriptions of restaurants, museums and hotels. By the 1880's, Appleton's Dictionary of Greater New York included a section on slumming, explaining to the bourgeoisie how to arrange a tour of the city's seamier side.
The mid-century even featured guides to brothels, some straightforward, some rather sneakily offered with a veil of disapproval.
"It was a genre," said Barbara Cohen, a co-owner of New York Bound, a bookshop in Rockefeller Center specializing in historical and contemporary works about the city. One 1839 volume was titled "Prostitution Exposed, Or, A Moral Reform Directory: Laying Bare the Lives, Histories, Residences, Seductions, Etc., of the Most Celebrated Courtezans and Ladies of Pleasure of the City of New York." A typical entry: "Jane P. Williams . . . resides at 148 Leonard Street . . . Rather well-formed and about 35 years of age . . . Keeps a good house and some very handsome girls . . . Prices moderate."
But 150 years ago there were no guides specifically aimed at cat owners, architecture appreciators, Jews, women, newcomers, crime aficionados, Francophiles, dance enthusiasts, children, peregrine falcon lovers, antiquers or apartment hunters. The arts scene may have been flourishing, but it had no comprehensive directory of performance spaces and repertory companies like the estimable "Applause: New York's Guide to the Performing Arts" (Applause Theatre Book Publisher, 1992) by Ruth Leon. The city may have been a grueling place to live even then, but there was no guide to coping like "The Intrepid New Yorker: How to Turn New York City Into a Manageable Small Town" (Villard Books, 1993) by Kathy Mayer Braddock and Tory Baker Masters. It offers voluminous advice (some of which is mere common sense) for consumers on things like how get better service from your butcher or avoid long lines at the bank.
There were no tours of ethnic enclaves, no lists of the best nightspots, coffeehouses, beauty services, places to find peace and quiet, public artworks, things to do on a Sunday or adult education courses. There was no published advice on how to get your child into private school, how to get a divorce, how to find a public toilet or how to live and die (a guide to negotiating the maze of New York probate court). Certainly there was no need for a book called "How to Beat a Parking Ticket" (J. F. Caroll Publishing, 1994). As diverse as they are, what all guidebooks have in common is that they are books; they are for reading, and to treat them as reading material is a way of choosing the ones that will best serve you.
Take the example of restaurant guides, of which there are dozens, many of them by well-known critics, like John F. Mariani and Peter D. Meltzer ("Passport to New York Restaurants 1995," Passport Press, Ltd., 1994) or Sylvia Carter and the Newsday staff ("Eats NYC," Andrews & McMeel, 1995) , to name a couple of the more prominent. Each has its own opinions, rating system, writerly style. How to choose? Isn't it a question of whom you trust?
But this is true even for the books that are mostly charts and ratings and straightforward information, like the Zagat's restaurant guide, the city's biggest seller.
An annual survey of diners, it uses the Zagat formula, which is to collect opinions, collate them and give them back to us as ratings and capsule commentaries. Now the publisher of more than 30 guides to restaurants, retailers and hotels, Zagat is among the leaders in the guide expansion derby, and the success of the line is largely formulated on the voice that emanates from its pages. Without actual words, we know whom we're listening to: us. That's both comforting and trustworthy. It is no wonder that the formula has spawned many imitators.
The restaurant guide is, of course, the prime example of the guidebook as before-the-fact reference: you consult it for a pragmatic purpose, to choose a place to eat, and consult it before you go.
There are, however, whole other categories that raise the question of what a guidebook is for. Do you read it at home or take it with you?
For example, consider guides to the city's architecture and social topography. The most comprehensive remains the AIA Guide to New York City, (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1988) by Elliot Willensky and Norval White. A neighborhood-by-neighborhood, block-by-block, building-by-building assessment of the city's notable structures, it is written, not without attitude and opinion, but almost in notes form, so that it isn't so much a reading experience or a prescription for how to see the city, but an on-the-spot reference.
On the other hand, Gerard R. Wolfe's "New York: A Guide to the Metropolis" (McGraw-Hill, 1993) is a text-heavy tome organized in 20 well-informed walking tours, and thus falls between the practical extremes. It's reasonably well-written but not a particularly good read; from an armchair you can appreciate the ample history it includes, but not the visual sense of what's being described, and there is a distinct disadvantage in not having the physical orientation the text carefully provides. On the other hand, this is a pretty dense piece of work to be grappling with as you walk.
"Seeing New York," (Temple University Press, 1995) by Hope Cooke, has some of the same problems, acknowledged in the subtitle: "History Walks for Armchair and Footloose Travelers." The book is essentially a collection of essays, organized in the form of walks through neighborhoods, and all written according to personal theory and consistent theme: that one gets rooted in a place by tracing its history. It is, I think, a reader's book first. If Ms. Cooke's voice is to your liking (the writing is authoritative but occasionally precious), you'll want to follow her out the door.
Next month, Citadel Press will publish "Infamous Manhattan," a book-length walking tour of the sites of the borough's most famous, grisly or interesting crimes, by Andrew Roth. Better researched and more elegantly written than a previous volume on the same theme, "New York Notorious," (Crown Publishers, Inc., 1992) by Paul Schwartzman and Rob Polner, which was nonetheless notable for its wisenheimer, tabloidlike prose, "Infamous Manhattan" is a perfect example of a guidebook that is better reading than it is service. It is full of wonderful historic tidbits -- it says New York's first murder victim, one Gerrit Slomp, was stabbed in a brawl outside a tavern near Broadway and Beaver Street on July 22, 1648.
It is written with wry, deliberate mischief."The great quantity of bad behavior in New York has given this city not only a fearful reputation," Mr. Roth writes, "but also a deep and fascinating criminal heritage."
There's much for a reader's pleasure, but what would you see at the corner of Broadway and Beaver? A bloodstain?
The comprehensive guides, those big monsters ostensibly full of everything, can be divided into two types: those that are group written and researched, and those, like Dr. Mitchill's original, that are the product of a single, monumentally obsessed individual.
Of the former, the first was the mammoth "King's Handbook of New York City," edited by Moses King and published in 1892, and perhaps the best known is "The W.P.A. Guide to New York City," a 1939 volume produced by the Federal Writers Project staff, a Works Progress Administration agency established to provide work relief for writers and artists during the Depression.
Both books are in print, and both make glorious reading, giving period glimpses of the city that, through the care of research and skill of writing, seem if not entirely accurate today then nonetheless valuable for their perspective. Among other things, what is apparent is the geometric inflation of the last half-century: "Prices in the better American-plan hotels range from $3 to $6 a day for a single room with board," the King informed its readers; by 1939, a room at the Sherry Netherland with a private bath had risen to $7.
The King is full of vintage photographs that make the city edifices look like stand-alones, and there is frequently a Margaret Mead tone to the writing, as though the author were a visitor to a previously unexplored territory:
"Novelty in restaurants is abundant variety. In the Chinese district are several Chinese restaurants, dirty, foul-smelling and cheaply furnished. National viands of a mysterious character and national drinks are served at reasonable prices."
The W.P.A. Guide begins with a section on general information, which includes listings, but not descriptions of, hotels, restaurants, theaters and the like, and is followed by descriptive, historical tours of the boroughs. It is full of writerly gems, like the following straightforward and graceful description of how the Bronx got its name:
"The area that is now called the Bronx, called Keskeskeck by the Indians, was purchased from them in 1639 by the Dutch West India Company. Two years later, Jonas Bronk, a Scandinavian, became the first white settler of the region when he bought 500 acres between the Harlem River and the Aquahung. The latter stream soon lost its Indian designation and became known as Bronk's River."
Among the more current crop of team-written, corporation-sponsored comprehensive guides, the main distinctions are of organization and orientation. There are the budget guides, notably Frommer's "New York '94-'95 on $70 a Day," (Prentice Hall Travel, 1994) by Joan Hamburg and Norma Ketay, which is aimed at the middle-class, middle-American visitor looking for a rather middle-of-the-road New York experience. And there's "Let's Go New York," (Let's Go, Inc., 1996) an annual guide produced by Harvard students for travelers who would probably just as soon sleep on someone's floor if they could (probably after finishing the night at Save the Robots, the nightclub) and is notable for its helpfully voluminous listing of cheap eats. (It should be noted that almost all of these current guides devote the lion's share of their pages to Manhattan, with cursory -- sometimes more than cursory -- ventures into the other boroughs.)
The slim Michelin Guide, elegantly designed and crammed with no-nonesense information, is probably the most convenient to carry around. Fodor's gold guide, the flagship volume of an expanding line (the company is planning to release a new guide next fall to compete with "Let's Go"), is the easiest of these guides to read, with uncluttered pages, reasonably eclectic restaurant and hotel listings, excellent, simple maps and generally clear prose, though every now and then, it tries for atmosphere, and New York begins to sound like Damon Runyon would have it:
"Delicate little ladies tottering about in their pillbox hats are really theatrical grande dames with fast answers to the flashers on 8th Avenue," it says, describing the populace of the theater district. "Shifty-looking guys toting battered briefcases turn out to be famous directors; and the girls and boys scuttling through stage doors are chorus members rushing to exchange their Nikes for tap shoes."
"NYC Access," (Access Press, 1994) by Richard Saul Wurman, is neither convenient for carrying -- it's too bulky -- nor, with an organizing principle that lumps restaurants, shops, hotels and notable sights in a particular neighborhood into one long list -- easy to follow.
Two relatively new entrants in this category, from Eyewitness Travel Guides (Dorlin Kindersley, 1993) and Knopf Guide (Alfred A. Knopf, 1994), stand out from the others for their stunning graphics, photos and map overlays; the Knopf, for instance, has a marvelous spread on the birds of Central Park. The Eyewitness book, which skews a little younger, clearly draws on the fragmented video style of MTV and the vivid collages familiar to those fluent in computers.
Anyway, much more enjoyable are the personally written guides that attempt to be as comprehensive as one person's experience can be. The idiosyncrasies are worth the price, quite aside from whether the information is any good. There's a longstanding tradition of such guides: Kate Simon's 1959 volume, "New York Places and Pleasures: An Uncommon Guidebook," remains a classic of the genre, for its arch explanation of city life to the uninitiated.
Herewith, Ms. Simon's description of a New York City saleswoman: "The saleswoman is not rude because her feet hurt -- everyone's feet hurt -- nor from the usual wounds of love and money. Having dealt with women who have the leisure and facade she envies, she has come to imitate the most rarefied of them, borrows in reasonable facsimile their tricks of style, reads the same magazines, and assumes the aloof expression and languid response suitable to the fantasy. . . . When you ask this goddess to wait on you, you have smashed the glass slipper and thrown her into the cinders, Quite reasonably, Cinderella is angry with you."
Of the current guides of this type, four are worth mentioning: "Blue Guide" (W. W. Norton & Company, Inc., 1991), a hugely authoritative text written with an easy formality by Carol von Pressentin Wright, a literature scholar and native Staten Islander, devotes an unusual amount of attention to boroughs other than Manhattan.
"Gerry Frank's Where to Find It, Buy It, Eat It in New York" (Gerry Frank, 1993) has remarkable listings, particularly since Mr. Frank lives in Salem, Ore. Its main irritations are that he shows he is an outsider in enthusiastic commonplace observations delivered as revelations. He tends to write with exclamation points, as in "The fact that most New Yorkers don't own cars ought to tell you something!" There's also, under safety tips, a long list of things not to do in New York, which has the tone of a chaperone on a school outing. And when he claims that his book is comprehensive, there's reason to be suspicious, especially if you happen to be needing a place to eat after a performance at the Public Theater: none of the more popular or well known restaurants in the neighborhood -- among them Time Cafe, Noho Star, Acme Bar and Grill, Great Jones Cafe and Indochine -- are listed.
Finally, a word about two guides written by the English, which are available here but probably meant for fellow countrymen. Michael Leapman's "A Companion Guide" (Harper Collins, 1991) speaks of New York as though it were the moon and New Yorkers strange aliens: "Not everybody on the subway is demented, or after your money," he writes at one point. At another: "New Yorkers love ice cream and have invested it with passionate sensuousness that shows through as they caress a cone and lick the last vestiges of the creamy confection from around their mouths."
Equally nutty but more entertaining is the Cadogan City Guides (Cadogan Books Ltd., 1991) by Vanessa Letts, a poor woman's Kate Simon: "In private, New Yorkers are spectacularly polite; they open doors for women, shake hands at the slightest opportunity, light your cigarettes and insist on paying for meals. They hardly ever swear in front of ladies, and if they do they apologize."
The specific lesson here is applicable to guidebooks in general: Look who's talking.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 976 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Despite New Curb, The Trend in China Points to Openness

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
IN the bad old days, an ordinary person in China could be jailed for listening to a radio broadcast that told the news straight, rather than with a jagged, left-leaning tilt. That was 20 years ago.
After fanatical politics receded and China became a more ordinary police state, listening to foreign news broadcasts became as common as dinner-table discussions of politics: it was fine as long as it stayed home, behind closed doors. That was 10 years ago. 
 Today, people openly curse the Government in restaurants, on the street, over the phone, just as in other countries. Even Communist Party officials talk about the vast corruption within their ranks, about the unnecessary brutality of the 1989 crackdown on the student protest movement, about how the police may be biggest traffickers in pornography.
Nonetheless, there is a line that cannot be crossed. While you can curse President Jiang Zemin as you walk down the street, try standing up on a street corner to draw a crowd and you won't last very long. Like the economy, which is half market-oriented, access to information in China is half open.
In this half world, where nothing is allowed but everything is possible, financial information services were on the "allowed" list until one day last week, when they were abruptly shifted to the "not allowed" list. In typical fashion, the New China News Agency announced that the Government had issued a decree on a new way of supervising foreign financial news agencies, but kept the decree itself secret. So the affected news agencies, Reuters and Dow Jones, were left to puzzle over what it means.
 
Showing Who's in Charge
 In approving the move, the Chinese Government seemed to be concerned more with exerting control over news organizations than with preventing news from reaching the eyes and ears of ordinary people.
In fact, the Chinese have many sources of information to choose from. A lot of people still listen to foreign radio broadcasts for news, but now they have other choices. Instead of the single, deadly dull television station that reigned a decade ago, multiple stations, and even cable TV, in cities like Shanghai and Beijing offer news features and foreign movies. Talk radio includes steamy discussions of sex and personal relationships, while music stations no longer shy away from rock-and-roll.
Shops full of pirated videos, though not officially allowed, offer almost everything you can find at a Blockbuster outlet in New York, though they endure periodic crackdowns when a round of talks with the United States on intellectual property rights is coming up. Official newspapers are still dull, but newsstands also sell semi-official magazines and books with racy stories about crime, prostitution and drugs, as well as books with scurrilous history about well-known political figures, including Mao Zedong and his wife, Jiang Qing.
Until now, the Government had not seemed threatened by the financial news services.
"If they were really worried about what flickered on a Reuters screen, they would have shut them down long ago," said an executive of an American news organization based in Beijing.
Instead, the executive pointed out, financial news services began in China at such a small level that control was not deemed necessary. Before 1990, only a few Chinese banks bought financial news terminals to enable them to trade on world currency and commodity markets.
At least two things will change for the financial news services. First, the New China News Agency will eat seriously into the profits of agencies like Reuters and Dow Jones's Telerate, which have each been making tens of millions of dollars a year from customers in China. It has been trying to set up a competing financial service, and since it hasn't yet, it will simply charge the foreign agencies fees for doing business.
 
Vetting the News
 Second, the New China News Agency will also decide who can get financial wire services, how much they pay, and what they can read on the terminal. It won't be clear how the process of vetting news will delay up-to-the-minute market information until the decree is publicized and the new regime actually begins.
Putting them under tighter supervision is a belated recognition of how large financial services have grown in China. The boom began in 1991, as China's own commodity and stock markets began trading real money, peaked in 1993, and has eased since, after a series of financial scandals led to the closing of some commodity markets and to sharper regulation of others.
"In a way, it's amazing it took them so long," said an executive of a news agency in Shanghai.
After all, the New China News Agency is gaining the same control over financial news services that it has long exercised over Reuters's and the Associated Press's regular news wires, which the New China News Agency distributes to Chinese newspapers. Doing the same with financial news services is only more painful for the freedom that has been enjoyed until now.
The incident is a replay of what occurred in 1993 with satellite TV dishes. After looking the other way for two years while thousands of Chinese bought satellite dishes to receive foreign broadcasts, the Government suddenly announced that no more dishes could be sold to individuals.
Then, as now, the Government didn't mind when there were just a few buyers. But once the few became many, and the buyers less easily identifiable, the bureaucracy began its slow process of making a decision to assert authority, delayed in part because the danger was not deemed critical and in part because those making money off the permissiveness lobbied against any restrictions.
Then, as now, new restrictions are step backward for access to information in China, but they comes after several steps forward. The overall trend is unmistakable.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Though China curbed financial news agencies last week, the trend has been to let more information in. (Jeffrey Aaronson/Network Aspen)

HEADLINE: Seeing Green;
The Red Menace Is Gone. But Here's Islam.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN Americans consider the safety of the world these days, many still seem conditioned to look for end-of-the-world threats that must be confronted. The end of the cold war sparked a kind of intellectual contest to identify the biggest and most credible new enemy. There was unfair trade. Global warming. Computer terrorism. The spread of weapons of mass destruction. Drugs. But none of these caught fire. Even ethnic hatred did not capture Americans' imaginations, as illustrated by the lack of enthusiasm for sending G.I.'s to Bosnia.
But one threat has resonated in the public mind: Islamic holy war. Just last week, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman was sent to Federal prison for life in a conspiracy to follow the World Trade Center bombing with a string of bombings in New York that could have killed thousands of people. The Sheik played the role perfectly; even as he proclaimed his innocence and called himself a martyr of God, he portrayed his prosecution as part of a new cold war against Islam. 
 Exactly what does he represent, though? Is he the emissary of a global threat to America and its allies, or just another opportunist with a claim to God's truth, a band of followers and not much of a future?
Certainly, powerful Islamic movements have sprung up to emulate Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's victory in Iran as they challenge Western allies in Algeria, Egypt, Kuwait, Bahrain, Pakistan. The greatest danger to peace between Israel and the Palestinians remains the Islamic radicals of Hamas. And Iran has tried repeatedly to export its revolution.
So there are many respected intellectuals who see the acts of terrorism and the ubiquitous Muslim diatribes against the West as part of a deepening conflict between an aggressive Islam and a defensive Western civilization. Take Bernard Lewis, the eminent historian from Princeton University, who wrote more than five years ago: "The struggle between Islam and the West has now lasted 14 centuries. It has consisted of a long series of attacks and counterattacks, jihads and crusades, conquests and reconquests. Today much of the Muslim world is again seized by an intense -- and violent -- resentment of the West. Suddenly, America had become the archenemy, the incarnation of evil, the diabolic opponent of all that is good, and specifically, for Muslims, of Islam."
But a number of other experts on Islam think it is a big mistake to see politicized Islam as a unified threat, rather than as a way of thinking that inspires local bids for power. Their argument goes something like this: Overstating the threat, and misunderstanding the role of religion in it, risks playing into the hands of the extremists by portraying Islam itself as the enemy. Algeria's Muslims don't answer to Iran, and there are inherent divisions between the Sunni and Shiite branches of Islam. What's more, the extremists represent only one part of Islamic theology -- those who would mobilize the religion to foment social revolutions, often against repressive, corrupt governments.
"Explosive headline events and acts of violence make it tempting to view Islam through the prism of religious extremism and terrorism," said John Esposito, director of the Center for Muslim-Christian Understanding at Georgetown University and author of a book titled "The Islamic Threat: Myth or Reality?" "But the demonization of a great religious tradition because of the perverted actions of a minority of dissident voices remains the real threat."
In fact, political Islam has become one of the hottest, nastiest debates in academic circles today, mirroring the old debate on how well-organized and monolithic the Communist menace was. Supporters of the notion of fundamentalism as a global threat label their opponents simplistic and naive; opponents label the supporters simplistic and bigoted.
The Council on Foreign Relations, hardly a hotbed of radical thinking, has come under fire for its new monthly newsletter, Muslim Politics Report, a forum for a broad range of thought on Islam. "It's a front for radical Islamic extremists attempting to legitimize their agenda and to put on a friendly face in the United States," said Steven Emerson, a writer who believes the extremists represent a global Islamic conspiracy against America. The council has denied his accusations, with Leslie Gelb, its president, saying: "We consider the report a major contribution to let people know about a range of thinking by Islamic experts and leaders. It will stay. Period."
In Europe, the debate is even more virulent. America's European allies have been skittish about supporting the Muslim-dominated Government in Bosnia in part because of fears about their own Muslim populations. The presence of up to 15 million Muslims in Europe, many of whom are poor and have refused to embrace the ways of the West, has fueled prejudices and fears. Some French schools prohibit girls from wearing head scarves, and Germany has refused to give Turks citizenship.
So it was not surprising that last year Willy Claes, the Belgian who was then NATO's Secretary General, said offhandedly that "Islamic fundamentalism is at least as dangerous as Communism was." The remark prompted King Hassan of Morocco, one of North Africa's most pragmatic and Western-oriented leaders, to retort: "I don't think NATO was created to fight fundamentalism, but to fight Soviet guns and missiles. Anyway, if fundamentalism has to be engaged in battle, it would not be done with tanks."
Several incidents in recent weeks show just how complex the issue is.
Bahrain's ruling family has put down demonstrations by the Islamic Front for the Liberation of Bahrain, blaming them on Iran. But American intelligence has found no evidence that the opposition is anything but locally organized -- spawned by economic discontent, an uneven distribution of wealth and the absence of any political freedom.
The Islamic Welfare Party won a stunning 21 percent of the vote in Turkish elections last month. But a pro-Islamic vote -- for a party that has not been associated with violence -- was the only vehicle for protesting the Government's failure to tackle poverty and inflation.
 
A Handy Explanation
 Under pressure from Saudi Arabia this month, Britain ordered the expulsion of Mohammed al-Massari, an opponent of the regime, to the Caribbean island of Dominica. But the Kingdom itself is an Islamic state that rules by strict Islamic law; what Mr. Masari accuses the royal family of is corruption (which, he says, is un-Islamic).
And consider this: the "green menace" (the new catch-phrase in the debate, after the color associated with Islam) is a convenient way for a leader to explain away opposition based on a country's economic, social and political inequities. In visits to Washington seeking American support last year, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and then-Prime Minister Tansu Ciller of Turkey all told President Clinton that the greatest threat to their governments came from globally linked fundamentalism. While they clearly believe that, they risked sounding like one-time American friends, such as President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines and Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran, who resisted reform to the very end, while presenting themselves as bulwarks against Communism.
Israel's reconciliation with the Palestine Liberation Organization has also helped cast Islam as a larger-than-life enemy. "After the fall of Communism, fundamentalism has become the greatest danger of our time," Shimon Peres, now Israel's Prime Minister, has said. The American Jewish Congress has replaced its "Boycott Report" on the Arab economic boycott of Israel with a newsletter titled "Radical Islamic Fundamentalist Update."
In the absence of other compelling threats to the United States, Islamic radicalism has also seized the imagination of some in Congress. House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who has warned about "totalitarian Islam," led Congress last month to approve $20 million in covert aid to moderate Iran's behavior. No matter that there is no viable opposition to Iran's Government; that the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that despite severe economic problems the regime is not going to collapse any time soon, and that the policy is likely only to fuel paranoia in Teheran that the United States is determined to destroy Iran's Islamic republic. The initiative was so odd that the Administration (which calls Iran an "outlaw state") found itself in the bizarre position of weakening the covert program so its mandate did not include overthrowing Iran's Government.
In fact, Iran, the only country that has tried in a serious way to export an Islamic revolution, provides a case study of how "global, radical Islam" can fail miserably. In 1991, the mullahs failed to respond when Saddam Hussein's army attacked two of the holiest shrines of Shiite Islam, in the Iraqi cities of Najaf and Kerbala. And this year, Iran has shown no inclination to take on Moscow by supporting the Muslim rebels of Chechnya. In its 17 years, in short, the Islamic Republic of Iran may have spread a lot of money around, armed assorted guerrillas and terrorized Salman Rushdie. But its society is far from content and its brand of revolution has simply not caught on.
"The last 17 years has shown that however attractive or influential they may be, no individual or state has enjoyed any kind of unitary leadership in the Islamic world," said Mr. Esposito. "There are religious extremist leaders and organizations, but there is no global Islamic threat."

LENGTH: 1522 words

HEADLINE: A Six-Lane Test Case for a Turnaround on Carpool Lanes

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Twice every weekday, one side of the six-lane Cross Westchester Expressway, better known as Interstate 287, becomes a stop-and-go stream of glowing red brake lights as tens of thousands of drivers commute to and from work. The result has been air pollution, frayed tempers, accidents and countless hours of lost work and leisure time.
Now, after more than a decade of study, state transportation planners have settled on a $365 million fix: a high-occupancy vehicle lane -- or H.O.V. lane, in the parlance of officialdom -- down the middle of the highway, reserved for buses, vans and cars with two or more occupants. 
 In its proposal, the state Department of Transportation predicts that as many as 2,500 commuters an hour will shift from the clogged existing lanes, lured by the prospect of a quicker trip. "It only takes a fraction of people to decide to ride-share or use a bus to make a difference," said Wayne R. Ugolik, a director of travel-demand management on Long Island, where the state plans to spend almost $500 million to extend 12 miles of new car-pool lanes on the Long Island Expressway to 42 miles.
But environmentalists, urban planners and some local politicians say that in the long run, these proposals are no fix at all. In particular, the battle over the future of the Cross Westchester Expressway is becoming a highly visible example of a turnaround in environmental thinking on highways.
Clean-air advocates, who played a major role in the push for car pools and the creation of the lanes two decades ago, now say the concept is failing, largely because states are content to label a car with two people "high occupancy" and because lanes are being added to roads instead of converted from existing lanes.
Studies by transportation engineers have concluded that adding car-pool lanes does not ease congestion in the long run and rarely results in reduced air pollution because they draw more traffic.
The critics say that, in effect, without simultaneous programs to discourage people from driving, high-occupancy vehicle lanes are little more than a new way for highway departments to do what they have always done: solve traffic problems by laying more blacktop.
Environmentalists have focused their criticism on the Cross Westchester Expressway partly because it has not yet moved from design to construction, while the Long Island lanes are almost a forgone conclusion.
Critics say state transportation officials have latched on to the H.O.V. solution for I-287 not because it will work, but because it can be paid for with the help of more than $200 million in Federal funds.
But that money comes from a program that is meant to shunt gasoline-tax revenue into transportation projects that cut pollution and single-occupant-vehicle travel, environmentalists say. Critics contend that the Westchester lane -- which they say would ultimately cost closer to $500 million -- would constitute a waste of taxpayers' money.
Today, the Cross Westchester Expressway is chronically clogged, particularly at choke points like the spot two miles east of the Tappan Zee Bridge, where the New York State Thruway curves south toward New York City and slender ramps link it to the Cross Westchester's western end.
At such points, and in spots where exit and entry ramps come one right after the other, cars weave from lane to lane, slowing traffic to a crawl, according to state highway engineers.
With the number of vehicles on the road expected to rise from an average of about 100,000 a day now to 170,000 a day in 2021, state planners predict the peak periods of morning and evening congestion will grow from one hour to three hours if nothing is done.
Supporters of the Westchester car-pool lanes and similar projects say highway capacity must increase or economic growth will be stifled along with mobility.
In New York's environmental impact statement for the Westchester project, computer-modified photographs of the once and future I-287 show today's congestion alongside a neat vision of trucks and cars smoothly flowing in three lanes, with a scattering of buses and car pools speeding by in the car-pool lane.
Supporters of such projects are quick to point to other H.O.V. lanes around the region and the nation that have turned solo drivers into passengers.
They cite the bus lane leading from Route 495 in Union City, N.J., into the Lincoln Tunnel. Each morning, buses in the 25-year-old lane carry more than 34,000 commuters into Manhattan, more people than all 12 adjacent general-purpose lanes combined.
But those are exceptions to the rule, according to some transportation analysts. The reserved Lincoln Tunnel lane is the ideal H.O.V. lane, restricted only to buses, the highest-occupancy vehicles of all. If all such lanes were operated this way, car-pool lanes would work wonders, said Lee Epstein, director of land programs for the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, which did a widely cited study of H.O.V. lanes in 1994.
But few new lanes today resemble the bus-only lane to the tunnel, Mr. Epstein said. Instead, most require only two people per car, which he termed low occupancy. "A date is not a car pool," he said.
All the car-pool lanes in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut require a minimum of only two riders. Several transportation studies have pointed out that many of these lanes, including those leading to Hartford on Interstate 91 and Interstate 84, started with a three-person minimum, but standards softened quickly as commuters stuck in traffic complained about the empty lane a few feet away, Mr. Epstein said.
Environmentalists also point to many examples of H.O.V. lanes that have been abandoned completely and turned over to general traffic. In New Jersey, the region's first car-pool lane, created in 1980 on a 12-mile stretch of the Garden State Parkway, was opened to general traffic two years later. In another form of backsliding, environmentalists say that lanes once reserved for car pools are increasingly reverting to general use outside of peak periods. And the peak periods themselves are shrinking; earlier this month, for example, the Long Island Expressway increased the hours that its H.O.V. lanes are open to general traffic.
The Chesapeake Bay Foundation undertook its study to assess the impact of highway design on suburban sprawl, a major source of pollution. Indeed, the overriding concern of many environmental groups is the potential for added highway capacity to encourage suburban sprawl, with more commuters willing to drive greater distances. The growth eats open space and creates widespread pollution of water and air, environmentalists say.
Transportation planners, more focused on traffic than on pollution, conclude that newly-built lanes do not ease congestion in the long run. A 1995 study of highway options by the Transportation Research Board, a branch of the National Research Council, stated that where a car-pool lane is added to a highway instead of converted from an existing lane, the process "usually results in decreased average auto occupancy."
"Although politically popular in the short run, it is extremely costly and counterproductive in the long run" to add H.O.V lanes, wrote the authors of the study, engineers at the Universities of Pennsylvania and Delaware.
And the goal of cleaner air is also rarely met, according to several analyses. In a 1994 study, Jon Kessler and Will Schroeer, two economists at the Federal Environmental Protection Agency calculated projected changes in air quality in the Washington region if H.O.V. lanes there were expanded from the current 75 miles to 334 miles of roadway. Car pools would increase, the economists said, but the overall number of miles traveled by vehicles would hardly shrink at all, and air quality would not be measurably improved.
The Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a coalition of environmental and urban planning groups from New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, has submitted an alternative proposal to New York State that would shift the focus from lane construction on Interstate 287 to rebuilding the existing highway so it works better.
By smoothing out choke points and introducing measures to encourage commuters to leave their cars behind or shift work patterns, congestion and construction delays could be reduced and at least $100 million saved, the group said.
But even with novel programs to change commuter behavior, state highway planners said, the region around New York City will need added highway capacity.
Mr. Ugolik said that without it, economic growth on Long Island and in other areas cannot be sustained.
"You've got to have freedom of movement to have economic growth," he said. "And the best way to keep things moving is with H.O.V. lanes."
But Maureen M. Morgan, the president of Federated Conservationists of Westchester County and a member of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, said such lanes are simply business as usual dressed up with a new environmental-sounding name. "It's just the latest version of the old highway building philosophy that got us where we are today," she said.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 8; Column 5; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Everybody's Asking The Question: Whither Gretzky?

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
A couple of weeks ago, in an interview with Wayne Gretzky, a Toronto reporter told the Great One how strange it seemed that he might be traded not once but twice in his marvelous career.
The first time was in 1988, a multiplayer, multimillion dollar deal that sent Gretzky from Edmonton to Los Angeles. 
 "I wasn't traded," Gretzky responded. "I was sold."
The man who bought his contract, the former Kings owner Bruce McNall, is headed to jail for financial fraud unrelated to Gretzky. But the economics lessons seem to have left an impression on hockey's most famous, and highest-paid, player as he begins the second half of his 17th National Hockey League season.
As he took the ice for the Western Conference in tonight's All-Star game in the Fleet Center, most of the talk was of Gretzky's demand that the new owners of the Kings either improve their team immediately or trade Gretzky to a Stanley Cup contender. If they don't, he can leave, as a free agent, next summer. He turns 35 years old on Friday; he is in the autumn of his career.
The Gretzky chatter superseded discussion of Mario Lemieux's brilliant comeback after a year off to recover from Hodgkin's disease and a sore back, and about the new, little lump on Lemieux's neck that is believed to be benign.
It minimized conversation about Mark Messier's leadership of the surging Rangers, or about the problems the Devils are having defending the Stanley Cup.
Instead, the whispers and murmurs were mostly of Gretzky! Gretzky! Gretzky! Should the leading goal scorer of all time stay, or should he go? Which teams will bid for him? Is he hurting his current teammates by telling them, in effect, they are not good enough for him? And, is he hurting his image by appearing to be manipulative as his skills gradually recede from extraordinary to merely superb?
"I don't back down from what I said," Gretzky said at a news conference here. "I have come forward and said my piece. I wanted what was best for myself and what was best for the L.A. Kings. And if what was best for the L.A. Kings was to get some new guys, some young guys for Wayne Gretzky, then all the more power to them. I don't think that is self-serving."
He made his points clearly, often speaking of himself in the third person. Other stars came through during the day, talking to groups of reporters. But only Gretzky needed a big podium and a speaker system. This even though his public visibility has lessened as the Kings' success has diminished.
Sometimes, playing in the southwest corner of the country before increasing gaps of empty seats, he seems like yesterday's fashion, a sports hero from the era of Larry Bird and Bo Jackson.
But apparently, he doesn't wish to just fade away with four championship rings from his Edmonton period. In recent days, the well-oiled rumor mill has had him on the way to St. Louis, with a few other teams listed as faint possibilities. Gretzky predicted that things would be settled last week after a meeting between his agent, Mike Barnett, and the new owners of the Kings.
But the new owners, Ed Roski and Philip Anschutz, didn't even attend the session. Instead, they sent lower-ranking front-office executives.
"The immediate answer that I thought we would probably get didn't really materialize," Gretzky said. "We're still kind of in limbo."
If the Kings wish to trade Gretzky, they have until the deadline of March 20, two months from today and a month before the playoffs. Most players here, at least in their public comments, seem firmly in support of Gretzky, who has scored 827 goals and 1,746 assists in the 1,219 regular-season games.
This season, he has 67 points, fourth in the league behind Lemieux's 100. Fifty-four of them are assists; he still has the feathery passing touch and uncanny creativity to make average linemates look good and good linemates look great. Many would still love to play alongside him.
Craig MacTavish, the Flyer veteran who played with Gretzky in Edmonton, said Philadelphia would be "the best fit in the league for Wayne Gretzky."
St. Louis fans can imagine him setting up Brett Hull; Devils fans can envision him filling their need for an attacking, veteran center; Ranger fans can wonder about a reunion with Messier and other former Oilers now skating in Manhattan.
Barry Melrose, the former coach of the Kings and now a television commentator for ESPN, said Gretzky had told him he would play for less than the $6.5 million he now earns, if it's with a good team. If so, that could undermine the N.H.L. Players Association, which won free agency for veterans in the hope of increasing their wages.
Melrose said Kings players have told him they don't resent Gretzky's comments because some of them want out too, and that most understand Gretzky's desire to play on another championship team.
"I'm hearing everyone say Wayne is doing this as a ploy to get more money and it's not true," said Melrose, who coached the Kings when they made it to the N.H.L finals in 1993. "He's been honest and up front. He's telling the Kings, 'Why not deal from a position of strength?' If they wait, they get nothing." Some around hockey, Melrose included, feel Gretzky would best fit with the Maple Leafs. He grew up near Toronto, and they are a veteran team.
For now, he's still dressed in the black and silver of the Kings, a 16-19-11 team that will appear at Madison Square Garden on Monday night against the Rangers and in Continental Airlines Arena on Tuesday night against the Devils.
Of his team, Gretzky said, "I don't want the thoughts of the organization to be that, 'Well, our plan is to win three years from now.' Because that doesn't do a whole lot of good for Wayne Gretzky. I'd like to have a chance to win now, simple as that."

HEADLINE: Many in Haiti Are Troubled By Marriage Of Aristide

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
At City College in the early 1980's, Mildred Trouillot was a reserved, winsome bookworm, one of a coterie of American-born students whose Haitian roots had been transplanted to New York City.
Last night, Ms. Trouillot, the youngest child of a steelworker and a hospital technician, became the First Lady of Haiti, the wife of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, at their wedding in Haiti. 
 But the couple's romance troubles many Haitians who remember when Mr. Aristide was a Roman Catholic priest, and still consider him a saint-like figure who was somehow above such things.
Mr. Aristide's choice of a light-skinned wife also angers some followers. For much of Haiti's nearly 200-year history as a republic, a rigid social and economic caste system has been based largely on the lightness of one's skin. To some, the marriage of the dark-skinned Mr. Aristide to the light-skinned Ms. Trouillot comes as a disappointment, almost a betrayal, for light skin was once considered to be too patrician.
"Aristide was already married to the Haitian people," said Olrich Charles, a sports instructor in Port-au-Prince, the capital. "This is like a divorce, only three times: first from his supporters, then from his class and finally from the church."
But others applaud the match.
"He's not a priest anymore, so he has every right to get married," said Pe Mack, 30, a musician. "I think he's also made a good choice for a wife: she's smart, she's a lawyer."
Mr. Aristide, 42, won a landslide victory in the presidential elections in December 1990. In September 1991 he was overthrown by Haiti's generals and sent into exile. He returned to power in October 1994, after an American-led invasion, but is to leave office on Feb. 7, when his successor and close friend, Rene Preval, is inaugurated.
The timing of the wedding was closely tied to Mr. Aristide's departure from office because it was feared the union could take attention away from Mr. Preval, a Haitian Government official said.
Although Ms. Trouillot, known as "Minouche," comes from a strong Haitian heritage, counting several judges and lawyers, her family was not among in the economic elite. Her father, Emile, left Haiti in 1958 and two years later his wife, Carmelle, followed. They settled in New York, where Mr. Trouillot worked grueling hours in a steel factory and his wife was a laboratory technician.
Ms. Trouillot, 33, grew up in the Bronx, where she attended St. Barnabas High School. She graduated from City College and from the University of Pennsylvania Law School, and became an associate at Robinson, Silverman, Pearce, Aronsohn & Berman, in Manhattan.
She met Mr. Aristide in 1992 at a lecture he gave at City College. Two years later, Ms. Trouillot was recruited to work as a legal adviser to Mr. Aristide in Washington.
And there a romance blossomed.
After he returned to power, Mr. Aristide officially asked the Vatican to release him from his vows. The Vatican, which had a stormy relationship with Mr. Aristide, largely because of his political activities, has never said whether it granted the request. But the marriage was blessed by Msgr. Willy Romelus, and Archbishop Joseph Lafontant of Port-au-Prince had a role in the ceremony, The Associated Press repoorted from Tabarre, on the outskirts of the capital.
Ms. Trouillot has said she will dedicate her efforts to working with Haiti's homeless and street children housed at an orphanage founded by Mr. Aristide.
The couple were married at Mr. Aristide's modest home -- he has refused to live in the presidential palace -- in a ceremony attended by about 500 family members, friends and foreign dignitaries, including American military officers and Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser.
The couple exchanged vows at a table in the garden, the A.P. reported. The bride wore a simple coral-colored suit, the groom a dark blue one. The simplicity was reflected by the lack of a bridal gown or a bouquet; there was not even a wedding cake.

HEADLINE: DEADLY TURNING POINT: A special report.;
AIDS Epidemic, Late to Arrive, Now Explodes in Populous Asia

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: LOPBURI, Thailand

 BODY:
A ribbon of acrid yellow smoke rose from the crematory as a Buddhist monk approached, clutching his saffron robe in a bony, withered hand. His skin was mottled, his body wasting away from the disease that would soon take his life, just as it had killed two others whose bodies had been committed to the fire only hours before.
"I know that my body will end up here," said the AIDS-stricken monk, Phra Kamthorn Kitisalo, as he entered the crematory, the still-warm ovens at one end of a high-ceilinged room. "I accept that." 
 In one corner, set beneath a gilded statue of the Buddha, was a pile of fist-sized white cotton bags, each containing ashes from an earlier cremation. "These people died of AIDS, and the ashes stay here because the families are afraid to claim them," said the 38-year-old monk, gently lifting one of the dozens of sacks. "They are afraid that they will get sick if they hold the ashes."
Thailand was among the first countries in Asia to fall victim to AIDS, which is now beginning to ravage the world's most populous continent. And nowhere is the devastation more jarring than in this Buddhist temple set among parched hills in central Thailand.
The temple, Wat Phrabat Nampo, is the nation's largest AIDS hospice. Nearly 80 victims are gathered here, waiting to die; about a dozen are monks, some abandoned by their monasteries.
Now the daily scenes of misery and death at Wat Phrabat are becoming commonplace across Asia, where the epidemic is entering a new, visible phase.
AIDS arrived late in Asia, with the virus beginning to spread here in earnest in the late 1980's, more than a decade after it took hold in the United States and Africa. Until now, AIDS in Asia has been mostly a silent, unseen epidemic. The virus has a long incubation period, often lingering in a human body for more than a decade before making itself known in a serious illness.
But for millions of Asians, time is about to run out. The incubation period is ending, and across this continent, the dying has begun.
Asians infected in the 1980's are now falling sick, and they have begun to die in such huge numbers that the epidemic now threatens to dent some of the world's fastest-growing economies, overwhelm hospitals and health-care systems and undermine traditional ways of life. Few Asian Governments are prepared for the health emergency that is nearly upon them.
 
The Disease
Infection Rates Still Exploding
Asian epidemiologists are optimistic that they can avert the sort of devastation unleashed in Africa, where some sub-Saharan countries, including Botswana, Uganda and Zimbabwe, could lose a quarter of their adult population to the disease.
But in absolute terms, AIDS will almost certainly claim more victims in Asia, home to two-thirds of the world's population, than in Africa. Without a cure, an estimated 10 million Asians will die of AIDS before 2015. Last year, nearly 50,000 people died of AIDS in Thailand alone.
Even as the infection rate has peaked in other parts of the world, it is still exploding in Asia, with the virus spreading mostly through heterosexual intercourse. Epidemiologists working with the World Health Organization have predicted that the number of infected Asians will rise from 3.5 million this year to as many as 12 million by 2000.
Last year, for the first time, estimates suggest that the number of people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, was larger in Asia than in Africa. By the turn of the century, more people will be infected each year in Asia than in the rest of the world combined.
And while most of Asia should be able to avoid an Africa-scale disaster, a handful of countries, including Cambodia and Myanmar, and areas of Thailand and Vietnam could face the level of devastation seen in Africa. In Cambodia, an estimated 4 percent of pregnant women are already infected with H.I.V., as well as 40 percent of the prostitutes in some Cambodian provinces.
Asia's most populous countries -- China, India and Indonesia -- do relatively little blood screening, so health care workers cannot say for sure how far the virus has spread, but the available evidence suggests that they face severe epidemics.
The epidemic is in its infancy in China, but the virus is reported to be spreading quickly. Health officials estimate that close to 100,000 Chinese are infected. While the virus is thought to be nonexistent in large stretches of the Chinese countryside, it is spreading wildly in border areas where intravenous drug use is common.
Many epidemiologists believe that AIDS will ultimately claim the lives of more people in India than in any other country. United Nations estimates suggest that 1.75 million Indians are already infected with H.I.V., and that 4 million will be infected by the end of the decade.
Indian victims are mostly in the cities, especially Bombay, the financial capital, and along major national roadways. The roadways are lined with brothels serving truckers, who are thought to offer a transmission route for the virus.
In Indonesia, which has a population of 190 million and is the world's fourth most populous nation, the Government has suggested that as many as two million people could be H.I.V.-positive by 2000. City dwellers are the principal victims, although Indonesian sailors traveling across the vast archipelago country have carried the virus to remote islands.
Asia's other archipelago country, the Philippines, has been relatively lucky so far, with the World Health Organization estimating that only about 18,000 Filipinos are infected with H.I.V., a fifth of the infection rate of Thailand.
Yet some epidemiologists think that the estimate must be too low, given the number of brothels and massage parlors in Manila and other Philippine cities. Whatever the accurate figure today for the spread of the virus, health workers believe the Philippines is headed for disaster because of rampant prostitution -- and because of the opposition of the Roman Catholic Church to anti-AIDS educational programs.
In Asia, like Africa, the virus often spreads through families, with an unfaithful husband infecting his wife and their unborn children. AIDS is killing Asians from all walks of life -- peasant farmers as well as royalty, prostitutes as well as religious men and women. In Thailand, the Public Health Ministry has said that it knows of at least 170 infected Buddhist monks.
"Everybody is dying of AIDS, even the monks," said Phra Kamthorn, the AIDS-stricken monk, who says he was infected with the virus during his days as a prostitute-loving "playboy" before entering a monastery six years ago. "I would see prostitutes every day."
 
The Denial
Populations Pay For State Inaction
To a degree that health experts find startling, many Asian governments are refusing to deal with the AIDS crisis, or even to acknowledge that the disease is a problem.
Their inaction reflects an unwillingness by Asian leaders to accept an uncomfortable truth: that prostitution is a way of life across most of this continent, and that millions of Asian men visit brothels.
In confronting the problem, the notable exception is the Government of Thailand, the Asian country most closely associated with AIDS because of its notorious commercial sex industry. To their credit, the Thais have developed Asia's most effective AIDS-prevention program, arguably the best prevention program in the developing world.
However bad things may get in Thailand, it might have been far worse.
"In Thailand, we've bitten the bullet." said Mechai Viravaidya, a Thai public-health crusader who is considered the father of the AIDS-prevention program.
"But in much of the rest of Asia, the fuse has been lit. You'd think that other Asian nations would learn from our experience, but most of their governments are still in the denial stage -- they've blinded themselves to this problem -- and sadly they will pay for it."
They will pay for it out of their pocketbooks. Just as they were beginning to pull themselves out of poverty and enjoy the fruits of an economic boom that is transforming the continent, millions of Asians are facing an epidemic that threatens to kill them and pauperize their families.
A study by DRI/McGraw Hill, an American research organization, found that by the end of the decade, AIDS could cost Asian economies as much as $52 billion, much of it through the loss of a generation of laborers struck down in the prime of their working lives.
AIDS could condemn some of Asia's poorest countries, notably Cambodia and Myanmar, to more years of misery as they are forced to spend their paltry resources to care for the dying.
"Asia has the fastest growing epidemic in the world, and people there don't seem to realize it yet," said Peter Piot, a Geneva-based epidemiologist who is the director of AIDS-prevention programs for the United Nations. "Thailand is the exception, unfortunately."
 
The Defense
Prevention Efforts Slow the Spread
It was only a few years ago that Thailand was seen by its complacent Asian neighbors as an exception of an entirely different sort -- the only Asian country likely to be decimated by AIDS. From a handful of cases detected in 1988, AIDS swept through this country of 58 million people, its transmission made easy by the availability of commercial sex.
Brothel visits have long been considered a rite of passage for young Thai men. In Bangkok, brothels are found in virtually every neighborhood -- and in some neon-lit neighborhoods, on every corner. A survey in 1990 found that more than 20 percent of Thai men admitted that they had paid for sex in the previous year.
It was a military coup that turned things around. A 1991 army uprising brought to power a transitional Government led by a former diplomat, Anand Panyarachun, who instituted a far-reaching AIDS-education program.
Condoms were widely distributed to brothels and massage parlors, and brothels that refused to insist on condom use were shut down. A public education program required radio stations to run explicit AIDS-prevention commercials at least once every hour.
The results are seen today, with Thailand recording a drop in the number of new H.I.V. infections each year since 1991. According to Government estimates supported by independent researchers, the number of people infected in 1990 was about 215,000, a figure that is expected to fall to 90,000 in 2000.
Researchers say Thai men and the prostitutes appear to have made significant changes in their behavior, with fewer men visiting brothels and more prostitutes demanding that customers use condoms.
By 1994, the Government estimated that only 10 percent of Thai males between 15 and 49 were paying for sex, half the figure from several years earlier. Surveys of brothels showed that condom use has increased to 60 percent, double the rate in 1990. The incidence of other sexually transmitted diseases has dropped during the same period by more than half, additional proof of condom use.
But the Government has no time for self-congratulation. Thousands of Thais are dying of AIDS each month, and Thailand remains a harbinger of the struggles in store for its neighbors. An estimated 860,000 Thais are already infected with H.I.V., a number that is expected to rise to 1.8 million within a decade.
The World Health Organization has estimated that 2 percent of all Thais from 15 to 49 are already infected. AIDS is expected to be Thailand's leading cause of death by 2000, with life expectancy plunging to only 40 years of age by 2010.
Families are being torn apart as parents fall ill and die, leaving children as orphans who often must fend for themselves. A recent study showed that 205,000 Thai children under 15 had mothers infected with H.I.V.
In Thailand's main Klong Prem prison, an average of five inmates die of AIDS each week. About 400 of the 5,300 inmates at the prison are infected with the virus, and the prison hospital has built a 500-bed ward specifically for inmates dying of AIDS.
 
The Devastation
Victims and Survivors Are Left Abandoned
"We have to accept the fact that this is a disaster," said Dr. Sampant Kahintapongs, director of Nokornping Hospital in Chiang Mai, Thailand's second-largest city. "We cannot keep up."
The 320-bed public hospital, one of the city's largest, is being swamped with AIDS patients, with at least one patient dying of AIDS -- and often two or three -- each day.
The overcrowding is so serious that beginning this year, the hospital will routinely turn away AIDS patients who have already been admitted once before for a so-called opportunistic infection, caused by the collapse of a patient's immune system. "We do not have the space to admit them a second or a third time," Dr. Sampant said.
Unrelated to their work, the hospital's own staff members are also being devastated by the disease, with an employee dying of AIDS every two or three months.
At lunchtime, dozens of frail AIDS patients struggled to sit up in their beds to eat, the lucky ones attended by parents or husbands. The others, not as fortunate, are abandoned by fearful relatives, a rare situation in a country that traditionally places high value on closely knit families.
"Sometimes after an AIDS death, the families will not come back to claim the body," Dr. Sampant said. As a result, the hospital is often forced to pay to cremate the bodies and dispose of the ashes.
Poon, a 29-year-old AIDS patient and former prostitute in a beer hall, looked warily at the bowl of dried beef and sticky rice her mother had brought to the hospital. "I know I am lucky that my mother will be here with me," she said. A doctor nearby whispered that she was only days from death.
"I cannot eat the hospital food," Poon explained with a feeble smile, her discolored lips drawing back against sunken cheeks, her hospital gown ballooning around her emaciated body.
"I feel so sick that it is difficult for me even to eat this delicious food from my mother," she said as she slowly lifted a spoonful of rice to her mouth, chewing it with an expression of muffled pain.
Her mother, Aeh, fished into the plastic bag that served as her purse to find a photograph of her once beautiful daughter. Aeh, 67, runs a vegetable stall in a open-air market several miles outside Chiang Mai, and with the $25 she earns each week, she will be left to care for Poon's 8-year-old son when her daughter dies.
"All of my daughter's friends are already dead," Aeh explained in a small voice, trying not to be overheard by Poon. "I love my daughter, but I am angry that she would allow this to happen. She never should have worked at that bar. She knew this could happen. We Thais know about AIDS."
 
The Destitute
Poverty and Piety Leave Many Ignorant
In their understanding of AIDS, Thais are in a distinct minority among Asians. In neighboring countries, there is simply no money or expertise for prevention programs.
After a generation of civil war, Cambodia has been left one of the poorest nations in the world, with most adults earning little more than the equivalent of a dollar a day. The Government is unable to provide most Cambodians with clean water and electricity, let alone an effective AIDS program.
Ignorance is widespread even among Cambodian doctors and nurses. A recent poll showed that most hospital nurses believed that AIDS was a disease of foreigners, and that it could not be passed between Cambodians. Only 5 percent knew that the virus could be transmitted through a shared needle between drug addicts.
Their ignorance may help explain why Cambodia, which had no recorded AIDS cases five years ago, is now confronted with an estimated 90,000 infections.
In other, less destitute Asian countries, ignorance about the disease is tied to the opposition of powerful religious and political leaders who disapprove of sex education of any sort.
In the Philippines, where 90 percent of the population is Catholic, the Government has tried to organize a national AIDS program, but it has been blocked at almost every turn by Jaime Cardinal Sin, the impassioned Catholic leader of Manila, who has described the Government's anti-AIDS program as "intrinsically evil." Church leaders have been known to set boxes of condoms on fire at anti-Government demonstrations.
In Muslim countries like Indonesia and Malaysia, religious fundamentalists denounce anti-AIDS campaigns as an effort to encourage promiscuity. In Indonesia, the country's highest Muslim authority has demanded that the Government limit the sale of condoms only to married couples.
Malaysia is led by a physician-turned-politician, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, but his Government has been reluctant to offer the kind of vast anti-AIDS program that health experts say is vital to curtailing the spread of the virus. The number of H.I.V. infections in Malaysia has jumped from an estimated 2,400 to nearly 30,000 in the last three years.
The president of the Malaysian Aids Council is Marina Mahathir, the Prime Minister's 38-year-old daughter, and she is bluntly critical of Asian governments, including her father's, for doing too little to avert a health disaster.
"I think there's a fear of having to deal with some really sticky issues," she said. "You have to talk about sex, and all the conservative elements of this society don't want to talk about it."
She said that she recently telephoned her father to ask which of his health advisers was briefing him on AIDS. The answer startled her.
"He said nobody was giving him any AIDS briefings at all," Miss Mahathir said. "He said that he'd never had a briefing. Nobody ever wanted to talk to the Prime Minister about AIDS."

HEADLINE: Rich Nations See Slowdown In Economies As Temporary

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Top financial officials of the world's seven richest industrial democracies decided today that a slowdown in economic growth in Europe and the United States was probably only temporary and that existing policies were enough to insure continued recovery.
"We concluded that despite a temporary slowdown of activity in most of our countries in recent months, the underlying conditions for sustained recovery are in place," the French Finance Minister, Jean Arthuis, said in words that were substantially repeated by his American, German and other counterparts. 
 The Deputy Secretary of the United States Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers, said, "There certainly has been some slowing on the European continent that was recognized in the meeting as a matter of some concern." He said American economic growth was expected to fluctuate from quarter to quarter, but added, "We continue to expect solid growth going forward."
The participants also urged Russia not to reverse the policies of economic liberalization partly repudiated by last month's elections, and by President Boris N. Yeltsin's dismissal last week of Anatoly B. Chubais, an architect of change.
"It is very important for our relations with Russia that progress in economic reform go forward," Mr. Summers said.
European officials welcomed recent gains made by the dollar because a stronger dollar would make it harder for American exports to undercut European prices on world markets.
But the president of the German central bank, Dr. Hans Tietmeyer, said, "I am not of the opinion that the dollar has yet exhausted its upward potential."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who returned to Washington for more negotiations on balancing the budget, said on Friday that a stronger dollar was in the best interest of the United States.
In Europe, there has been considerable fear that deflationary policies required in all the key European economies by the terms of a treaty to establish a common currency by 2000 could drag Europe into recession after barely three years of modest recovery.
France, which suffered a crippling three-week national transport strike in December, has revised expected growth this year downward to around 1.6 percent, from 2.8 percent. It could be even lower if Germany, its main trading partner, slumps. But some economists predict only 1 to 1.5 percent growth there this year, down from 3 percent in 1994.
Without stronger growth, unemployment will rise, and with the jobless rate already close to 10 percent in Germany and 12 percent in France, the both Governments are under increasing pressure to bring unemployment down.
When the dollar was at its weakest a few months ago -- 6 to 8 percent below last week's values against the mark and the franc -- there was a tendency to blame it for some of Europe's economic and monetary troubles.
But after Germany, France, Britain and Belgium all lowered interest rates this week to encourage consumer demand, the dollar strengthened against the franc and the mark.
This surprised some experts, because of the unsettling effects on currency markets of the impasse between Congress and President Clinton over the budget. The current United States budget deficit, as a percentage of gross national product, is by far the lowest of the seven countries.
Driven by their treaty on monetary union, the big European countries are all trying to cut their deficits too, and with less government borrowing, interest rates have been coming down.
Since October, average three-month money market rates in Germany have dropped to 3.40 percent, from 4.10 percent, and France has been able to lower them to 3.20 percent, from 7.40 percent, in the same period without provoking the kind of run on the franc against the mark that was set off when the dollar was falling earlier last year.
