HEADLINE: Maine Voters' Eclecticism Easily Bests Party Spirit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SKOWHEGAN, Me., Jan. 18

 BODY:
In elections over the last four years, Ginny Foster helped a Democrat (Bill Clinton) win the White House, a Republican (Olympia J. Snowe) win a seat in the Senate and an independent (Angus King) become Governor.
"I'm pretty much just a Maine person," said Mrs. Foster, a 70-year-old retired special education teacher and a registered Democrat, surprised that anyone would find her voting pattern all that unusual. 
 In Maine, it is not. For years, voters here have resisted party loyalty by exercising a spirited streak of independence rarely seen in other states. This is, after all, where more voters are registered as independent than Democrat or Republican; where Ross Perot made his best showing in 1992, with 30.4 percent of the vote, to nip George Bush for second place behind Mr. Clinton, and where Mr. King in 1994 became the nation's only independent governor.
"Each side thinks I'm too much of the other," Mrs. Foster said today at a center for the elderly.
But few election years in recent memory have offered Maine voters so many possibilities as 1996. The surprise announcement this week by Senator William S. Cohen, a moderate Republican, that he would not seek a fourth term has scrambled state politics top to bottom, much in the way George J. Mitchell did two years ago when he decided to quit the Senate after 14 years, the last 4 as majority leader.
Mr. Cohen's decision has set off a chain reaction of unexpected opportunities, starting with a chance for the state's two members of Congress -- James B. Longley Jr., a freshman Republican who represents the southern district around Portland, and John E. Baldacci, a freshman Democrat who represents the rest of the state -- to abandon the House and join a Senate race that had already attracted a handful of Democrats.
Both Congressmen said this week that they are considering making the Senate race and would reach a decision soon. The possibility that they will enter it has led a wide spectrum of state lawmakers, business executives and former officeholders to consider running for their House seats and, beyond that, has led scores of county and local officials to consider a run for the State Legislature.
"The ground is shaking all over," said Thomas H. Andrews, a former Democratic Congressman from Mr. Longley's district who, having been defeated by Ms. Snowe for Mr. Mitchell's seat, has decided to sit this year out. "No one is sure where it's going to end, maybe all the way down at the school board level."
Prof. Christian P. Potholm, who teaches government and legal studies at Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., said, "The state tends to be moderate, but people here are personality-driven, not ideology- or party-driven."
But Senator Cohen's decision to leave Congress comes at a time that Maine voters appear particularly restless, even as Governor King says the state's economy, battered by the last recession, is improving. In 1994, Ms. Snowe and Mr. Longley succeeded Democrats; Mr. Baldacci won Ms. Snowe's House seat for the Democrats for first time in 24 years, and Mr. King succeeded a two-term Republican Governor, John R. McKernan Jr., who is Ms. Snowe's husband.
The 1994 results, and the voting record of people like Mrs. Foster, also reflect Mainers' general tendency to elect candidates they feel will not stray far from the center.
"There's a powerful middle in the state, and people like to exercise a kind of self-correcting mechanism," said Professor Potholm, adding that as many as 50 people have said they are considering a run for the three seats in Congress in the aftermath of Mr. Cohen's decision.
For now, many voters say the two Congressmen would become the instant front-runners for the Senate seat. But if centrist preferences continue, Mr. Baldacci might be better positioned to win.
As a moderate Democrat, he has supported the compromise budget proposed by the "Blue Dog" Democrats, term limits and tighter controls on lobbying. Mr. Longley, whose father was the state's first independent Governor in 1974, has become more of a partisan -- to the surprise of some state Republicans -- as a strong supporter of Speaker Newt Gingrich on most issues.
Even before Mr. Cohen's announcement, Democrats in the state had begun an aggressive campaign to unseat Mr. Longley with attack commercials and bumper stickers that read, "Longley Votes Wrongly."
With the election 10 months away, many voters say they will wait until the field is set before they decide whom to support for the various offices. Until then, little is certain, except, as Governor King said with a laugh: "This is going to be a great year for political consultants. I'm looking for a big boost in the state economy."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Address to Take Broad Tack

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
White House aides say President Clinton will use his State of the Union Message on Tuesday night to try to rise far above the bitter partisanship of the budget battle and summon the nation to meet the challenges of an "age of possibility" as it approaches the 21st century.
The White House acknowledges that the Republican-controlled Congress would not be sympathetic to a full legislative agenda from the Democratic President. And so, although Mr. Clinton is expected to renew his calls for a budget agreement, an increase in the minimum wage and campaign reform, much of his address at the start of this election year will be a philosophical one aimed largely at an audience beyond the halls of Congress. 
 Offering a taste of likely campaign themes, aides say, Mr. Clinton plans to emphasize that the economy is strong and that the nation has added nearly eight million jobs during his Presidency. But, mindful that many workers remain besieged by job insecurity and stagnant wages, he will call for broadening the base of America's economic well-being.
"The President will argue it's not always a government response that's required, it's not always a response that requires spending of taxpayers' money," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary. Instead, Mr. McCurry said, the President will speak of "challenges that must summon forth the best from the American people as we work together in our communities and our churches and our schools and our neighborhoods to improve the quality of life of all Americans."
Political analysts will be watching to see what kind of vision Mr. Clinton offers for a second term in office and what tone of leadership he adopts before a Congress intensely divided by the unresolved budget dispute.
"The State of the Union Message in an election year," said Stephen J. Wayne, a professor of government at Georgetown University, "should enhance the image the President is trying to project: an image of moderation, an image of reaching out, a very Presidential image. The best thing that could happen for Clinton would be for House Republicans to behave like kindergarteners."
Equally aware of the importance of image in this election year, the Republicans asked the major television networks to allow them a distinctly separate forum in which to offer their 30-minute response. Rather than replying immediately after the President's address, as has become the norm, the Republicans want television time on the following evening, Wednesday.
The networks said they would decide on the request by Monday, but by this afternoon one of them had already done so. ABC said it would provide time to the Republicans only on Tuesday night, because, said Eileen Murphy, a network spokeswoman, "that's where we feel the audience is best served."
Aides say that in addition to the economy, Mr. Clinton will most likely touch on social issues like crime, for instance sketching out aggressive new measures to drive drug dealers and gangs out of housing projects. And, building on steps taken by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich to keep employers from dipping into their workers' assets in 401(k) plans, he is expected to announce new measures to protect pensions. He will also make several proposals intended to enhance the ability of individuals and communities to help themselves, and he may renew a campaign against teen pregnancy that was sidetracked last year with the failure of Dr. Henry Foster's nomination to be Surgeon General.
But much of the address is expected to take a broader, philosophical approach. Mr. Clinton himself has said that he spent his first two years in office behaving too much like a prime minister, too consumed with the details of policy-making and legislation and too little consumed with the Presidential tasks of addressing public values and helping to chart a moral course for the nation.
Now, with his role limited by the Republican ascendancy in Congress, he has been exploring many of the themes -- like the nation's need for the "common ground" that he has often cited of late -- to which he will turn in his State of the Union Message.
To prepare him for the speech, Mr. Clinton's aides solicited work from a vast array of thinkers ranging from the humorist Garrison Keillor to the scholar David Herbert Donald, who recently published a biography of Lincoln. The writing was gathered into a binder that was presented to Mr. Clinton to study before Christmas.
Earlier this month, the President had two White House dinners with political scientists, law professors and historians. Among them were intellectuals who have studied racial polarization, including Henry Louis Gates Jr. Other writers in the group have focused on the lack of civic participation in today's America: Alan Ehrenhalt, the author of "Discovering the Forgotten Virtues of Community in the Chicago of the 1950's," and Robert D. Putnam, a Harvard professor who has explored why Americans now bowl alone instead of in leagues.
"I think the subject of our discussion was whether it's possible to find in the real world a place where citizens' groups can work with government to solve problems," said Benjamin R. Barber, the Walt Whitman Professor of political science at Rutgers University, who attended one of the dinners. "What I liked best about it is I felt a genuine commitment to trying to envision a somewhat long-term horizon and what difference government can make in shaping the kind of country our children will live in."
After last year's address, Mr. Clinton was mocked by Republicans for its length: 81 minutes, a record for a State of the Union Message. Aides have vowed that he will be more concise in this year's speech, which begins at 9 P.M. "The White House," Mr. McCurry said, "fully expects him to be concluded by the time 'Nightline' is on."

HEADLINE: Winning by Losing on Trade

 BODY:
The newly created World Trade Organization issued its first major ruling last week, rendering a judgment against the United States. A judicial panel ruled that a provision in the Clean Air Act discriminates against foreign oil producers, violating trade rules. Contrary to a reflexive denunciation by Pat Buchanan, the Republican Presidential candidate who charged that the ruling threatens American sovereignty, the action shows that the trade organization is off to a good start. In the long run, the W.T.O. will greatly benefit Americans.
It is important to note that the W.T.O. ruled against only one part of the act and affirmed the right of the United States to protect its environment to any extent it wants, as long as the law does not favor domestic producers over foreign producers. The United States has fought hard for that principle because it protects American exporters. The panel ruled that a provision of the Clean Air Act forced foreign oil producers to temporarily meet higher pollution standards than their American counterparts. That judgment was reasonable. 
 The ruling does not force the United States to change its law. If it does not, Venezuela and Brazil, the complainants, would be free to retaliate with, for example, higher tariffs against United States exports. Americans have little to fear. No country relishes a fight with the biggest trading power in the world. Besides, the discriminatory provision expires in 1998, and it will take nearly that long to settle the case if the Administration decides to appeal the ruling, making the whole matter moot.
The ruling helps establish W.T.O. panels as deliberative judicial bodies willing and able to enforce rules of fair trade. That is beneficial to the United States, which brings more complaints to trade-dispute panels than any other country. Washington will win more than its share of cases in the years ahead. The W.T.O. has shown it can keep trading honest. That is a welcome development.

HEADLINE: 'Make No Little Plans'

 BODY:
In an era of shrinking resources and denigration of government, New Yorkers often forget that they enjoy some of the greatest transportation projects in American history, built at public expense. A defeatist attitude prevails about whether government will ever again try to construct anything like the great bridges, tunnels, canals and highways that have long supported the economies of the city and state. It turns out, however, that the resources for one more attempt to think big are there, if the will and imagination are there as well.
New York State is the beneficiary of a little-known $5 billion windfall from the Federal Government, payable in installments over a 15-year period. The money is to reimburse New York for construction of the New York State Thruway under Gov. Thomas Dewey. Back in the 1950's, Washington committed itself to the principle of reimbursement because the state's highway became a part of the Federal highway system. But not until 1992 did Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, get Congress to pass a measure redeeming the earlier commitment. 
 The first payment of about $300 million is coming this year, but it will be dribbled away without notice. Gov. George Pataki has folded the money into the state's overall program for routine maintenance of its bridges and highways. What a waste! These are substantial, uncommitted funds that New York may not see the likes of anytime soon. They should be set aside to build something worthy of past projects that could revitalize the state's economy.
Any number of projects come to mind. The long-discussed rail link to Kennedy Airport from midtown Manhattan is still being studied by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which could put up part of the money. Widening the highway accesses to the airport would increase its value as a hub for freight and passengers. Other projects might include two long pushed by Senator Moynihan: restoring Penn Station to its Beaux-Arts glory by relocating it in the old post office across the street, or reconstructing the Erie Canal and other upstate canals for tourism and recreation.
None of these projects will be realized if Albany continues its constricted view of the role of government. The Pataki administration argues that Mr. Moynihan's windfall is less than it seems, since overall Federal support for highway maintenance is declining. To be fair to the current Governor, it was actually Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Legislature that first determined in 1993 that initial installments of the $5 billion Thruway reimbursement should be used for routine upkeep of the existing system.
But it is Mr. Pataki's huge tax cuts that are now forcing the state to grab the Thruway reimbursement to cover routine expenses. He and the Legislature would do better to think more broadly about the concept of economic growth and realize that government can serve as a stimulus in ways other than cutting taxes.
Nearly a century ago, the great Chicago architect Daniel Burnham was quoted as saying: "Make no little plans! They have no magic to stir men's blood." His was an optimistic era that seems almost foreign today. But there is no reason for New Yorkers to feel that the days of imaginative and useful development ideas are behind them, especially when the money is there to bring them to life.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Heart Of Darkness

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia

 BODY:
I've been following America's U.N. Ambassador, Madeleine Albright, on a tour of the four major civil wars in Africa -- Liberia, Angola, Burundi and Rwanda. This column begins a diary of the trip.
I knew it was going to be a long day when the pilots of the tiny prop plane flying us from Abidjan to Liberia asked me to sign a form releasing the U.S. Government of any responsibility if we crashed. The main airport in once charming Monrovia has been closed by civil war, the pilot explained, and "there is no navigational equipment where we're landing so we may have to orbit for a while to find it." 
 The makeshift Monrovian airstrip was still littered with the carcasses of aircraft from a civil war that began in 1989 and has since left 150,000 Liberians dead and 1.2 million displaced -- out of a population of only 2.5 million people. The first tall building you see driving into town is the Foreign Ministry. It's completely gutted and squatters now occupy every floor, their laundry flapping in the morning breeze.
Liberia, which was founded by American slaves in 1847, is a country in meltdown. It is in the grip of a clique of evil warlords and teen-age gunmen, who rampage the countryside, high on drugs or drunk on moonshine made from sugar cane, where they routinely murder civilians with machetes. It is an African "Clockwork Orange" in which militias don't even pretend to stand for anything other than looting villagers of all they own. Indeed, the militias rarely fight each other. They fight the people. The six-man ruling council, which supposedly runs the country, is made up of three warlords, two political figures and one powerless man whose title is "Representative of the Civilians." Each of the warlords has his own floor in the executive palace, and each also controls ministries and is in private business. Prince Johnson, the warlord who is said to have killed the country's last president, Samuel Doe, by slicing off his ears, used to pass out a business card that said: "Prince Johnson, Building, Construction and Home Repairs."
On the day before we arrived, the Minister of Rural Affairs, Roosevelt Johnson, launched his militia on a terror campaign in northern Liberia. He was allegedly running a scam stealing diamonds there, with the help of a Nigerian peacekeeping unit. The Nigerians, though, changed units and their new commander wouldn't play along, so the "Minister of Rural Affairs" started ransacking rural Liberia, upsetting the African-brokered peace plan, which was supposed to begin Jan. 15 with the militias turning in weapons.
Ms. Albright came to shore up the Nigerian peacekeepers and to browbeat the militia leaders into getting back to the peace plan. Charles Taylor and Alhaji Kromah, two of the ruling warlords, are eager to be interviewed by CNN and myself. While children with distended bellies haunt the streets, these two look as if they have not missed a meal. Their watches are gold, their shoes brightly polished, their offices cool with air-conditioning. They are peacocks strutting through the graveyard, killers with fax machines. Sitting on his pink divan, Mr. Kromah waxes optimistic: "A new Liberia is being born," he says. "We are developing a Renaissance." I leave thinking he is out of his mind.
There is Bosnia envy here. Gen. J. M. Inieger, commander of the Nigerian peacekeepers, says the only way to heal Liberia is for Nigerian forces to occupy the whole country. (Right now large areas outside the cities remain under militia control.)
But that would mean Nigeria increasing its force from 7,000 to 18,000 men, which would require $135 million. "It is what NATO spends in a few days in Bosnia," complains General Inieger. But no one wants to pay for peacekeeping in Liberia. "It is because we are Africans, not Europeans," says Liberian newspaper publisher Sando Moore. "People say, 'They are Africans; let them just kill each other.' "
No, Liberia is a country that will have to liberate itself. We can apply the Band-Aids to reduce the suffering, and we should. But as long as the innocent civilians have only one seat in the ruling council, any major funds poured in here will never get to the people who truly need them. As one U.S. relief worker whispered to me as we left: "I never hear any patriotism here. It's always: 'What are you going to do for me?' The people here have to reclaim their country. They just have to start all over."

HEADLINE: Gay Images, Once Kept Out, Are Out Big Time

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
WITH nearly 32 million acquaintances in attendance, Carol and Susan, two lesbian characters, were married on Thursday on the NBC comedy "Friends." The presiding minister was played by Candace Gingrich, whose brother presides over the House of Representatives.
During any other television season, it would have been the same-sex wedding of the year. This season, it was more like the same-sex wedding of the month. 
 In December, the gay characters Leon and Scott were married on "Roseanne" on ABC. And only two weeks ago, on the NBC comedy "Mad About You," the main character's sister, Debbie, professed her love for Joan. So it is not hard to imagine more commitment-ceremony bells in the future.
A same-sex wedding might have provoked rebellion among network affiliates not too many years ago, but NBC reported that only two -- KJAC in Port Arthur, Tex., and WLIO in Lima, Ohio -- had decided that the "Friends" episode was "not appropriate" for their viewers. On the other hand, 212 affiliates chose to broadcast the segment.
In other words, the biggest news about the wedding on "Friends" was that it was almost not news at all. Lesbian and gay figures are becoming commonplace in mainstream media. And established institutions are growing less timid in courting gay and lesbian audiences.
"This has created discussions in families during prime-time viewing that families weren't having in the 1980's," said Grant Lukenbill, author of "Untold Millions: Positioning Your Business for the Gay and Lesbian Consumer Revolution" (Harper Business, 1995). "It's breaking down stereotypes. The more people are forced to look at what gay and lesbian culture is like, the more they see what we have in common."
The increase in gay and lesbian images may have resulted more from the canny recognition that homosexuals are a powerful part of the marketplace than from a growing belief that they are integral members of the American family.
But the phenomenon itself is beyond dispute.
"We're in the golden era of gay and lesbian visibility," Mr. Lukenbill said. "There's never been a time in history that gay and lesbian people have had this level of exposure in mainstream society. It's reverberating through the Western world."
His assertion is not as hyperbolic as it may sound. After all, it was not a gay magazine that proclaimed, "Let them wed," in mid-January, emphasizing its editorial support of same-sex unions with a cover picture of a tiered white cake topped by two plastic grooms, hand in hand. It was the 152-year-old Economist of London.
Bill Emmott, the magazine's editor, said in a telephone interview that the letters and E-mail received had run roughly 3 to 1 against the magazine, matching both in volume and proportion the negative response to a cover story urging abolition of the monarchy.
"If there was a surprise," Mr. Emmott said, "it was that the hostile letters were quite reasonable. They were not abusive or offensive. And small mercy though that may sound, actually I think it represents something of a change."
Even the Los Angeles Police Department, which was famously antagonistic toward homosexuals, has used a deeply tanned, chisel-faced model in a wet suit to convey its recruitment message to readers of a gay magazine called Urban Fitness. "Not All Our Officers Wear the Same Uniform," the full-color advertisement proclaimed.
Numerous candidates have responded, said Lisa Phillips, whose title at the department is liaison to the gay and lesbian community. There is no way to say exactly how many, since it would be illegal to ask recruits about their sexual orientation, but Officer Phillips said the campaign was "very successful."
Macy's seemed to invite the attention of gay customers in a holiday catalogue of men's wear. It included a picture of two men, one bare-chested, exchanging presents and affectionate smiles. They could have been brothers. But they could just as easily have been companions sharing their Christmas morning.
Nothing explicitly gay was intended, but neither did the store object to conveying a sense that gay shoppers were as welcome as anyone else. "If that's the way you're interpreting it, I can say, 'Thank you and continue to shop at Macy's,' " said Ronnie Taffet, vice president for public relations for Macy's East Coast stores.
Abercrombie & Fitch, another venerable name in retailing, borrowed a fig leaf from Calvin Klein with a two-page advertisment in the December issue of Vanity Fair. It depicted eight football players in a locker-room tableau, three clad in nothing but Abercrombie briefs. The store, a division of the Limited, has also advertised in Out, a gay and lesbian magazine, with shirtless, sinewy fellows wrestling over a basketball.
"We don't segment our thinking about the universe of our customers," the company said in a statement. "Each and every Abercrombie customer is an individual, and our strategy is to provoke a personal reaction in him or her that will lead to greater awareness of our brand."
Or as Mr. Lukenbill put it, "Capitalism thrives off the shrewd use of attractive imagery."
And it is capitalism that may explain growing visibility in a hostile political climate. "While we've got a Congress that does not seem to embrace who we are, the megamillions of the gay market are not being ignored," said Joseph Cohen, author of "You Know You're Gay When . . ." (Contemporary Books, 1995).
Searching for that market, Tanqueray's "Mr. Jenkins" has ventured into a gay bar and sent a gin and tonic over to a "glamour girl," although he "admits she is rather burly for a glamour girl." More daringly, Diesel Jeans and Workwear has recently shown two luminously pretty nurses with their lips only inches away from a kiss.
Physical intimacy is where most television shows draw the line. "There is still a failure to capture the wholeness of what it means to be gay or lesbian," said Lorri L. Jean, executive director of the Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Community Services Center.
Yet, she noted that the range of characters on television had grown appreciably wider. "You don't just have the ice-pick lesbian murderer," Ms. Jean said. "You have the lesbian lovers on 'Friends,' one of whom is the ex-wife of a primary character."
The ex-wife, Carol (Jane Sibbett), was married on Thursday to her new partner, Susan (Jessica Hecht). Performing as the minister was Ms. Gingrich, who heads the voter mobilization project of the Human Rights Campaign, a lesbian and gay political organization in Washington.
Appearances by homosexual characters on network television used to be the topic of conversation for weeks in advance. Now, they turn up so often that even well-informed advocates can lose track. For instance, Ms. Gingrich did not know until she saw the show that Debbie Buchman (Robin Bartlett) of "Mad About You" was about to come out to her television family.
"It's not an event anymore," Ms. Gingrich said. "It's commonplace. It's supposed to be something you could see anywhere. Gays and lesbians are part of the work force. We have relationships. We have commitment ceremonies. When you watch television, you want to see America reflected back. Having gay characters is an accurate way to do that."
As the minister, Ms. Gingrich declared that "nothing makes God happier than when two people -- any two people -- come together in love." But she was not heard to say, "You may kiss the bride." To either one.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

THE MARKET
Sponginess in Technology Gets Wrung Out
"Past performance is no guarantee of future results" is a caveat to investors that ripples through mutual-fund advertisements and prospectuses. It seemed to carry less weight on Wall Street last week, as strong earnings -- a backward indicator -- from I.B.M., Microsoft and Caterpillar sparked another rally in the stock market. The rally came despite some skepticism that I.B.M. could continue its growth and amid reports that sales of Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system were lagging -- and even though Intel, the dominant chip maker for personal computers, and Apple Computer reported disappointing earnings and a loss, respectively.
 
THE FED
Vice Chairman Stands Down
Scarcely a day has passed recently without some indicator showing the economy is slowing. Now, his advice to cut interest rates in order to stimulate growth largely resisted, Alan S. Blinder, has resigned after 19 months as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Blinder was President Clinton's first appointee at the Fed, and until the Republicans gained control of Congress he had been regarded as a possible successor to the chairman, Alan Greenspan. He plans to return to Princeton.
 
JUNK BONDS
Fidelity Bails Out
After dominating high-profile bankruptcies like those of Federated Department Stores and R. H. Macy, Fidelity Investments abruptly announced that it was "discontinuing its aggressive style" of investing in insolvent companies. It also said three key members of its bankruptcy investing team had resigned. A Fidelity spokesman said the funds did not want to play a governance role in reorganizations.
 
TAXES
The Kemp Panel Punts
A private commission, created by Republican leaders and headed by Jack Kemp, recommended that the wages and salaries of all Americans be taxed at a single low rate. But the flat-tax proposal made no mention of the key issues: what the rate would be, whose taxes would change how much, and whether home-mortgage interest deductions would be preserved. Republican Presidential candidates continue to offer competing flat-tax plans, denying the party a unified point it can rally around.
 
DEPARTURES
Viacom Ousts Chief
In 1994, Viacom gave Frank J. Biondi Jr., its chief executive, a $3 million bonus for his role in the acquisition of Paramount Communications. Last week, it gave him a pink slip. Sumner M. Redstone, the 72-year-old billionaire chairman, said he would add the chief executive's duties. Mr. Biondi's dismissal was necessary, Mr. Redstone said, because Viacom needed more aggressive leadership after its acquisition of Paramount and Blockbuster Entertainment.
 
TRADE
Fuel for the Republicans
In a decision that will resound through the election year, the World Trade Organization found that the Clean Air Act discriminates against foreign oil companies and ordered the United States to change its rules. Bob Dole, Pat Buchanan and many other Republicans have been warning that American participation in the W.T.O. would allow foreign judges to rule on the validity of American laws.
 
OVERHAULS
An Agribusiness Giant Adjusts
The directors of Archer-Daniels-Midland unanimously approved a series of measures that would turn majority control of the board over to a group of outside directors -- but no sooner than October. For more than a year, the company has been criticized by some investors, who said it was dominated by insiders even as it was being investigated after accusations of price-fixing and corruption. Some large investors promptly said the changes did not go far enough.
 
COMPROMISES
Pataki Finds a Path
In a rare arrangement that pleased environmentalists, landowners and paper and timber companies, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York found a way for people whose land in the Adirondack Park was damaged by a windstorm in July to clear their land without making enemies. Under his compromise, state foresters will inspect proposed salvage sites in the wetlands, and clear-cutting is forbidden on steep slopes.
 
CRISIS MANAGEMENT
Responding to the Storms
Some employers forced workers to use vacation days if the snow kept them away from work; others knee-jerked away a day's pay. Not so the New York Stock Exchange, which decided to open for three hours on Monday, Jan. 8, despite the blizzard and the snow emergency declared by the Government. Every worker who slogged through the drifts to the Big Board has been rewarded with a choice of an extra day's pay or an extra day off. Those who did not make it in simply missed out on the bonus.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
How a Flat Tax Would Work, For You and for Them

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The big issue in these first weeks of the 1996 Presidential campaign has been how Americans should tax themselves. And most of the talk is about a flat tax on incomes, with a large deduction for individuals so that lower-income people would pay no income tax.
There are about as many flat tax variants floating around as there are would-be occupants of the White House. But all derive from "The Flat Tax" (Hoover Institition Press, 1995), by Robert Hall and Alvin Rabushka, both economists at the Hoover Institution, who devised the concept in 1981 and have been refining it ever since. 
 The two economists say their proposed tax, which would be 19 percent, would spur investment and growth by taxing income only once, eliminating taxes on capital gains and taxing individuals only on wages, salaries and pensions. Interest and dividends would not be taxed directly, but would be affected by a business tax, also at 19 percent. (Businesses would no longer be able to deduct the cost of fringe benefits, except pensions, for their employees, however.)
So how would a flat tax affect the typical family? And how would it affect the tax bills of the Presidential candidates who have pushed the issue to center stage?
The New York Times recalculated the taxes that some of the major candidates would have owed in 1994 had a flat tax been in effect that year, consulting with the Republican candidates' advisers and making minor adjustments to eliminate anomalies in the complex tax returns that are irrelevant to a flat tax.
The two candidates most closely identified with the flat tax -- Steve Forbes, the magazine owner, and Patrick J. Buchanan, the television commentator -- would not make their tax returns available. Mr. Forbes said he would never disclose his returns; Mr. Buchanan said he would make his public if he wins the Republican nomination.
President Clinton and three prominent Republican candidates -- Senators Bob Dole and Phil Gramm and Lamar Alexander, the former Education Secretary -- made available copies of their 1994 Federal income tax returns. (Mr. Clinton opposes the flat tax, as does Mr. Alexander. Mr. Dole has said he would go along with a flat tax. Mr. Gramm favors a 16 percent flat tax.)
All four candidates, whose incomes place them among the top 1 percent of Americans in terms of personal income, would enjoy considerable savings in personal income taxes under the Hall-Rabushka flat tax. A comparison also requires calculating the effect of the Hall-Rabushka business tax on business income, but even with both taxes, all four candidates would see their tax bills decline -- although probably none would save as much as Mr. Forbes, a fervent flat-tax advocate who is one of the wealthiest men in the United States.
Senator Dole and his wife, who had $607,000 in income in 1994, would save about $49,000, and the Clintons, whose income was $267,000, would save about $21,000.
Senator Gramm, who with his wife reported $305,000 in income, would save about $40,000; his aides acknowledged that under his own proposal, which differs considerably from the others, the Senator's taxes would decline even more sharply.
Mr. Alexander's savings would be about $184,000 on an income of about $1 million. The savings would presumably be significantly greater for Mr. Forbes, who has an income of $1.4 million as chief executive officer of Forbes Inc. and a net worth that Fortune magazine last week estimated at $439 million.
The picture is not so bright for the Smiths, a hypothetical family of four used by the Tax Foundation in its analyses of the various flat-tax plans floating around Washington. The Smiths, who have $50,000 in total income, nearly all from wages, would see no change in their individual tax bill if the Hall-Rabushka proposal were put into effect. And if interest rates decline as predicted, the Smiths, who collected $1,425 in interest in 1994, would come out a few dollars behind.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DEVELOPMENT;
Community Consensus for the Navy Yard: Yes on Housing, No on Trash

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
The Brooklyn Navy Yard has long dominated life in Northern Brooklyn, from the days when thousands built warships to the recent battles over a city plan to build a huge incinerator there. The Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation recently received $739,000 from the Mayor's Office to assess the state of the 260-acre plot and figure out how to attract more jobs and businesses to the industrial park. Last week, community leaders discussed what they think should be done with the Navy Yard. SOMINI SENGUPTA
 
Luis Garden Acosta, president of El Puente, a community organization in Williamsburg:
"We have always had a dream of building a bridge between the Latino and Hasidic communities by founding a unity housing community in the Brooklyn Navy Yard so that Latinos, the Hasidim, African-Americans and others in the Williamsburg community could live equally and in peace. At one point there were officers' quarters in the Navy Yard. All that could be razed to create a wonderful landscape for affordable residential housing."
 
 City Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, who represents Williamsburg and surrounding communities.
"First of all, they shouldn't build an incinerator there. Secondly, there's the industrial park portion of the Navy Yard, and that is today a wonderful resource for the city that's been neglected in past. Today, it successfully houses many small businesses and employs a lot of people. It's an example of how to re-use obsolete military facilities. The third component is what I call the campus -- the officers' quarters, the hospital building, the surgeon general's house and a lot of open space. It's 40-some odd acres. I feel strongly that the campus should be part of an overall development strategy for the adjacent neighborhoods. Maybe you could move something from Williamsburg and make room for housing."
 
The Rev. Mark V. C. Taylor, Church of the Open Door in Fort Greene.
"Some of the money should definitely go into a study of a recycling alternative, to build a recycling plant as an alternative to an incinerator and something that leads to job development. After we talk about cleaning up the Navy Yard and looking at recycling, we need to talk about economic development. I think the city has to look at the opportunity and the responsibility of providing jobs for residents of the surrounding public housing."
 
 Rabbi David Niederman, executive director of United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg and a member of the board of directors of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation.
"The community's foremost interest, of course, is housing. The question is, is that suitable or not? We know it has been a dump site for so many toxic elements that part of it had to be put on the Superfund list. As for institutional use, it might be health care, might be education, it could be training and vocational programs that are very much needed in the community. We are also looking for small businesses. One thing we don't want to do is to relocate something that won't bring jobs to the community. If a major manufacturer comes and just relocates his crew, that's not beneficial to the community."

HEADLINE: The 104th Congress at Midpoint: Where Its Major Legislation Stands;
AGRICULTURE

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
The elections of 1994 transformed the Congress, giving Republicans control of both House and Senate for the first time since 1955. As the second session of the 104th Congress begins, here is a look at the progress of major legislative initiatives.
Republicans promised drastic cuts in farm subsidies under the complex programs dating to the Depression. Economists deride as inefficient these subsidies that pay farmers not to plant some fields, lend money to plant other fields and underwrite farmers when crop prices are low. But the payments are popular among farmers and the Congressmen who represent them -- a third of the Republican Party's House and Senate members. 
 Republicans radically revised farm subsidies to make American agriculture more sensitive to consumers' needs while continuing the flow of Government checks to large-scale private and corporate farms in the next seven years.
The plan, which is part of the budget bill, would replace most existing subsidies with an annual payment to farmers equal to most of the money they are receiving under various programs now. The payments would be made regardless of what crops the farmers planted or whether they left their fields fallow.
Clinton Administration officials and prairie populists in Congress criticized the plan because it would not limit the size of payments to large farms and would not provide any increase in payments if prices were low. KEITH BRADSHER

HEADLINE: Of Renters, Artists and Plumbers;
Don't Pick On Us Renters; We Make the City Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert Lipsyte's Jan. 14 Coping column, "My Neighbor and His Renter's Sensibility," implies that tenants are lazy freeloaders who don't have a "sense of community" equal to that of owners like him. 
 This reminds me of the bitter battle during the late 1970's and early 80's in Boerum Hill when gentrification was displacing thousands of working-poor tenants who had lived there for decades. A group of tenants, including me, were trying to get approval to build a small low- and moderate-income housing project on an urban renewal site so that some of us could afford to stay. The new homeowners opposed us, worried that the project would depress their property values.
At one heated meeting, I -- then a 14-year Boerum Hill tenant -- stood up to speak. I was shouted down by a neighbor. "What do you care about the community?" she said. "You don't own a house."
Before the real estate boom of the 1980's, New York was a city of renters. We who can't afford to buy have always nurtured and protected New York's communities. For this we get no tax breaks, no equity, no rental income. Neither as citizens nor as consumers do tenants "take and run," as Mr. Lipsyte puts it. In fact, as he might remember from his own pre-ownership years, for services such as snow shoveling and hall sweeping we pay rent.
 
JUDITH LEVINE
Boerum Hill, Brooklyn

HEADLINE: China's Dam Project Must Go Forward

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Woe to Those Displaced by China Dam Project" (letter, Jan. 19) and your Jan. 15 front-page article on the Three Gorges Dam project: 
 The two photographs of construction activities that you published on Jan. 15 indicate that excellent progress has been made in only a year's time.
All such projects face large problems, and those you cite -- resettlement and waste disposal -- should not kill the project.
Resettlement of a million people means that complaints are to be expected. And the problem of waste disposal must be solved regardless of whether or not the project is completed.
The idea for the Three Gorges Dam project originated in 1919 with Sun Yat-sen, the founder of the Chinese Republic. Many feasibility studies have been made with participation of foreign experts.
In 1946 the United States Government showed great interest by allowing 50 Chinese engineers to visit the United States Bureau of Reclamation to study technology for project implementation.
For the United States to decline assistance to the project because of environmental and human rights concerns would put our Government at odds with the private sector of contractors and manufacturers and would serve to discourage them from competing with the Europeans and Japanese in China's fast-growing market.
China needs this project to provide a large block of energy to sustain rapid economic development, and to control the floods that have killed thousands of people and displaced millions.
Project costs may well reach $30 billion, but stretched over 15 years the cost and challenge will not cause a crack in the dam.
 
CHUNG Y. LI
Silver Spring, Md., Jan. 19, 1996
The writer, a civil engineer, has worked on the design and construction of dams.

HEADLINE: Flat Tax Won't Make Us a Nation of Savers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Flawed Flat Tax and the Way Out" (Op-Ed, Jan. 17): 
 Ordinarily, I would let pass Patrick J. Buchanan's implication that I favor a flat tax. I am sorry to disappoint him and to remove an arrow from his quiver of populist proposals, but I also have strong reservations about the various flat tax proposals, at least as they are currently structured.
Actually, I agree with some, although not all, of Mr. Buchanan's points of opposition to the flat tax. My principal reservations derive from concerns about a basic issue he ignores completely.
All Americans face a common problem.
Our national savings rates is remarkably -- some would say disastrously -- low, and our economic productivity has suffered as a consequence.
To rectify this condition, we need a tax system that, in addition to operating in a fair manner, will both reward savings and stimulate growth in productivity.
A national value-added tax would deal with this fundamental economic problem most effectively by bringing into better balance the imperative to save with the compulsion to spend. A value added tax would also relieve many of us from the exceptionally high burdens now borne exclusively by the income tax. Combined with other reforms of the tax system, a value added tax would offer a more efficient and equitable way out of our dilemma than the hodgepodge of proposals advanced by Mr. Buchanan.
 
DAVID ROCKEFELLER
New York, Jan. 18, 1996

HEADLINE: Flat Tax Won't Make Us a Nation of Savers;
Penalties Abound

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Republican flat tax proposals would have inequitable consequences. 
 Elimination of the residential property tax deduction would affect every homeowner by reducing the market value of property as well as frequently raising taxable income. In many instances property taxes are higher than mortgage interest, and mortgage interest declines as the loan is repaid, while property taxes almost always rise.
The elimination of the tax deduction of state and local income taxes would have a penalizing effect. Residents of states like Texas pay no income taxes, and those living in low-tax states would suffer little. Others in places like New York City who pay substantial state and local income taxes would be punished more.
The proposal to make interest income nontaxable is a time bomb that would neutralize the tax advantage now enjoyed by municipal bond holders. It would force state and local governments to increase the interest rates paid to attract investors.
All taxpayers would have to pay even higher state and local taxes to make up for the additional interest to be paid.
 
JAMES S. STRAUCH
Tenafly, N.J., Jan. 18, 1996
The writer is an accountant.

HEADLINE: The View From: Hamden;
Does a Green or a Golf Course Better Suit the Middle of Town?

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
LILLIAN CLAYMAN, the Mayor of Hamden, has found a solution to what she and other residents describe as a problem: the lack of a town green. She has proposed converting the centrally situated Meadowbrook golf course into one.
Hamden is almost the only town in south central Connecticut, and probably one of the few in all of New England, that has no green to serve as the focus of community life. Mayor Clayman would like to see the 67-acre town-owned golf course, across from Town Hall and adjacent to Hamden's main library and auditorium and the Miller Senior Center, become that focus. 
 To that end, she decided not to renew the contract for the lease on the golf course when it expires on March 31. She has enlisted the Hamden Arts Commission and the town's Parks and Recreation Commission, along with the head of the Department of Parks and Recreation, to come up with a plan for the space. They, along with the Hamden Historical Society and the Hamden Farmington Canal Commission, called a meeting early this month to get public input.
At that meeting, as well as at a previous meeting of the town's Legislative Council in December, golfers voiced their extreme displeasure with recent developments.
They invoked economic, esthetic, athletic and democratic arguments to make their case: namely, that Meadowbrook, as administered by an outside vendor for 30 years, has been a revenue producer for the town; that the town already does a poor job of upkeep on the other parks it administers; that the humble nine-hole golf course provided many Hamden residents -- particularly elderly people and youngsters -- with healthful and very affordable exercise, and that the decision to convert the course into a green was made without a formal public hearing.
To these arguments the Mayor has responded that the $15,000 a year the contract contributed to town coffers until 1992, and the $30,000 a year it has brought in since then, represent an "insignificant" part of the $104 million annual town budget.
She added that the investment required to upgrade the course enough to justify doubling lease revenue again would be economically unfeasible. She disagreed with the claim that existing town parks are not maintained.
Even though she is a golfer herself, the Mayor believes the town residents who have used Meadowbrook as a golf course represent "a select few" compared to the numbers who would make use of it as a public green. Ms. Clayman said it's the Mayor's prerogative not to renew such leases, and that people have had plenty of opportunities to make their views known. There will be more opportunities to do so as plans go along, she said.
Meadowbrook was a dairy farm owned by H. Irving Todd; it was bought in 1920 by the Meadowbrook Realty Corporation for a golf course, according to a 1962 report quoted by the town's director of Parks and Recreation, Stephen J. Humes. The old cow barn became the first clubhouse. The land was bought by the town in 1962 with a $375,000 bond issue.
The report says that "during the period of the development of Meadowbrook, active effort should be made by the town officials to obtain a new location, while open spaces are available at reasonable cost, to begin construction of a golf course in anticipation of the day when Meadowbrook is given over as a Civic Center of Hamden." Subsequently, the town's full-scale golf course at Laurel View was built.
Mr. Humes said interested parties are beginning to consider the possibilities for the Meadowbrook land. One is to shift a portion of the Farmington Canal Greenway to the east, so that it runs along the border of Meadowbrook rather than through the middle of a shopping center parking lot.
Mr. Humes said such a route would save significant money on the Greenway project, which is scheduled to run the length of Hamden into neighboring New Haven and Cheshire, and result in a more scenic trail.
Another idea is to move a 150-year-old barn from the lot of a nearby hardware store to Meadowbrook property for use as an arts and recreational space. The hardware store wants the land for expansion, and the Hamden Historical Society is interested in acquiring the barn for the price of moving it.
Future golfing options at Meadowbrook include a Par Three executive course, a nine-hole Chip 'n' Putt, or miniature golf, Mr. Humes said.
Once the lease expires, the golf course land will revert to town management. Mr. Humes said his department will then fill in the nine holes, secure the clubhouse and maintain the property. He added that the town may set up temporary soccer fields on the site.
At this month's meeting, Daniel Kops, the town planner, explained that a permit from the Planning and Zoning Commission would be needed to make any changes to Meadowbrook once it ceases to be a golf course. Approval is also required from the town's Conservation Commission, since there are wetlands on the property. Finally, any changes must be approved by the town's Legislative Council. Public comment would be invited at all stages.
Golfers have made specific suggestions to try to save Meadowbrook. Michael Albis said, "If the main purpose of a green is to provide space for concerts and other special events, that could still happen while leaving the golf course intact," he said. Furthermore, he noted, "Many towns have a central green, but how many have a centrally located golf course?"
Another golfer, John McGlynn, asked if people were aware of the heritage of Meadowbrook. "Sam Snead even played here at one time," he said. He urged the town to create a "modified green" around the veterans' monument at one end of Meadowbrook.
Several golfers felt that creating a green in the middle of town would lead to an increase in crime or the creation of a wasteland no one would use.
To these objections, the Mayor responded that the land around the veterans' monument is much too small, and that not everyone loves a central golf course.
"Over the four years I've been Mayor," says Ms. Clayman, "people have asked me, 'Why don't we have a green?' I agree with them. I think we should have one." She also said that people who live at Meadowbrook -- a housing development that occupies what used to be the back 9 holes of the formerly 18-hole golf course -- "are sick and tired of having a golf course out their window."
"I told them to be patient," she said, "that I wouldn't renew the contract this year."
Tom Duffy, chairman of the Hamden Arts Commission, solicited volunteers for a task force to explore ideas for the future use of the land. About 40 people signed up.
"I hope this will be a fun process," said Mr. Duffy. "It's a tremendous opportunity; anything could go in that space. Nothing has been decided except that the contract to run Meadowbrook ends on March 31. This is so complicated and will take so long that I'm not sure anybody can say what will happen. No person, regardless of position, could say today with absolute certainty what will be there" when the process is completed.

HEADLINE: ART;
No Simple Innocence, Childhood Now Invoked Has More in Tow

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
MANY who track the shifting enthusiasms of the contemporary art world have noted that childhood is now much in vogue. It's not unalloyed innocence, but rather a convenient area in which to channel the discomfort and anxiety that have marked contemporary art for the last several seasons. Sometimes there is irony, but frequently the art in this vein is more childish than childlike.
These conflicts are present in the exhibition "Playtime: Artists and Toys" at the Whitney Museum in Stamford. But it turns out to be a strong show, in part because the curators -- Jennifer Gauthier, Angela Kramer Murphy and Cynthia Roznoy, all members of the satellite museum's staff -- have buttressed the latest work with relevant pieces that stretch back in art history. 
 The immediate impetus for the show was Alexander Calder's "Circus" (from 1926-31) being temporarily dismantled at the Whitney Museum in Manhattan. The show includes parts of it accompanied by a fetching videotape of Calder taking about his creation.
Other venerable works in the exhibition are photographs for "The First Picture Book: Everyday Things for Babies" by Edward Steichen (1930), and a bronze model from the 1960's for the Riverside Drive Playground by the sculptor Isamu Noguchi.
Part and parcel of the Surrealist movement was the impulse to play games, and the show has good representation by American Surrealists, including Joseph Cornell whose "Memoires inedits de Madame la Comtesse de G." is a small tin filled with strips on which are random words. Putting disparate words together was a favorite Surrealist pastime.
Man Ray, Ruth Bernhard and Val Telberg are other early Surrealist contributors.
The best of the contemporary work has its roots in Surrealism. Vija Celmins's small house is decorated with Magritte-like clouds on its facade, but a blazing fire is painted on its roof.
Some of the new work has an apparitional quality. Michael Ballou's enormous "Big Hand Puppet," for example, lies supine in the middle of the gallery. Jane Hammond's "Clown Suit" has the usual pointy hat and pom-poms for buttons, but it is decorated half with familiar cartoon characters and half with esoteric symbols that might come from tarot cards.
One of the most intriguing new artists is Tony Oursler, because his sculptures are at once obvious and mysteriously absorbing. He makes rag dolls with featureless heads and puts them in compromising situations. His small "Crying Doll" is hung on a pole. On the head is projected a videotape, a human face going through histrionics. Part of the torment of the "Crying Doll" is that the small video projector is as big as he is, very visible, and it never lets him escape surveillance. This work encapsulates the dark undercurrents ubiquitous in "Playtime."
Of course some of the art world's best-known enfants terribles populate the exhibition. Much critical ink has been spilled on Mike Kelley, claiming to find deep existential and psychological depth, as well as a pointed critique of contemporary art in general, in his massings of stuffed toys on blankets. Such meaning doesn't come through in "More Love Hours Than Can Ever Be Repaid," hung like a tapestry on the wall, or "The Wages of Sin," a tower of melting wax candles shaped like childhood icons like Frosty the Snowman.
Nicole Eisenman is another provocateur, but her work in the show -- race cars made from commercial packaging -- is rather tame. Some are economy models, including one made from a box that once held Glad bags, but there is also one fashioned from a blue Tiffany box.
Kim Dingle's work is always horrific: Her dolls are preternaturally adult-like. Her "Priss," exhibited in a crib filled with worn-out toys and empty tuna fish cans, is like the feared substitute teacher of cliche. Ms. Dingle also paints over wallpaper, mixing some of her looming, fat babies with innocent vignettes from an idealized childhood.
One of the healthiest pieces in the show is Chris MacDonald's train of oak, pine, cedar and steel that runs the length of one of the gallery's side corridors.
Complementing the photographs from the Surrealist era is contemporary photography with childhood as a subject. David Levinthal and Laurie Simmons are both expert at photographing toys to resemble altered versions of reality. Sally Mann is sometimes accused of manipulating her own children as if they were dolls. In some non-controversial images, including "The New Mothers," the children lampoon grown-ups. Bleary watercolors by Ellen Phelan have the look of nostalgic photographs. The best of the photographers is the redoubtable Cindy Sherman with her chilling illustrations for a tale by the Brothers Grimm.
This is a big show; bite-size contributions by Chris Burden, Red Grooms and Claes Oldenburg seem extraneous. But a CD-ROM game that viewers are invited to play, devised by Laurie Anderson and Hsin-Chien Huang, is right on the money. Such games are today's form of play, disquieting as that can sometimes be. Any exhibition running from Alexander Calder to Laurie Anderson has, at the very least, the potential for recapitulating the cultural history of this century.
"Playtime: Artists and Toys" is at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford through March 20.

HEADLINE: ART;
Scenes From Photojournalism's Post-Golden Age

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

DATELINE: SOMERS

 BODY:
HAVING begun with a storm that was nothing if not a photo opportunity, the year turns out to be the 60th anniversary of Black Star Agency and Life Magazine. The first represents photographers who seize such opportunities, the second made its name by publishing the results, week after week.
Together, these organizations presided over the golden age of photojournalism in the United States, which ended a quarter of a century ago with the metamorphosis of Life into a monthly, the death of its rival, Look, the transcendence of television and other manifestations of progress. 
 A show celebrating the dual anniversary would properly cover the period, but "Cycle of Voices," a roundup of photojournalists at Nardin Galleries here, does no such thing. And the reason soon becomes obvious: the show is an advertisement for Black Star as a going concern and, as such, looks forward rather than back. Besides, the guest curator, Richard Falco, is a Black Star photographer and, as explained in his introduction, he means to showcase a profession that for various reasons -- most of them economic -- grows increasingly difficult to practice.
Mr. Falco acknowledges Eugene Smith as the perceived "Father of Photojournalism" by including his early 1970's picture of a Japanese woman bathing a deformed child. This comes from the "Minimata" series documenting the effect of mercury poisoning in the Japanese town of Minimata -- the photographer's last assignment for Life.
The curator also incorporates shots by Charles Moore of the civil rights struggle in Alabama, notably one that features an immaculate Martin Luther King Jr. getting his comeuppance in a police station as his wife looks on. The scene is so stiff as to seem like a re-enactment. Otherwise, the miscellany consists of pictures taken during the last decade by a new generation of photojournalists.
The Berlin wall, South Africa, Haiti, Rwanda, the Kurds on the Turkish-Iraqi border, the Palestinian uprising in Israel, the civil war in the Republic of Georgia: The period has lacked neither disasters nor the photographers to document them. There are more than 65 prints on view, all of them serviceable but few of them unforgettable.
This could have to do with the prettifying effect of photographic color, but it may also be that the great shots of these subjects have already been circulated. One example of an act impossible to follow was the picture of a waterfall clogged with bodies, which, taken by a photographer whose name I have forgotten, said all there was to be said about the horror in Rwanda.
Another was Librado Romero's shot of the devastated Federal Building in Oklahoma City under a half moon, a composition worthy of the great Surrealist Max Ernst. Though it has nothing to equal these pictures, the show is not without memorable works, chief among which is Malcolm Linton's color print of a soldier, alone in a Georgian museum that has been sacked. He stands on a floor sprinkled with rubble, surveying the presumed remains of the museum's painting collection, which is stacked against the wall, neatly but sometimes upside down.
More affecting, though, is Christopher Morris's rendering of a summary execution performed in Haiti during the riots of 1994. The victim lies in an empty room, back against a door and hands up to his face as the executioner takes aim from a window on the side. Mr. Morris is also responsible for the scene of a soldier standing over the prone body of a Haitian in the street. This is a tricky picture, for while no handcuffs are visible, the angle of the victim's arms implies their presence, and there is no telling if the photographer took the picture at a dramatic angle or merely mounted it that way.
Photojournalism is a medium fraught with ambiguities, and Joseph Rodriguez provides a classic example in his view of a Harlem interior, furnished by a bookcase stuffed with record albums and, on one wall, a poster advertising the art collections at Amherst College. There is a child yelling in the foreground and, behind, a man on the telephone. The caption, however, says that the child is crying as his uncle "makes drug deals on the phone," thus hinting at a connection between the two activities.
Mr. Rodriguez also covers the domestic side of gang life in Los Angeles by portraying in black and white a man, woman and infant contemplating a dismembered gun. Having gained the confidence of his subjects, the photographer notes in the caption, somewhat priggishly, that "a father teaches his baby daughter how to use a gun," when, -- who knows? -- he may well look forward to her becoming a photographer.
As one of the growing band of curators who include their own work in anthologies, Mr. Falco contributes 10 shots in color, one of them a study of hands poking through an opening in a blue cell door. Though not the first photographer to represent a prisoner by his hands, Mr. Falco does it as scrupulously as a Renaissance painter, locating the opening dead center and providing a glimpse of the man's face through a metal grille.
Predictably, the show is heaviest on violence and its effects, but the scene of a Russian midwife listening by way of a little horn to a baby stirring in the belly of its mother is nonetheless one of the best shots. This is a case where color is indispensable, for the figure of the mother is much enhanced by the wall behind her bed, which is covered by a red cloth riotously patterned with yellow flowers. The scene is set in Bokhara, a town in Uzbekistan, which is famed for its carpets; the photographer is Peter Turnley, whose contributions also include a graphic scene of a man with a rifle bearing down on a looter in South Africa.
Photojournalism may have a short shelf life, but its impact lasts longer than that of television and, for all its flaws, "Cycle of Voices" proves the point. The show continues through Feb. 20. The information number is 276-8485.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

VOICES '96 CONCERT
A chance to dance in the aisles or on the stage, not only without censure but with enthusiastic encouragement, will be offered to the audience at the Voices '96 dance concert next Saturday at 2 P.M. in the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College. 
 Performed by Forces of Nature, a nine-member troupe, the concert is the museum's yearly observance of Martin Luther King Day and Black History Month, and it is appropriate for families. Forces of Nature was founded in 1981 by Olabemidele Husbands and Abdel R. Salaam. Ms. Husbands is the executive director and leader of many master classes and workshops on the history and dance of West Africa and black America. She also serves on the faculty of the Alvin Ailey Dance Center and the Ruth Williams Dance Center in Manhattan.
Mr. Salaam, the company's choreographer and artistic director, has performed with several dance companies including those of Chuck Davis and Fred Benjamin. In 1987 he received the Dance Africa Award from the Brooklyn Academy of Music; in 1988 he won the Morani Shujaa Alumni Award and in 1989 the Carla Sayre Dance Award, both presented by the Department of Black Studies at Lehman College in the Bronx.
Voice '96 is a meld of music, movement and folk lore, incorporating the dance of West Africa with contemporary urban dance in America. After the performance the audience will be invited to a hands-on drum-making workshop. Tickets at $8 are available by calling 251-6110.
 
EARLY PAINTING STYLES
Painting in the style of late Gothic Flemish and Early Renaissance Florentine masters will be taught by Sally Randall, a Manhattan artist, tomorrow and the subsequent eight Mondays at the Rye Arts Center.
Fresco and tempera painting, glazing and other techniques culminating in an original work on wood or slate will be embellished by discussion of artists' writings from 1550 to the present.
Students should have some knowledge of art history and oil painting to benefit from the course, but whether they are abstract, contemporary, figurative or representational painters makes no difference.
Classes will meet from 7 to 10 P.M. through March 25, except on Feb. 19. The fee is $150 plus a $60 materials fee. Limited scholarships are available from the New York State Council on the Arts. Call the center at 51 Milton Road, 967-0700, for more information.
 
'NIXON' DISCUSSION
New York Film Salons will hold a Westchester discussion on the film "Nixon" today at 2:30 P.M. at Happiness Is . . . Cafe, 255 North Bedford Road in Mount Kisco. The salons, held in various spots in New York City and on Long Island as well as in Westchester, give attendees a forum in which to unload their opinions. "Nixon," already critiqued in Manhattan and Brooklyn sessions, has generated lively conversation.
The fee of $20 includes a light lunch, capuccino and dessert. Call 242-0919 for reservations or more information.
 
ARTISTS' WORKSHOPS
A series of workshops devoted to artists' skills is in progess at the Katonah Museum of Art through Feb. 22, offering participants a list of useful outlets for creativity.
On Thursday from 9 A.M. to noon Toni Mahr, a Greenwich-based floral designer, will conduct a class in dried topiaries, using lemon leaves, flowers and ribbons. The fee of $75 covers all materials, but students who have them are asked to bring low-temperature glue guns.
Three Easy Pieces Pottery Design with Jurg Lanzrein, a professional potter formerly with Tiffany & Company, will design dishes and bowls in colored clay. Mr. Lanzrein's work has been featured in Architectural Digest and other publications. The fee of $110 covers all materials. The workshop will be held on Jan. 30 from 9 A.M. to noon.
A two-session workshop on fantasy furniture finishes will be taught on Wednesday and Jan. 31 from 9 A.M. to noon by Ruben Teles, whose work is in the permanent collection of the Museum of American Folk Art. The fee of $110 covers all materials.
Decorative furniture painting in four sessions, mosaic-decorated pottery in two sessions and painted floor cloths in three sessions are on the February schedule. Fees are $150, $85 and $95, respectively, but there may be an additional charge for extra furniture or floor-cloth paints.
The museum is on Route 22 at Jay Street, and the phone number is 232-9555.
 
MEDIEVAL MUSIC
Istampita, a program of medieval music, will be performed by Hesperus, a period-instrument ensemble, next Saturday at 8 P.M. in Sommer Center at Concordia College in Bronxville.
Hesperus is made up of several overlapping ensembles specializing in Baroque, American Colonial, Spanish and American Indian music, and it has developed a conglomerate style.
Formed in 1979 and based in Washington, Hesperus performs with various combinations of recorders, vielle, viol, rebec, lute and dulcimer. Each member plays at least two instruments and sings.
Now in its sixth year as ensemble in residence at the Smithsonian Institution and visiting ensemble at the Corcoran Gallery of Art, Hesperus also performs on National Public Radio and gives 30 concerts a year in the United States, Europe and Southeast Asia.
Some members will give a lecture-demonstration for children 8 and older at 4 P.M. in the center. They will talk about early music play their medieval and Renaissance instruments. Tickets to the concert are $10, $8 for students and people 62 and older. Admission to the children's program is free.
The college is at 171 White Plains Road. Call 337-9300, extension 2431, for reservations.
 
ROCK CLUB'S DEMISE
"Times have changed: Generation X seems less interested in live music," said George Russ, owner of Fore and Aft, a 35-year-old rock 'n' roll club in White Plains. "Closing the club at the end of January comes down to economics."
Before that happens, however, Fore and Aft will have a last hurrah this week with musicians, former staff members and patrons stopping by to listen to their favorite music and say their farewells from 10 P.M. to 4 A.M.
The Machine will perform its Pink Floyd Show on Thursday; the Subterraneans will head an all-star show on Friday featuring a jam session with musicians who have played at the club during the last 15 years, and on Saturday, the establishment will close with the classic rock of Hog Wild.
Fore and Aft is on Route 22, and the phone number, answerable after 9 P.M., is 761-2417.
 
INDOOR ROLLER SKATING
Indoor Rollerblading and roller skating will be in progress today from 2 to 3 P.M. for ages 4 and 5, and from 3:15 to 4:15 for ages 6 through 8 at the Jewish Community Center, 371 South Broadway in Tarrytown. Only rubber or plastic wheels will be allowed.
Admission is $3, and the center is just north of the Tarrytown Hilton. Call 366-7898 for more information.
 ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
The Tax That's Tearing Clifton Apart

BYLINE: By MATTHEW J. WARD; Matthew J. Ward is the president of the Clifton Taxpayers Association.

DATELINE: CLIFTON

 BODY:
THE task of financing our children's education is tearing this city apart, and we are not alone. The headlines go to the "special needs" districts like our neighbors Paterson and Passaic -- or to wealthy ones, some of which have come under fire for top-heavy administrative budgets. But for the sandwich towns, the hundreds of middle-class communities like Clifton, the property-tax way of paying for our schools has become an unacceptable burden.
It's true, as Governor Whitman said in her State of the State address, that the educational focus should not be simply on adding money to school budgets. "We must stop chasing dollars and start creating scholars," she said. But education costs money, and the Governor had nothing to say about redressing the unfairness of the existing property tax system. 
 The school budget in Clifton is now $64.6 million. In just two years the budget has grown $6.6 million as the student population has soared, from 6,800 in 1991 to 8,450 today. We spend only about $6,400 per student, one of the two or three lowest rates in the state for a kindergarten-through-12th-grade district of our size.
Our schools are still strong, but there are serious doubts as to how long that can last. Property taxes pay 84 percent of school costs, and the people who pay those taxes have run out of patience. Since 1988, only one budget has been passed by voters. Last year's defeated budget called for an increase of only 3.1 percent -- the smallest since '88. A kind of intergenerational conflict has broken out between residents with children in the schools and those at or near retirement.
Forty percent of our residents are 55 or older. Many are house-rich but cash-poor, living on a fixed income of $15,000 to $20,000 or so a year. Some have to pay out as much as a quarter of their income in property taxes. They express their bitterness each year when the school budget comes up for the voters' approval. That bitterness is directed not at the schools but against a tax system that takes what they do not have to give.
There is a widespread perception that the financial squeeze on the schools will affect the quality of education, sooner rather than later. Families interested in moving to Clifton can see the writing on the wall: school budget defeats, growing enrollment, aging buildings, less spending on computers and the like. Already, we have seen an exodus of young families and older residents.
Sadly, a number of school districts seem to see themselves as self-sustaining fiefs; their attitude is, "As long as we educate our own children, who cares about our neighbors?" We will all pay dearly because of this narrow-minded, insular focus. Students emerging from failing districts have few marketable skills in today's highly technical world. "Out of sight, out of mind" thinking means that the companion ills of homelessness, drug addiction, crime, teen-age pregnancy and illiteracy will grow and grow. I live in Clifton, but I care if kids in Passaic and Paterson do not receive a thorough education.
We must eliminate the property tax as the major source of financing for local education and replace it with a statewide source that is uniform and equitable in its application and centered on the notion of the ability to pay.
The only real answer is to rely on the income tax, alone or in combination with additional taxes on alcohol, cigarettes or gambling. That would replace an inequitable and onerous tax with one that finally is fair to the overwhelming number of residents.
Over the years, the property tax burden has multiplied; we now pay higher rates than any other state, except for one that does not have an income tax. Decade after decade, our political leaders kowtow to special interest groups, call for new studies or propose an amendment to the Constitution -- anything to sweep the problem under the rug.
Too often, the political talk focuses on the extremes, school districts at the top of the economic ladder and those at the bottom. For cities like Clifton, that's just not good enough.
