HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
An Experiment in Single-Sex Education Comes to An End

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON

 BODY:
When Anthony Pilone took charge of the Myrtle Avenue Middle School three years ago, he did not like what he saw in the classrooms. Discipline problems were rampant, he said, and test scores were abysmal. Fights broke out regularly, and students paid scant attention to teachers.
"It was like bedlam," he said. "The whole business of horsing around was out of control, and there was no focus on learning." 
 From the start, Mr. Pilone blamed what he called "he-said, she-said antics" between girls and boys. Students were constantly trying to impress the opposite sex, he said, and few seemed interested in learning. So in September 1994, the principal took a radical step. Without consulting the district superintendent or state education officials, he separated the boys from the girls, segregating every classroom by sex.
For more than a year, boys attended classes on one side of the hallway and girls on the other. They ate lunch together, but for most of the day they did not interact. Mr. Pilone divided his teachers into teams, each working with one group of boys or girls throughout the year.
By the year's end, he said, there were obvious improvements at the school, where most of the students are black and many are poor. Attendance rates and grades had crept up, he said, and both teachers and students seemed more motivated. Scores on the Early Warning Test, which the state administers to eighth graders each March, improved by about 7 percentage points during the experiment, Mr. Pilone said. In 1994, for example, nearly 82 percent of his students scored at the lowest level in mathematics. In 1995, the number decreased to 75 percent.
Parents did not fight the program, Mr. Pilone said, and although teachers were skeptical at first, they warmed to it.
"It was the only thing I've ever done as a principal that I felt touched all the bases," he said. "I had the support of parents, students and teachers, and at least tacit approval from the district."
That changed last fall, when a new superintendent took charge of the 9,000-student district. The superintendent, Peter Carter, told Mr. Pilone that his experiment violated Title IX of the Federal Education Amendments of 1972, which prohibit sex discrimination in public schools. Moreover, Mr. Carter said, the New Jersey administrative code states that no course "shall be offered separately on the basis of race, color, creed, religion, sex, ancestry, national origin, or social or economic status."
In an interview last week, Mr. Carter said the State Department of Education had investigated the Myrtle Avenue program during the 1994-95 school year and had warned the previous superintendent that it could not continue. When he took charge of the district in October and discovered the program was still in place, he said, he had to stop it.
"I'm not saying it was good or bad," Mr. Carter said. "It was simply illegal."
Iliana Okum, who directs the Department of Education's Office of Bilingual Education and Equity Issues, said her office had indeed informed the district that the program could not continue, and Mr. Carter was correct to stop it.
"We could not allow the district to run single-sex classes," Ms. Okum said. "We have to insure that districts are following law and code, both state and Federal."
Apparently Mr. Pilone was not the first educator to challenge the Title IX rules with single-sex classrooms. Public schools in several other states, including California, Maryland, Florida and Michigan, have experimented with single-sex education in recent years. And in New Jersey, three public schools in Camden have segregated some classrooms by sex, said John Khanlian of the Camden County Department of Education.
Ms. Okum said she had not been aware that Camden schools were experimenting with single-sex classrooms. "They will probably be informed by the county superintendent that they will have to terminate those classes,"she said.
Several Myrtle Avenue teachers interviewed last week said they were disappointed when their classrooms returned to normal. Michael Dixon, a teacher who attended the Myrtle Avenue school in the early 1980's, said the experiment helped his male students gain confidence. Without girls to distract them, they became close friends and helped each other learn, he said.
"They didn't have to worry about that girl sitting next to them with the pretty-smelling perfume," he said. "It came to the point where they were like family. Discipline problems dropped off because you don't want your family fighting."
Wanda Warren, a teacher who worked with girls last year, said the experiment was even more beneficial for them. Girls who were used to getting F's started getting B's and C's, she said, and they became more comfortable in classroom discussions.
"With the boys around, they were afraid to raise their hand and call out an answer," said Ms. Warren, who has taught at Myrtle Avenue for nine years.
Mr. Pilone said he believed that Early Warning Test scores would have improved more dramatically this March, since the current eighth graders would have had almost two years of single-sex education. He had planned to take the program even further this year, with a dress code and separate floors of the building for boys and girls. Although he does not plan to challenge the superintendent's decision, he said he did not regret his course of action.
"My belief is that I have to act instead of react," he said. "You don't get permission to do anything risky."
Since the experiment ended, Ms. Warren said, many girls have resumed their old habits, dressing to impress the boys and rarely speaking out in class. And although some students were happy to return to coed classrooms, Ms. Warren said most are nostalgic for the single-sex days.
"These kids would go back to it in a heartbeat," she said. "They're missing that sense of pride."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anthony Pilone, principal of the Myrtle Avenue Middle School in Irvington, thinks single-sex classes helped motivate students. (Lenore Victoria Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: What's in a Name? Old Industrial Fame

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
NICKNAMES of cities are like nicknames of people. Once they're acquired, they're awfully hard, if not impossible, to shake.
On the people level, a man nicknamed Slim as a child will invariably still be Slim decades later, even though he might now weigh 248 pounds and be shaped like a pear. 
 On the city level, nicknames are most often associated with industries that once brought fame, sometimes worldwide fame, to town. When the industries declined, went out of business altogether, or simply went South for cheaper labor and more sun, the nicknames lived on.
Consequently, Manchester is still known as the Silk City for the sprawling Cheney mill empire, which no longer exists. Waterbury is still the Brass City even though the huge Scovill plant has been vacant for years. Naugatuck is the Rubber City although rubber is no longer processed there.
Bristol is the Clock City but that industry has long since ticked away. New Britain is the Hardware City but only the Stanley Works remains of a one-time battery of industrial hardware giants, including North & Judd and the American Hardware Corporation, that made the city not only the hardware capital of Connecticut but of the world.
Among bigger cities, New Haven is still the Elm City but a visitor might have some trouble finding elms. Pat Rubano, the deputy director for maintenance for the Parks Department, said that when he went to work half a century ago, "The elms made arches over whole streets." But Dutch elm disease put an end to that. Some new trees, immune from the disease, have been planted. But you have to look hard for them, even on Elm Street.
Bridgeport is still known as the Park City, for its 19 parks, but is much better known now for its economic troubles, including nearly going into bankruptcy several years ago, and this year's failed attempt at bailout-by-casino.
And in Hartford, the Insurance City, the insurance industry is in decline and one of the biggest companies, the Travelers, now has headquarters in Manhattan. The nickname of the city will survive, however. Bank on it.
In a few cities, community nicknames have been used, and still are, for sports teams.
The Hatters, for instance. When football and basketball players suit up for games at Danbury High, that's the name on their uniforms, which sometimes surprises newcomers who wonder why the athletes are hatters or, indeed, what a hatter is.
A hatter, of course, is a person who makes hats, and Danbury had an abundance of them when it was the hat capital of the world. But no hats have been produced in Danbury, the Hat City, for 10 years, since the last of the manufacturers, the Mallory Company, closed up.
Never mind, said Michael R. Seri, Danbury's veteran town clerk. "Danbury will never lose its identity for hats," said Mr. Seri who is 72 years old and who worked at hat companies before World War II. Hats were so important to the city's economy for more than two centuries -- the first hat factory in America was established in Danbury in 1780 by one Zadoc Benedict -- that a workman couldn't get inside a factory unless he was wearing a hat, Mr. Seri said.
He, like many others, credits the demise of the hat as everyday apparel to John F. Kennedy. Before Mr. Kennedy, every President of the United States had worn a hat to his swearing-in ceremony. Mr. Kennedy showed up hatless for his Inauguration in 1961 and the hat business was never the same again.
If Hatters seem obsolete, Whalers might seem more so. But all sports teams at New London High School are still known as Whalers, and the school's logo includes a harpoon, in deference to the city's main claim to fame in the last century: hunting down whales. The state's only National Hockey League team is the Hartford Whalers and the sperm whale was designated the state's animal by the General Assembly in 1975. That was in recognition not only of its contribution to the state's history but also of its present status as an endangered species. It is still hunted by -- of course -- whalers, but none from Connecticut.
In two cities, Meriden and Willimantic, efforts have been made over the last few years to create museums about the products that once made them famous.
Meriden is the Silver City, the largest manufacturer of silver tableware in the world in the 1930's and 1940's. The silver industry had long since departed when a group decided to establish a silver museum, backed by city and state money, to tell the story of Meriden's glory days. After years of planning, it opened in 1994. It closed a few months ago, badly in debt and with little public support.
Willimantic was known as the Thread City for the American Thread Company, which dominated the economic life of the community for most of this century. It moved South 10 years ago, leaving several fortress-like mills of brick and granite that dominate one end of Main Street.
A textile and history museum was opened in 1989 in a three-story Victorian mansion near the old mills. But last spring its founder declared the museum insolvent and gave the keys to a bank that held a mortgage on the property. The museum has since been reopened under new management but its future is still in doubt.
Perhaps the saddest aspect of the tale is that Willimantic itself, the city the mills made famous, the Thread City, technically doesn't even exist anymore. Willimantic was established within the rural town of Windham in 1893 when the thread company was booming. It was where people lived and worked, shopped, went to school. Then in 1983, with the thread mills almost silent, 90 years after it was conceived, Willimantic ceased to exist. It was consolidated into Windham, legally and officially.
But not in the minds of people who live there. If anyone asks where they live, the answer is not Windham. It is Willimantic. The streets are the streets of Willimantic. Those old thread mills are in Willimantic. It is the Thread City. Remember that.

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE;
A Quality Bill of Fare in a Bare-Knuckles Pub

BYLINE: By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM 

 BODY:
THE Ritz in Northport is Cheers with a heavyweight chef. The cast of the TV sitcom would feel at home at this convivial cafe, which has the spirit of a club even more than a pub.
There are as many ties and jackets as jeans and baseball caps at the old polished-wood L-shape bar that dominates this waterfront spot at 42 Woodbine Avenue (754-6348). 
 The dishes emerging from the postage-stamp-size kitchen are a mixture of typical bar-and-grill fare like hamburgers, clam strips and shrimp in a basket (all $6.95) as well as potato-crusted sea bass, lobster tails with cashew-beurre blanc sauce, sea scallop Napoleon with a Pernod sauce, lamb chops with tomato-red wine risotto and suckling pig in a natural juice with rice, black beans and corn.
The pig, so popular in Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking countries, no doubt springs from the chef's Latin American background. The chef, Alberto Andia, originally from Peru, arrived at the Ritz a year and a half ago. He had worked as executive chef at the Stork Club and Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan and chef and owner of Savories in Port Jefferson and Sempre Vivolo in Hauppauge.
It is possible to spend as much as $23.95 for an a la carte entree with vegetables, potato and salad at dinner, but there is no need to. That is because the Ritz offers an opportunity to eat for much less, with meals like the $12.95 four-course Sunday sunset supper; the 18-ounce steak with vegetables, potatoes and salad for $14.95 on Tuesdays, and the $10.95 Sunday brunch that includes an appetizer and cocktail.
There were no duds one night. The double green-pea soup ($2.50 a cup and $3.50 a bowl) came with fresh peas that bobbed in the tasty broth. A starter of four tender puffy sea scallops ($7.50), crowned with wispy leeks on a lush black-butter sauce, surrounded by circles of beet vinaigrette and garnished with ripe avocado, was satisfying and notable for its striking black, red, white, green presentation. Warm rare slices of soft duck breast radiate out from a medium-size pillbox of fancy greens like frisee and red-tipped and oak-leaf lettuces in the duck salad ($11.95), which is topped with terrific shoestring potatoes and dressed in saffron vinaigrette.
A boat-shape piece of medium-rare peppercorn-crusted swordfish ($15.95), covered with a thatch of julienned fried vegetables, in a sea of sun-dried tomato sauce and accompanied by broad brown steak fries and a fresh green salad with Dijon vinaigrette, was a triumph.
Perhaps the least economical course is dessert ($4.95). But the all-homemade delights should be sampled.
A note or two of caution is in order. Service is always sweet, but rarely swift. And although the Ritz, with its green tablecloths, vases of red carnations and baby's breath on each table, hardwood floors and hanging artificial plants has a certain charm, the dinner-time din can be deafening, and cold air sometimes sweeps in when the front door opens.
 
Festival Cooking
The second edition of "Food Festival," a guidebook to regional food celebrations, features down-home recipes from small-town festivals. Alice Geffen and Carole Berglie of Sea Cliff, came up with the idea for the book while devouring peach pie made from Wickham's peaches at the fund-raising chicken barbecue for the Cutchogue Fire Department. Shortly afterward, Ms. Geffen and Ms. Berglie began traveling and tasting throughout the country. They visited the Okra Strut in South Carolina; the Black-Eyed Pea Jamboree in Texas; the Pork, Peanut and Pine Festival in Virginia, and Yambilee in Louisiana, took the prize-winning and best-loved recipes from each and put them in the 295-page book. "Food Festival," a $16 soft cover published by Countryman Press, is at bookstores or can be requested from 10 Highland Avenue, Sea Cliff 11579.
 
Openings
Inaka, a 10-year-old Japanese restaurant on Court Street in Brooklyn Heights, opened a branch in Manhasset, Inaka East, at 411 Plandome Road (869-8080), last month. The 60-seat wood-paneled restaurant with a private tatami room offers entrees in the $8.95-to-$16.50 range. Eileen Wu, who along with her husband, Willis, owns the restaurant, said the average main course cost $12.
Guo Hong, from the Brooklyn Heights restaurant, will be executive chef in Manhasset until he trains a permanent kitchen commander.
Bassets, on the water at 2849 Ocean Avenue in Seaford (826-2710), which bills itself as "a cozy eating and dining establishment," also opened last month. The restaurant offers a selection of pastas, steaks, chops and poultry. Bassets replaces the Seal's Cove at that location. Main courses are $9.95 to $16.95.
Bassets is on a canal and seats 70 indoors and 50 on an outdoor deck in warm weather. Two sisters, Joan and Irene McElligott, who have worked at various restaurants in Nassau County, own Bassets, and Andrew De Gregorio is head cook. Mr. De Gregorio has worked as a manager, an expediter and a cook at a number of restaurants in Manhattan, including the Tavern on the Green, Ruth's Chris, the Post House and Smith & Wollensky.
 
Wine Tasting
The first of three winter wine tastings at the Inn at the Harbor in Cold Spring Harbor is scheduled for Jan. 31. The four-course $50 dinner will feature wines from California and Oregon. Among the wines to be poured are two sparkling-wine Champagne-style selections from Oregon, Gloria Ferrer Royal Cuvee and Argyle Brut.
The chef, Guy Peuch, plans to prepare his celebrated crab cakes, Southwestern lamb-and-white bean chili and rachers, an almond-and-chocolate truffle with a Grand Marnier-and-chocolate sauce.
 
Potpourri
An evening of fine food, a benefit for United Cerebral Palsy of Queens (718-380-3000, ext. 279), at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows, will be held at 6:30 P.M. on Feb. 7. Among the participants at the $50 tasting are Ben's Restaurants and Cooking With Jazz.
Restaurants, bakeries, wineries and food purveyors will be offering samples at the third annual Evening of Good Taste at the Huntington Town House from 6 to 9 P.M. on March 11.
The benefit, which is sponsored by South Nassau Communities Hospital (763-3919), costs $30 in advance and $40 at the door. Among the 50 participating restaurants are 107 Forest in Locust Valley, Route 66 in Merrick, Del Fina of Seaford and the Metropolitan in Glen Cove.

HEADLINE: Mohicans Denounce Retailer in Land Fight

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER KINCADE JR. 

DATELINE: LEEDS, N.Y.

 BODY:
WITH a tribal drum reverberating in the December wind, a small fire sending sparks into the pristine winter sky and a group of reporters surrounding his fellow Mohican tribesmen, Steve Comer drew the curtain for his take on the great American morality play.
In the shadow of the Catskill Mountains, Mr. Comer, the Mohican's soft-spoken Northeastern representative, referred to the 14-hour journey that seven of his tribe had taken from their reservation in Wisconsin as a historic occasion, a chance to salve centuries-old wounds. 
 "This is the first time since our holocaust, the first time in nearly 500 years, that we as a people have come back and said we are here," Mr. Comer told the crowd of 30 outside the town of Leeds. "Despite James Fenimore Cooper's book, we are not the last of the Mohicans."
Ostensibly protesting a Wal-Mart planned for a Mohican archeological dig, Mr. Comer's words echoed those sounded two weeks earlier at a public hearing in Dobbs Ferry. Attempts to build a town house complex on another archeological site there, an Onondaga chief said, could turn the Westchester County village into a pan-Indian battleground.
In development disputes that have splintered the quiet hamlets and divided archeologists and Government agencies, the Indians have brought a politically loaded issue to the fore: desecration of sacred Indian sites. Their entrance has reshaped the political landscape for developers and local administrators, who tout the economic boon the projects would be to the villages.
As public forums on both projects have become cathartic filibusters of sorts, geared toward delaying or derailing development, the Mohicans and their allies have transformed the Hudson Valley conflicts into debates on the value of Indian heritage.
One resident in Dobbs Ferry even delivered an emotional speech at follow-up hearings comparing Indian removal to ethnical cleansing in Bosnia, a notion that has forced developers and administrators to shift their mindset from complying with the environmental review process to addressing a contentious historical record. Dr. Robert Kuhn, program coordinator for the State Historic Preservation Office, which oversees the 10,000 archeological sites in the state, said the Hudson Valley was a particularly fertile ground for such disputes.
Once the homeland of the Mohican and Delaware tribes, the area from Manhattan to Lake Champlain has also been one of the most heavily developed regions in the Northeast. Those two competing interests, Dr. Kuhn said, combine to create combustible battles pitting expensive excavations against economic growth.
"In each of these projects, we have to balance that," Dr. Kuhn said. "Our goal is to find a way that the project can go forward and still protect the resource. In many instances, there are ways to do both."
He did concede, however, that the Indians have become powerful land advocates, largely by virtue of their ability to attract news organizations. In Leeds, where the Mohicans, also known as Munsee Indians, occupied a small hunting camp through five archeological eras, the Dec. 2 peace conference focused attention on a site that has undergone only preliminary excavations.
After the Mohicans had paid homage, one by one, to their ancestors, Dr. Christopher Lindner, a professor of archeology at Bard College, turned the discussion toward science. "Out there in nine feet of flood plain deposit," he said, "there are layers upon layers of archeological artifacts."
Citing fireplace remnants, storage pits, post-hole structures and other earmarks of settlement discovered in a dig last summer, Dr. Lindner said that the site could be one of the greatest archeological finds in the Northeast. In a later interview, he advocated long-term excavations and a research center at the site.
While Dr. Kuhn said he agrees with his colleague's assessment of the site's significance, the Green County Legislature voiced its support for Wal-Mart. With the Mohicans threatening to sue for inadequate excavations, the battle may just be starting in Leeds.

HEADLINE: Patrol Program Credited With Drop in Crime

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
IT was in a neighborhood now considered one of the toughest police beats in this teeming 4.2-square-mile city that Sgt. Terrance Raynor was raised. He walks the same sidewalks today as he did growing up, and he sees many of the same faces -- only now he watches over the neighborhood and keeps pace with the news on the street.
"What's up man?" Sergeant Raynor said on a recent afternoon, greeting a citizen along the East Third Street corridor, as the busy, crime-ridden shopping area is known. "Where you been?" 
 That afternoon Sergeant Raynor was not only surprised but also happy to encounter Richard Morales, which had not always been the case. In the past, Mr. Morales, 27, an admitted drug dealer, had been one of the less-welcome denizens of the neighborhood.
"I've changed my life around," Mr. Morales told the sergeant, as they talked about jobs, apartments and people they knew in common. "No more jail time for me."
That type of social exchange between a law-enforcement officer and a member of the community is becoming more common in municipalities throughout the country under a Federal program that takes more police officers out of patrol cars and from behind desks and puts them on the beat.
The program, known as Community-Oriented Policing or by its acronym COPS, appears to be paying off and is increasingly cited as one of several factors contributing to a pattern of lower crime across the country. Its goal is to put 100,000 officers on the street; to date, about 26,000 police officers have been hired under the program.
In Westchester, where many municipalities have redeployed officers to neighborhood beats, statistics show that for the first 10 months of 1995 -- the latest period for which figures were available -- the number of offenses known to the police dropped by 11 percent to 23,186, from 26,040 for the corresponding period in 1994.
The numbers, which are part of the state's Uniform Crime Report, indicate trends for murders, negligent manslaughters, rapes, robberies, aggravated assaults, burglaries, larcenies and motor vehicle thefts. Last year appears to continue a downward trend in most crime categories that began early in the decade, although not all jurisdictions had filed their statistics at the time of the report.
Most notably, the number of automobile thefts in Westchester dropped 21 percent from 3,916 in the first 10 months of 1994 to 3,096 in the corresponding period last year. The county, which is striped with north-south highways, affords quick access to auto thieves from the suburbs to chop shops in Manhattan and other boroughs of New York City.
Here in Mount Vernon, for example, motor vehicle thefts alone were down almost 18 percent, but other crimes also showed decreases. Burglaries, for example, dropped by 13 percent, and Chief Michael J. Craparo credited the successes in part to a three-year, $750,000 Federal grant, which is paying the salaries of six community police officers like Sergeant Raynor.
But Chief Craparo also observed that some offenses -- particularly crimes like robberies and aggravated assaults -- remained resistant to police efforts, and he said the statistics indicated "there is still much work to be done." Robberies were up by 12 percent and aggravated assaults by 2 percent. Overall, crime in Mount Vernon dropped by 3 percent in 1995 compared with 1994.
In Yonkers, crime was down 6 percent for the first 10 months of last year, and the city was ranked the ninth safest of the 100 largest cities in the country, according to Federal Bureau of Investigations statistics for 1994 in a book called "City Crime Rankings," published by Morgan Quitno Press of Lawrence, Kan. The safest city, according to the rankings, was Huntington Beach, Calif.
Motor vehicle thefts in Yonkers were down by 13 percent, burglaries by 14 percent and robberies by 18 percent. But the gains were in part offset by a 6 percent increase in larcenies.
New Rochelle also noted a significant decrease in crime last year. Its latest figures for all of 1995, which showed a 14 percent drop overall, revealed decreases in every category except murder. Commissioner Patrick J. Carroll credited much of his city's success to the Federal anti-crime effort, which two years ago put 12 community police officers on foot and bicycles throughout the city.
White Plains saw a 4 percent decrease in crime during the first 10 months of last year. Rye City had not filed its statistics with the state at the time of this report.
Of all of Westchester's cities, only Peekskill reported an increase -- a hefty 18 percent -- and Chief Eugene S. Tumolo could offer little explanation.
"It's too sterile to just examine the statistics," he said, suggesting that Peekskill's community policing efforts and other new law-enforcement strategies there would need more time to bear fruit.
In other cities in the state, the crime rate also dropped. In New York City, crime was down 16 percent for the first six months of 1995, and in Buffalo it dropped 7 percent. In Albany, though, crime was up by 4 percent for the period, and in Rochester it increased by 1 percent.
Many of the smaller villages and towns in Westchester reported increases in crime for the 10-month period last year. For example, Briarcliff Manor reported a 25 percent increase -- from 64 crimes committed for the period in 1994 to 80 last year. And Bronxville reported a 39 percent increase -- from 54 crimes overall in 1994 to 75 crimes in 1995.
But Robert M. Maccarone, Westchester's Deputy Commissioner of Corrections and Director of Criminal Justice, urged caution in drawing conclusions, because the numbers were so small and skewed the percentages.
He also suggested that the cities fared better because they had earlier access to the Federal community policing grants and that in time the numbers in the smaller municipalities would follow suit.
Meanwhile, social scientists and law-enforcement experts are trying to pinpoint the reasons for the decrease in crime.
Mr. Maccarone cited two major contributing factors: shifting demographics and a get-tough policy toward criminals at the state and local level.
He said that in Westchester there are only 20,000 people, or about 2 percent of the population, in the 16-to-30-year-old category, which is the group considered largely responsible for crime.
Throughout the country, too, that group represents only a small percentage of the general population.
Mr. Maccarone also said that stiffer sentencing policies overall and Gov. George E. Pataki's elimination of parole for second-time violent offenders has kept more criminals locked up for longer periods and "out of the loop."
In Manhattan at the John Jay School of Criminal Justice, Professor Andrew Karmen, a sociologist, said that everyone from the Governor to local police chiefs was taking credit for the latest statistics.
Dr. Karmen is part of a team of researchers -- including an economist, police officials, criminologists and computer experts -- studying the reasons that crime in New York City is down.
Unfortunately, the decrease in crime "might just be a pause until the next baby boom comes of age," because it appears to be related to demographic trends, he said.
Westchester's District Attorney, Jeanine Pirro, said that the lower crime statistics notwithstanding, arrests of juveniles for violent offenses rose 70 percent in the county from 1984 to 1994. Specifically, almost half of the robbery indictments in Westchester for the period were filed against suspects who were 19 or younger, she said.
Those local statistics also appear to be following a national trend: throughout the country, there was a 68 percent increase in arrests of juveniles for in connection with killings between 1989 and 1993.
But even though the incidence of violent crime has been on the decrease for five years, the perception among the populace is that criminal behavior overall is on the upswing, Dr. Karmen said. In part, the fear that things are getting worse, not better, is generated by a few spectacular crimes that get front-page headlines and, according to many police chiefs, alter the public's perception of reality.
In Greenburgh, where a former auto-parts worker was charged with the gunshot killing of his former boss earlier this month and the wounding of two other workers, Chief John A. Kapica said many people now think of his town "as a real shoot-em-up community -- even though that's not the routine here."
At a nearby shopping mall, Seihui Lee, owner of Century Art Gallery, said: "Everyone is very nervous. We used to think Westchester was safe, not like the Bronx, but now we believe that crime can happen anywhere."
Merchants along the shopping strip said they were worried about making bank deposits of the day's receipts after dark and that some muggings and car thefts had also contributed to their anxieties.
"We don't care what the statistics say; it seems like things are getting worse," said Thomas J. Vassilio, a manager at Petland Discounts.

HEADLINE: The New York Times Introduces a Web Site

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS

 BODY:
The New York Times begins publishing daily on the World Wide Web today, offering readers around the world immediate access to most of the daily newspaper's contents. 
 The New York Times on the Web, as the electronic publication is known, contains most of the news and feature articles from the current day's printed newspaper, classified advertising, reporting that does not appear in the newspaper, and interactive features including the newspaper's crossword puzzle. 
 The electronic newspaper (address: http:/www.nytimes.com) is part of a strategy to extend the readership of The Times and to create opportunities for the company in the electronic media industry, said Martin Nisenholtz, president of The New York Times Electronic Media Company. 
 The company, formed in 1995 to develop products for the rapidly growing field of digital publishing, is a wholly owned subsidiary of The New York Times Company, and also produces the times service on America Online Inc.
 Mr. Nisenholtz reports to Russell T. Lewis, the president and general manager of The New York Times, and to Joseph Lelyveld, the newspaper's executive editor. 
 The Web-based Times is the newest of dozens of papers available to a global audience on the Internet's fastest-growing service, which lets computer users see electronic publications consisting of text, pictures and, in some cases, video and sound. 
 A selection of the day's news, discussion forums and other material from The Times has been available through the @times service since the spring of 1994 on America Online. 
 The Web site's global audience means a larger potential readership than that of @times, which is limited to America Online's subscribers, currently more than four million. The new site also offers new products and services. 
 "Our site is designed to take full advantage of the evolving capabilities offered by the Internet," said Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of The Times. "We see our role on the Web as being similar to our traditional print role -- to act as a thoughtful, unbiased filter and to provide our customers with information they need and can trust." 
 The Web site will also offer access to much of what the newspaper has published the previous week and access to feature articles from as far back as 1980. 
 Mr. Nisenholtz said that initially, at least, no subscription or access fee would be charged for readers in the United States and that the electronic paper would generate revenue from advertising. Readers who connect to the electronic paper from outside the country will be offered a 30-day trial without charge, but will eventually face a subscription fee. 
 Advertisers that have already announced participation on the Web site include Toyota Motor Corporate Services, Chemical Bank and the Northeast real estate concern Douglas Elliman. 
 Subscribers will have limited access to archives of Times articles and features dating to 1980, and will be able to copy articles to their own computers for $1.95 each, Mr. Nisenholtz said. 
 The new service will also offer, for a fee, a customized clipping service that delivers to a subscriber's electronic mailbox articles gleaned from each day's editions of the newspaper, based on key words the subscriber selects. 
 With its entry on the Web, The Times is hoping to become a primary information provider in the computer age and to cut costs for newsprint, delivery and labor. Companies that have established Web-based information sites include television networks, computer companies, on-line information services, magazines and even individuals creating electronic newspapers of their own. 
 "The New York Times name will get people to look at the product once or maybe twice, and the fact that The New York Times has the kind of reach and credibility it does may persuade people to look three or four times," said John F. Kelsey 3d, president of the Kelsey Group, a consultancy running a conference on interactive newspapers next month. 
 "The market is booming for newspapers on the World Wide Web," Mr. Kelsey said.

HEADLINE: Bringing Advanced Medical Expertise to the World's Poorest Regions

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

 BODY:
The patient was getting the best care the local doctors could provide. But this case needed outside expertise, and a long-distance phone call was not an option.
There was a low-cost communications alternative, however, thanks to Satellife, a Boston-based nonprofit organization helping bring the information age to parts of Africa and Asia where up-to-date medical information can be scarce. 
 As Dr. Fred Bukachi, a Kenyan internist, recalls the episode, he and a team of renal surgeons in Nairobi were treating a first-year medical student who had sickle-cell anemia, an incurable blood condition that had been under control. Now, however, the condition had suddenly worsened. As the student's kidneys failed, his doctors knew he had to have blood-cleansing dialysis treatments.
No one on the team had experience putting such a patient on a dialysis machine, which typically requires use of blood-thinning drugs that could be deadly to someone with sickle-cell anemia. There was no good nearby medical library. Even an overseas phone call would cost $12 a minute -- an unaffordable luxury in an economy where hospitals can afford to spend an average of only $1 a day on patients.
But turning to the keyboard of his specially outfitted personal computer, Dr. Bukachi typed an urgent call for advice that was sent via radio signals to a nearby satellite earth station. A few hours later the earth station's dish antenna beamed the message to the small Satellife satellite that passes over Africa four times each day.
Several hours later, when the satellite swung into electronic view of Boston, Dr. Bukachi's missive was downloaded to a Satellife ground station, where the organization's staff broadcast it over the global Internet computer web.
Half a day later came an Internet reply to Boston from a physician at St. Mary's Hospital in London who had successfully handled a similar case. The prescribed treatment: small doses of the blood thinner Heperin. A Satellife staff member telephoned Dr. Bukachi with the information. The treatment saved the Kenyan medical student's life.
"In this case, there was no other alternative -- there was no other place to turn for help," said Dr. Bukachi, who serves as Satellife's Africa region director.
Since its founding in 1989 by the renowned cardiologist, inventor and promoter of social causes Bernard Lown, Satellife has helped save many lives. Its Healthnet medical network now serves thousands of physicians and health care workers in 15 African nations and parts of Asia.
Healthnet subscribers receive the electronic Healthnet News, a weekly summary of the latest medical research from more than 20 major medical journals. They also get medical information from a growing list of health organizations like the World Health Organization and numerous AIDS research projects.
During last year's outbreak of the dreaded ebola virus in Zaire, Dr. Paul Fountain, an American Baptist missionary and chief physician at Vanga Hospital in Kikwit, the epicenter of the outbreak, used Healthnet to communicate about the disease with other physicians in Africa and elsewhere.
Within African nations, Healthnet gives physicians in even the most remote hospitals access to up-to-date knowledge.
Last year, for example, a doctor in the village of Kafue Gorge in southern Zambia was treating a 12-year-old girl who had severe lesions in her mouth and could barely swallow. Unable to treat the child and cut off by roads washed out in the rainy season, the physician asked for help via Healthnet. Before nightfall he had received instructions from doctors at the University of Zambia, in Lusaka, on how to surgically remove the lesions. After the surgery, the child recovered.
Satellife's founder, Dr. Lown, 74, is as well known for his medical innovations as he is for his political and social causes. He is credited with conceiving the modern cardiac-care unit and founded International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, an organization that won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1985.
And when he set up Satellife with multimillion-dollar grants from corporations including NEC and AT&T, since supplemented by donors including the actor Hume Cronyn and the media entrepreneur Ted Turner, it was out of recognition that technology and social concerns might be combined.
"Ignorance fosters chaos," said Dr. Lown, who in the case of most of sub-Saharan Africa realized that medical professionals were hampered by an appallingly inadequate communications system. Voice, fax and video-conference transmissions were either unavailable or made unaffordable by government-run telecommunications agencies.
What was required was some sort of "off line" or "store and forward" communications system that did not require connections to the real-time telephone network.
So Dr. Lown and his advisers settled on so-called low-earth-orbit satellite technology. The approach is a stark contrast to the giant geostationary satellites, which are commonly used for telephone and television transmissions in the United States. These complex spacecraft, costing several hundred million dollars to build and up to $20 million more to launch, are positioned over the equator at an altitude of more than 22,000 miles, where they orbit in unison with the earth's rotation, seeming to hang in a fixed position.
A low-earth satellite, which would be the size of a television set and would zip around the globe at an altitude of only 550 miles, could be built and launched for $1 million. Satellife bought and launched Healthsat 1 in 1991 and three years later sent up a more sophisticated replacement, Healthsat 2, which cost $2.2 million. Both were paid for with private donations.
Taking 100 minutes for each pole-to-pole orbit of the earth, the satellite makes 14 circumnavigations a day. Every 24 hours, any given spot on earth is within electronic range of the satellite at least four times.
Each time the satellite comes into view, an earth station has approximately 13 minutes to exchange data with Healthsat 2 via radio signal. The network's software allows the spacecraft to poll each earth station in turn, collecting any stored messages and downloading any information collected elsewhere on the globe and addressed to that particular station.
The equipment for each ground station costs less than $15,000. And as telephone service is gradually improving in some African cities, a Healthnet subscriber can use a modem to transmit messages via local phone line to a centrally located earth station, rather than requiring a satellite antenna at each site.
"We've devised a system that can easily be replicated within a country for free," said John Mullaney, executive director of Satellife. "It is a medical information system that can be run by Africans for Africans and can be sustained internally."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Faces Another Deficit Despite Cutting

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
For the last two years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has wrestled down huge gaps in New York City's budgets, slashing spending, cutting municipal jobs and trimming welfare rolls. And yet, as he begins his third year in office, the Mayor faces another gaping hole in his spending plan and a new round of cuts that could further erode the city's services.
The new shortfall, which has more than doubled in size in just seven months, is forcing the Mayor and his aides to scramble once again for ways to keep the budget balanced for the coming fiscal year, either by making more cuts or taking other actions like refinancing debt or selling assets. 
 Only this time the task has become all the more complicated and the consequences more painful, according to budget experts, city officials and privately even some of the Mayor's aides. For now, they say, the Mayor has less room to maneuver. Fewer options remain. And any new cuts will come in the wake of earlier ones that have already strapped many of the city's agencies.
"Where there was fat in the budget," the city's Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said. "There's a lot less fat now."
Neither the Mayor nor his aides have disclosed the full extent of the gap projected for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. But the city's fiscal monitors -- Mr. Hevesi, the state's Financial Control Board and the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall -- estimate it to be at least $2 billion, or more than 6 percent of the current $32 billion budget.
That is roughly the amount spent each year on the Police Department, with its force of 38,000 officers and 6,000 civilians. The gap is fast approaching the scale of the first two Mr. Giuliani had to face: $2.3 billion in his first year and $3.1 billion in the second.
The Mayor and his aides are now drafting a preliminary budget for the new fiscal year and plan to unveil it on Jan. 31. At the same time, they are trying to close a widening shortfall in this fiscal year, estimated to be at least $600 million and probably more.
First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers declined to discuss what proposals the Mayor would offer to close the gap. He did say, however, that Mr. Giuliani remained committed to controlling spending, and he disputed the notion that there were fewer and fewer places to cut.
"In some areas, you've probably hit your maximum cutting," Mr. Powers said, "but in other areas there are other opportunities."
The reasons for the new gap -- despite two years of cuts under the Republican Mayor who came into office vowing once and for all to tackle the city's chronic budget woes -- are varied and complex. Some fall within the Mayor's control. Others do not, leaving Mr. Giuliani susceptible to larger political and economic forces like mayors before him.
Simply put, the city continues to spend more money than it can hope to receive in revenues, a trend that has dogged three mayors since the end of the economic boon of the 1980's.
In the coming fiscal year, the city's revenues -- primarily from taxes but also from state and Federal aid -- are not going to grow by as much as forecast by Mr. Giuliani's budget aides. In fact, the Mayor's office announced last week that the city's largest source of revenue, the property tax, would fall as much as $180 million short of what was estimated only two months ago.
And while Wall Street had a boisterous year, the Comptroller's office has tracked an unexpected shortfall in personal income taxes and some other business taxes in the last few months of 1995. On Friday, the Federal Government reported a jump in the city's unemployment rate despite recent gains in the tourism and retail industries, possibly signaling an economic slowdown that could reduce revenues even more.
What's more, the Mayor has proposed $340 million in new tax cuts for the new fiscal year, including a reduction in the personal income tax, which have added to the size of the gap.
At the same time, the city's spending is projected to continue its rampant growth, outpacing the reductions made by Mr. Giuliani in his first two years.
For example, the largest part of the city's budget -- personnel costs -- is projected to grow by more than $500 million in the next year despite a reduction of 19,000 workers from the city-financed payroll of 223,000 from the time Mr. Giuliani took office two years ago. The reason for the increase: salaries, pensions and health care costs of the remaining workers have continued to grow.
That, in part, explains why some fiscal monitors and budget experts have criticized Mr. Giuliani for not extracting more concessions in his recent settlements with the city's labor unions.
"Until he faces up to the challenge of getting big labor savings on a recurring basis, he's going to be in the same bind year after year," said Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private nonprofit group financed by businesses.
The growth in spending also reflects the mounting costs of paying interest and principal on the city's debt, which has skyrocketed in part because of the refinancings that saved the city money in the past at a cost in the future.
Mr. Hevesi's office has found that the price of the refinancings, which began in 1987, came home to roost for the first time this year and will add $145 million to the city's spending in the next fiscal year.
The Mayor's first two budgets also assumed savings from new initiatives that have not yet materialized or have little chance of doing so, adding to the projected shortfalls in the coming budget. The savings from his agreements with labor unions, for example, have proved less than first touted, while the strict screening of welfare recipients has reduced costs considerably, though not by as much as first estimated.
Beyond what he has little control over, Mr. Giuliani, the fiscal monitors say, has also contributed to the new gap through budget gimmicks -- known as "one shots" because they provide only temporary relief. They include relying on refinancings, tapping pension reserves and selling assets, like the city-owned United Nations Plaza Hotel.
Using a one shot to balance the budget is like selling your television set to pay the rent: it gets you through this month, but next month the rent comes due again and then there is no television left to sell.
Mr. McCall, the State Comptroller, said the continued use of one shots left unresolved the underlying problem of spending growing faster than revenues. "You've got this structural problem that just keeps repeating itself," he said.
Mr. Powers, the Mayor's senior aide, said the gaps were the lingering consequences of the city's tradition of generous spending and high taxes. The latter, he argued, caused the erosion of the city's tax base to the point that the city can no longer pay for the former.
"We're suffering from the sins of the past," he said. "The city simply spends too much money."
The Mayor's new budget could be as important politically as the first two were, particularly since it will carry over into the election year. The recurring gaps pose risks that could cut both ways.
"I think Giuliani is in an impossible situation," said Fred Siegel, a history professor at Cooper Union and a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute, a research group in Washington associated with centrist Democrats. "If he makes the cuts he has to make, it might be political suicide. If he doesn't make the cuts, the city continues to limp along, hoping for an economic recovery that never arrives."

HEADLINE: Cadillac-Sized Hits by the VW of Producers;
Carsey-Werner Keeps Its Independence and Still Picks Television's Winners

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19

 BODY:
It has been 12 years since the weekly listings of television's 10 most popular programs did not include a comedy from Carsey-Werner Productions -- and that string of success now looks secure at least through the end of the century.
Last week, the latest Carsey-Werner effort, "Third Rock From the Sun," a comedy about a family of aliens-disguised-as-earthlings adapting to the often inscrutable behavior of humans, firmly established itself as the first undeniable new hit show of the 1995-96 season; by its second week it was NBC's highest-rated show on Tuesday night. It is also Carsey-Werner's first breakthrough hit on NBC since "The Cosby Show" in the mid-1980's. 
 But the producers are not choosy about the network company they keep. They have put hits on ABC ("Roseanne" and "Grace Under Fire") and CBS ("Cybill") as well. In fact, Carsey-Werner is almost surely the only television production company capable of pulling off a network hat trick like that because they are the last of the true independents, steering a small self-propelled vehicle among the big rigs that dominate the network highways.
Years ago there were many independents -- production companies that are not aligned with networks or studios -- including MTM, which produced "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" and "Hill Street Blues," or Garry Marshall, which produced "Happy Days" and "Laverne and Shirley." But today most have found that the costs of producing shows make the backing of big studios highly desirable, if not necessary.
"No one else in series television is doing this," said Tom Werner, the co-chief executive of the company along with his career-long partner, Marcy Carsey. "You do feel a little like you're in the VW bug on the New Jersey Turnpike."
"We're doing very well," Ms. Carsey said, "but in this environment, with mega-companies being built and everyone merging with everyone else, we are a little lonely. We're feeling either very smart or very stupid."
There is no question how the rest of the television industry would answer that equation. "Tom and Marcy get the game," said Leslie Moonves, president of CBS Entertainment, to whom Carsey-Werner will deliver the much-anticipated new Bill Cosby comedy in the fall. "They're great producers; they know programming and they know scheduling. They're also very good business people. And right now, they are very, very hot."
Carsey-Werner, which only a couple of years ago was down to "Roseanne" as its only running hit, now has more successful shows on the air -- four -- than ever before. With the new Cosby show in the wings and, it says, another comedy pilot called "Men Behaving Badly" likely to be picked up by a network next fall, the tiny company, with only about 100 employees, will surpass all other production companies and most Hollywood studios in the total number of shows on network prime-time television.
And now they are thinking of taking on the movie business.
"We see an opportunity in movies," Ms. Carsey said in an interview conducted with the company's executives in their brightly lit, comfortably furnished offices on the old MTM studio lot (now owned by CBS).
"It's a great opportunity," Mr. Werner added. "There's a kind of comedy the studios are not making." Putting it simply, he called it "smart comedy."
"We all have families," said Caryn Mandabach, president of Carsey-Werner. "We found we couldn't take them to any movie. It's irritating to have to go to a movie and not laugh."
But just as they did when they started their television production company in 1981, Carsey-Werner is avoiding rushing into movie production with 20 deals in various stages of development, with exclusive distribution contracts being negotiated, or with big-money stars in tow.
"We feel there must be some way to maneuver" to avoid all that, Mr. Werner said. "We feel if we get the right material we'll get it made. And we won't spend $20 million on an actor. We'll try to find our own Jim Carrey."
At the moment, Carsey-Werner Moving Pictures has a staff of one and there is exactly one script in development. For Carsey-Werner that amounts to a strength, not a limitation.
"They are very discriminating," said Warren Littlefield, president of NBC Entertainment. "They won't do something they don't believe in. That can be maddening at times when you want them for a project. But it gives them a lot of freedom."
Freedom was the big reason that Ms. Carsey and Mr. Werner left ABC in 1981. Even then it was conventional for former network executives to tie themselves to a studio or network, simply because it was the best way to insure that a new company could survive the fearsome start-up economics of television production.
All series are produced at a deficit because networks do not pay enough in license fees to cover the costs of making a show. A typical episode of a half-hour comedy costs between $500,000 and $600,000 to produce and runs a deficit of $100,000 to $200,000. Without a big bankroll, it is almost impossible to absorb those deficits while waiting for the payoff that a big hit brings: the hundreds of millions of dollars that can be made in syndication.
But in 1981, when the pair left their jobs as programmers at ABC, Ms. Carsey was adamant about remaining independent. She wanted no strings attached.
The company's first comedy, "Oh Madeline," was a miss. Still, Carsey-Werner resisted all entreaties from networks and studios.
"One of the things we think is very important is not only did we not make a studio deal, but we never made a network deal," Mr. Werner said. "Some shows are just served better by one network but not by another."
Carsey-Werner has proved that several times over. "If we had been exclusive to ABC when we did 'The Cosby Show,' it wouldn't have gotten on the air because ABC rejected it," Ms. Carsey said. "Then when we were at NBC, that was sort of our home network for the time being, but they passed on 'Roseanne.' So if we had had an exclusive arrangement with them, that show might not have seen the light of day."
The same pattern has held with "Cybill," which was rejected by ABC and picked up by CBS, and now "Third Rock from the Sun," which ABC executives did not believe could be a hit and so delivered it into the waiting arms of NBC.
As with many Carsey-Werner shows, "Third Rock" began with the producers musing about subjects not currently being done on network television. (The pair, coincidentally, helped give birth to another alien-comes-to-town series, "Mork and Mindy," in the 1970's.)
This time, they came up with the notion of "aliens on a field trip," as Ms. Mandabach put it, then took the concept to Bonnie and Terry Turner, a husband-wife writing team, who fleshed out the idea into a series that dealt with observations about the variety and silliness of human behavior. John Lithgow, an actor the company loved from his film work, was brought in to star. After two pilots, the show finally took shape.
Both Mr. Lithgow and the Turners have ownership stakes in the series, another formula usually followed at Carsey-Werner. The results have been to make some stars and producers high-multiple millionaires. "The Cosby Show," for example, has made the most money in television syndication history, a figure that is approaching $1 billion.
The cash has supplied Carsey-Werner with the cushion it needs to stay independent and go in other directions. "What we've used some of the money for is to expand our business," said Stuart Glickman, the chief operating officer and the principal deal maker for Carsey-Werner.
Beyond that, the company's profits are managed carefully. All the principals have steered clear of the religion of conspicuous consumption practiced so widely in Hollywood.
In one flight of extravagance, Mr. Werner took a bit of his "Cosby" stash and fulfilled a lifelong dream by buying the San Diego Padres. His ownership of the baseball team was a disaster that he says he is thrilled to have put behind him.
Among other things, it reminded him too much of the excesses now plaguing Hollywood. "One of the things that troubles us is studios paying exorbitant amounts of money for writers. It's very much like these baseball players who aren't worth that kind of money.
"We are focusing on growing our writers," Mr. Werner said. "We try to get them when they're babies and we try to keep them as long as possible."
Ms. Carsey and Mr. Werner work as what they call "line producers," which means they are down on the stage when episodes of their shows are put on tape or film. They also cast and supervise scripts and everything else down to the construction of the sets.
"Television is an adventure for us," Mr. Werner said.
"It's opening night every night on every show," Ms. Carsey said.
In the late 1980's Carsey-Werner almost accepted an offer from CBS to run all of the network's programming.
Stepping up to something much bigger still has some appeal.
"We would consider something odd and different. We look at what Michael Eisner has done with Disney and it's very exciting to have that sort of major impact on American culture," Mr. Werner said.
For the networks that employ them now, the impact Carsey-Werner already has is impressive. As Mr. Moonves of CBS noted, next season the company may have two hit comedies at each of the three established networks.
"They are like holding the key to three different networks at the same time," Mr. Moonves said. "That is very, very unusual."

HEADLINE: Goldman, Sachs Partners Decide Not to Sell, After All

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs & Company, Wall Street's last big private partnership, has decided after weeks of deliberation that it will not put itself up for sale, people who attended the firm's annual partners' meeting over the weekend said yesterday.
The decision, which was not put to a vote of the Goldman partners, is expected to put aside for at least several years the issue of whether to remain private, to sell the firm or to offer stock in it to the public. 
 The buoyant stock market; a recent successful public stock offering by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and Goldman's large profit -- $1.37 billion before taxes for the fiscal year that ended on Nov. 30 -- had made the question of whether the firm would go public one of Wall Street's favorite topics of speculation over the last several months. All of Goldman's big competitors have, one by one, decided to sell stock in their businesses.
The Goldman partners reached their decision after a panel of them had spent several weeks studying the firm's capital structure. Almost all of the 174 partners were gathered on Friday and Saturday at the Doral Arrowwood conference center in Rye Brook, N.Y., north of New York City, for the meeting.
There have always been formidable obstacles to Goldman's going public. In particular, there would be complex tax and accounting questions, people familiar with the firm's accounts and with Goldman's recent study of its capital structure said yesterday.
In addition, prices for the shares of brokerage firms have declined recently, taking the shine off any possible Goldman offering in the near future. In recent weeks, Goldman partners had speculated that they might be able to sell the firm for twice its book value, but the recent slide in brokerage stocks might have lowered the multiple to around 1.5 times book value.
"The bottom line is we came out enthusiastic believers and supporters that we should go forward with our business plans in a private partnership format," a person who attended the meetings said. "I think the sense of the partners is this is the best motivational and organizational structure for us and for our business plans. There's tremendous allure to stimulate people" in the partnership, he added, referring to the financial attractiveness of senior status in Goldman, Sachs.
Partnership usually brings compensation of millions of dollars a year, and has been the brass ring the firm used to draw in talent and keep its ambitious employees working long hours.
Nevertheless, the idea of selling Goldman has come up every few years. It was an issue in 1986, when the firm's management committee, which included Jon S. Corzine, the current chairman and senior partner, voted for a sale. But dissent over the details among the younger partners -- who usually have smaller shares in the partnership and therefore stand to make less money from a sale -- derailed that initiative.
This time, Mr. Corzine and his colleagues preferred the partnership format, apparently convinced that Goldman's ability in recent years to gain access to capital from outsiders like the Sumitomo Bank of Japan and the Kamehameha Schools/Bernice Pauahi Bishop Estate, an educational trust in Hawaii, more than met its needs.
In an interview last month, Mr. Corzine and Henry M. Paulson Jr., the firm's vice chairman and chief operating officer, emphasized that Goldman had always had access to the capital it needed. Finding and training the right people, Mr. Paulson said, was a bigger challenge than securing capital.
Nevertheless, Mr. Corzine and Mr. Paulson, who took over the running of the partnership in September 1994, when Goldman was experiencing one of its most difficult years, said that they wanted to review the firm's capital structure.
At the meetings this weekend, Mr. Corzine also reportedly talked to partners about Goldman's strategy for 1996, and there was a special focus on Asian business. Goldman is apparently optimistic about prospects for the coming months, and its leaders believe that the strong momentum the firm built up in 1995, when profit rebounded, is continuing.
Goldman's leaders apparently also believe that there is a good prospect of lower interest rates and do not expect a recession soon in the United States.

HEADLINE: THE FLOODING AFTER THE STORM: THE OVERVIEW;
Flooding Called Worst in Decades

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Swollen rivers and streams across the New York and mid-Atlantic regions receded yesterday as tens of thousands of evacuated residents returned to flood-ravaged homes and businesses in eight states, and public officials began to assess the costs of the worst flooding in decades.
But the danger had not passed everywhere. Some 10,000 residents were still being evacuated yesterday from West Virginia towns along the surging Ohio River. About 1,100 homes on Wheeling Island, at Wheeling, were under six feet of water, their 3,000 occupants still refugees. So were the 700 residents of Port Deposit, Md., in the shadow of an overflowing river dam. 
 From Virginia to New York, there were tales of tragedy, survival, oddity and hardship: five members of a New York family were killed when a road washed away and their car plunged into a reservoir; a Maryland mud slide, like lava, engulfed six car dealerships; driftwood decorated a bridge in upstate New York, and the Governor of Pennsylvania was forced to evacuate his mansion.
And the new Mayor in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., who has seen two huge snowstorms and a flood since his inauguration three weeks ago, was marveling at the wonders of public service. "I don't know what to expect next, maybe a volcano eruption," said Mayor Tom McGroarty, whose town narrowly escaped inundation after almost all its 90,000 residents were evacuated over the weekend.
No immediate estimate of the mid-Atlantic's flood damage was available, but experts said it would probably add tens of millions of dollars to the burden that states, cities and families are bearing for the Blizzard of '96, which shut down much of the East under two to three feet of snow earlier this month.
Deep into a winter that has brought heavy snows, bitter cold, pounding rains and a January thaw that suddenly melted the mountainous snowpack across eight states, weekend floods added another misery for thousands along the great tree of eastern waterways: the Susquehanna, the Delaware, the Monongahela, the Ohio, the Allegheny, the Potomac and other rivers and their latticework tributaries.
As the engorged rivers crested and fell, the toll of death and damage began to emerge, and emergency officials in many areas called it the worst flooding since Tropical Storm Agnes in 1972, which killed 48 people and left 220,000 homeless in Pennsylvania alone, or Hurricane Eloise, which caused 44 deaths and hundreds of millions in damage from the Caribbean to New England in 1975.
Since Friday's heavy rains and unseasonal warmth, which unleashed the melting and flooding, at least 35 weather-related deaths have been reported in the East, 10 of them in New York State. Five people are missing.
While many rivers and streams crested above flood stage, all did not overflow their banks and many areas were spared. But flood damage was heavy in dozens of locales, including Pittsburgh; Wilkes-Barre; Cumberland, Md.; Wheeling, W.Va., and the devastated little village of Walton, N.Y., where almost every home and business was severely damaged.
Lesser damage was reported in Trenton, where the Delaware flowed into a newly renovated State House Annex and parking garage; in Washington; Harrisburg, Pa.; Port Jervis, N.Y.; Wayne, N.J.; Bucks County, Pa., and scores of small towns and rural areas from Virginia to upstate New York.
In the most severely flooded areas, refugees from the surging water returned to find homes and businesses partly submerged or caked in mud. Many roads and bridges were out. Power was off in many areas, telephone lines were down, some sewage plants had failed and debris littered streets that had run like rivers.
Pennsylvania appeared to have been hit hardest, and President Clinton yesterday declared the state a Federal disaster area, making available temporary housing, individual family and home repair grants, disaster unemployment benefits and low-interest loans for affected businesses and homeowners.
"It was very clear that the need was there," James Le Witt, administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said after members of his staff made a flying survey of the state. He immediately designated six counties eligible for relief and said more would be added as damage assessments were made. "With the amount of homes that were flooded, businesses and communities affected, it was absolutely clear that some Federal help was needed," Mr. Le Witt added.
Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, who had asked that 58 of the 67 counties be included in the disaster declaration, called the aid inadequate and said he would seek more. Mr. Ridge, who fled the Governor's mansion with his family Saturday night as floods in Harrisburg closed in, ordered state offices under his jurisdiction closed today in Harrisburg and Pittsburgh. The Legislature canceled sessions for the week as many roads were closed and Amtrak service between Philadelphia and Harrisburg was suspended.
Downtown Pittsburgh was inundated by its worst flooding in two decades. A park and many streets became vast lakes, and hundreds of homes and businesses were damaged by the overflowing Ohio, Monongahela and Allegheny Rivers. The sewage system in Allegheny County was shut down. Water also spilled into Three Rivers Stadium, but the Steelers' Super Bowl gear for next Sunday was saved.
At the other end of the state, nearly all of the 100,000 evacuted residents of flood-plain areas of the Susquehanna, including most of the 90,000 people of Wilkes-Barre, went home yesterday. For almost 24 hours, Wilkes-Barre had lived in fear that the river would breach its dikes, but it overflowed in only a few areas.
Still, hundreds of returning evacuees yesterday found damaged homes and businesses, and many spent the day pumping water, scraping away mud and surveying ruined furniture and wrecked premises. Utilities had been turned off in most areas of the city, and many homes were still without power or heat.
In Washington, the Potomac poured over its banks in some areas, causing what was expected to be the worst flooding in the nation's capital in a decade. Some streets in historic Georgetown and other sections of the city were under water. City officials rerouted buses, closed a bridge to Virginia and peppered the citizenry with warnings.
In New York, Gov. George E. Pataki declared a state of emergency in 22 upstate counties as widespread flooding and mud slides were reported. Ten weather-related deaths were reported across the state -- two people trapped in a flooded Schoharie County house died of exposure, a Schenectady man was caught in a mud slide that engulfed a gas station and the rest died in traffic accidents.
In Delaware County, 40 miles east of Binghamton, a roadway collapsed and four cars plunged into the Cannonsville Reservoir in the Town of Tompkins. A family of five was killed and another man was missing. But several people were rescued in the incident, including a police officer who spent 20 minutes trapped in an air pocket in his car before getting out.
In the nearby village of Walton, hundreds of homes and businesses -- virtually every structure in town -- were five feet deep in floodwaters over the weekend. Yesterday, as the three Delaware River tributaries that run through the village receded, residents pumped out cellars and surveyed the damage. "The heart of the village is in really bad shape," Mayor Jack Kelly said.
He recalled how firefighters, at the height of the flooding, stood waist-deep in water on the main street and battled flames that eventually destroyed clothing and hardware stores. Old-timers recalled that the village had been deluged in 1935 but said this weekend's flooding was worse.
Thousands of residents were evacuated in other upstate New York communities, including Campbell and Erwin on the Cohocton River; Addison, Cameron and Canisteo on the Canisteo River; Schoharie on Schoharie Creek, and Wellsville on the Genesee. In Port Jervis, six feet of water flooded low-lying homes.
In New Jersey, thousands who had been evacuated, some by boat, returned to their homes yesterday in Warren and Mercer Counties, and smaller numbers to homes they had left in Bergen, Burlington, Passaic and Somerset Counties. The most serious flooding was along the Delaware north of New Hope, near Frenchtown on the New Jersey side and Tinicum Township on the Pennsylvania side, and in Manville, N.J., where 400 homes were flooded in the worst deluge since Tropical Strom Doria in 1971.
In Trenton, floodwaters entered the garage of the State House Annex, apparently bubbling up through a storm drain. Three feet of water submerged the garage's lower level and threatened heating, electrical and air-conditioning systems of the annex, which might have been shut down for weeks without power. Firefighters and the National Guard used pumps and sandbags to save the day.
Perils continued yesterday in parts of West Virginia and Maryland. On Wheeling Island, an enclave of Wheeling where all 1,100 homes were flooded by the Ohio River and many residents were still staying in shelters or the homes of friends or relatives, Carl Bradford, director of the West Virginia Office of Emergency Services, said:
"This is a miserable time to flood. We've had temperatures in the 20's and teens. The water goes down and the house is full of ice."
Some 10,000 residents were still being evacuated from towns along the flooding Ohio on West Virginia's western edge. The river crested at 10 feet above flood stage at Wheeling, but the crest still had to traverse hundreds of miles and was not expected to reach the state's southern border until tomorrow.
Rains and runoff pushed a thick mud slide through a commercial district of Cumberland, Md., burying a series of car dealerships. "Every car on every lot of six car dealerships was destroyed," said Cpl. Steve Winiger of the state police.
