HEADLINE: Mexico City Journal;
Mariachis of Mexico Are Living the Blues

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Though it was still early in the night, the temperature was 38 degrees and dropping. The trumpeter's lips were blue and the fiddler could barely bend his fingers. One stumbling patron ordered up a string of songs and then got so drunk he could not be coaxed to pay. The musicians were tempted to roll him and seize their fee. Glumly, they let him go.
They had reached the depths of mariachi misery. 
 These are bitter times for the street-corner musicians-for-hire known as mariachis, whose trumpet choruses and silver-buttoned suits are trademarks of Mexican nationalism. An unsparing year-old economic crisis has left Mexicans with precious little extra cash to buy a sweetheart's serenade or a musical Mother's Day homage.
At the same time, mariachi groups are besieged with competition from other styles, especially tropical dance rhythms and norteno music from the United States border region with its boisterous sagas of bumbling cops and heroic cocaine traffickers.
If that was not enough, for more than a month the nighttime cold here in the capital, site of the Plaza Garibaldi, the main place in Mexico where mariachis congregate to wait for customers, has been cruelly biting.
Both the music and uniform of the mariachi are symbols of a stubbornly independent and macho but also sentimental Mexican identity. Their suits, inspired by rural rodeos, are bolero jackets, silk bow-ties, tight pants with silver buttons down the sides and often a flashy pistol. For fancy occasions they don huge velvet-lined sombreros. They play ranchera music, sometimes plaintive and sometimes spirited hymns to the romantic conquests and humiliations of everyday Mexicans.
The tradition of mariachi music, which originated in west-central Mexico in the 1850's, is an intimate part of Mexican family life. (The word mariachi, whose origins are in dispute, is a 19th-century term referring to a party.) While most other Latin countries have adopted some version of the American "Happy Birthday," Mexicans sing a mariachi song. Many Mexican men still bring along a mariachi band when making a marriage proposal. Baptisms, weddings and other rites of passage are accompanied by mariachi brass and the thump of the big acoustic bass guitar.
"Mexicans have a deep need for music to be present in their emotional moments, to vent either a great joy or a great sorrow," said Jesus Jauregui of the National Institute of Anthropology and History, who has written a book about mariachis. "The mariachi is there to play in person to satisfy the urgent needs of the soul of the customer."
Mariachi music thrived in periods when nationalist fervor surged. During the revolutionary turmoil after 1910, Mexican insurgents brought rural mariachi bands with them to the capital to demonstrate their commitment to local culture. In the 1960's and 70's, when anti-Americanism ran high, mariachis prospered.
Today, most Mexicans are too beleaguered by financial hardship and uncertain about their future to celebrate their nationality. So the nights in the Plaza Garibaldi can get very long.
"There are nights when we earn something and nights when we earn exactly nothing," said Javier Solis Junior, a soulful singer in a maroon sombrero who has worked in Garibaldi for 12 years. Some musicians confessed they had stooped to the ultimate indignity for a professional mariachi: a day job.
Many bars ringing the plaza have switched from mariachis to electric bands that play Caribbean dance music, leaving the mariachis quite literally out in the cold. Last week, a bar called the Mariachi Corner featured a salsa band, blaring its music into the plaza.
"It's an abomination," said Jonathan Clark, an American from California whose love of the music led him to play with mariachi groups in the Plaza Garibaldi for more than a decade. "Before, no one ever put a loudspeaker out. It ruins the plaza and makes it impossible for the mariachis to work."
In the 1980's the zone around Garibaldi descended into disrepute as muggers worked over tourists and brothels spread. To clean things up, the Government almost killed the mariachis with kindness by sponsoring a project to dig up the plaza for an underground garage, recently completed after a three-year ordeal.
Authentic musicians are battling pirate mariachis who peddle cut-rate services by accosting cars on the avenues that lead to Garibaldi. "They're lousy musicians and they don't wear the costume with dignity," grumbled Ismael Gutierrez, a singer with a handlebar moustache.
Mariachis have been forced to adapt their music to modern tastes without sacrificing their sound. They have purloined spicy tropical dance beats, norteno ballads, weeping romantic trio songs, even rock tunes if customers ask.
"We can play anything," said Jose Serafin Ruiz, leader of a band called the Mariachi Zihualteco. "We are here to please the people who listen to us, not to satisfy ourselves."
Paradoxically, Mexican mariachis are at a low point just as their music has become popular internationally. Mariachi groups have been formed in 40 countries, including Aruba and Japan.
Even in Mexico, the desire for mariachis is depressed but hardly defunct. Last year Mexican television networks, which were ignoring the mariachis, were shamed by the success of a nighttime soap opera produced in Colombia with mariachi theme music and characters.
"If someone really feels Mexican music, all it takes is a tequila or two to bring it back," Roberto Lopez Olvera, a guitar player, said confidently.
In fact, just when the plaza seemed unbearable to the musicians, a group of jubilant elderly women appeared. They had come to Mexico City from the provinces to visit the shrine of Mexico's patron Virgin of Guadalupe. Their husbands were at home and they had cash to burn.
"Mariachis can never die!" proclaimed Esperanza Mora Navarro, 63, as she stepped into the ring of musicians for a fast-kicking dance. She ordered up obscure songs from her home state and Mr. Gutierrez knew them all. He took off with a yodeling croon and, under his mustache, a big, satisfied smile.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Like squeegee-wielding Manhattanites, mariachis serenade passing motorists in hopes of being hired. (Keith Dannemiller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A DEFAULT THREAT IS HINTED AS WAY TO SETTLE BUDGET

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
In the latest Republican effort to revive the party's stymied economic and social agendas, the House majority leader, Dick Armey, said today that Congress would refuse to extend the nation's ability to borrow money to meet its bills unless President Clinton yields to the party's budget-cutting initiatives to decrease "the size and intrusiveness of government."
The position outlined by Mr. Armey of Texas, a close ally of Speaker Newt Gingrich, signaled that the Republicans might be willing to use the threat of national default to force Mr. Clinton to give more ground. Mr. Armey's comments on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" came just a day before Congress goes back into session. 
 His position directly contradicted assurances given the past week by other Republican leaders -- including Mr. Gingrich and Representative John R. Kasich, the chairman of the House Budget Committee -- that a way would be found to make sure the Government paid its obligations, from interest on the debt to Social Security to veteran's benefits.
Mr. Gingrich could not be reached for comment on Mr. Armey's statement. And it was not known what kind of conditions the Speaker or Mr. Kasich of Ohio or other Republican leaders might be willing to place on an increase in the debt limit. But there are signs of sharp disagreement in the Republican ranks, and Mr. Armey is known for having an accurate reading of where the most conservative members stand.
For Mr. Clinton, any delay or prolonged debate over raising the nation's borrowing authority would have the same effect as no increase at all: It would force the Treasury Department to find new techniques -- including some that the Clinton Administration itself has said may be of uncertain legality -- to raise cash to keep paying its bondholders. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has said that the country would run out of money around Feb. 15.
Mr. Rubin's fear -- but, in a way, his greatest weapon against the Republicans -- is that the bond markets would suddenly conclude that the threat of default is quite real. That would likely result in a surge in the interest rates that the world markets charge the United States to borrow money -- an increase that would ripple through the economy, sending mortgage rates and other major interest rates higher.
Already, the nation's two biggest credit rating agencies, Moody's and Standard and Poor's, have warned that the United States's AAA credit rating could be at risk. Traditionally, American Treasury securities have been regarded as the world's least-risky investment, but that judgment, and the cost of borrowing, could change dramatically if investors concluded that gridlock in Washington could delay the Government's ability to pay them on time.
Mr. Rubin has made clear that he has a plan to evade the $4.9 trillion debt limit. But he has refused to discuss the details publicly, in part because lawyers for the Treasury and Justice Departments are still working on legal justifications for such steps. "Clearly, we're in terra nova," Mr. Rubin said recently, "and this is not something we can do indefinitely."
So Mr. Rubin's challenge is to simultaneously reassure the markets and scare the Republicans, convincing them they will be blamed for undermining America's credit rating. But the big question is how long Mr. Rubin can maintain this approach, and whether evading the debt limit would begin to exact a political cost on Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Rubin said through a spokesman that he did not want to respond to Mr. Armey's comments today. But appearing on the same television show, Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said that it was "disturbing" that "the Republicans are going to hold the debt ceiling hostage to their agenda."
The Texas Republican said that Congress would not shut the Government down again, as it did twice last year. Instead, he suggested that a "continuing resolution" would be passed to keep Government operations running for 30 days or so, though with considerably less money for many agencies.
He made it clear that, in his view, no effort to get a "clean debt limit increase" through Congress -- that is, one with no conditions -- would succeed.
"John Kasich's willingness to vote for it to the contrary," said Mr. Armey, "it's not coming through the House unless it carries with it something that is a substantial share of our agenda of decreasing the size and the intrusiveness of government."
"We have a House that is committed to getting this job done, and we're going to use every instrument we can to move the ball forward," he said.
For several months now, Mr. Rubin has stymied Republican efforts to use the debt limit as a weapon to force the President to accede on the budget. He has accomplished that by "disinvesting" two Government pension funds -- in essence, selling the securities held in those funds and replacing them with i.o.u.'s to repay the principal and interest. The i.o.u.'s do not count against the debt limit, though they are essentially a Government obligation. Congress gave the Treasury Secretary that power in the 1980's when Democrats were using the debt limit to force action by President Ronald Reagan, and it guaranteed the Government would restore lost principle or interest.
Despite that legislative guarantee, Republican leaders have already accused Mr. Rubin of "raiding" Government pension funds, a term Mr. Armey used again today. "Secretary Rubin has been extremely ingenious at how he's been able to get into people's retirement funds and grab up that money to keep the Government running," he said.
But Mr. Rubin has now used as much of the pension money as he legally can. Other options -- making use of other Government money, selling or leasing the Government's gold supplies, calling in more Government deposits held in commercial banks or kept in foreign currencies -- have substantial legal impediments.
By forcing Mr. Rubin to take extraordinary steps, the Republicans hope to make considerable political gains. If they could convince the public that Mr. Rubin is manipulating public money, they could prompt a backlash against the Administration. Some conservative Republicans have even suggested beginning impeachment hearings against the Treasury Secretary for exceeding his authority, but the Republican leadership fears that could backfire.
The Republicans also could load up a debt limit increase with conditions they know President Clinton would find unacceptable. If he vetoes that increase, Republican strategists figure, he would bear the blame for whatever financial chaos follows.
Today, Mr. Armey said he would support linking the debt limit increase to a commitment to eliminate the Commerce Department, a periodic priority of the Republican Congress, and preventing the Treasury secretary from "ever again raiding the trust funds of Federal workers' retirement programs."
In other words, in order to get a temporary debt increase, Mr. Clinton would have to agree to tie Mr. Rubin's hands in the future. That is a deal the White House has said repeatedly it would not accept.

HEADLINE: Michigan Welfare Plan Draws Unlikely Support

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Gov. John Engler of Michigan is known in Washington as a zealous lobbyist for overhauling welfare who has turned up there 21 times in the last year and is sometimes mentioned as a Republican Vice-Presidential prospect.
But in his home state, Governor Engler is pursuing changes in welfare policy that are pleasing the Clinton Administration more than his Republican allies on Capitol Hill. 
 The Democrats' unlikely and somewhat unwilling hero announced an ambitious pilot project on Wednesday that seeks to cut welfare costs by providing generous social services so that poor people can go to work. Democrats call his plan enlightened. Republicans have been caught off guard.
Mr. Engler's plan may change the shape of the welfare debate because many governors, increasingly expected to design their own programs, are looking for guidance. Michigan, Wisconsin and Massachusetts are at the forefront of the search to make welfare programs less costly by finding jobs for those without work.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said the plan showed that "sanity may be returning to this debate." He praised Mr. Engler for breaking with Congressional Republicans by using child care and transportation subsidies and fashioning a more active role for social workers in an effort to turn welfare recipients into workers.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich was delighted with the Michigan plan.
"The Engler approach appears to be fundamentally different than the Republican approach in Congress and much closer to the President," he said.
Mr. Engler's fellow Republicans say his plan is a terrific example of their push to give power back to the states by allowing them to shape their own welfare programs. But they have moved quickly to distance themselves from the specifics.
"It may not be the way we want to go in Pennsylvania," said Senator Rick Santorum, the conservative Pennsylvania Republican who managed the welfare debate on the Senate floor last year.
Mr. Santorum said he favored strict limits on the number of years that anyone could receive welfare, whether the person had found a job or not. The Michigan plan has no such time limits, although Mr. Engler has said he is considering them.
Even William F. Weld, the moderate Republican Governor of Massachusetts, said he would not try to follow the Engler example. "This is a generous plan on the part of John Engler," Mr. Weld said. But, he added, "I like a sterner approach" that requires work -- the Michigan plan allows community service for those who cannot find jobs -- and that throws people off welfare rolls after a certain time.
The Michigan plan, which takes effect on April 1, is called Project Zero because its aim is to reduce unemployment to zero among welfare recipients. It will start as a pilot program in a Detroit suburb, a poor Detroit neighborhood and four rural counties. As part of the program, Michigan will send social workers into the homes of every welfare recipient in those six areas and offer them help in finding jobs, along with subsidized child care and transportation to work. If the pilot effort shows itself to be successful after a year, Governor Engler hopes to expand it statewide.
Those who refuse to try to find jobs would lose all of their benefits almost immediately, provided that Congress and the President reach a compromise soon that would give states the discretion to cut off benefits. But at that point the Engler plan diverges from other Republican proposals. Welfare recipients who cannot find work will be required to perform unpaid community service to keep receiving checks. Most Congressional Republicans have favored requirements that recipients get jobs, and would cut off benefits after five years for recipients who had not worked.
Also unlike legislation supported by Congressional Republicans, the Michigan approach allows payments for children born to women already receiving welfare.
In response to unwanted compliments from Democrats, Mr. Engler is talking tough about how he will kick welfare recipients off the rolls if they do not participate in his jobs program. "It won't be five years now, it will be a month if they miss their appointments," the Governor said.
Stung by criticism that his plan is not conservative enough, Mr. Engler took pains in a telephone interview on Friday to say that he supported on principle some of the more severe restrictions on welfare benefits advocated by Congressional Republicans, but did not have the authority to put them into effect. "There are significant limitations on what we can do because of limits under Federal laws," he explained.
He said his preference would be to cut off all benefits to welfare recipients who had not found work in two to five years. But he said that he had not decided whether to cut off benefits to babies born to mothers already on welfare even if Congressional Republicans make it possible for him to do so.
And while liberals see his child care and transportation subsidies as a sign of enlightened policy tastes, Mr. Engler describes them differently: "We've used that to eliminate excuses from welfare recipients" who complain they cannot work.
But some prominent conservatives have agreed with the Clinton Administration that the Michigan welfare plan resembled programs more often put forward by Democrats.
"This is Bill Clinton's plan," said Charles A. Murray, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group in Washington and an author whose works link race, genetics and I.Q.
Nonpartisan welfare policy experts, including some who have criticized other Republican initiatives, have been intrigued by Michigan's experiment.
"This meets the public's interest in both protecting children and getting tough on parents," said Judith M. Gueron, president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit policy research group based in New York.
"This could have real reverberations at a state level," Ms. Gueron said. "States have the opportunity to recast the safety net, and Michigan is doing that in a way that really pays attention to what the message from the public has been on welfare reform."
Republican reaction has been more cautious. "Governor Engler's actions show that governors need flexibility -- what works in Michigan may not work in California," said Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican.
But Mr. Wilson praised the Engler plan as showing that states given more power to shape welfare programs will not "race to the bottom, as has been suggested by opponents to welfare reform," but would "develop new approaches designed to address the root causes of welfare dependency and to help recipients become self-sufficient."
Senator Spencer Abraham, a Michigan Republican and close ally of Mr. Engler, made a similar point. "One of the arguments we have had to go up against is that the states would be less compassionate" in dealing with the poor, he said. But Michigan's effort will genuinely help the poor, he said.
Mr. Abraham said that while conservatives may often oppose giving government too active a role, making Michigan's welfare workers more active might not be a bad idea. Michigan welfare workers typically spend two-thirds of their time filling out required paperwork, rather than working with welfare recipients, Mr. Abraham said, and Mr. Engler is right to send them into homes more frequently.
Mr. Moynihan said the Engler plan, with its open-ended commitment to provide welfare to anyone who at least expressed a desire to work, was simply more practical than other Republican approaches to welfare. "To impose a five-year time limit on the city of Detroit, where two-thirds of the children are on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, would invite social ruin," he said.

HEADLINE: California's Universities Confront New Diversity Rules

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Now that the University of California has reaffirmed its decision to use social and economic disadvantage, not race and sex, as criteria in hiring and admissions, the state's nine campuses face the difficult task of deciding which applicants will get preference.
The University's Board of Regents, which said it still wanted to pursue ethnic and racial diversity in hiring faculty, admitting students and awarding contracts, has issued guidelines to the nine campuses. Now the individual campuses must decide how to apply those guidelines in admitting students. 
Under the guidelines, 50 percent of the applicants would be admitted solely on academic achievement. But up to half the applicants meeting minimum academic requirements would then be evaluated based on what the Regents call "special circumstances."
Those circumstances include whether a student has shown unusual persistence and determination, needs to work, is from a socially or educationally disadvantaged environment or has a difficult family situation. All decisions will be made by college admissions officers.
"It really is going to boil down to a judgment call," said Charles A. Ratliff, deputy director of the California Postsecondary Education Commission, an independent state agency that provides information about higher education.
"You start with the traditional academic criteria, and then the question is whether one set of personal circumstances is more or less valuable than a different set," he said. "It's doable, but it sounds far more labor-intensive, and many wonder what is the hidden cost of moving to this gender- and race-blind approach to diversifying."
Among those who have questioned the approach are the faculty members and students who protested outside the Regents meeting last week in an 11th-hour effort to persuade the board to reinstate the traditional affirmative action policies. They argued that the new policy would reverse years of progress toward racial diversity and would saddle admissions officers with the unusual burden of deciding who was disadvantaged. New admissions policies will be used to select freshmen entering in 1997; revised hiring policies for faculty took effect on Jan. 1.
In July, when the Regents first approved the new approach to affirmative action, one special circumstance that admissions officers were asked to use as a criterion was whether a student is from "an abusive or otherwise dysfunctional home."
"The idea of measuring 'dysfunctionality' is a bureaucratic nightmare," said Jerome Karabel, a professor of sociology at Berkeley who opposes the Regents' action.
Keith F. Widaman, a professor of psychology at the Riverside campus and a member of a task force that helped the Regents develop their guidelines, agreed. "Most of us thought that was kind of bizarre," Mr. Widaman said. "What teen-ager doesn't think they come from a dysfunctional family?"
Instead, when the Regents gave their final guidelines to the campuses, the criterion "dysfunctional home" was replaced with "difficult family situations."
The campuses are now reviewing the Regents' guidelines and will develop new admissions policies in the next year, barring any successful challenges to the policy. Despite the protests on Thursday, the Regents rejected motions that would have delayed or overturned their new approach to affirmative action.
Beyond the potentially muddy task of sorting through a student's psychological difficulties, other criteria for identifying disadvantaged students could also pose dilemmas, educators said.
Economic disadvantage would seem to be clearly determined by a family's income level, parents' educational level and the applicant's neighborhood. But in deciding whether a student is poor, some suggest that there is an important distinction between the "newly poor," like students whose parents were among the thousands laid off from Air Force bases in Southern California, and students who have always been poor and at more of a disadvantage.
"There is no easy way to do this," Mr. Widaman said. "The campuses are going to have to figure it out."
Those developing new admissions policies said applications would include more personal essays, which could provide insight into an applicant's experiences and struggles.
On the current application, which is used for all nine campuses, students are asked to write a personal statement; part of the instructions say, "If you have faced unusual circumstances, challenges or hardships, describe them and how you have responded."
The new applications are expected to be more direct and to include a supplemental questionnaire that would ask students to describe their life circumstances in detail.
"Instead of discussing the job you had, we are going to need to know if you had to work to supplement family income or to pay for the car insurance on the BMW that mommy bought you," Mr. Widaman said.

HEADLINE: Ranchers Hurt By Steep Drop In Beef Prices

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: CASPER, Wyo., Jan. 21

 BODY:
In the 1980's, falling beef prices led to the failure of thousands of ranches, with more than 80,000 ranches disappearing from 1986 through 1990.
Now, many ranches are again at risk. Responding to an oversupply of beef, cattle prices have plunged about 35 percent in the last three years, threatening a replay of the 1980's. 
 "The cattle market has just fallen through the floor," said Jim Hendry, co-owner of the 150,000-acre Clear Creek Ranch, 60 miles west of Casper. "There seems to be no slowing up. It's in a free fall. There will be a washout before this is done."
Some ranches are already being forced by their lenders to liquidate, with the prospects of more to come, with no quick way for the cattle industry to overcome an excess of beef. High prices early in the decade spurred too much production, which is why the United States is now awash in record supplies of beef. Economists predict two more years of low prices before supplies begin to fall into line with demand.
The financial pain afflicting ranchers is very likely to be felt in other industries as cattle producers curtail capital costs to stay afloat. When beef prices are strong, many of the nation's 900,000 ranchers buy pickup trucks and heavy equipment, and build new corrals and barns. When prices plunge, those expenditures are put on hold.
"Most of our costs are fixed costs," said Mr. Hendry's son, Rob, a co-owner who oversees day-to-day operations. "You can't cut them." But big-ticket purchases can be put off, and that is exactly what Rob Hendry plans to do.
While ranchers suffer, consumers are getting a break. Many supermarkets are slashing beef prices, sometimes taking as much as 25 percent to 50 percent off 1993 prices, the National Cattlemen's Association reports.
Making the problem worse is a general meat glut nationwide -- too much pork and too much chicken as well, along with low-cost Mexican cattle. The devaluation of the peso has made Mexican beef a bargain. As a result, Mexican cattle are being imported to feedlots in the United States where they are fattened and slaughtered, adding to the supply, the Cattlemen's Association reported.
"There are record supplies of meat," said Chuck Lambert, the economist for the Cattlemen's Association. "There's a lot of competiton for consumer meat dollars."
In 1993, ranchers were selling steers for an average of $1.03 a pound. The price fell to 93 cents in 1994 and continued to drop almost every month through 1995. By the end of the year, ranchers were getting just 68 cents a pound, and the price could go lower.
Ranchers with low debts are likely to survive, but those with high debts are at risk, Mr. Lambert said. "The longer it drags on, the lower prices go, the more likely we are to see a greater percentage of failures," he said.
Neal Hilston, a ranch real estate broker here, said he had recently listed a 90,000-acre ranch for sale because the bank declined to renew its loans. If depressed beef prices stay low for through 1997, as economists expect, Mr. Hilston said, "More and more people will come to the end of their line of credit, and more and more ranch properties will come on the market.
"Eventually land prices will fall," said Mr. Hilston, recalling the 1980's when ranchland prices dropped about 50 percent, with prices varying depending on the sites. As the crash in the 1980's worsened, the fallout hit agricultural lenders who were stuck with growing inventories of land. "A lot of lenders took property back and then couldn't resell it for the money they had against it," he said.
Longtime ranchers have seen it all before. The Clear Creek Ranch, for example, has been in the Hendry family since 1912. Since then, successive generations of Hendrys survived the Depression and a series of post World War II beef price swings.
The Hendrys expect to ride out this cycle as well, but Jim Hendry said the lower beef prices would claim some ranches. "I just hope to goodness we're not one of them," he said.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Jobless Rate Jumps to 7.3%

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
When it comes to jobs, the news in New Jersey recently has not been good. On Friday, the Federal Government announced that the state's unemployment rate jumped to 7.3 percent in December from 6.1 percent in November; that translates into 295,000 people without jobs.
Those figures, of course, do not reflect the 7,000 layoffs that AT&T began last week. 
 Today Commerce Commissioner Gualberto Medina will press a Senate committee for fast action on two bills designed to create jobs.
One measure would provide relocation aid to companies that move to New Jersey and create at least 25 new full-time jobs.
The second bill would give grants to businesses that create new jobs; the grants would be based on a percentage of state income taxes generated by the new workers.
The bills passed the Senate Natural Resources, Trade and Economic Development Committee last session but died when the full Senate did not vote on them.
Other Senate committees will be discussing whether motorcyclists should wear helmets, whether hospitals can use vacant beds to provide the kind of care now limited to nursing homes and whether illegal aliens should be eligible for workers' compensation.

HEADLINE: Young Turks and Plain English

BYLINE: By Laura Ingraham; Laura Ingraham, a lawyer, writes frequently about politics.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Stars like Tony Bennett, Rod Stewart and Eric Clapton found new fame with "Unplugged" albums, which feature tracks uncluttered by electronic enhancements. Politicians can learn from this. Last week, a group of freshmen Republican senators led by Spence Abraham of Michigan set off from Washington on a national bus tour to take a plain-talk conservative message to the people. Call it Conservative Young Turks, Unplugged.
The senators hit the heartland because recent polls show that the shine is off the Republicans' apple. Here are three steps they should take to get back to basics. 
 Speak a new language. Most Democrats concede that they were caught flat-footed during much of the first "100 days" when Speaker Newt Gingrich and his oxen were plowing through the Contract With America. Welfare, tort and tax reform were debated within a conservative framework and in plain language.
Today, however, Republicans squander precious time on news talk shows debating the merits of C.B.O. versus O.M.B. numbers or what sort of inflation rate should be used to calculate COLA's.
President Clinton, accompanied by thousands of tiny violins, soars above such details and simply vows not to balance the budget "on the backs of our children, our poor and our elderly." Too smart to waste any opportunity to bond with the public, the President uses his bully pulpit to cast the budget battle as a struggle between the Great Protector (himself) and the Great Wrecking Balls (Speaker Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole).
Like the President, Republicans should eradicate wonk-speak. They should talk about entrepreneurship and empowerment. Republicans should remind Americans that Democrats have nothing to offer but a white-knuckled grip on the status quo, and that their "answers" demand more taxpayer money to finance more government bureaucracy.
Get off the defensive. On Sunday talk shows, Republicans are insisting: "We're not really cutting this! We're not really cutting that." But wasn't that the whole point of taking over Congress? Republicans promised to free up individual enterprise by pruning the gnarled vines of the Federal bureaucracy.
Republicans have also bollixed their case for welfare reform. Welfare is not bad because it's expensive. It's bad because it's destructive. Democrats call it a safety net. Republicans should call it an unscalable wall. Then they should ask David Bonior, the House minority whip, to justify maintaining a system that has left the underclass burdened with illegitimate births and violent crime.
The other side's numbers make the point. The Children's Defense Fund says that 12 million American children go hungry every year. This is what $5 trillion of Federal welfare spending bought over 30 years.
Use new messengers. Turn on the television set, and you'll find that Republicans are almost always represented by Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole. It's understandable that Bob Dole wants media coverage during Campaign '96, but he and his party could reap major electoral benefits if they regularly passed the microphone to new, young, energetic leaders in the House like Susan Molinari, J. C. Watts and Christopher Cox, who can demolish the stereotype of Republicans as humorless country clubbers.
By using new messengers and sharpening their arguments, Republicans could play to packed houses again. One thing is for sure: They can't wait for a Presidential nominee to rescue them from themselves.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Stubborn Inequality

BYLINE: By DOROTHY J. SAMUELS 

 BODY:
Two decades ago, in a distant life, I was hired fresh out of law school to be a starting associate at a large Wall Street law firm. A year later, I left to pursue other adventures. But I retain fond memories of my brief high-paying apprenticeship in big-time corporate law. The firm was a surprisingly friendly place, and working there satisfied a wonky interest in the intricacies of the Federal tax code, and an ambition, stemming from my 60's upbringing, to be part of important social change.
This, recall, was 1976. Thanks largely to the women's movement, hard-won changes in discrimination law and the not unrelated boom in the number of women attending law school, major private firms were making a concerted effort to open their doors to women. At the point I showed up for work, along with a handful of other women more obviously suited for the enterprise, my firm's crowded letterhead included just one female associate and no female partners. That made us pioneers of sorts. The thought that we were helping to advance the cause of women's equality imbued even my low-level work on drab tax-shelter deals with a sense of larger social purpose. 
 Though it was concededly not the stuff of civil rights legend, I did make one tangible contribution. My boycott of the firm's monthly associates' luncheon, held at an all-male private club, helped persuade the partners in charge to switch the gatherings to a more welcoming place. It was a big victory, back then. I sensed that the day when women would be fully integrated into the work and profits of big firm life was not far off.
I was wrong. A new report by an American Bar Association panel carries the reminder that all these years later bias against women remains entrenched in the legal profession, with resulting inequities in pay and opportunities. This, despite the impressive surge in the number of women lawyers. The report points to the discouraging law firm scene portrayed last year in a study of eight large law firms by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. It found women actually losing ground in the law firm retrenchment following the expansion of the high-flying 1980's, with the partnership rate for women falling even further behind the rate for men.
Curious, I checked the latest Martindale-Hubbell listing. In a development I like to think unrelated to my departure, my old law firm has grown bigger and more prosperous. By my count, there are now 92 partners. Nine are women -- progress, to be sure, but hardly the equality revolution I expected way back when.
What happened? Both bar reports cite a complex mix of factors, including subtle and not-so-subtle prejudice and harmful gender stereotyping. They also cite even harder to address obstacles beyond the tightening law firm economy, like punishing work demands and an ethos that requires attorneys to show they are partner-ready by logging an inhumane number of billable hours. This is hard on everyone. It works a special hardship on women, who, after all, still share the brunt of family responsibility in our society -- a problem not isolated, of course, to the legal profession. Addressing the problem should not remain just a woman's burden.
I guess I am getting old. When I was a new attorney just starting out, changing the world seemed a lot simpler. DOROTHY J. SAMUELS

HEADLINE: A Promising Palestinian Election

 BODY:
Saturday's elections for a Palestinian president and a legislative council marked another milestone toward peaceful coexistence between self-governing Israeli and Palestinian communities. The voting extended the evolution of the Palestine Liberation Organization from a guerrilla movement to an elected party of government and conferred a mandate of democratic legitimacy on the P.L.O.'s longtime leader, Yasir Arafat.
Mr. Arafat's election as President of the Interim Self-Government was a foregone conclusion. Facing only token opposition, he drew 88 percent of the vote. The legislative contests were more interesting. Nearly 700 candidates ran for the 88 seats, 7 of which were reserved for members of the minority Christian and Samaritan communities. 
 Turnout was encouragingly high, even though the Islamic Hamas movement and radical secular groups boycotted the election to protest Mr. Arafat's compromises with Israel over territory and security arrangements. But some of their members ran as independents, as did P.L.O. activists denied official endorsement. Other independents included figures like Hanan Ashrawi, the main Palestinian spokeswoman during the Madrid and Washington peace talks, who was elected from East Jerusalem.
Incomplete results suggested a significant number of these independents were elected. If these and other legislators take their responsibilities seriously, they could provided a democratic check on Mr. Arafat's previously unchallenged, and frequently abused, authority. The council's powers include deciding on legislation, passing on the budget and overseeing government performance. If the council were to vote no confidence in Mr. Arafat's government, the cabinet would have to resign.
Palestinians see the election as bringing them closer to having their own state. Israel's Labor Government insists that self-rule will not necessarily lead to statehood. It is fair to say that the elections make the prospect of eventual statehood seem more realistic, a point not lost on militant right-wing Jewish settlers.
For the most part these settlers did not follow through on their threats to disrupt the election. A large Israeli military presence may have kept the settlers in line. But in East Jerusalem, Israeli security measures appeared to intimidate Palestinians from voting. After complaints from international election observers, security was eased.
Despite the East Jerusalem tensions, and an assortment of problems at local polling stations, outside observers expressed general satisfaction with the election's conduct.
Israel can best serve its own interest by encouraging the democratic political development of the Palestinian community. If the mature voices of village elders, shopkeepers, doctors and lawyers can now be heard over the shouting of restless young men from the refugee camps, political arguments may gradually shift from the angry streets to the peaceful electoral arena and the overall level of violence may decrease.
America has an interest in helping the self-rule government get established economically and politically. But Washington need not restrain its criticisms of any major security lapses or human rights abuses. The line between restraining terrorism and respecting human rights can be difficult to maintain, but Washington must insist the Palestinian government do so on the West Bank and in Gaza.
Though the path has been bumpy and the timetable frequently set back, Israel's peace agreement with the P.L.O. has now been realized to an extent skeptics once considered impossible. This election brings both sides closer still to the ultimate goal of two self-governed communities living together in peace.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Defense Anomaly

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The debate about how to balance the budget is distorted by a singular phenomenon. Both sides, President and Congressional Republicans, treat as untouchable one of the biggest spending areas: defense.
At around $265 billion, defense accounts for nearly half of what is called discretionary Federal spending. Congress and the President are doing all their cutting in the other half: domestic and international programs. 
 Military spending has not been made sacrosanct because it is unchallengeable in policy terms. Nor can anyone believe that fraud and waste are unknown there. The reasons for excluding the Pentagon and defense contractors from the budget-exercise are in fact political.
The United States now accounts for 37 percent of the world's annual military spending. We spent more in 1995, discounted for inflation, than we did at the peak of the cold war in 1980. Why?
The policy answer, formulated in the Clinton Administration, is that we must be able to fight two major regional wars simultaneously. But even on that premise it does not follow that we need such huge forces and massive spending on weapons systems. So Lawrence J. Korb, who was Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration, showed in a devastating analysis. He wrote in the November-December issue of Foreign Affairs.
For example, Mr. Korb noted, the Pentagon figured that it would take 400,000 American troops to counter a North Korean invasion of South Korea. That is more than we deployed in the Korean War, when the North was supported by Chinese forces: Highly unlikely to happen now. Moreover, South Korea's army has grown from nothing to a professional force of 650,000. The Pentagon's estimated requirement is grossly inflated.
As for waste, the amount is literally incalculable. That is because financial managers in the Defense Department cannot produce auditable books. The director of its accounting service so testified to a Congressional committee in November. Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said last March that the Pentagon had $33 billion in "problem disbursements."
The finagling of figures threatens something worse than unauditable accounts. The military services are embarked on enormous acquisitions of weapons, and before long the costs are going to run way beyond what budget forecasts have calculated.
Franklin C. Spinney, a Defense Department program analyst who has irritated the Pentagon for years by his candor, describes the situation as a "time bomb being fueled by the Pentagon's corrupt budget numbers." The bomb, he says, will explode "early in the next century."
Why have both Congress and the White House been so lavish with the Defense Department, and so inattentive to inflated requirements and waste? The first answer is that looking "tough" on defense is regarded as good politics -- even after the fall of the Soviet Union, the great adversary whose menace led us to build up our forces after 1950.
But an even more powerful factor has developed in recent years. That is the belief, shrewdly encouraged by arms manufacturers, that cutting military spending will cost jobs in Congressional districts. Mr. Korb put it:
"Both the Administration and Congress increasingly view defense as a Federal jobs program. Weapons programs like the B-2 bomber, the Seawolf submarine and the V-22 Osprey, designed to combat the Soviet threat, live on because of the temporary economic problems that taking them out of production would cause."
The B-2 is an extreme case in point. After 14 years of work on it, the so-called Stealth bomber still fails crucial tests. Its radar cannot distinguish a mountain from rain. Yet Congress has just voted to buy more at $2.2 billion a plane, and President Clinton agreed. The House Budget Committee chairman, John Kasich, made a big effort to stop the increase but was beaten by members who wanted work to continue in their districts.
Weapons make-work is a highly inefficient way to provide jobs in this country. But it will go on until we have leadership courageous enough to take on the politics of defense. It will probably take an Eisenhower: a President who knows the military and who cannot be attacked as soft on defense.

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Is No Eleanor Roosevelt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Ever since Hillary Rodham Clinton became First Lady there have been many attempts to compare her with Eleanor Roosevelt (see A. M. Rosenthal's Jan. 19 column, for example, and Blanche Wiesen Cook's Jan 17 Op-Ed article). 
 Until the 1990's Eleanor Roosevelt remained better known than any other woman who has occupied that formidable but informal public position known as the First Lady. Largely because her husband was disabled, Mrs. Roosevelt acted in effect as his vice president, representing him all over the country.
While vicious partisan comments were made about her unprecedented public prominence during his four terms in office, many people, especially Democrats, accepted her unusual role because of his disability.
Since President Nixon institutionalized the office of the Vice President in the 1950's, it has been impossible for First Ladies to act even unofficially as their husbands' "vice presidents."
When Franklin Delano Roosevelt was first elected, Mrs. Roosevelt had already established an independent social and political network of women friends unrelated to his career. This gave her private and public autonomy that has also not since been duplicated.
In particular, she belonged to a generation of influential women coming out of the Progressive Era who had successfully advocated social justice and international peace since 1900. The Great Depression gave Mrs. Roosevelt and some of these women an unusual opportunity to influence national social welfare legislation demanded by the economic crisis.
None of the independent money Mrs. Roosevelt earned through her books, news column and talks was tainted by scandal or insider information. And no other First Lady to date has had an international career after her husband's death.
By contrast, Mrs. Clinton's prominence, symbolized by her early position as head of the national health care task force, is derivative of her husband's power as President and has raised serious constitutional questions about whether she was responsible to him or to Congress.
Unlike Mrs. Clinton, Mrs. Roosevelt never claimed an independent career, and never touted herself as a feminist. She opposed the Equal Rights Amendment her entire life and resigned her one official administrative position as deputy director of the Office of Civil Defense in 1942 when criticism of her performance rose. Mrs. Clinton's feminism, while more apparent, is compromised by her "stand by my man" public persona and male-oriented careerism.
 
JOAN HOFF
President, Center for the
Study of the Presidency
New York, Jan. 19, 1996

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Close Above $400 On Political Talk of U.S. Default

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold and platinum prices jumped yesterday, with gold settling above $400 an ounce for the second time this month, after Republicans in Congress talked of possibly forcing a default on the Federal debt if President Clinton did not agree to the Republicans' balanced-budget plan.
Gold was also supported by recent instability in other financial markets, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst for Prudential Securities Inc. in New York. 
 Investors buy precious metals during times of economic instability because their price remains fairly constant.
"A convenient place to park is gold and platinum," said Dave Esrig, an economist with the Platinum Guild International in New York.
On other commodity markets, energy futures prices dropped as traders reacted to concerns that some Iraqi oil might re-enter the world markets and to mild weather in parts of the country. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 0.25 point, to 240.88.
Gold for February delivery settled up $3.60, to $403.50 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. That was the highest settlement price for the contract closest to delivery since August 1993.
Also on the Comex, January silver rose 12.5 cents, to $5.5610 an ounce. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, April platinum rose $7.20, to $427.80 an ounce, and March palladium rose 80 cents, to $133.25 an ounce.
Ms. Raptopoulos said platinum was mostly following the rise in gold but was also supported by reports that Japanese investors bought platinum overnight.
In the energy markets, the expiring February crude oil contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange settled with a loss of 32 cents a barrel at $18.62. March crude oil dropped 10 cents, to $18.15.
Crude oil was under pressure from the announcement on Friday that Iraq was interested in resuming talks on a United Nations plan to allow it to sell some oil to get money to buy food and medicine, said Tim Evans, an analyst in New York for Pegasus Econometric Group.
Heating oil and natural gas closed lower with forecasts for mild weather in the Midwest and Northeast. February heating oil dropped 0.55 cent, to 53.67 cents a gallon; February unleaded gasoline fell 0.53 cent, to 54.88 cents a gallon, and February natural gas dropped 4.3 cents, to $2.125 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: More Budget Woes for the City

 BODY:
As if on schedule, the winter season has brought a torrent of painful developments that will make it harder for New York City to balance its budget. Real estate tax revenues are down. Savings that the city had projected in welfare, Medicaid and other areas have fallen short of targets. Relations with all the municipal labor unions have been in turmoil since the teachers rejected their contract last fall. Faced with a gap that could widen to $2 billion for the next fiscal year, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani needs to rethink some of his basic assumptions about how to restore the city to solvency.
If these problems sound familiar, they are. Since the bottom dropped out of the city's economy in the late 1980's, budget after budget has been pasted together every summer with overly optimistic assumptions and financial gimmickry insuring that the deficits buried within would open up in the winter. Mr. Giuliani deserves credit for making the city aware of the enormity of the challenges, and he has pushed through some real economies, most notably by reducing the size of the city's work force by 17,000 employees. He was clearly hoping that by exacting painful austerity in his first two years of office, he could ease up in his second two. Recent developments demonstrate that he cannot. 
 Among the biggest factors eating at the budget are the disappointing pace of Mr. Giuliani's attempts to rein in health-care costs, both for Medicaid recipients and municipal employees. Some progress has been made in enrolling Medicaid recipients in managed-care programs, and the city labor unions were persuaded to accept cuts in payments to the funds that pay for health benefits. But the savings are not as great as hoped. Meanwhile, the falloff in real estate taxes seems to signal a leveling off of the city economy, the Board of Education continues to spend at a rate that will consume hundreds of millions of dollars it does not have, and lurking in the background is the prospect of further cutbacks from Albany and Washington.
Last year Mr. Giuliani negotiated a five-year deal with the city labor unions that involved a two-year wage freeze and other modest concessions in return for a pledge not to lay anyone off. It now appears possible that employees in the main city labor unions may follow the teachers' lead and reject this contract, in which case layoffs are almost certain. Since wages and benefits account for half the city's budget, Mr. Giuliani must stand firm against any further concessions to employees.
City Hall also needs to think about some alternatives that Mr. Giuliani has rejected. New tax cuts proposed for the next fiscal year should be deferred. Although it has been politically difficult, the Mayor could show some leadership and call for a review of the entire real estate tax system, in which residential property is undertaxed. The Mayor should also change his policy of sparing the police, fire and sanitation departments from significant cuts. He has not made sufficient progress, for instance, in replacing police officers at desk jobs with civilian workers, a step that would allow him to reduce the number of officers in the force without reducing the number actually in the streets.
There is still more he can demand of the unions in easing overtime guarantees and other costly work rules. In fact, he took a step in the opposite direction by yielding to a union demand and placing a fifth firefighter aboard pumper engines, ending a practice of having four-member crews. Although Mr. Giuliani insists that this step is a safety measure, city officials acknowledge that the real reason was pressure from the firefighters.
Above all, Mr. Giuliani needs to forge a better working relationship with the Legislature in Albany to squeeze as much aid for the city as possible out of an admittedly stringent state budget. His antipathy toward the Democrats who control the Assembly served the city poorly last year. One thing Mr. Giuliani must not do is rely heavily on one-shot savings to balance the budget this year and next. His recent proposal to refinance some city bonds in a way that poses a bigger debt service burden down the road was properly rejected by City Comptroller Alan Hevesi. Only by demanding that the budget be balanced with recurring savings can Mr. Giuliani insure in the long term that the hopes of the summer do not sink perpetually into talk of budget doom when winter comes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
AMERICAN EXPRESS CO. (AXP,N)

 BODY:
The American Express Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 14.6 percent in the fourth quarter, bolstered by rising consumer spending and gains in its travel business.
The travel and finance company said net income advanced to $384 million, or 77 cents a share, from $335 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose 6.6 percent, to $4.05 billion. 
 American Express earnings met analysts' estimates of 77 cents a share, based on the average estimate of nine analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.
American Express said fourth-quarter earnings in its travel services division, which includes the American Express charge and credit card operations, rose 12 percent, to $266 million. Earnings from American Express Financial Advisors increased 17 percent, to $133 million. Profits at American Express Bank, the company's overseas banking division, rose 31 percent, to $21 million. HEADLINE: Flat Tax Lite

BYLINE: By Alvin Rabushka; Alvin Rabushka is senior fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford and co-author, with Robert E. Hall, of "The Flat Tax."

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif.

 BODY:
The flat tax has emerged as the central issue in the Republican Presidential primaries. The debate now pits an ideal, pure flat tax proposed by Steve Forbes against modified plans proposed by Phil Gramm and Patrick J. Buchanan that retain popular deductions like home mortgage interest and charitable contributions.
Advocates for a modified flat tax are worried that, under the unadulterated plan, housing values, home ownership and charitable giving would fall. But these dire predictions are unfounded. Under the current graduated rate system, the deductions for mortgage interest and charitable giving favor people in high tax brackets. Currently, the Treasury allows someone with a million-dollar mortgage to deduct the interest and receive a refund exceeding $70,000, while someone with a smaller mortgage gets a refund of a few thousand dollars. 
 Under a pure flat tax, this regressive feature would be eliminated. Indeed, housing would become more affordable, while housing values would be unaffected. This is because the pure flat tax plan would not just eliminate the deduction for home mortgage interest. There would also be no deduction for any interest paid, even by businesses, and no taxes on any interest received.
Once these tax considerations were removed, interest rates would fall. In a hypothetical 25 percent tax bracket, for example, a 10 percent interest rate equals an after-tax yield of 7.5 percent for both borrower and lender. If interest were neither deductible nor taxable, the yield would fall to the same 7.5 percent rate.
Lower rates would reduce mortgage interest payments. Most homeowners would be able to refinance their mortgages at the new lower rates. For most taxpayers, these lower rates would offset the loss of the mortgage interest deduction.
Housing prices are affected by the demand for housing, which in turn is affected by the ability to carry a mortgage. Since the flat tax would not reduce the ability to carry a mortgage, housing values would not decline.
But, paradoxically, it could be easier to own a home. Israel, Australia, Canada and Japan do not permit mortgage interest deductions, yet home ownership rates in those countries exceed or rival that in the United States.
Under a pure flat tax, American home buyers would find it easier to save for a down payment. Most public-finance economists maintain that a low flat tax would increase overall economic growth by one percentage point or more a year for the next seven years. That means by the year 2002, a family of four would have an additional $8,000 in income. The flat tax would also end double and triple taxation of dividends, capital gains and estates, making it easier for families to save.
What about charitable giving? From 1980 to 1989, total contributions increased from $49 billion to $107 billion, despite a fall in the top marginal tax rate from 70 to 28 percent, a drop of 60 percent. Strong economic growth, which increases real incomes and wealth, is a more important factor in giving than any tax break.
Perhaps the most important reason to stick to the pure flat tax is that any modification would probably kill tax reform. There would be other demands for "modification" -- to keep deductions for state and local taxes and fringe benefits, for example. Adding more deductions narrows the tax base, thus pushing up rates.
The principles that underpin the pure flat tax are growth, integrity, coherence and simplicity. Once these principles are abandoned, it is but a few small steps back to the current complicated, costly, inefficient, distorted tax system.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

PUB-DATE: January 23, 1996

SECTION: Section D; Page 10; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 597 words

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 34.68 Points to Set Closing High of 5,219.36

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks bolted into record territory yesterday on a late burst of computer-driven trading, but the wider market struggled higher as investors sought to minimize risks.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped past 5,200 points for the first time since mid-December, rising 34.68 to close at 5,219.36. The previous closing high of 5,216.47 was set on Dec. 13. 
 Most broad-market indexes were only slightly higher, though the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index advanced solidly, gaining 10.99 points to close at 1,029.44 as that depressed sector continued to firm its footing.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a slim margin on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,218 to 1,109. Big Board volume totaled 398 million shares, down from Friday's heavy pace of 502.9 million.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 0.84 point, to 328.70. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.57 points, to 613.40. The American Stock Exchange's market-value index gained 1.09 points, to 531.71.
The failure of the broader market to advance more decisively indicates a no-confidence vote for the market, said Brian Belski, technical analyst at Dain Bosworth in Minneapolis.
"The market is once again being led by a narrowing list of issues," he said. "Investors were chasing stocks that came out with earnings last week, but they're late to the party."
Caterpillar and I.B.M., which both posted strong earnings last week, added to their gains. Caterpillar shares rose 3 3/4, to 62 3/4, and those of I.B.M. rose 1/4, to 102 1/4.
Gold stocks rose as gold cracked the $400-an-ounce level amid new frictions in the protracted battle over Federal spending cuts. Investors often buy precious metals as a hedge during times of economic instability because their price remains fairly constant. Among gold issues, Homestake Mining added 1, to 18 3/4, and Newmont Mining rose 2 1/4, to 56 1/8.
Technology stocks rose, continuing last week's renewed confidence.
"The buyers have come back into technology," said Andrew M. Brooks, head of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore "I can't see the group moving the way it has without admitting that."
Intel, which plunged early last week after a disappointing earnings report, was up throughout the session, ending 5/8 higher at 52. Among other technology issues on Nasdaq, Sun Microsystems rose 19/16 a share, to 48 9/16, and Cisco Systems advanced 21/16, to 77 13/16.
Chrysler and Motorola both gained after favorable mentions in an article in Barron's, the financial weekly. Chrysler shares added 3 5/8, to 57 3/4, and Motorola gained 2 1/8, to 53 1/8. Chrysler was also aided by an article in The Wall Street Journal, which said the auto maker's smaller-than-expected decline in fourth-quarter earnings could mean a strong 1996 despite a weak domestic auto market.
Airline stocks helped prod the transportation sector, which trailed last week's blue-chip rebound. The Dow Jones index of transportation issues rose more than 1 percent, with USAir Group adding 3/4, to 15 3/4, after reporting its first fourth-quarter profit since 1988. Delta Air Lines rose 2 1/8 a share, to 74; AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, climbed 1 1/2, to 73 3/4, and UAL, the parent of United Airlines, jumped 7 5/8 a share, to 168 1/2.
In other active trading, Woolworth rose 1 1/4, to 11 1/8, after the retailer disclosed an investor proposal to spin off the company's successful athletic footwear and apparel division, which includes the Foot Locker and Lady Footlocker chains, to shareholders.
